div1.p: Scene: —Before the palace of Oedipus at Thebes. In front of the large central doors (basi/leios qu/ra) there is an altar; a smaller altar stands also near each of the two side-doors: see verse 16. Suppliants—old men, youths, and young children—are seated on the steps of the altars. They are dressed in white tunics and cloaks, —their hair bound with white fillets. On the altars they have laid down olive-branches wreathed with fillets of wool. The PRIEST OF ZEUS, a venerable man, is alone standing, facing the central doors of the palace. These are now thrown open: followed by two attendants (pro/spoloi), who place themselves on either side of the doors, OEDIPUS enters, in the robes of a king: for a moment he gazes silently on the groups at the altars, and then speaks. See Appendix, Note 1, sect. 1.

div2.p: Oedipus asks why they are suppliants. The Priest of Zeus, speaking for the rest, prays him to save them, with the gods' help, from the blight and the plague. Oedipus answers that he has already sent Creon to consult Apollo at Delphi, and will do whatever the god shall bid.

ne/a last-born (not “young,” for te/kna includes the old men, v. 17), added for contrast with tou= pa/lai. Oedipus, —who believes himself a Corinthian (774), —marks his respect for the ancient glories of the Theban house to whose throne he has been called: see esp. 258 f. So the Thebans are strato\s *kadmogenh/s Aesch. Seven 303, *kadmogenh\s ge/nna Eur. Phoen. 808, or *kadmei=o. trofh/ = qre/mmata (abstract for concrete); Eur. Cycl. 189 a)rnw=n trofai/ = a)/rnes e)kteqramme/nai. Cadmus, as guardian genius of Thebes, is still trofeu/s of all who are reared in the dw=ma *kadmei=on (v. 29). Campbell understands, “my last-born care derived from ancient Cadmus,” —as though the trofeu/s were Oedipus. But could *ka/dmou trofh/ mean “[my] nurslings [derived from] Cadmus”? It is by the word te/kna that Oedipus expresses his own fatherly care.

e(/dras The word e(/dra= “posture,” here, as usu., sitting: when kneelingis meant, some qualification is added, as Eur. Phoen. 293 gonupetei=s e(/dras prospi/tnw s', “I supplicate thee on my knees.” The suppliants are sitting on the steps (ba/qra) of the altars, on which they have laid the kla/doi: see 142: cp. 15 prosh/meqa, 20 qakei=: Aesch. Eum. 40 (Orestes a suppliant in the Delphian temple) e)p' o)mfalw=| (on the omphalos) e(/dran e)/xonta prostro/paione)lai/as q' u(yige/nnhton kla/don. qoa/zete prob. = qa/ssete, “sit,” e(/dras being cognate acc. In Eur. qoa/zw(qoo/s) always =“to hasten” (transitive or intrans.). But Empedocles and Aesch. clearly use qoa/zw as =qa/ssw, the sound and form perh. suggesting the epic qaa/ssw, qo/wkos. See Appendix.

i(kthri/ois kla/doisin The suppliant carried a branch of olive or laurel (i(kethri/a), round which were twined festoons of wool(ste/fh, ste/mmata, —which words can stand for the i(kethri/a itself, below 913, Hom. Il. 1.14): Plut. Thes. 18 h)=n de\ [h( i(kethri/a] kla/dos a)po\ th=s i(era=s e)lai/as, e)ri/w| leukw=| katestemme/nos. He laid his branch on the altar (Eur. Her. 124 bwmo\n kataste/yantes), and left it there, if unsuccessful in his petition (Eur. Supp. 259); if successful, he took it away (Eur. Supp. 359, below 143). i(kthri/ois kla/doisin e)cestemme/noi= i(kthri/ous kla/dous e)cestemme/nous e)/xontes: Xen. Anab. 4.3.28 dihgkulwme/nous tou\s a)kontista\s kai\ e)pibeblhme/nous tou\s toco/tas, “the javelin-throwers with javelins grasped by the thong(a)gku/lh), and the archers with arrows fitted to the string.” So 18 e)cestemme/non absol., = provided with ste/fh (i.e. with i(kethri/ai: see last note). Triclinius supposes that the suppliants, besides carrying boughs, wore garlands(e)stefanwme/noi), and the priests may have done so: but e)cestemm. does not refer to this.

o(mou= me\no(mou= de\ The verbal contrast is merely between the fumes of incense burnt on the altars as a propitiatory offering (Hom. Il. 8.48 te/menos bwmo/s te quh/eis), and the sounds — whether of invocations to the Healer, or of despair.

a)/llwn Redundant, but serving to contrast a)gge/lwn and au)to/s, as if one said, “from messengers,—at second hand.” Blaydes cp. Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.2 o(/pws mh\ di' a)/llwn e(rmhne/wn ta\s tw=n qew=n sumbouli/as sunei/hs, a)ll' au)to\sgignw/skois. w(=d' =deu=ro, as in vv. 144, 298, and often in Soph.: even with ble/pein, o(ra=n, as in Soph. Trach. 402 ble/f' w(=de = ble/pe deu=ro.

o( pa=si kleino\skalou/menos pa=si with kleino/s (cp. 40 pa=si kra/tiston), not with kalou/menos: “called Oedipus famous in the sight of all,” not “called famous Oed. by all.” Cp. pasi/gnwstos, pasi/dhlos, pasime/lousa, pasi/filos. The tone is Homeric (Hom. Od. 9.19 ei)/m' *)oduseu/skai/ meu kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei, imitated by Verg. Aen. 1.378 sum pius Aeneasfama super aethera notus): Oedipus is a type, for the frank heroic age, of Arist.'s megalo/yuxos—o( mega/lwn au(to\n a)ciw=n, a)/cios w)/n (Aristot. Nic. Eth. 4.3).
e)/fus which is more than ei)=, refers, not to appearance(fuh/), but to the natural claim (fu/sis) of age and office combined.

pro\ tw=nde “in front of,” and so “on behalf of,” “for” these. Ellendt: “Non est a)nti\ tw=nde, nec u(pe\r tw=nde, sed ma=llon s. ma/lista tw=nde, prae ceteris dignus propter auctoritatem et aetatem.” Rather a)nti\ tw=nde = “as their deputy”: u(pe\r tw=nde = “as their champion”: pro\ tw=nde = “as their spokesman.” So Soph. OC 811 e)rw= ga\r kai\ pro\ tw=nde. ti/ni tro/pw| with kaqe/state only: dei/santes h)\ ste/rcantes = ei)/te e)dei/sate/ ti, ei)/te e)ste/rcate (not po/teron dei/santes; h)\ ste/rcantes;), “in what mood are ye set here, whether it be one of fear or of desire?”

ste/rcantes “having formed a desire”: the aor. part., as Soph. Aj. 212 e)pei/ se | ste/rcas a)ne/xei “is constant to the love which he hath formed for thee.” Soph. El. 1100 kai\ ti/ boulhqei\s pa/rei; Soph. Aj. 1052 auto
 e)lpi/santesa)/gein. Cp. Soph. OC 1093 kai\ to
 a)greuta
 *)apo/llw | kai\ kasignh/tan| ste/rgw dipla=s a)rwga\s | molei=n, “I desire”: where, in such an invocation(i)w\*zeu=,po/rois, k.t.l.), ste/rgw surely cannot mean, “I am content.” Oed. asks: “Does this supplication mean that some new dread has seized you (dei/santes)? Or that ye have set your hearts (ste/rcantes) on some particular boon which I can grant?”—Others render ste/rcantes “having acquiesced.” This admits of two views. (i) “Are ye afraid of suffering? Or have ye already learned to bear suffering?” To this point the glosses u(pomei/nantes, paqo/ntes. But this seems unmeaning. He knows that the suffering has come, and he does not suppose that they are resigned to it (cp. v. 58). (ii) Prof. Kennedy connects h)\ ste/rcantes w(s qe/lontos a)
 | e)mou= prosarkei=n pa=n; i.e. are ye come in vague terror, or in contentment, as believing that I would be willing to help you? This is ingenious and attractive. But (a) it appears hardly consonant with the kingly courtesy of this opening speech for Oedipus to assume that their belief in his good-will would reconcile them to their present miseries. (b) We seem to require some direct and express intimation of the king's willingness to help, such as the words w(s qe/lontospa=n give only when referred to fra/ze. (c) The rhythm seems to favour the question at ste/rcantes. —ste/cantes, explained as “having endured,” may be rejected, because (1) the sense is against it—see on (i) above: (2) ste/gein in classical Greek = “to be proof against,” not “to suffer”: (3) ste/cw, e)/steca are unknown to Attic, which has only the pres. and the imperf. w(s qe/lontos a)
 (to be connected with fra/ze) implies the apodosis of a conditional sentence. Grammatically, this might be either (a) ei) dunai/mhn, qe/loimi a)/n, or (b) ei) h)duna/mhn, h)/qelon a)/n: here, the sense fixes it to (a). w(s, thus added to the gen. absol., expresses the supposition on which the agent acts. Xen. Mem. 2.6.32 w(s ou) prosoi/sontos (e)mou=) ta\s xei=ras,di/daske: “as (you may be sure) I will not lay hands on you, teach me.”

katoikti/rwn oi)kti/rw, not oi)ktei/rw, is the spelling attested by Attic inscriptions of circ. 550-350 B.C.: see Meisterhans, Grammatik der Attischen Inschriften, p. 89. mh\ ou) katoikti/rwn. An infinitive or participle, which for any reason would regularly take mh/, usually takes mh\ ou) if the principal verb of the sentence is negative. Here, dusa/lghtos = ou)k eu)a/lghtos: Dem. 19.123 (po/leis) xalepai\ labei=nmh\ ou) xro/nw| kai\ poliorki/a|(sc. lamba/nonti,) where xalepai/ = ou) r(a/|diai: “cities not easy to take, unless by a protracted siege.” The participial clause, mh\ ou) katoikti/rwn, is equivalent to a protasis, ei) mh\ katoikti/roimi. Prof. Kennedy holds that the protasis is ei) mh\ qe/loimi understood, and that mh\ ou) katoikti/rwn is epexegetic of it: —“Yes(ga/r) I should be unfeeling, if I did not wish (to help you): that is, if I refused to pity such a supplication as this.” But the double negative mh\ ou) could not be explained by a negative in the protasis (ei) mh\ qe/loimi): it implies a negative in the apodosis (dusa/lghtos a)\n ei)/hn). Since, then, the resolution into ou)k eu)a/lghtos a)\n ei)/hn is necessary, nothing seems to be gained by supposing a suppressed protasis, ei) mh\ qe/loimi.

bwmoi=si toi=s soi=s The altars of the prostath/rioi qeoi/ in front of the palace, including that of Apollo *lu/keios (919). makra\n
pte/sqai. So Andromache to her child —neosso\s w(sei\ pte/rugas e)spi/tnwn e)ma/s Eur. Tro. 746. The proper Attic form for the aor. of pe/tomai was e)pto/mhn, which alone was used in prose and Comedy. Though forms from e)pta/mhn sometimes occur in Tragedy, as in the Homeric poems, Elms. had no cause to wish for pta/sqai here.
su\n gh/ra| barei=s = barei=s w(s gh/ra| suno/ntes. Soph. OC 1663 su\n no/sois | a)lgeino/s: Soph. Aj. 1017 e)n gh/ra| baru/s.

e)gw\ me
 The answering clause, oi( de\ a)/llwn qew=n, must be supplied mentally: cp. Hom. Il. 5.893 th
 me
 e)gw\ spoudh=| da/mnhs' e)pe/essi(sc. ta\s de\ a)/llas r(a|di/ws). It is slightly different when me/n, used alone, emphasizes the personal pronoun, as in e)gw\ me
 ou)k oi)=da Xen. Cyrop. 1.4.12. oi(/de t'. The conjecture oi( d' e)p'(“chosen to represent the youth”) involves a questionable use of e)pi/: cp. Soph. Ant. 787 n. h)|qe/wn, unmarried youths: Hom. Il. 18.593 h)i/+qeoi kai\ parqe/noi: Eur. Phoen. 944 *ai(/monosga/moi | sfaga\s a)pei/rgous': ou) ga/r e)stin h)/|qeos: Plut. Thes. 15 h)|qe/ous e(pta\ kai\ parqe/nous.
e)cestemme/non see on 3.

a)gorai=si local dative, like oi)kei=n ou)ranw=| Pind. N. 10.58. Thebes was divided from N. to S. into two parts by the torrent called Strophia. The W. part, between the Strophia and the Dirce, was the upper town or Cadmeia: the E. part, between the Strophia and the Ismenus, was h( ka/tw po/lis. The name *kadmei/a was given especially to the S. eminence of the upper town, the acropolis. (1) One of the a)gorai/ meant here was on a hill to the north of the acropolis, and was the a)gora\ *kadmei/as. See Paus. 9.12.3. (2) The other was in the lower town. Xen. Hell. 5.2.29 refers to this —h( boulh\ e)ka/qhto e)n th=| e)n a)gora=| stoa=|, dia\ to\ ta\s gunai=kas e)n th=| *kadmei/a| qesmoforia/zein: unless *kadmei/a has the narrower sense of “acropolis.” Cp. Aristot. Pol. 4.12.2 on the Thessalian custom of having two a)gorai/— one, e)leuqe/ra, from which everything ba/nauson was excluded. pro/s te *palla/dos
naoi=s. Not “both at the two temples,” etc. as if this explained a)gorai=si, but “and,” etc.: for the a)gorai/ would have their own altars of the a)gorai=oi qeoi/, as of Artemis (161). One of the diploi= naoi/ may be that of *palla\s *)/ogka, near the *)ogkai/a pu/lh on the W. side of Thebes(pu/las | *)/ogkas *)aqa/nas Aesch. Seven 487, *)/ogka *palla/s Aesch. Seven 501), whose statue and altar e)n u(pai/qrw| Paus. mentions (9. 12. 2). The other temple may be that of Athene *kadmei/a or of Athena *)ismhni/a— both mentioned by the schol., but not by Paus. Athena *zwsthri/a, too, had statues at Thebes (Paus. 9.17.3). The schol. mentions also *)alalkomeni/a, but her shrine was at the village of Alalcomenae near Haliartus (Paus. 9.23.5). It was enough for Soph. that his Athenian hearers would think of the Erechtheum and the Parthenon—the shrines of the Polias and the Parthenos—above them on the acropolis.

e)p' *)ism. m. spodw=| “The oracular ashes of Ismenus” = the altar in the temple of Apollo *)ismh/nios, where divination by burnt offerings(h( di' e)mpu/rwn mantei/a) was practised. So the schol., quoting Philochorus (in his peri\ mantikh=s, circ. 290 B.C.). spodw=|: the embers dying down when the mantei=on has now been taken from the burnt offering: cp. Soph. Ant. 1007. Soph. may have thought of *)apo/llwn *spo/dios, whose altar(e)k te/fras tw=n i(erei/wn) Paus. saw to the left of the Electrae gates at Thebes: 9. 11. 7. *)ismhnou=, because the temple was by the river Ismenus: Paus. 9.10.2 e)/sti de\ lo/fos e)n decia=| tw=n pulw=n (on the right of the *)hle/ktrai pu/lai on the S. of Thebes, within the walls) i(ero\s *)apo/llwnos: kalei=tai de\ o(/ te lo/fos kai\ o( qeo\s *)ismh/nios, pararre/ontos tou= potamou= tau/th| tou= *)ismhnou=. Ismenus (which name Curt. Etym. 617, connects with rt i)s, to wish, as = “desired”) was described in the Theban myths as the son of Asopus and Metope, or of Amphion and Niobe. The son of Apollo by Melia (the fountain of the Ismenus) was called Ismenius. Cp. Hdt. 8.134 (the envoy of Mardonius in the winter of 480-79) tw=| *)ismhni/w| *)apo/llwni e)xrh/sato: e)/sti de\ kata/per e)n *)olumpi/h| i(roi=si xrhsthria/zesqai: Pind. O. 8.1 ff. *ou)lumpi/a |i(/na ma/nties a)/ndres | e)mpu/rois tekmairo/menoi parapeirw=ntai *dio/s. In Pind. P. 11.4 the Theban heroines are asked to come pa\r *meli/an (because she shared Apollo's temple) “to the holy treasure-house of golden tripods, which Loxias hath honoured exceedingly, and hath named it Ismenian, a truthful seat of oracles” (MSS. mantei/wn, not manti/wn, Fennell): for the tripod dedicated by the dafnafo/ros, or priest of Ismenian Apollo, see Paus. 9.10.4. Her. saw offerings dedicated by Croesus to Amphiaraus e)n tw=| nhw=| tou= *)ismhni/ou *)apo/llwnos (1. 52), and notices inscriptions there (5. 59). The *)ismh/nion, the temple at Abae in Phocis, and that on the hill *ptw=on to the E. of Lake Copais, were, after Delphi, the chief shrines of Apollo in N. Greece.

buqw=n “from the depths,” i.e. out of the trough of the waves which rise around. Cp. Soph. Ant. 337 peribruxi/oisin | perw=n u(p' oi)/dmasin, under swelling waves which threaten to engulf him. Arat. 426 u(po/bruxa nauti/llontai. foini/ou here merely poet. for qanasi/mou, as Soph. Trach. 770 foini/as | e)xqra=s e)xi/dnhs i)o/s: Soph. OC 1689 fo/nios *)ai/+das. But in Soph. Aj. 351 foini/a za/lh= the madness which drove Ajax to bloodshed. e)/t' ou)x oi(/a te: for position of e)/t', cp. Soph. Trach. 161 w(s e)/t' ou)k w)/n, Soph. Phil. 1217 e)/t' ou)de/n ei)mi. With oi(=o/s te the verb is often omitted, as 1415, Soph. OC 1136, Soph. Trach. 742, Aristoph. Kn. 343.

fqi/nousa me

fqi/nousa de/ rhetorical iteration(e)panafora/); cp. 259, 370, Soph. OC 5, 610, etc. The anger of heaven is shown (1) by a blight (fqi/nousa) on the fruits of the ground, on flocks and on child-birth: (2) by a pestilence (loimo/s) which ravages the town. Cp. 171 ff. For the threefold blight, Hdt. 6.139 a)poktei/nasi de\ toi=si *pelasgoi=si tou\s sfete/rous pai=da/s te kai\ gunai=kas ou)/te gh= karpo
 e)/fere ou)/te gunai=ke/s te kai\ poi=mnai o(moi/ws e)/tikton kai\ pro\ tou=: Aeschin. 3.111 mh/te gh=n karpou\s fe/rein mh/te gunai=kas te/kna ti/ktein goneu=sin e)oiko/ta, a)lla\ te/rata, mh/te boskh/mata kata\ fu/sin gona\s poiei=sqai. Schneid. and Blaydes cp. Philostr. Apoll. 3.20, p. 51. 21 h( gh= ou) cunexw/rei au)toi=s i(/stasqai: th/n te ga spora
 h(
 e)s au)th
 e)poiou=nto, pri
 e)s ka/luka h(/kein, e)/fqeire, tou/s te tw=n gunaikw=n to/kous a)telei=s e)poi/ei, kai\ ta\s a)ge/las ponhrw=s e)/bosken.

ka/lucin e)gka/rpois The datives mark the points or parts in which the land fqi/nei. ka/lucin e)/gkarpos is the shell or case which encloses immature fruit, —whether the blossom of fruit-trees, or the era of wheat or barley: Theophr. Hist. Plant. 8.2.4 (of kriqh/ and puro/s) pri\n a)\n proau/chqei\s (o( sta/xus) e)n th=| ka/luki ge/nhtai.

a)ge/lais bouno/mois (paroxyt.) =a)ge/lai bow=n nemome/nwn: but a)kth\ bou/nomos, proparoxyt., a shore on which oxen are pastured, Soph. El. 181. Cp. Soph. El. 861 xalargoi=s e)n a(mi/llais = a(mi/llais a)rgw=n xhlw=n: Pind. P. 5.28 a)risqa/rmatonge/ras = ge/ras a)ri/stou a(/rmatos. The epithet marks that the blight on the flocks is closely connected with that on the pastures: cp. Dionys. Hal. 1. 23 (describing a similar blight) ou)/te po/a kth/nesin e)fu/eto diarkh/s. to/koisi, the labours of child-bed: Eur. Med. 1031 sterra\s e)negkou=s' e)n to/kois a)lghdo/nas: Eur. IT 1466 gunai=kes e)n to/kois yuxorragei=s. Dion. Hal. 1.23 a)delfa\ de\ tou/tois(i.e. to the blight on fruits and crops) e)gi/neto peri/ te proba/twn kai\ gunaikw=n gona/s: h)\ ga\r e)chmblou=to ta\ e)/mbrua, h)\ kata\ tou\s to/kous diefqei/reto e)/stin a)\ kai\ ta\s ferou/sas sundialumhna/mena.

a)go/nois abortive, or resulting in a still birth. e)n d', adv., “and among our other woes,” “and withal”: so 183, Soph. Trach. 206, Soph. Aj. 675. Not in “tmesis” with skh/yas, though Soph. has such tmesis elsewhere, Soph. Ant. 420 e)n d' e)mestw/qh, Soph. Ant. 1274 e)n d' e)/seisen. For the simple skh/yas, cp. Aesch. Ag. 308 ei)=t' e)/skhyen, “then it swooped.” So Aesch. Pers. 715 loimou= tis h)=lqe skhpto/s. o( purfo/ros qeo\s, the bringer of the plague which spreads and rages like fire (176 krei=sson a)maimake/tou puro/s, 191 fle/gei me): but also with reference to fever, pureto/s. Hippoc. 4.140 o(ko/soisi de\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn pu=r (= pureto\s) e)mpi/pth|: Hom. Il. 22.31 kai/ te fe/rei(Seirius) pollo
 pureto
 deiloi=si brotoi=si (the only place where pureto/s occurs in Il. or Od.). In Soph. OC 55 e)n d' o( purfo/ros qeo\s | *tita
 *promhqeu/s refers to the representation of Prometheus with the narthex, or a torch, in his right hand (Eur. Phoen. 1121 decia=| de\ lampa/da | *tita
 *promhqeu\s e)/feren w(/s). Cp. Aesch. Seven 432 a)/ndra purfo/ron, | fle/gei de\ lampa/s, k.t.l. Here also the Destroyer is imagined as armed with a deadly brand, —against which the Chorus presently invoke the holy fires of Artemis (206) and the “blithe torch” of Dionysus (214). For qeo\s said of loimo/s, cp. Simonid. Amorg. fr. 7. 101 ou)d' ai)=ya limo
 oi)ki/hs a)pw/setai, | e)xqro
 sunoikhth=ra, dusmene/a qeo/n. Soph. fr. 837 a)ll' h( fro/nhsis a(gaqh\ qeo\s me/gas.

me/las d' elision at end of v. is peculiar in Trag. to Soph., who is said to have adopted it from a poet Callias (Athen. 10 p. 453 E): hence it was called ei)=dos *sofo/kleion. Examples: d' 785, 791, 1224; Soph. OC 17; Soph. Ant. 1031; Soph. El. 1017: t' below, 1184: tau=t' 332. [In Soph. OC 1164 molo/nt' should prob. be mo/non.] In Comedy: d' Eur. Hipp. 1716, Aristoph. Eccl. 351: m' Aristoph. Frogs 298.

plouti/zetai with allusion to *plo/u/twn, as Hades was called by an euphemism(u(pokoristikw=s, schol. Aristoph. Pl. 727), o(/ti e)k th=s ka/twqen a)ni/etai o( plou=tos (crops and metals), as Plato says, Plat. Crat. 403a. Cp. Soph. fr. 251 (Nauck(2)) (from the satyric drama Inachus) *plou/twnos (= *(/aidou) h(/d' e)pei/sodos: Lucian Timon 21(*plou=tos speaks), o( *plou/twn (Hades) a)poste/llei me par' au)tou\s a(/te ploutodo/ths kai\ megalo/dwros kai\ au)to\s w)/n: dhloi= gou=n kai\ tw=| o)no/mati. Schneid. cp. Statius Theb. 2.48 pallentes devius umbras Trames agit nigrique Iovis vacua atria ditat Mortibus.
me/n nun as in Soph. Trach. 441.

ou)k i)sou/meno/n s', governed by kri/nontes in 34. But he begins as if instead of e(zo/mesq' e)fe/stioi, i(keteu/omen were to follow: hence i)sou/menon instead of i)/son. It is needless to take i)sou/menon (1) as accus. absol., or (2) as governed by e(zo/mesq' e)fe/stioi in the sense of i(keteu/omen, —like fqora\syh/fous e)/qento Aesch. Ag. 814, or ge/nosne/wson ai)=nonAesch. Supp. 533. Musgrave conj. i)sou/menoi as = “deeming equal,” but the midd. would mean “making ourselves equal,” like a)ntisoume/nou Thuc. 3.11. Plato has i)sou/menon as passive in Plat. Phaedrus 238e, and i)sou=sqai as passive in Plat. Parm. 156b: cp. 581 i)sou=mai.

daimo/nwn sunallagai=s = “conjunctures” caused by gods (subjective gen.), special visitations, as opposed to the ordinary chances of life(sumforai=s bi/ou). Such sunallagai/ were the visit of the Sphinx (130) and of the purfo/ros qeo/s (27). Cp. 960 no/sou sunallagh=|, a visitation in the form of disease (defining gen.). Here, the sense might indeed be, “dealings (of men) with gods,” = o(/tan a)/nqrwpoi sunalla/sswntai dai/mosin: but the absolute use of sunallagh/ for “a conjuncture of events” in Soph. OC 410 (n.) favours the other view. In Soph. Trach. 845 o)leqri(aisi sunallagai=s= “at the fatal meeting” of Deianeira with Nessus. But in Soph. Ant. 157 qew=n suntuxi/ai = fortunes sent by gods. The common prose sense of sunallagh/ is “reconciliation,” which Soph. has in Soph. Aj. 732.

o(/s g' The g' of the MSS. suits the immediately preceding verses better than the conjectural te, since the judgment(kri/nontes) rests solely on what Oed. has done, not partly on what he is expected to do. Owing to the length of the first clause (35-39) t' could easily be added to nu=n in 40 as if another te had preceded. e)ce/lusas
dasmo\n. The notion is not, “paid it in full,” but “loosed it,” —the thought of the tribute suggesting that of the riddle which Oed. solved. Till he came, the dasmo/s was as a knotted cord in which Thebes was bound. Cp. Soph. Trach. 653 *)/arhse)ce/lus' | e)pi/ponon a(me/ran, “has burst the bondage of the troublous day.” Eur. Phoen. 695 podw=n sw=n mo/xqon e)klu/ei parw/n, “his presence dispenses with (solves the need for) the toil of thy feet.” This is better than (1) “freed the city from the songstress, in respect of the tribute,” or (2) “freed the city from the tribute(dasmo/n by attraction for dasmou=) to the songstress.”
sklhra=s “hard,” stubborn, relentless. Eur. Andr. 261 sklhro\n qra/sos. In 391 ku/wn expresses a similar idea.

kai\ tau=q' “and that too”: Soph. Ant. 322(e)poi/hsas to\ e)/rgon) kai\ tau=t' e)p' a)rgurw=| ge th
 yuxh
 prodou/s: Soph. El. 614. ou)de
ple/on, nothing more than anyone else knew; nothing that could help thee. Plat. Crat. 387a ple/on ti h(mi=n e)/stai, we shall gain something. Plat. Sym. 217c ou)de
 ga/r moi ple/on h)=n, it did not help me. e)ceidw\s
e)kdidaxqei/s: not having heard (incidentally)—much less having been thoroughly schooled.

prosqh/kh| qeou= “by the aid of a god.” Dem. 25.24 h( eu)taci/a th=| tw=n no/mwn prosqh/kh| tw=n ai)sxrw=n peri/esti, “discipline, with the support of the laws, prevails against villainy.” Dion. Hal. 5.67 prosqh/khs moi=ran e)pei=xon ou(=toi toi=s e)n fa/laggi tetagme/nois, “these served as supports to the main body of the troops.” prosti/qesqai/ tini, to take his side: Thuc. 6.80 toi=s a)dikoume/noisprosqeme/nous: so Soph. OC 1332 oi(=s a)\n su\ prosqh=|. (The noun prosqh/kh does not occur as = “mandate,” though Hdt. 3.62 has to/ toi prose/qhka prh=gma.) The word is appropriate, since the achievement of Oed. is viewed as essentially a triumph of human wit: a divine agency prompted him, but remained in the background.
nu=n t' it is unnecessary to read nu=n d': see on 35. pa=sin, ethical dat. masc. (cp. 8), “in the eyes of all men.” Soph. Trach. 1071 polloi=sin oi)ktro/n.

ei)/te oi)=sqa a)lkh/n, a)kou/sas fh/mhn qew=n tou (by having heard a voice from some god), ei)/te oi)=sqa a)lkh\n a)p' a)ndro/s pou. We might take a)p' a)ndro\s with a)lkh/n, but it is perh. simpler to take it with oi)=sqa: cp. 398 a)p' oi)wnw=n maqw/n, Thuc. 1.125 e)peidh\ a)f' a(pa/ntwn h)/kousan th\n gnw/mhn: though para/ (or pro/s) tinos is more frequent.

fh/mhn any message (as in a dream, fh/mh o)nei/rou, Hdt. 1.43), any rumour, or speech casually heard, which might be taken as a hint from the god. Hom. Od. 20.98 *zeu= pa/ter| fh/mhn ti/s moi fa/sqw (Odysseus prays), “Let some one, I pray, show me a word of omen.” Then a woman, grinding corn within, is heard speaking of the suitors, “may they now sup their last”: xai=ren de\ klehdo/ni di=os *)odusseu/s, “rejoiced in the sign of the voice.” o)mfh/ was esp. the voice of an oracle; klhdw/n comprised inarticulate sounds(kl. duskri/tous, Aesch. PB 486).

w(s toi=sin
bouleuma/twn I take these two verses with the whole context from v. 35, and not merely as a comment on the immediately preceding words ei)/t' a)p' a)ndro\s oi)=sqa/ pou. Oedipus has had practical experience(e)mpeiri/a) of great troubles; when the Sphinx came, his wisdom stood the trial. Men who have become thus e)/mpeiroi are apt to be also (kai/) prudent in regard to the future. Past facts enlighten the counsels which they offer on things still uncertain; and we observe that the issues of their counsels are not usually futile or dead, but effectual. Well may we believe, then, that he who saved us from the Sphinx can tell us how to escape from the plague. Note these points. (1) The words e)mpei/roisi and bouleuma/twn serve to suggest the antithesis between past and future. (2) ta\s cumfora\s
tw=n bouleuma/twn= literally, the occurrences connected with (resulting from) the counsels. The phrase, “issues of counsels,” concisely expresses this. The objection which has been made to this version, that cumfora/ is not teleuth/, rests on a grammatical fallacy, viz., that, in cumfora\ bouleu/matos, the genitive must be of the same kind as in teleuth\ bouleu/matos. tu/xh is not teleuth/, yet in Soph. OC 1506 it stands with a gen. of connection, just as cumfora/ does here:(qew=n) tu/xhn tis e)sqlh\n th=sd' e)/qhke th=s o(dou= (a good fortune connected with this coming). Cp. Thuc. 1.140 e)nde/xetai ga\r ta\s cumfora\s tw=n pragma/twn ou)x h)=sson a)maqw=s xwrh=sai h)\ kai\ ta\s dianoi/as tou= a)nqrw/pou: the issues of human affairs can be as incomprehensible in their course as the thoughts of man (where, again, the “occurrences connected with human affairs” would be more literal): ib. pro\s ta\s cumfora\s kai\ ta\s gnw/mas trepome/nous, altering their views according to the events. Thuc. 3.87 th=s cumfora=s tw=| a)poba/nti, by the issue which has resulted. (3)

zw/sas is not “successful,” but “operative,” —effectual for the purpose of the bouleu/mata: as v. 482 zw=nta is said of the oracles which remain operative against the guilty, and Soph. Ant. 457 zh=| tau=ta of laws which are ever in force. Conversely lo/goi qnh/|skontes ma/thn (Aesch. Lib. 845) are threats which come to nothing. The scholium in L gives the sense correctly:— e)n toi=s sunetoi=s ta\s suntuxi/as kai\ ta\s a)poba/seis tw=n bouleuma/twn o(rw= zw/sas kai\ ou)k a)pollume/nas. See Appendix.

eu)labh/qhq' have a care for thy repute— as the next clause explains. Oed. is supposed to be above personal risk; it is only the degree of his future glory (55) which is in question; a fine touch, in view of the destined sequel.
th=s pa/ros proqumi/as causal genit.: Plat. Crito 43b polla/kis me\n dh/ seeu)daimo/nisa tou= tro/pou.

memnw/meqa This subjunctive occurs also in Hom. Od. 14.168 pi=ne kai\ a)/lla pare\c memnw/meqa, Plat. Stat. 285c fula/ttwmenkai\memnw/meqa, Plat. Phileb. 31a memnw/meqa dh\ kai\ tau=ta peri\ a)mfoi=n. Eustathius (1303. 46, 1332. 18) cites the word here as memnw/|meqa (optative). We find, indeed, memnw=|o Xen. Anab. 1.7.5 (v. l. memnh=|o), memnew=|to Hom. Il. 23.361, memnw=|toXen. Cyrop. 1.6.3, but these are rare exceptions. On the other hand, memnh/|mhn Hom. Il. 24.745, memnh=|to Aristoph. Pl. 991, Plat. Rep. 518a. If Soph. had meant the optative he would have written memnh/|meqa: cp. Soph. Phil. 119 a)\nkeklh=|o. See Curtius Greek Verb 2.226 (Eng. tr. p. 423). The personal appeal, too, here requires the subjunct., not optat.: cp. Soph. OC 174 mh\ dh=t' a)dikhqw=, Soph. Trach. 802 mhd' au)tou= qa/nw.

sta/ntes t' For partic. with me/mnhmai cp. Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.31 e)me/mnhto ga\r ei)pw/n: Pind. N. 2.15 qnata\ memna/sqw periste/llwn me/lh: for tekai/, Soph. Ant. 1112 au)to/s t' e)/dhsa kai\ parw\n e)klu/somai, as I bound, so will I loose.

a)sfalei/a| “in steadfastness”: a dative of manner, equivalent to a)sfalw=s in the proleptic sense of w(/ste a)sfalh= ei)=nai. Cp. Soph. OC 1318 kataskafh=| |. . dh|w/sein, n. Thuc. 3.56 oi( mh\ ta\ cu/mfora pro\s th\n e)/fodon au(toi=s a)sfalei/a| pra/ssontes, those who securely made terms on their own account which were not for the common good in view of the invasion. Thuc. 2.82 a)sfalei/a| de\ to\ e)pibouleu/sasqai (where a)sfa/leia is a false reading), to form designs in security, opp. to to\ e)mplh/ktws o)cu/, fickle impetuosity. The primary notion of a)sfalh/s (“not slipping”) is brought out by peso/ntes and a)no/rqwson.

o)/rniqiai)si/w| like secunda alite or fausta avi for bono omine. A bird of omen was properly oi)wno/s: Hom. Od. 15.531 ou)/ toi a)/neu qeou= e)/ptato decio\s o)/rnis: | e)/gnwn ga/r min e)sa/nta i)dw
 oi)wno
 e)o/nta: Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.22 oi)wnoi=s xrhsa/menos ai)si/ois. But cp. Eur. IA 607 o)/rniqa me
 to/nd' ai)/sion poiou/meqa: Eur. Her. 730 o)/rniqos ou(/neka: Aristoph. Birds 720 fh/mh g' u(mi=n o)/rnis e)sti/, ptarmo/n t' o)/rniqa kalei=te, | cu/mbolon o)/rnin, fwnh
 o)/rnin, qera/pont' o)/rnin, o)/non o)/rnin. For dat., Schneid. cp. Hipponax fr. 63 (Bergk) deciw=|e)lqw
 r(wdiw=|(heron). In Bergk Poet. Lyr. p. 1049 fr. incerti 27 decih=| si/tth| (woodpecker) is a conject. for decih\ si/tth. kai\ is better taken as = “also” than as “both” (answering to kai\ tanu=n in 53).

a)/rceiskratei=s
kratei=n kratei=n tino/s, merely to hold in one's power; a)/rxein implies a constitutional rule. Cp. Plat. Rep. 338d ou)kou=n tou=to kratei= e)n e(ka/sth| po/lei, to\ a)/rxon; Her. 2. i a)/llous te paralabw\n tw=n h)=rxe kai\ dh\ kai\ *(ellh/nwn tw=n e)pekra/tee, i.e. the Asiatics who were his lawful subjects, and the Greeks over whom he could exert force. But here the poet intends no stress on a verbal contrast: it is as if he had written, ei)/per a)/rceis, w(/sper a)/rxeis. Cp. Soph. Trach. 457 kei) me\n de/doikas, ou) kalw=s tarbei=s: below 973 prou)/legon| hu)/das.

cu
 a)ndra/sin not “with the help of men,” but “with men in the land,” = a)/ndras e)xou/shs gh=s. Cp. 207 cu
 ai(=s = a(\s e)/xousa. Soph. El. 191 a)eikei= su
 stola=|: Soph. Aj. 30 su
 neorra/ntw| ci/fei. Soph. Ant. 116 cu/n q' i(ppoko/mois koru/qessi.

w(s ou)de/n e)stin Thuc. 7.77 a)/ndres ga\r po/lis, kai\ ou) tei/xh ou)de\ nh=es a)ndrw=n kenai/. Dio Cass. 56. 6 a)/nqrwpoi ga/r pou po/lis e)sti/n, ou)k oi)ki/ai, k.t.l. Hdt. 8.61 (Themistocles, taunted by Adeimantus after the Persian occupation of Athens in 480 B.C. with being a)/polis, retorted) e(wutoi=siws ei)/h kai\ po/lis kai\ gh= me/zwn h)/per kei/noisi, e)/st' a)\n dihko/siai nh=e/s sfi e)/wsi peplhrwme/nai.
pu/rgos = the city wall with its towers: the sing. as below, 1378: Soph. Ant. 953 ou) pu/rgos, ou)x a(li/ktupoi |na=es: Eur. Hec. 1209 pe/ric de\ pu/rgos ei)=x' e)/ti pto/lin.

Lit., “void of men, when they do not dwell with thee in the city”: a)ndrw=n depends on e)/rhmos, of which mh\ cunoikou/ntwn e)/sw is epexegetic. Rhythm and Sophoclean usage make this better than to take a)ndrw=n mh\ cunoik. e)/. as a gen. absol. Cp. Soph. Aj. 464 gumno\n fane/nta tw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter: Soph. Phil. 31 kenh\n oi)/khsin a)nqrw/pwn di/xa: Lucret. 5.841 muta sine ore etiam, sine voltu caeca.

gnwta\ kou)k a)gnw=ta The emphasis of this formula sometimes appears to deprecate an opposite impression in the mind of the hearer: “known, and not (as you perhaps think) unknown.” Hom. Il. 3.59 e)pei/ me kat' ai)=san e)nei/kesas ou)d' u(pe\r ai)=san, duly, and not, —as you perhaps expect me to say, —unduly. Hdt. 3.25 e)mmanh/s te e)w\n kai\ ou) frenh/rhs— being mad, —for it must be granted that no man in his right mind would have acted thus. Soph. OC 397 baiou= kou)xi\ muri/ou xro/nou, soon, and not after such delay as thy impatience might fear.

nosou=ntes
nosei= We expected kai\ nosou=ntes ou) nosei=te, w(s e)gw/. But at the words w(s e)gw/ the speaker's consciousness of his own exceeding pain turns him abruptly to the strongest form of expression that he can find —ou)k e)/stin u(mw=n o(/stis nosei=, there is not one of you whose pain is as mine. In Plat. Phileb. 19b (quoted by Schneid.) the source of the anacolouthon is the same: mh\ ga duna/menoi tou=to kata\ panto\s e(no\s kai\ o(moi/ou kai\ tau)tou= dra=n kai\ tou= e)nanti/ou, w(s o( parelqa
 lo/gos e)mh/nusen, ou)dei\s ei)s ou)de
 ou)deno\s a)
 h(mw=n ou)de/pote ge/noito a)/cios, — instead of the tamer ou)k a)
 genoi/meqa.

ei)s e(/n'
mo/non kaq' au(to/n kaq' au(to/n, “by himself” (Soph. OC 966), is strictly only an emphatic repetition of mo/non: but the whole phrase ei)s e(/na mo/non kaq' au(to/n is virtually equivalent to ei)s e(/na e(/kaston kaq' au(to/n, each several one apart from the rest.

po/lin te ka)me\ kai\ s' The king's soul grieves for the whole State, —for himself, charged with the care of it, —and for each several man(se/). As the first contrast is between public and private care, ka)me/ stands between po/lin and se/. For the elision of se/, though accented, cp. 329 ta)/m', w(s a)\n ei)/pw mh\ ta\ s': 404 kai\ ta\ s': Soph. El. 1499 ta\ gou=n s': Soph. Phil. 339 oi)/moi me\n a)rkei=n soi/ ge kai\ ta\ s': Eur. Hipp. 323 e)/a m' a(martei=n: ou) ga\r e)s s' a(marta/nw.

The modal dat. u(/pnw|, more forcible than a cogn. acc. u(/pnon, nearly = “soundly.” Cp. Soph. Ant. 427 go/oisin e)cw/|mwcen: Soph. Trach. 176 fo/bw|, fi/lai, tarbou=san: [Eur.] fr. 1132 (Nauck(2)) 40 o)rgh=| xolwqei/s (where Nauck, rashly, I think, conjectures e)/rgei). Verg. Aen. 1.680 sopitum somno. eu(/dein, kaqeu/dein (Xen. Anab. 1.3.11) oft. = “to be at ease” (cp. e)/nq' ou)k a)\n bri/zonta i)/dois, of Agam., Hom. Il. 4.223): the addition of u(/pnw| raises and invigorates a trite metaphor.

pla/nois has excellent manuscript authority here; and Soph. uses pla/nou Soph. OC 1114, pla/nois Soph. Phil. 758, but pla/nh nowhere. Aesch. has pla/nh only: Eur. pla/nos only, unless the fragment of the Rhadamanthus be genuine (659 Nauck(2), v. 8, ou(/tw bi/otos a)nqrw/pwn pla/nh). Aristoph. has pla/nos once (Aristoph. Wasps 872), pla/nh never. Plato uses both pla/nh and pla/nos, the former oftenest: Isocrates has pla/nos, not pla/nh.

hu(/riskon “could find” (impf.). Attic inscriptions of the t=h or early t/h cent. B.C. support the temporal augment in the historical tenses of eu(ri/skw (Meisterhans, Gram. Att. Inschr., p. 78). Our best MS. of Soph. (L), however, preserves no trace of it, except in Soph. Ant. 406 (see cr. n. there). Curtius (Curt. Verb. 1.139, Eng. tr. 93) thinks that, while the omission of the syllabic augment was an archaic and poetical license, that of the temporal was “a sacrifice to convenience of articulation, and was more or less common to all periods”: so that ei)/kazon could exist in Attic by the side of h)/|kazon, eu(/riskon by the side of hu(/riskon.
tau/thn e)/praca a terse equivalent for tau/th| e)/rgw| e)xrhsa/mhn.

*foi/bouo(/ ti
drw=nti/ fwnw=n Cp. Plat. Rep. 414d ou)k oi)=da o(poi/a| to/lmh| h)\ poi/ois lo/gois xrw/menos e)rw=. These are exceptions to the rule that, where an interrogative pronoun (as ti/s) and a relative (as o)/stis) are both used in an indirect question, the former stands first: cp. Plat. Crito 48a ou)k a)/rafrontiste/on, ti/ e)rou=sin oi( polloi\ h(ma=s, a)ll' o(/ ti o( e)pai/+wn, k.t.l.: Plat. Gorg. 448e ou)dei\s e)rwta=| poi/a tis ei)/h h( *gorgi/ou te/xnh, a)lla\ ti/s, kai\ o(/ntina de/oi kalei=n to\n *gorgi/an: Plat. Gorg. 500a e)kle/casqai poi=a a)gaqa\ kai\ o(poi=a kaka/: Plat. Phileb. 17b(i)/smen) po/sa te/ e)sti kai\ o(poi=a.

drw=n h)\fwnw=n: there is no definite contrast between doing and bidding others to do: rather “deed” and “word” represent the two chief forms of agency, the phrase being equivalent to “in what possible way.” Cp. Aesch. PB 659 qeopro/pous i)/allen, w(s ma/qoi ti/ xrh\ | drw=nt' h)\ le/gonta dai/mosin pra/ssein fi/la.

r(usai/mhn (L's reading) is right: r(usoi/mhn is grammatically possible, but less fitting. The direct deliberative form is ti/ drw=n r(u/swmai; the indirect, punqa/nomai o(/ ti (or ti/) drw=n r(u/swmai, e)puqo/mhn o(/ ti (or ti/) drw=n r(usai/mhn. This indirect deliberative occurs, not only with verbs of “doubting” (Xen. Hell. 7.4.39 h)po/rei o(/ ti xrh/saito tw=| pra/gmati), but also with verbs of “asking”: Thuc. 1.25 to
 qeo
 e)ph/ronto, ei) paradoi=enth
 po/lin (oblique of paradw=men th
 po/lin). Kennedy wrongly says that r(usai/mhn here could be only the oblique of e)rrusa/mhn (as if, in Thuc. 1.25, paradoi=en could be only the oblique of pare/dosan); and that, for the sense, it would require a)/n. This would also be right, but in a different constr., viz., as oblique of ti/ drw=n r(usai/mhn a)/n; Cp. Soph. Trach. 991 ou) ga e)/xw pw=s a)
 | ste/rcaimi, and Soph. Ant. 270 ff. n. In Soph. El. 33 w(s ma/qoim', o(/tw| tro/pw| patri\ | di/kas a)roi/mhn, the opt. is that of h)ro/mhn, being oblique for a)/rwmai, rather than of a)rou=mai. r(usoi/mhn would be oblique of ti/ drw=n r(u/somai; r(usoi/mhn (oblique for r(u/somai) would imply that he was confident of a successful result, and doubtful only concerning the means; it is therefore less suitable.

kai/ m' h)=marxro/nw| Lit., “and already the day, compared with the lapse of time [since his departure], makes me anxious what he doth”: i.e. when I think what day this is, and how many days ago he started, I feel anxious. h)/dh, showing that to-day is meant, sufficiently defines h)=mar. xro/nw| is not for tw=| xro/nw|, the time since he left, —though this is implied, —but is abstract, —time in its course. The absence of the art. is against our taking xro/nw| as “the time which I had allowed for his journey.” cummetrou/menon: cp. Hdt. 4.158 summetrhsa/menoi th\n w(/rhn th=s h(me/rhs, nukto\s parh=gon, “having calculated the time, they led them past the place by night”: lit., “having compared the season of the day (with the distance to be traversed).” Eur. Orest. 1214 kai\ dh\ pe/las nin dwma/twn ei)=nai dokw=: | tou= ga\r xro/nou to\ mh=kos au)to\ suntre/xei “for the length of time (since her departure) just tallies (with the time required for the journey).”

lupei= ti/ pra/ssei Soph. Aj. 794 w(/ste m' w)di/nein ti/ fh/|s. tou= ga\r ei)ko/tos pe/ra. to\ ei)ko/s is a reasonable estimate of the time required for the journey. Thuc. 2.73 h(me/rase)n ai)=s ei)ko\s h)=n komisqh=nai (au)tou/s), the number of days which might reasonably be allowed for their journey (from Plataea to Athens and back). Porson conjectured tou= ga\r ei)ko/tos pera=|, as = “for he overstays the due limit”—thinking v. 75, a)/pestixro/unou, to be a spurious interpolation. The same idea had occurred to Bentley. But (1) pera=n with the genitive in this sense is strange (in 674 qumou= pera=n is different), and would not be readily understood as referring to time; (2) it is Sophoclean to explain and define tou= ei)ko/tos pe/ra by plei/w tou= kaqh/kontos xro/nou.

ei)s kalo
 to fit purpose, “opportunely”: Plat. Sym. 174e ei)s kalo
 h(/keis. Soph. Aj. 1168 kai\ mh
 e)s au)to
 kairo
| pa/reisin. Cp. Aristoph. Ach. 686 ei)s ta/xos=taxe/ws, Aristoph. Birds 805 ei)s eu)te/leian=eu)telw=s. oi(/de: some of those suppliants who are nearer to the stage entrance on the spectators' left—the conventional one for an arrival from the country— have made signs to the Priest. Creon enters, wearing a wreath of bay leaves bright with berries, in token of a favourable answer. See Appendix, Note 1, sect. 2.

e)n tu/xh|o)/mmati may his radiant look prove the herald of good news. e)n tu/xh|, nearly = meta\ tu/xhs, “invested with,” “attended by”: cp. 1112 e)/n te ga\r makrw=| | gh/ra| cuna/|dei: Soph. Aj. 488 sqe/nontos e)n plou/tw|. tu/xh swth\r (Aesch. Ag. 664), like xei\r pra/ktwr(Aesch. Ag. 111), qe/lktwr peiqw/ (Aesch. Supp. 1040), karanisth=res di/kai(Aesch. Eum. 186).
lampro\s with e)n tu/xh| k.t.l., —being applicable at once to brilliant fortune and (in the sense of faidro/s) to a beaming countenance.

ei)ka/sai me/n, h(du/s (sc. bai/nei). Cp. Soph. El. 410 e)k dei/mato/s tou nukte/rou, dokei=n e)moi/. Soph. OC 151 dusai/wn | makrai/wn t', e)peika/sai. h(du/s, not “joyous,” but “pleasant to us,” “bringing good news”: as 510 h(du/polis, pleasant to the city: Soph. El. 929 h(du\s au)de\ mhtri\ dusxerh/s, a guest welcome, not grievous, to her. In Soph. Trach. 869 where a)hdh\s kai\ sunwfruwme/nh is said of one who approaches with bad news, a)nhdh/s is not “unwelcome,” but rather “sullen,” “gloomy.”

polustefh\sda/fnhs The use of the gen. after words denoting fulness is extended to the notions of encompassing or overshadowing: e.g. peristefh=|a)nqe/wn qh/khn (Soph. El. 895), ste/ghnh)=s [v. l. h(=|] kathrefei=s do/moi (Eur. Hipp. 468). But the dat. would also stand: cp. Hom. Od. 9.183 spe/osda/fnh|si kathrefe/s: Hes. WD 513 la/xnh| de/rma kata/skion. pagka/rpou, covered with berries: cp.Soph. OC 676. Plin. NH 15.30 maximis baccis atque e viridi rubentibus (of the Delphic laurel). The wreath announces good news, Soph. Trach. 179: so in Eur. Hipp. 806 Theseus, returning from the oracle at Delphi to find Phaedra dead, cries ti/ dh=ta toi=sd' a)ne/stemmai ka/ra | plektoi=si fu/llois, dustuxh\s qewro\s w)/n; So Fabius Pictor returned from Delphi to Rome coronatus laurea corona (Liv. 23.11).
cu/mmetros ga\r w(s klu/ein He is at a just distance for hearing: cu/mmetros = commensurate (in respect of his distance) with the range of our voices (implied in klu/ein).
kh/deuma “kinsman” (by marriage). = khdesth/s, here = gambro/s (70). Soph. Ant. 756 gunaiko\s w)\n dou/leuma mh\ kw/tille/ me. Eur. Orest. 928 ta)/ndon oi)kourh/mata = ta\s e)/ndon oi)kourou/sas.

le/gw ga\r
eu)tuxei=n Creon, unwilling to speak plainly before the Chorus, hints to Oedipus that he brings a clue to the means by which the anger of heaven may be appeased.

e)celqo/nta, of the event, “having issued”; cp. 1011 mh/ moi *foi=bos e)ce/lqh| safh/s; so 1182 e)ch/koi. The word is chosen by Creon with veiled reference to the duty of banishing the defiling presence (98 e)lau/nein). pa/nt' predicative with eu)tuxei=n, “will all of them (= altogether) be well.” le/gw a)\n eu)tuxei=n = le/gw o(/ti eu)tuxoi/h a)/n.
tou)/pos the actual oracle(tou)/pos to\ qeopro/pon, Soph. Trach. 822): lo/gw| (90), Creon's own saying(le/gw, 87).

prodei/sas, alarmed beforehand. Cp. Hdt. 7.50 kre/sson de\ pa/nta qarse/onta h(/misu tw=n deinw=n pa/sxein ma=llon h)\ pa=n xrh=ma prodeimai/nonta mhdama\ mhde\n paqei=n. No other part of prodei/dw occurs: protarbei=n, profobei=sqai = “to fear beforehand,” but u(per de/doika/ sou, I fear for thee, Soph. Ant. 82. In compos. with a verb of caring for, however, proo/ sometimes = u(pe/r, e.g. prokh/domai Soph. Ant. 741.

plhsiazo/ntwn here = plhsi/on o)/ntwn: usu. the verb = either (i) to approach, or (2) to consort with (dat.), as below, 1136. ei)ei)/te, as Aesch. Eum. 468 su\ d', ei) dikai/ws ei)/te mh/, kri=non di/khn.

ei)/te kai\ stei/xein e)/sw (xrh/|zeis), (e(/toimo/s ei)mi tou=to dra=n). So Eur. Ion 1120 (quoted by Elms., etc.) pepusme/nai ga/r, ei) qanei=n h(ma=s xrew/n, | h(/dion a)\n qa/noimen, ei)/q' o(ra=n fa/os: i. e. ei)/te o(ra=n fa/os (xrh/), (h(/dion a)\n o(rw=|men au)to/).

e)s pa/ntas Hdt. 8.26 ou)/te h)ne/sxeto sigw=n ei)=pe/ te e)s pa/ntas ta/de: Thuc. 1.72 e)s to\ plh=qos ei)pei=n (before the assembly). ple/on adverbial, as in Soph. Aj. 1101, etc.: schol. peri\ tou/twn ple/on a)gwni/zomai h)\ peri\ th=s e)mautou= yuxh=s.
tw=nde object. gen. with to\ pe/nqos (not with peri/): cp. Soph. El. 1097 ta=| *zhno\s eu)sebei/a|.

h)\ kai\ “than even.” This must not be confounded with the occasional use of h)\ kai/ in negative sentences containing a comparison: e.g. Soph. Aj. 1103 ou)k e)/sq' o(/pou soi\ to/nde kosmh=sai ple/on | a)rxh=s e)/keito qesmo\s h)\ kai\ tw=|de se/: Soph. El. 1145 ou)/te ga/r pote | mhtro\s su/ g' h)=sqa ma=llon h)\ ka)mou= fi/los: Antiph. 5.23 e)zhtei=to ou)de/n ti ma=llon u(po\ tw=n a)/llwn h)\ kai\ u(p' e)mou= (where kai/ is redundant, = “on my part”).

le/goim' a)
 a deferential form, having regard to the permission just given. Cp. Soph. Phil. 674 xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw: Soph. El. 637 klu/ois a)
 h)/dh.

w(s marks that the partic. teqramme/non expresses the view held by the subject of the leading verb (a)/nwgen): i.e., “as having been harboured” = “which (he says) has been harboured.” Cp. Xen. Anab. 1.2.1 e)/lege qarrei=n w(s katasthsome/nwn tou/twn ei)s to\ de/on: he said, “Take courage, in the assurance that” etc.
e)lau/nein for e)celau/nein was regular in this context: Thuc. 1.126 to\ a)/gos e)lau/nein th=s qeou=(i.e. to banish the Alcmaeonidae): and so 1. 127, 128, 135, 2. 13.

mhd' a)nh/keston tre/fein The mi/asma is a)nh/keston in the sense that it cannot be healed by anything else than the death or banishment of the bloodguilty. But it can still be healed if that expiation is made. Thus a)nh/keston is a proleptic predicate: cp. Plat. Rep. 565c tou=ton tre/fein te kai\ au)/cein me/gan:Soph. OC 527 n. See Antiph. 4.3.7 a)nti\ tou= paqo/ntos/GREEK> (in the cause of the dead) e)piskh/ptomen u(mi=n tw=| tou/tou fo/nw| to\ mh/nima tw=n a)lithri/wn a)kesame/nous pa=san th\n po/lin kaqara\n tou= mia/smatos katasth=sai, “to heal with this man's blood the deed which angers the avenging spirits, and so to purge the whole city of the defilement.”

poi/w|cumfora=s By what purifying rite (does he command us e)lau/nein to\ mi/asma)? What is the manner of our misfortune (i.e. our defilement)? Eur. Phoen. 390 ti/s o( tro/pos au)tou=; ti/ fuga/sin to\ dusxere/s; “what is the manner thereof?) sc. tou= kakou=, exile). cumfora=s, euphemistic for guilt, as Plat. Laws 934b lwfh=sai polla\ me/rh th=s toiau/ths cumfora=s, to be healed in great measure of such a malady (viz., of evil-doing): Plat. Laws 854d e)n tw=| prosw/pw| kai\ tai=s xersi\ grafei\s th\n cumfora/n, “with his misfortune [the crime of sacrilege] branded on his face and hands.” Hdt. 1.35 sumforh=| e)xo/menos=e)nagh/s, under a ban. Prof. Kennedy understands: “what is the mode of compliance (with the oracle)?” He compares Soph. OC 641 th=|de ga\r cunoi/somai (“for with that choice I will comply”). But elsewhere, at least, sumfora/ does not occur in a sense parallel with sumfe/resqai, “to agree with.”
a)ndrhlatou=ntas As if, instead of poi/w| kaqarmw=|, the question had been ti/ poiou=ntas;

w(s to/d' ai(=ma xeima/zon po/lin since it is this blood [to/de, viz. that implied in fo/non] which brings the storm on Thebes. xeima/zon, acc. absol. w(s presents the fact as the ground of belief on which the Thebans are commanded to act: “Do thus, assured that it is this blood,” etc. Cp. Soph. OC 380: Xen. Hell. 2.4.1 oi( de\ tria/konta, w(s e)co\n h)/dh au)toi=s turannei=n a)dew=s, proei=pon, k.t.l. Cp. Eur. Supp. 268 po/lis de\ pro\s po/lin | e)/pthce xeimasqei=sa, “city with city seeks shelter, when vexed by storms.”

a)peuqu/nein to steer in a right course. The infin. is of the imperf., = pro/teron h)\ a)phu/qunes, before you were steering (began to steer). Oedipus took the State out of angry waters into smooth: cp. 696 e)ma\n ga=n fi/lan | e)n po/nois a)lu/ousan kat' o)rqo\n ou)/risas: fr. 151 plh/ktrois a)peuqu/nousin ou)ri/an tro/pin, “with the helm(plh=ktra, the blades of the phda/lia) they steer their bark before the breeze.”

ou) ga\r ei)sei=do/n ge/ pw As Oed. knows that Laius is dead, the tone of unconcern given by this colloquial use of ou)/pw (instead of ou)/pote) is a skilful touch. Cp. Soph. El. 402 *x*r. su\ d' ou)xi\ pei/sei; *e*l. ou) dh=ta: mh/pw nou= toso/nd' ei)/hn kenh/: Eur. Hec. 1278 mh/pw manei/h *tundari\s toso/nde pai=s: Hom. Il. 12.270 a)ll' ou)/pw pa/ntes o(moi=oi | a)ne/res e)n pole/mw|: cp. our (ironical) “I have yet to learn.”

tou\s au)toe/ntastinas tou/s implies that the death had human authors; tinas, that they are unknown. So in Soph. OC 290 o(/tan d' o( ku/rios | parh=| tis, “the master—whoever he be.” timwrei=n, “punish.” The act., no less than the midd., is thus used even in prose: Lys. 13.42 timwrei=n u(pe\r au(tou= w(s fone/a o)/nta, to punish (Agoratus), on his own account, as his murderer. xeiri\ timwrei=n, here, either “to slay” or “to expel by force,” as distinguished from merely fining or disfranchising: in 140 toiau/th| xeiri\ timwrei=n is explained by ktanw\n in 139

pou= to/d'
ai)ti/as; to/de i)/xnos ai)ti/as = i)/xnos th=sde ai)ti/as, cp. tou)mo\n frenw=n o)/neiron Soph. El. 1390.

ai)ti/as,“crime”: Soph. Aj. 28 th/nd' ou)=n e)kei/nw| pa=s tis ai)ti/an ne/mei. For duste/kmarton, hard to track, cp. Aesch. Eum. 244 (the Furies hunting Orestes) ei)=en: to/d' e)sti\ ta)ndro\s e)kfane\s te/kmar. The poet hints a reason for what might else have seemed strange—the previous inaction of Oedipus. Cp. 219

e)/faske sc. o( qeo\s (eu(reqh/sesqai to\ i)/xnos). to\ de\ zhtou/menon: de\ has a sententious force, = “now.” The gnw/mh, though uttered in an oracular tone, is not part of the god's message. Cp. Eur. fr. 435 au)to/s ti nu=n drw=n ei)=ta dai/monas ka/lei: | tw=| ga\r ponou=nti kai\ qeo\s sullamba/nei.

sumpi/ptei The vivid historic present suits the alertness of a mind roused to close inquiry: so below, 118, 716, 1025: Soph. Trach. 748: Soph. El. 679. —Cp. Soph. Aj. 429 kakoi=s toioi=sde sumpeptwko/ta.

qewro/s Laius was going to Delphi in order to ask Apollo whether the child (Oedipus), formerly exposed by the god's command, had indeed perished: Eur. Phoen. 36 to
 e)kteqe/nta pai=da masteu/wn maqei=n | ei) mhke/t' ei)/h. w(s e)/fasken, as Laius told the Thebans at the time when he was leaving Thebes. e)kdhmw=n, not going abroad, but being [= having gone] abroad: cp. Plat. Laws 864e oi)kei/tw to
 e)niauto
 e)kdhmw=n. w(s = e)pei/: Xen. Cyrop. 1.3.2 w(s de\ a)fi/keto ta/xistah)spa/zeto. Cic. Brut. 5 ut illos libros edidisti, nihil a te postea accepimus.

ou)d' a)/ggelo/s
e)xrh/sat' a)/n; The sentence begins as if a)/ggelo/s tis were to be followed by h)=lqe but the second alternative, sumpra/ktwr o(dou=, suggests katei=de [had seen, though he did not speak]: and this, by a kind of zeugma, stands as verb to a)/ggelos also. Cp. Hdt. 4.106 e)sqh=ta de\ fore/ousi th=| *skuqikh=| o(moi/hn, glw=ssan de\ i)di/hn. ou)d' a)ggelo/s: Hom. Il. 12.73 ou)ke/t' e)/peit' o)i/+w ou)d' a)/ggelon a)pone/esqai.

o(/tou, gen. masc.: from whom having gained knowledge one might have used it.e)kmaqw
 = a protasis, ei) e)ce/maqen, e)xrh/sat' a)/n, sc. tou/tois a(\ e)ce/maqen. Plat. Gorg. 465e e)a
 me
 ou)=n kai\ e)gw\ sou= a)pokrinome/nou mh\ e)/xw o(/ ti xrh/swmai, if, when you answer, I also do not know what use to make [of your answer, sc. tou/tois a(\ a)
 a)pokri/nh|), —where shortly before we have ou)de\ xrh=sqai th=| a)pokri/sei h)/n soi a)pekrina/mhn ou)de
 oi)=o/s t' h)=sqa.

qnh/|skousi The i subscript in the pres. stem of this verb is attested by Attic inscriptions )Meisterhans, Gram. p. 86(. The practice of the Laurentian MS. fluctuates. It gives the i subscript here, in 623, 1457; Soph. OC 611; Soph. Ant. 547, 761; Soph. El. 1022. It omits the i subscript in Soph. El. 63, 113, 540, 1486; Soph. Trach. 707, 708; Soph. Phil. 1085. Cp. Etym. M. 482, 29, qnh/|skw, mimnh|skw. *di/dumos [circ. 30 B.C.] xwri\s tou= i_h( me/ntoi para/dosis e)/xei to\ i. — fo/bw| fugw\n, “having fled in fear”: fo/bw|, modal dative; cp. Thuc. 4.88 dia/ te to\ e)pagwga\ ei)pei=n to\n *brasi/dan kai\ peri\ tou= karpou= fo/bw| e)/gnwsan: Thuc. 5.70 e)nto/nws kai\ o)rgh=| xwrou=ntes.

ei)dw\s with sure knowledge )and not merely from confused recollection, a)safh\s do/ca(: so 1151 le/gei ga ei)dw\s ou)de
 a)ll' a)/llws ponei=: Soph. El. 41 o(/pws a)
 ei)dw\s h(mi
 a)ggei/lh|s safh=. Iocasta says )849(, in reference to this same point in the man's testimony, kou)k e)/stin au)tw=| tou=to/ g' e)kbalei=n pa/lin.

to\ poi=on; Cp. 291: Soph. El. 670 pra=gma porsu/nwn me/ga. | *k*l. to\ poi=on, w)= ce/n'; ei)pe/. Aristoph. Peace 696 eu)daimonei=. pa/sxei de\ qaumasto/n. “EPM. to\ ti/; e)ceu/roi maqei=n. One thing would find out how to learn many things, i.e. would prove a clue to them. The infin. maqei=n as after a verb of teaching or devising: Hdt. 1.196 a)/llo de/ ti e)ceurh/kasi newsti\ gene/sqai. Plat. Rep. 519e e)n o(/lh| th=| po/lei tou=to mhxana=tai e)ggene/sqai.

e)/faske sc. o( fugw/n )118(. ou) mia=| r(w/mh| = ou)x e(no\s r(w/mh|, in the strength not of one man. Cp. Hdt. 1.174 pollh=| xeiri\ e)rgazome/nwn tw=n *knidi/wn. Soph. Ant. 14 diplh=| xeri/ = by the hands of twain. So perh. xeri\ didu/ma| Pind. P. 2.9.
su\n plh/qei cp. on 55.

ei)/ ti mh\ if some intrigue, aided by (cu\n) money, had not been working from Thebes. ti is subject to e)pra/sseto: distinguish the adverbial ti (= “perchance”) which is often joined to ei) mh/ in diffident expressions, as 969 ei)/ ti mh\ tw)mw=| po/qw| | kate/fqit', ‘unless perchance’: so Soph. OC 1450, Soph. Trach. 586 etc. Schneid. cp. Thuc. 1.121 kai/ ti au)tw=| kai\ e)pra/sseto e)s ta\s po/leis tau/tas prodosi/as pe/ri: and Thuc. 5.83 u(ph=rxe de/ ti au)toi=s kai\ e)k tou= *)/argous au)to/qen prasso/menon.
e)pra/ssetoe)/bh the imperf. refers here to a continued act in past time, the aor. to an act done at a definite past moment. Cp. 402 e)do/keis—e)/gnws: 432 i(ko/mhn—e)ka/leis.
dokou=ntah)=n expresses the vivid presence of the do/ca more strongly than tau=ta e)do/kei would have done )cp. 274 ta/d' e)/st' a)re/skonq'(: Hdt. 1.146 tau=ta de\ h)=n gino/mena e)n *milh/tw|.

e)mpodw/n sc. o)/n, with kako
, not with ei)=rge, “what trouble (being) in your path?” Cp. 445 parw
e)mpodw
 | o)xlei=s. turanni/dos. Soph. conceives the Theban throne as having been vacant from the death of Laius—who left no heir—till the election of Oed. The abstract turanni/dos suits the train of thought on which Oed. has already entered, —viz. that the crime was the work of a Theban faction )124( who wished to destroy, not the king merely, but the kingship. Cp. Aesch. Lib. 973 i(/desqe xw/ras th
 diplh=n turanni/da )Clytaemnestra and Aegisthus(.

poikilw|do\s singing poiki/la, subtleties, ai)ni/gmata: cp. Plat. Sym. 182a o( peri\ to
 e)/rwta no/mos e)n me
 tai=s a)/llais po/lesi noh=sai r(a/|dios: a(plw=s ga w)/ristai: o( de\ e)nqa/de kai\ e)n *lakedai/moni poiki/los. Hdt. 7.3 pro/mantis de\ h( xre/ousa, kata/per e)n *delfoi=si, kai\ ou)de
 poikilw/teron, “the chief prophetess is she who gives the oracles, as at Delphi, and in no wise of darker speech.”

prosh/getoThe constr. is prosh/geto h(ma=s, meqe/ntas ta\ a)fanh=, skopei=n to\ pro\s posi/. prosh/geto, was drawing us )by her dread song(, said with a certain irony, since prosa/gesqai with infin. usually implies a gentle constraint )though, as a milit. term, a)na/gkh| proshga/gonto, reduced by force, Hdt. 6.25(: cp. Eur. Ion 659 xro/nw| de\ kairo
 lamba/nwn prosa/comai | da/mart' e)a=n se skh=ptra ta)/m' e)/xein xqono/s. to\ pro\s posi\ )cp. e)mpodw
 128(, the instant, pressing trouble, opp. to ta\ a)fanh=, obscure questions )as to the death of Laius( of no present or practical interest. Pind. I. 7.12 dei=ma me
 paroixo/menon | kartera
 e)/pause me/rimnan: to\ de\ pro\s podo\s a)/reion a)ei\ skopei=n | xrh=ma pa=n. Soph. Ant. 1327 ta)
 posi
 kaka/.

e)c u(parxh=s i.e. taking up anew the search into the death of Laius. Aristot. Soul 2.1 pa/lin d' w(/sper e)c u(parxh=s e)pani/wmen: so pa/lin ou)=n oi(=on e)c u(parxh=s Aristot. Rh. 1.1.14: Dem. 40.16 pa/lin e)c u(parxh=s lagxa/nousi/ moi di/kas. The phrase e)n th=| th=s e)pisth/mhs u(parxh=| occurs in the paraphrase by Themistius of Arist. peri\ fusikh=s a)kroa/sews 8. 3 )Berlin ed. vol. 1. 247 b 29(: elsewhere the word occurs only in e)c u(parxh=s. Cp. Soph. El. 725 u(postrofh=s = u(postrafe/ntes: Hdt. 5.116 e)k ne/hs: Thuc. 3.92 e)k kainh=s. au)=qis, as he had done in the case of the Sphinx's riddle: au)/t' = ta\ a)fnh=.

e)paci/ws )which would usually have a genitive( implies the standard—worthily of his own godhead, or of the occasion— and is slightly stronger than a)ci/ws. Cp. Eur. Hec. 168 a)pwle/sat', w)le/sat': Eur. Orest. 181 dioixo/meq', oi)xo/meq: Eur. Alc. 400 u(pa/kouson, a)/kouson.

pro\ on behalf of, cp. pro\ tw=nde 10, Soph. OC 811: Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.4 ei)/ tisdiakinduneu/seie pro\ basile/ws: 1. 6. 42 a)ciw/sousi se\ pro\ e(autw=n bouleu/esqai. Campb. reads pro\s tou= qano/ntos, which here could mean only “at the instance of the dead.” pro/s never = “on behalf of,” “for the sake of,” but sometimes “on the side of”: e.g. Hdt. 1.124 a)posta/ntes a)p' e)kei/nou kai\ geno/menoi pro\s se/o, “ranged themselves on your side”: Hdt. 1.75 e)lpi/sas pro\s e(wutou= to\n xrhsmo\n ei)=nai, that the oracle was on his side: below, 1434, pro\s sou=fra/sw, I will speak on your side, —in your interest: Soph. Trach. 479 kai\ to\ pro\s kei/nou le/gein, to state his side of the case also.

e)pistrofh/n a turning round (Soph. OC 1045), hence, attention, regard: e)pistrofh\n ti/qesqai )like spoudh/n, pro/noian ti/q., Soph. Aj. 13, 536( = e)pistre/fesqai/ )tinos(, Soph. Phil. 599. Dem. 23.136 ou)k e)pestra/fh “heeded not” = ou)de\n e)fro/ntise Dem. 23.135.

u(pe\r ga\r ou)xi\ i.e. not merely in the cause of Laius, whose widow he has married. The arrangement of the words is designed to help a second meaning of which the speaker is unconscious: “in the cause of a friend who is not far off” )his own father(. The reference to Laius is confirmed by kei/nw| prosarkw=n in 141.

au(tou= = e)mautou=. The reflexive au(tou=, etc., is a pron. of the 1st pers. in Soph. OC 966, Soph. El. 285, Soph. Aj. 1132: of the n)d pers., in Soph. OC 853, 930, 1356, Soph. Trach. 451. a)poskedw=, dispel, as a taint in the air: cp. Hom. Od. 8.149 ske/dason d' a)/po kh/dea qumou=: Plat. Phaedo 77d mh\o( a)/nemos au)th
 )th
 yuxh
( e)kbai/nousan e)k tou= sw/matos diafusa=| kai\ diaskeda/nnusin.
e)kei=non o( ktanw/n e)kei=non has emphasis: cp. 820.
toiau/th referring to ktanw\n, implies foni/a|: on timwrei=n see 107. The spectator thinks of the time when Oed. shall be blinded by his own hand. —For the double a)\n cp. 339, 862, 1438.
pai=des The king here, as the priest in 147, addresses all the suppliants. a)/llos )144( is one of the king's attendants.

ba/qrwn
i(/stasqe Cp. Soph. Ant. 417 xqono\sa)ei/ras: Soph. Phil. 630 new\s a)/gonta. Prose would require a compound verb: Xen. Sym. 4.31 u(pani/stantaiqa/kwn.
a)/rantes. Aesch. Supp. 481 kla/dous ge tou/tous ai)=y' e)n a)gka/lais labw\n | bwmou\s e)p' a)/llous daimo/nwn e)gxwri/wn | qe/s.

pa=ndra/sontos to do everything = to leave nothing untried: for w(s cp. 97. Plat. Apol. 39a e)a/n tis tolma=| pa=n poiei=n kai\ le/gein. Xen. Hell. 7.4.21 pa/nta e)poi/ei o(/pws, ei) du/naito, a)paga/goi. eu)tuxei=s
peptwko/tes: “fortunate,” if they succeed in their search for the murderer, who, as they now know, is in their land )110(: “ruined,” if they fail, since they will then rest under the a)nh/keston mi/asma )98(. The unconscious speaker, in his last word, strikes the key-note of the destined peripe/teia.

w)= pai=des see on 142. —kai\ deu=r' e)/bhmen, we e'en came here: i.e. this was the motive of our coming in the first instance. Soph. Phil. 380 e)peidh\ kai\ le/geis qrasustomw=n: Lys. 12.29 para\ tou= pote kai\ lh/yesqe di/khn;

e)cagge/lletai, proclaims on his own part )midd.(, of himself: i.e. promises unasked, ultro pollicetur. Cp. Soph. Aj. 1376 a)gge/llomaiei)=nai fi/los, “I offer friendship.” Eur. has thus used e)cagg. even where metre permitted the more usual e)pagge/llomai: Eur. Heraclid. 531 ka)cagge/llomai | qnh/|skein, I offer to die.
a(/ma i.e. may the god, who has summoned us to put away our pollution, at the same time come among us as a healing presence.

div1.p: The Chorus consists of Theban elders—men of noble birth, “the foremost in honour of the land” (1223) —who represent the *ka/dmou lao/s just summoned by Oedipus (144). Oedipus having now retired into the palace, and the suppliants having left the stage, the Chorus make their entrance )pa/rodos( into the hitherto vacant o)rxh/stra. For the metres see the Analysis which follows the Introduction. 1st strophe )151-158(. Is the god's message indeed a harbinger of health? Or has Apollo some further pain in store for us? 1st antistrophe )159-166(. May Athene, Artemis, and Apollo succour us! 2nd strophe )167-178(. The fruits of the earth and the womb perish. 2nd antistrophe )179-189(. The unburied dead taint the air: wives and mothers are wailing at the altars. 3rd strophe )190-202(. May Ares, the god of death, be driven hence: may thy lightnings, O Zeus, destroy him. 3rd antistrophe )203-215(. May the Lycean Apollo, and Artemis, and Dionysus fight for us against the evil god.

div2.p:
fa/ti of a god's utterance or oracle )1440(, a poet. equivalent for fh/mh: cp. 310 a)p' oi)wnw=n fa/tin. *dio\s, because Zeus speaks by the mouth of his son; Aesch. Eum. 19 *dio\s profh/ths d' e)sti\ *loci/as patro/s. a(duepe\s, merely a general propitiatory epitnet: the Chorus have not yet heard whether the response is comforting or not. It is presently told to them by Oed. )242(. Cp. Soph. El. 480 a(dupno/wno)neira/twn, dreams breathing comfort )from the gods(. ti/s pote
e)/bas; What art thou that hast come? i.e. in what spirit hast thou come? bringing us health or despair?

ta=s poluxru/sou, “rich in gold,” with allusion to the costly a)naqh/mata dedicated at Delphi, and esp. to the treasury of the temple, in which gold and silver could be deposited, as in a bank, until required for use. Hom. Il. 9.404 ou)d' o(/salai+nos ou)do\s a)fh/toros e)nto\s e)e/rgei | *foi/bou *)apo/llwnos, *puqoi= e)ni\ petrhe/ssh|. Thuc. 1.121 nautiko/n te a)po\ th=s u(parxou/shs te ou)si/as e)cartuso/meqa, kai\ a)po\ tw=n e)n *delfoi=s kai\ *)olumpi/a| xrhma/twn. Athen. 233 F tw=| me
 ou)=n e)n *delfoi=s *)apo/llwni to
 pro/teron e)n th=| *lakedai/moni xruso
 kai\ a)rgunon [pro/teron = before the time of Lysander] i(storou=sin a)nateqh=nai. Eur. Andr. 1093 qeou= | xrusou= ge/monta gu/ala )recesses(, qhsaurou\s brotw=n. Eur. Ion 54 *delfoi/ sf' e)/qento )the young Ion( xrusofu/laka tou= qeou=, | tami/an te pa/ntwn. Pind. P. 6.8 e)n poluxru/sw| *)apollwni/a|na/pa|) i.e. e)n *puqoi=(.
*puqw=nos from Pytho (Delphi): for the gen. see on 142 ba/qrwn | i(/stasqe.

The bold use of e)kte/tamai is interpreted by fobera
 fre/na, dei/mati pa/llwn, which is to be taken in close connection with it. e)ktei/nesqai is not found elsewhere of mental tension )though Dion. Hal. Comp. Verb. 15 ad fin. has h( th=s dianoi/as e)/ktasis kai\ to\ tou= dei/matos a)prosdo/khton. Cp. Xen. Cyrop. 1.3.11 e(/ws paratei/naimi tou=ton, w(/sper ou(=tos e)me\ paratei/nei a)po\ sou= kwlu/wn, —‘rack,’ ‘torture’ him. But paratei/nesqai, when used figuratively, usually meant “to be worn out,” “fatigued to death”: e.g. Plat. Lysis 204c parataqh/setai u(po\ sou= a)kou/wn qama\ le/gontos, enecabitur, he will be tired to death of hearing it. So Xen. Mem. 3.13.6 parate/tamai makra
 o(do
 poreuqei/s. Triclinius explains here, “I am prostrated by dread”(e)kpe/plhgmai, par' o(/son oi( e)kplage/ntes e)/ktasin sw/matos kai\ a)kinhsi/an pa/sxousin: cp. Eur. Med. 585 e(
 ga e)ktenei= s' e)/pos): so Soph. Phil. 858 e)kte/tatai nu/xios (of a sleeper). But the context favours the other view.

pa/llwn transitive, governing fre/na, making my heart to shake; not intransitive, for pallo/menos, with fre/na as accus. of the part affected. An intransitive use of pa/llw in this figurative sense is not warranted by such instances as Aristoph. Lys. 1304 kou=fa pa/llwn, “lightly leaping in the dance”: Eur. El. 435 e)/palle delfi/s (= e)ski/rta), “the dolphin leaped”: Eur. El. 477 i(/ppoi e)/pallon “quivered” (in death). Cp. Aesch. PB 881 kradi/a fo/bw| fre/na lakti/zei: so, when the speaker is identified with the troubled spirit within him, we can say fre/na pa/llw, —where fre/na has a less distinctly physical sense than in Aesch. PB 881, yet has physical associations which help to make the phrase less harsh.

*da/lie The Delphian Apollo is also Delian—having passed, according to the Ionic legend, from his native Delos, through Attica, to Delphi (Aesch. Eum. 9). A Boeotian legend claimed Tegyra as the birthplace of Apollo: Plut. Pelop. 16 e)ntau=qa muqologou=si to
 qeo
 gene/sqai, kai\ to\ me
 plhsi/on o)/ros *dh=los kalei=tai. We can scarcely say, however, with Schneidewin that *da/lie here “bewrays the Athenian,” when we remember that the Theban Pindar hails the Delphian Apollo as *lu/kie kai\ *da/lou a)na/sswn *foi=be(Pind. P. 1.39).
i)h/ie (again in 1096), invoked with the cry i)h/: cp. Soph. Trach. 221 i)w\ i)w\ *paia/n. Soph. has the form paiw/n, paih/wn as = “a healer” (not with ref. to Apollo), Soph. Phil. 168, 832.

a(zo/menos (rt. a(g, whence a)/gios) implies a religious fear: cp. Hom. Od. 9.478 sxe/tli', e)pei\ cei/nous ou)x a(/zeo sw=| e)ni\ oi)/kw| | e)sqe/menai. ti/ moi
xre/os: “what thing thou wilt accomplish for me”: i.e., what expiation thou wilt prescribe, as the price of deliverance from the plague. Will the expiation be of a new kind(ne/on)? Or will some ancient mode of atonement be called into use once more(pa/lin)?pa/lin recalls Aesch. Ag. 154 mi/mnei ga\r fobera\ pali/nortos | oi)kono/mos doli/a mna/mwn mh=nis tekno/poinos. ne/on, adjective with xre/os:

pa/lin, adverb with e)canu/seis. ti/ moi ne/on xre/os e)canu/seis; h)\ ti/ xre/os pa/lin e)canu/seis; The doubling of h)/ harshly co-ordinates ne/on and pa/lin, as if one said ti/nas h)\ maxome/nous h)\ a)maxei\ e)ni/khsan; xre/os here = xrh=ma, “matter” (implying importance): cp. Aesch. Supp. 374 (of a king) xre/os | pa=n e)pikrai/neis: Eur. Her. 530 ti/ kaino\n h)=lqe toi=sde dw/masin xre/os; Others take it as = “obligation” (cp. Soph. OC 235), but against this is e)canu/seis, which could not mean either to “impose” or to “exact” it. Whitelaw renders, “what requirement thou wilt enact (by oracular voice),” finding this use of a)nu/w in Soph. OC 454, Soph. Ant. 1178; but there (as below, 720) it has its normal sense, “fulfil.”

peritellome/nais w(/rais an epic phrase which Aristoph. Birds 697 also has. Hom. Od. 14.293 a)ll' o(/te dh\ mh=ne/s te kai\ h(me/rai e)ceteleu=nto | a)\y peritellome/nou e)/teos, kai\ e)ph/luqon w(=rai.

xruse/as k.t.l. The answer (not yet known to them) sent by Apollo is personified as *fa/ma, a divine Voice, —“the daughter of golden hope,” because—whether favourable or not—it is the issue of that hope with which they had awaited the god's response.

keklo/menos is followed in 164 by profa/nhte/ moi instead of eu)/xomai profanh=nai. Cp. Plat. Laws 686d a)poble/yas ga\r pro\s tou=ton to\n sto/lon ou(= pe/ri dialego/meqa e)/doce/ moi pa/gkalosei)=nai. Antiph. 3.2.10 a)poluo/menos de\ u(po/ te th=s a)lhqei/as tw=n praxqe/ntwn u(po/ te tou= no/mou kaq' o(\n diw/ketai, ou)de\ tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn ei(/neka di/kaioi toiou/twn kakw=n a)ciou=sqai/ e)smen. Xen. Cyrop. 8.8.10 h)=n de\ au)toi=s no/mimonnomi/zontes. The repetition of a)/mbrot' has provoked some weak and needless conjectures: see on 517.

gaia/oxo/n holding or guarding our land; so Aesch. Supp. 816 gaia/oxe pagkrate\s *zeu=. In Soph. OC 1072 it is the Homeric epithet of Poseidon, “girdling the earth,” to\n po/ntion gaia/oxon. Cp. *palla\s poliou=xos Aristoph. Kn. 581(polia/oxos Pind. O. 5.10), polissou=xoi qeoi/ Aesch. Seven 69.

kuklo/ent' a)gora=s qro/non = kukloe/sshs a)gora=s qro/non: cp. Soph. Ant. 793 nei=kos a)ndrw=n cu/naimon, Soph. Trach. 993 w)= *khnai/a krhpi\s bwmw=n. “Round throne of the marketplace” means simply (I now think) “throne consisting of the round marketplace.” The sitting statue of Artemis is in the middle of the agora; hence the agora itself is poetically called her throne. The word ku/klos in connection with the Athenian agora, of which it perhaps denoted a special part; schol. Aristoph. Kn. 137 o( de\ ku/klos *)aqh/nhsi/n e)sti kaqa/per ma/kellos, e)k th=s kataskeuh=s (form) th\n proshgori/an labw/n. e)/nqa dh\ pipra/sketai xwri\s krew=n ta\ a)/lla w)/nia, kai\ e)caire/tws de\ oi( i)xqu/es. Cp. Eur. Orest. 919 o)liga/kis a)/stu ka)gora=s xrai/nwn ku/klon, “the circle of the agora,” i.e. “its bounds”: cp. Thuc. 3.74 ta\s oi)ki/as ta\s e)n ku/klw| th=s a)gora=s, “all round” the agora. In Hom. Il. 18.504, cited by Casaubon on Theophr. Char. 2.4, i(erw=| e)ni\ ku/klw| refers merely to the ge/rontes in council. This is better than (1) “her round seat in the agora”— kuklo/enta meaning that the pedestal of the statue was circular; (2) “her throne in the agora, round which ku/klioi xoroi/ range themselves.” This last is impossible. eu)kle/a, alluding to Artemis *eu)/kleia, the vipgin goddess of Faip Fame, wopshirred esr. by Locpians and Boeotians: Plut. Arist. 20 bwmo\s ga\r au)th=| kai\ a)/galma para\ pa=san a)gora\n i(/drutai, kai\ proqu/ousin ai(/ te gamou/menai kai\ oi( gamou=ntes: also at Corinth, Xen. Hell. 4.4.2. Pausanias saw a temple of *)/artemis *eu)/kleia, with a statue by Scopas, near the *proiti/des pu/lai on the N.E. side of Thebes. Near it were statues of Apollo Boedromios and Hermes Agoraios. The latter suggests that the Agora of the Lower Town (which was deserted when Pausanias visited Thebes) may have been near. In mentioning the a)gora/, Soph. may have been further influenced by the fact that Artemis was worshipped as *)agorai/a: thus in the altis at Olympia there was an *)artemi/dos *)agorai/as bwmo/s near that of *zeu\s *)agorai=os (Paus. 5.15.4).

a)/tas u(/per “on account of ruin” (i.e. “to avert it”): cp. Soph. Ant. 932 klau/maq' u(pa/rcei braduth=tos u(/per. So Aesch. Seven 111 i)/dete parqe/nwn i(ke/sion lo/xon doulosu/nas u(/per, “to avert slavery.” Cp. 187. o)rnume/nas po/lei: the dat. (poet.) as after verbs of attacking, e.g. e)pie/nai, e)piti/qesqai. Musgrave's conj. u(perornume/nas po/lei (the compound nowhere occurs) has been adopted by some editors.

h)nu/sat' e)ktopi/an made e)ktopi/an, = e)cwri/sate, a rare use of a)nu/w like poiei=n, kaqista/nai, a)podeiknu/nai: for the ordinary use, cp. 720 e)kei=non h)/nusen | fone/a gene/sqai, effected that he should become. In Soph. Ant. 1178 tou)/pos w(s a)/r' o)rqo
 h)/nusas, the sense is not ‘made right,’ but ‘brought duly to pass.’ e)/lqete kai\ nu=n, an echo of profa/nhte/ moi, prote/ras having suggested kai\ nu=n: as in 338 a)ll' e)me\ ye/geis repeats o)rgh
 e)me/myw th
 e)mh/n.
w(= po/poi is merely a cry like papai=: Soph. Trach. 853 ke/xutai no/sos, w)= po/poi, oi(=on, k.t.l.
sto/los like strato/s (Pind. P. 2.46, etc.), = lao/s.
e)/ni = e)/nesti, is available.
fronti/dos e)/gxos not, a weapon consisting in a device, but a weapon discovered by human wit, e)/gxos w(=| tis a)le/cetai being a bold equivalent for mhxanh\ a)lechthri/a.

This future has the support of the best MSS. in Xen. Anab. 7.7.3 ou)k e)pitre/yomenw(s polemi/ous a)leco/meqa: and of grammarians, Bekk. Anecd. p. 415: the aorist a)le/cai, a)le/casqai also occurs. These forms are prob. not from the stem a)lec (whence present a)le/cw, cp. a)e/cw, o)da/cw) but from a stem a)lk with unconsciously developed e, making a)lek (cp. a)/l-alkon): see Curtius, Verb, 11.258, Eng. tr. 445. Homer has the fut. a)lech/sw, and Her. a)lech/somai. —Cp. 539.

to/koisin by births. Women are released from travail, not by the birth of living children, but either by death before delivery, or by still births. See on 26, and cp. Hes. WD 244 ou)de\ gunai=kes ti/ktousin. If to/koisin= “in child-bed” (and so the schol., e)n toi=s to/kois), the meaning would be simply, “women die in child-bed,” —not necessarily “before child-birth”; but the point here is the blight on the fruits of earth and womb, —not merely the mortality among women.

a)/llon d'a)/llw| “one after another.” The dative here seems to depend mainly on the notion of adding implied by the iteration itself; though it is probable that the neighbourhood of pro/s in prosi/dois may have been felt as softening the boldness. That prosora=n could be used as = “to see in addition”is inconceivable; nor could such use be justified by that of e)nora=n tini as = o(ra=n e)/n tini. And no one, I think, would be disposed to plead lyric license for a)/llw| pro\s i)/dois on the strength of a)kta\n pro\s e(spe/rou qeou= in 177. Clearly there was a tendency (at least in poetry) to use the dative thus, though the verb of the context generally either (a) helps the sense of “adding,” or (b) leaves an alternative. Under (a) I should put Soph. El. 235 ti/ktein a)/tan a)/tais: Eur. Hel. 195 da/krua da/krusi/ moi fe/rwn. Under (b), Eur. Orest. 1257 ph/mata ph/masin e)ceu/rh|: Eur. Phoen. 1496 fo/nw| fo/nos | *oi)dipo/da do/mon w)/lese: where the datives might be instrumental. On the whole, I forbear to recommend a)/llon d' a)\n a)/lla| prosi/dois, though easy and tempting; cp. Thuc. 2.4 a)/lloi de\ a)/llh| th=s po/lews spora/dhn a)pw/llunto.
o)/rmenon aor. part. (Hom. Il. 2.571 dou=rao)/rmena pro/ssw), “sped,” “hurried,” since the life is quickly gone. krei=ssonpuro\s, because the purfo/ros loimo/s drives all before it.

a)kta\n pro\s for pro\s a)kta/n, since the attributive gen. e(spe/rou qeou= is equiv. to an adj. agreeing with a)kta/n: cp. Soph. OC 84 e(/dras | prw/twn e)f' u(mw=n, Soph. OC 126 a)/lsos e)skora=n: Soph. El. 14 toso/nd' e)s h(/bhs: so Aesch. PB 653, Aesch. Seven 185: Eur. Orest. 94. e(spe/rou qeou=: as the Homeric Erebos is in the region of sunset and gloom (Hom. Od. 12.81), and Hades is e)nnuxi/wn a)/nac Soph. OC 1559.

w(=na)na/riqmos w(=n, masc., referring to a)/llona)/llw|, — “to such (deaths) knowing no limit”: cp. a)na/riqmos qrh/nwn Soph. El. 232, mhnw=n | a)nh/riqmos Soph. Aj. 602. An adj. formed with a privative, whether from noun or from verb, constantly takes a gen. in poetry: see on 190(a)/xalkos),885(a)fo/bhtos).

ge/neqla (po/lews), “her sons”: cp. 1424 ta\ qnhtw=n ge/neqla, the sons of men. nhle/a, unpitied; a)noi/ktws, without oi)=ktos, lament, made for them: they receive neither tafh/ nor qrh=nos. Cp. Thuc. 2.50 pollw=n a)ta/fwn gignome/nwn (in the plague, 430 B.C.).
e)n d' cp. on 27. e)/pi, adv.: Hdt. 7.65 to/ca de\ kala/mina ei)=xon,e)pi\ de/, si/dhron(v. l. -os) h)=n. But e)/pi = e)/pesti, Hom. Il. 1.515.

a)kta\n para\ bw/mion “at the steps of the altars”: Aesch. Lib. 722 a)kth\ xw/matos, the edge of the mound: Eur. Her. 984 a)mfi\ bwmi/an | e)/pthce krhpi=d', at the base of the altar. a)/lloqen a)/llan (with e)pistena/xousi), because the sounds are heard from various quarters.
i(kth=res with lugrw=n po/nwn, entreating on account of (for release from) their woes, causal gen.: cp. a)lgei=n tu/xhs, Aesch. Ag. 571.
la/mpei 473 e)/lamyefa/ma: Aesch. Seven 104 ktu/pon de/dorka. o(/maulos, i.e. heard at the same time, though not su/mfwnos with it.
w(=n u(/per see on 165.
eu)w=pa a)lka/n cp. a)ganh\ sai/nous' | e)lpi/s, Aesch. Ag. 101 (where Weil profanei=s'), i(laro\n fe/ggos Aristoph. Frogs 455.

*)/area/ te k.t.l. The acc. and infin. *)/areanwti/sai depend on do/s or the like, suggested by the preceding words. Cp. Hom. Il. 7.179 *zeu= pa/per, h)\ *ai)/anta laxei=n h)\ *tude/os ui(o/n (grant that). Aesch. Seven 253 qeoi\ poli=tai, mh/ me doulei/as tuxei=n. malero/n, raging: cp. malerou= puro/s Hom. Il. 9.242: malerw=nleo/ntwn Aesch. Ag. 141. Ares is for Soph. not merely the war-god, but generally brotoloigo/s, the Destroyer: cp. Soph. Aj. 706. Here he is identified with the fiery plague. a)/xalkos a)spi/dwn (cp. Soph. El. 36 a)/skeuon a)spi/dwn: Eur. Phoen. 324 a)/peplos fare/wn): Ares comes not, indeed, as the god of war (o( xalkobo/as *)/arhs, Soph. OC 1046), yet shrieks of the dying surround him with a cry(boh/) as of battle.

peribo/aton could not mean “crying loudly”: the prose use (“famous” or “notorious” Thuc. 6.31) confirms the pass. sense here. a)ntia/zw, attacking: Hdt. 4.80 h)nti/asa/n min (acc.) oi( *qrh/i+kes. Aesch. has the word once only, as = “to meet” (not in a hostile sense), Aesch. Ag. 1557 pate/r' a)ntia/sasa: Eur. always as = “to entreat”; and so Soph. El. 1009. Dindorf reads fle/gei me peribo/aton (the accus. on his own conject.), a)ntia/zw (suggested by Herm.), “I pray that” etc. But the received text gives a more vivid picture.

nwti/sai to turn the back in flight (Eur. Andr. 1141 pro\s fugh\n e)nw/tisan), a poet. word used by Aesch. with acc. po/nton, to skim (Aesch. Ag. 286), by Eur. Phoen. 651 (Dionysus) kisso\s o(\ne)nw/tisen as = “to cover the back of.” dra/mhma, cognate acc.: pa/tras, gen. after verb of parting from: see on ba/qrwn, 142.

e)/pouron = e)pourizo/menon (ironical). Lidd. and Scott s. v. refer to Clemens Alexandr. Paed. 130 tw=| th=s a)lhqei/as pneu/mati e)/pouros a)rqei/s, “lifted on a prospering gale by the spirit of Truth.” So Soph. Trach. 815 ou)=ros o)fqalmw=n e)mw=n | au)th=| ge/noit' a)/pwqen e(rpou/sh| kalw=s: Soph. Trach. 467 a)lla\ tau=ta me
 | r(ei/tw kat' ou)=ron. Active in Soph. Trach. 954 e)/pouros e(stiw=tis au)/ra (schol. a)/nemos ou)/rios e)pi\ th=s oi)ki/as), “wafting,” The v.l. a)/pouron would go with pa/tras, “away from the borders of my country” —from Ionic ou)=ros = o(/ros, like o(/mouros (Hdt. 1.57), pro/souros(Soph. Phil. 691), cu/nouros (Aesch. Ag. 495), thlouro/s. Pollux 6. 198 gives e)/coros, e)co/rios, but we nowhere find an Ionic a)/pouros: while for Attic writers o)/foros (from o(/ros) would have been awkward, since a)/foros “sterile” was in use. me/gan | qa/lamon *)amfitri/tas, the Atlantic. qa/lamos *)amfitri/ths alone would be merely “the sea” (Hom. Od. 3.91 e)n pela/gei meta\ ku/masin *)amfitri/ths), but me/gan helps to localise it, since the Atlantic(h( e)/cw sthle/wn qa/lassa h( *)atlanti\s kaleome/nh, Hdt. 1.202) was esp. h( mega/lh qa/lassa. Thus Polyb. 3.37 calls the Mediterranean th
 kaq' h(ma=s,— the Atlantic, th
 e)/cw kai\ mega/lhn prosagoreuome/nhn. In Plat. Phaedo 109b the limits of the known habitable world are described by the phrase, tou\s me/xri tw=n *(hraklei/wn sthlw=n a)po\ *fa/sidos (which flows into the Euxine on the E.), Eur. Hipp. 3, o(/soi te po/ntou (the Euxine) termo/nwn t' *)atlantikw=n | nai/ousin ei)/sw: Eur. Her. 234 w(/st' *)atlantikw=n pe/ra | feu/gein o(/rwn a)/n.

a)po/cenon Aesch. has the word as = “estranged from”(gh=s, Aesch. Ag. 1282), cp. a)pocenou=sqai. Here it means “away from strangers” in the sense of “keeping them at a distance.” Such compounds are usu. passive in sense: cp. a)po/deipnos (Hesych., = a)/deipnos), a)po/qeos, a)po/misqos, a)po/sitos, a)po/timos (215), a)poxrh/matos.

a)po/cenos o(/rmos, the Euxine: an oxymoron, = o(/rmos a)/normos, as in Soph. Phil. 217 nao\s a)/cenon o)/rmon. Strabo 7.298 a)/ploun ga\r ei)=nai to/te th\n qa/lattan tau/thn kai\ kalei=sqai *)/acenon dia\ to\ dusxei/meron kai\ th\n a)grio/thta tw=n perioikou/ntwn e)qnw=n kai\ ma/lista tw=n *skuqikw=n, cenoqutou/ntwn, k.t.l. The epithet *qrh/|kion here suggests the savage folk to whom Ares is a)gxi/ptolis on the W. coast of the Euxine (Soph. Ant. 969). Ovid Trist. 4.4.55 Frigida me cohibent Euxini litora Ponti: Dictus ab antiquis Axenus ille fuit.

telei=n ga\re)/rxetai Reading telei=n, as Herm. suggested, instead of te/lei, I construe thus: —ei)/ ti nu/c a)fh=|, h)=mar e)pe/rxetai telei=n tou=to, “If night omit anything (in the work of destruction), day comes after it to accomplish this.” telei=n is the infin. expressing purpose, as often after a verb of going or sending, where the fut. participle might have been used: cp. Hdt. 7.208 e)/pempekata/skopon i(ppe/a, i)de/sqai[ = o)yo/menon] o(ko/soi te/ ei)si, k.t.l.: Thuc. 6.50 de/ka de\ tw=n new=n prou)/pemyan e)s to\n me/gan lime/na pleu=sai/ te kai\ kataske/yasqaikai\ khru=cai. Here the pres. inf. is right, because the act is not single but repeated. Observe how strongly telei=n is supported by the position of the word (“To accomplish, —if night omit aught, —day follows”).
