No version of te/lei explains this. The most tolerable is: —“In fulness— if night omit aught—day attacks(e)pe/rxetai) this”: but I do not think that such a rendering can stand. See Appendix.

ei)a)fh=| Cp. 874 ei) u(perplhsqh=| (lyric): Soph. OC 1443 ei) sterhqw= (dialogue): Soph. Ant. 710 kei)/ tis h)=| (do.). In using ei) with subjunct., the Attic poets were influenced by the epic usage, on which see Monro, Homeric Grammar sect. 292. The instances in classical prose are usu. doubtful, but in Thuc. 6.21 ei) custw=sin has good authority.

e)p'e)/rxetai for the adverbial e)pi/ separated from e)/rxetai, cp. Soph. OC 1777 mhd' e)pi\ plei/w | qrh=non e)gei/rete. This is “tmesis” in the larger sense: tmesis proper is when the prep. is essential to the sense of the verb: Hom. Il. 8.108 ou)/s pot' a)p' *ai)nei/an e(lo/mhn = ou(\s a)feilo/mhn *ai)nei/an: cp. Monro H. G. sect. 176.
to/n = o(/n, sc. *)/area (190). Cp. 1379 n.

*lu/keie Apollo, properly the god of light(luk), whose image, like that of Artemis, was sometimes placed before houses (Soph. El. 637 *foi=be prostath/rie, Aesch. Seven 449 prostathri/as | *)arte/midos), so that the face should catch the first rays of the morning sun(dai/monesa)nth/lioi Aesch. Ag. 519): then, through *lu/keios being explained as lukokto/nos (Soph. El. 7), Apollo the Destroyer of foes: Aesch. Seven 145 *lu/kei' a)/nac, *lu/keios genou= | stratw=| dai/+w|. Cp. below, 919.
a)gkula=n a)gku/lh, a cord brought round on itself, a noose or loop, here = the neura/ of the bent bow. a)gku/lwn, the reading of L and A, was taken by Eustath. 33.3 of the bow (a)/gkula to/ca).

e)ndatei=sqai pass., to be distributed, i.e. showered abroad on the hostile forces. The order of words, and the omission of se/, are against making e)ndat. midd., though elsewhere the pass. occurs only in de/dasmai: Appian, however, has gh=s diadatoume/nhs 1.1. It is possible that Soph. may have had in mind Hom. Il. 18.263 e)n pedi/w|, o(/qi per *trw=es kai\ *)axaioi\ | e)n me/sw| a)mfo/teroi me/nos *)/arhos date/ontai, “share the rage of war,” give and take blows. Others understand, “I would fain celebrate,”a sense of e)ndatei=sqai derived from that of distributing words (lo/gous o)neidisth=ras e)ndatou/menos, Eur. Her. 218). The bad sense occurs in Soph. Trach. 791 to\ duspa/reunon le/ktron e)ndatou/menos: the good, only in Aesch. fr. 340 o( d' e)ndatei=tai ta\s e(a\s eu)paidi/as, “celebrates his happy race of children.”

prostaqe/nta from proi/+sthmi, not prostei/nw. Cp. Soph. Aj. 803 pro/stht' a)nagkai/as tu/xhs. Soph. El. 637 *foi=be prostath/rie. Soph. OT 881 qeo\n ou) lh/cw prosta/tan i)/sxwn. For 1st aor. pass. part., cp. katastaqei/s Lys. 24.9, sustaqei/s Plat. Laws 685c. The conject. prostale/nta (as = “launched”) is improbable (1) because it would mean rather “having set out on a journey”; cp. Soph. OC 20: (2) on account of the metaphor in a)rwga/. prostaqe/nta from prostei/nw (a verb which does not occur) would scarcely mean “directed against the enemy,” but rather “strained against the bowstring.” prostaxqe/nta, found in one MS., would make a)rwga/ prosaic, while prostaqe/nta— if not strictly suitable—is at least poetical: the difference is like that between speaking of “auxiliary forces” and of “champions.”

*)arte/midos ai)/glas the torches with which Artemis was represented, —holding one in each hand (Aristoph. Frogs 1362 dipu/rous a)ne/xousa lampa/das, Soph. Trach. 214 *)/artemin a)mfi/puron), —in her character of *dii+lu/kh, selasfo/ros, fwsfo/ros, a)nqh/lios, —names marking her connection with Selene; cp. Aesch. fr. 164 a)sterwpo\n o)/mma *lhtw/|as ko/rhs.

*lu/ki' o)/rea dia/|ssei as e)lafhbo/los, a)grote/ra, huntress: Hom. Od. 6.102 oi(/h d' *)/artemis ei)=si kat' ou)/reos i)oxe/aira, |terpome/nh ka/proisi kai\ w)kei/h|s e)la/foisin: | th=|de/ q' a(/ma nu/mfai. *lu/kia: the Lycian hills are named here in order to associate Artemis more closely with her brother under his like-sounding name of *lu/keios. At Troezen there was even a temple of *)/artemis *lukei/a: Paus. says (2. 31. 4) that he could not learn why she was so called(e)s de\ th\n e)pi/klhsin ou)de\n ei)=xon puqe/sqai para\ tw=n e)chghtw=n), and suggests that this may have been her title among the Amazons—a guess which touches the true point, viz. that the *lukei/a was a feminine counterpart of the *lu/keios.

to
 xrusomi/tran mi/tra, a snood: Eur. Ba. 831 *d*i. ko/mhn me
 e)pi\ sw=| krati\ tanao
 e)ktenw=. *p*e*n*q*e*u*s. to\ deu/teron de\ sxh=ma tou= ko/smou ti/ moi; *d*i. pe/ploi podh/reis: e)pi\ ka/ra| d' e)/stai mi/tra.

ta=sd' e)pw/numon ga=s As he is *ba/kxos, so is Thebes called *bakxei/a(Soph. Trach. 510), while he, on the other hand, was *kadmei/+as nu/mfas a)/galma (1115). The mutual relation of the names is intended here by e)pw/numon. The word usually means called after (tino/s). But a)/rxwn e)pw/numos, h(/rwes e)pw/numoi were those who gave names to the year, the tribes: and so Soph. Aj. 574(sa/kos) e)pw/numon, the shield which gave its name to Eurysaces. Cp. Eur. Ion 1555 where Athena says, e)pw/numos de\ sh=s a)fiko/mhn xqono/s, giving my name to thy land.

oi)nw=paeu)/ion “ruddy”—“to whom Bacchants cry eu)oi=.” Note how in this passionate ode all bright colours(xruse/as, eu)w=pa, xrusostro/fwn, ai)/glas, xrusomi/tran, oi)nw=pa, a)glaw=pi), and glad sounds(i)h/ie *paia/n, eu)/ion), are contrasted with the baleful fires of pestilence and the shrieks of the dying.

*maina/dwn o(mo/stolon = stello/menon a(/ma tai=s *maina/sin, setting forth, roaming with the Maenads: Apoll. Rhod. 2. 802 o(mo/stolos u(mi
 e(/pesqai. The nymphs attendant on Dionysus, who nursed the infant god in Nysa, and afterwards escorted him in his wanderings, are called *maina/des, quia/des, *ba/kxai. Hom. Il. 6.132 mainome/noio *diwnu/soio tiqh/nas | seu=e kat' h)ga/qeon *nush/ion: ai( d' a(/ma pa=sai | qu/sqla(i.e. thyrsi and torches) xamai\ kate/xeuan. Aesch. fr. 397 pa/ter qe/oine, *maina/dwn zeukth/rie, who bringest the Maenads under thy spell. Hom. Il. 22.460 mega/roio die/ssuto, maina/di i)/sh, | pallome/nh kradi/hn. Catull. 63.23 capita Maenades vi iaciunt hederigerae: as Pind. fr. 224 r(iyau/xeni su
 klo/nw|. Lucian may have had our passage in mind, when he mentions the mi/tra and the Maenads together: Lucian Dial. D. 18 qh=lus ou(/tw,mi/tra| me
 a)nadedeme/nos th
 ko/mhn, ta\ polla\ de\ mainome/nais tai=s gunaici\ sunw/n.

a)glaw=pi A cretic has been lost. G. Wolff's su/mmaxon is simple and appropriate. Arndt's conjecture, dai/+a| (“destroying, consuming,” prob. from rt. dav, to kindle, Curt. Etym. sect. 258), is supported by the possibility of a corruption *d*a*i*d*i having been rejected as a gloss on peu/ka|. Cp. Hom. Il. 9.347 dh/i+on pu=r, Aesch. Seven 222 puri\ dai/+w|. But in connection with the “blithe torch” of Dionysus such an epithet is unsuitable.

to\n a)po/timon See on a)po/cenon196. Ares is “without honour” among the gentler gods: cp. Hom. Il. 5.31 (Apollo speaks), *)=ares, *)/ares brotoloige/, miaifo/ne, teixesiplh=ta: and Hom. Il. 5.890 where Zeus says to Ares, e)/xqisto/s te/ moi e)/ssi qew=n, k.t.l. So the Erinyes are stu/gh qew=n(Aesch. Eum. 644); and the house of Hades is hateful even to the gods (Hom. Il. 20.65).
qeo/n one syll., by synizesis: cp. 1519.

div1.p: First e)peiso/dion. Oedipus re-enters from the palace. He solemnly denounces a curse on the unknown murderer of Laius. The prophet Teiresias declares that the murderer is Oedipus.

div2.p: ai)tei=s Oedipus had entered in time to hear the closing strains of that prayer for aid against the pestilence which the Chorus had been addressing to the gods. a(\ d' ai)tei=s. The place of la/bois is against taking a)lkh\n ka)nakou/fisin kakw=n as in apposition with a)\: rather the construction changes, and a(\ is left as an accus. of general reference. ta)/m' emphatic by place: “you pray (to the gods): hear me and (with their help) you shall have your wish.”

klu/wn not strictly = peiqarxw=n, “obediently” (in which sense klu/ein takes gen., tw=n e)n te/lei, Soph. Aj. 1352), but simply, “on hearing them”: de/xesqai, as Soph. Phil. 1321 kou)/te su/mboulon de/xei. th=| no/sw| u(phretei=n, = qerapeu/ein th\n no/son, to do that which the disease requires (for its cure), like u(phretoi/hn tw=| paro/nti dai/moni Soph. El. 1306. In Eur. fr. 84, 7 ou)d' au)= pe/nesqai ka)cuphretei=n tu/xais | oi(=oi/ te, Nauck now gives with Athenaeus 413 C kai\ cunhretmei=n. Acc. to the commoner use of the word, the phrase would mean to humour the disease, i.e. obey morbid impulses: cp. Lys. 12.23 th=| e(autou= paranomi/a| proqu/mws e)cuphretw=n, eagerly indulging the excess of his own lawlessness.
a)lkh\n as well as a)nakou/fisin, with kakw=n: Hes. WD 199 kakou= d' ou)k e)/ssetai a)lkh/: Eur. Med. 1322 e)/ruma polemi/as xero/s: below 1200 qana/twn .. pu/rgos.

a(gw\ ce/nos me\n. Oedipus has just learned from Creon that Laius was believed to have been murdered by robbers on his way to Delphi, but that, owing to the troubles caused by the Sphinx, no effective search had been made at the time (114-131). He has at once resolved to take up the matter—both because Apollo enjoins it, and as a duty to the Theban throne (255). But the murder occurred before he had come to Thebes. He must therefore appeal for some clue — su/mbolon — to those who were at Thebes when the rumour was fresh.
ce/nos “a stranger” to the affair, is tinged with the notion, “unconnected with Thebes”: and this is brought out by a)sto\s in 222. For other explanations of the passage, see Appendix.

tou= praxqe/ntos the murder. Not, “what was done at the time by way of search”: for (a) to\ praxqe/n, as opp. to o( lo/gos, must mean the e)/rgon to which the lo/gos is related: (b) Oed. has lately expressed his surprise that nothing effective was done (128), and could not, therefore, refer with such emphasis to to\ praxqe/n in this sense.

ou) ga a)
 makra

i)/xneuon In his Syntax of the Moods and Tenses of the Greek Verb (1889), sect. 511, Prof. Goodwin deals with this passage. His view agrees with that given in my second ed., so far as concerns two points, viz.: (1) that the chief protasis is not contained in mh\ ou)k e)/xwn: and (2) that mh\ ou)k e)/xwn is still necessarily conditional. But his analysis of the whole is simpler; it is as follows. The chief protasis is contained in the word au)to/s, “unaided,” which is equivalent to, ei) mo/nos i)/xneuon, if I were attempting to trace it alone. [I had said that au)to/s “implies the protasis”; but had taken the protasis itself to be, ei) mh\ e)cei=pon, supplied from e)cerw=: if I had not thus spoken, —appealing to you for help.] Then, mh\ ou)k e)/xwn is equivalent to ei) mh\ ei)=xon. Now, the difficulty here seemed to be that ei) mh\ ei)=xon would imply, “but I have a clue”: whereas, in fact, he has none. [I met this by suggesting that mh\ ou)k e)/xwn expresses the fact (of his having no clue), not simply as a fact, but as a condition, —“in a case where I had no clue”; being equivalent, not to ei) mh\ ei)=xon, but rather to o(/te mh\ ei)=xon.] Goodwin's answer is that the conditional sentence, written in full, would stand thus, —(1) and (2) denoting respectively the chief protasis, and the subordinate protasis: (1) ei) mo/nos i)/xneuon, ou)k a)
 makra
 i)/xneuon, (2) ei) mh\ ei)=xo/n ti su/mbolon. Now (1) is an unreal supposition (he is not tracking alone); and that makes the whole supposition unreal. ei) mh\ ei)=xon is here a part of that unreal supposition; and therefore it can have that form, although, as a fact, he has no clue. (Suppose it to be said of a man too old for work: “If he were young, he would not be doing well, if he did not work”: ei) ne/os h)=n, ou)k a)
 eu)= e)poi/ei, ei) mh\ e)po/nei. The chief protasis, ei) ne/os h)=n, being unreal, makes all the rest unreal. The fact is, ou) ponei=: and ei) mh\ e)po/nei does not imply, ponei=. Compressed, this would be, ou)k a)
 eu)= e)poi/ei ne/os w)/n, mh\ ou) ponw=n.) au)to/s, unaided: cp. Hom. Il. 13.729 a)ll' ou)/pws a(/ma pa/nta dunh/seai au)to\s e(le/sqai.

nu=n d' “but as it is”: i.e., “since it would be vain to attempt the search alone— since I came to Thebes only after the event.” u(/steros, sc. tou= praxqe/ntos: for the adj. instead of an adv., cp. Soph. Aj. 217 nu/kterosa)pelwbh/qh: Hom. Il. 1.424 xqizo\s e)/bh: Xen. Anab. 1.4.12 toi=s prote/rois (= pro/teron) meta\ *ku/rou a)naba=si. ei)s a)stou\s telw=, inter cives censeor: a metaphor from being rated (for taxation) in a certain class: Hdt. 6.108 ei)s *boiwtou\s tele/ein: Eur. Ba. 822 e)s gunai=kas e)c a)ndro\s telw=. a)sto\s ei)s a)stou\s, like Soph. Aj. 267 koino\s e)n koinoi=si: Eur. Ba. 467 cumpesw\n mo/nos mo/nois: Soph. Phil. 135 e)n ce/na| ce/non: Eur. Ba. 633 i)/sos w)\n i)/sois a)nh/r.

kei) me
 fobei=tai tou)pi/klhm' u(pecelei=n k.t.l. is the reading of all the MSS.: for the u(pecelqw
 of the first hand in one Milan MS. of the early 1t/h cent. (Ambros. L 39 sup., Campbell's M(2)) is a mere slip. I read u(pecelei=n | au)to
 kaq' au(tou=, the change of au)to
 and au)to\s having necessarily followed that of u(pecelei=n into u(pecelw
 due to an interpretation which took the latter with fobei=tai. Cp. Thuc. 4.83 (Arrhibaeus, the enemy of Perdiccas, makes overtures to Brasidas, and the Chalcidians exhort Brasidas to listen): e)di/daskon au)to
 mh\ u(pecelei=n tw=| *perdi/kka| ta\ deina/, “they impressed upon him that he must not remove the dangers from the path of Perdiccas”— by repulsing the rival power of Arrhibaeus. u(pecelei=n ta\ deina/= to take them away (e)k) from under (u(po/) the feet, —from the path immediately before him: tw=| *perdi/kka| being a dat. commodi. Similarly Hdt. 7.8 tou/twnu(pecarairhme/nwn, “when these have been taken out of the way.” So here: kei) me
 fobei=tai, and if he is afraid (as knowing himself to be the culprit), then I bid him (keleu/w continued from 226) u(pecelei=n to\ e)pi/klhma to take the peril of the charge out of his path, au)to
 kaq' au(tou= (shmai/nonta) by speaking against himself. If the culprit is denounced by another person, he will be liable to the extreme penalty. If he denounces himself, he will merely be banished. By denouncing himself, he forestalls the danger of being denounced by another. For other explanations, see Appendix.

a)blabh/s the reading of A and most MSS., “without damage,” a)zh/mios, is far more suitable than a)sfalh/s to this context: and Soph. has the word as a cretic in Soph. El. 650 zw=san a)blabei= bi/w|. Although in L a)sfalh/s appears as the older reading, so common a word was very likely to be intruded; while it would be difficult to explain how the comparatively rare a)blabh/s could have supplanted it. A metrical doubt may have first brought a)sfalh/s in. Dindorf, reading a)sfalh/s, recognises the superior fitness of a)blabh/s here, and thinks that it may be the true reading, even though its appearance in the margin of L was due to conjecture.

a)/llone)c a)/llhs xqono\s “another [i.e. other than one of yourselves, the Thebans] from a strange land”: an alien, whether resident at Thebes, or not: cp. 451 ou(=to/s e)stin e)nqa/de, | ce/nos lo/gw| me/toikos. The cases contemplated in the proclamation (223-235) are (1) a Theban denouncing another Theban, (2) a Theban denouncing himself, (3) a Theban denouncing an alien.

to\
ke/rdos the (expected) gain, ta\ mh/nutra. Soph. Trach. 191 o(/pws | pro\s sou= ti kerda/naimi kai\ ktw/|mhn xa/rin.

proskei/setai will be stored up besides (cp. Eur. Alc. 1039 a)/lgos a)/lgeiproskei/menon, added). xa/ris kei=tai is perf. pass. of xa/rin ti/qemai or katati/qemai (tini/ or para\ tini/), —a metaphor from deposits of money: ta\ xrh/matakei/sqw par' oi(=s tisin a(\n u(mi=n dokh=| Plat. Letter 346c.
fi/lou, au(tou= with a)pw/sei only (Hom. Il. 15.503 a)pw/sasqai kaka\ nhw=n).

fi/lou
dei/sas as = dei/sas u(pe\r fi/lou (like kh/domai, fronti/zein) would be too harsh, and rhythm is against it. tou)/posto/de, this command to give up the guilty.

div3.p:
a)paudw=(a)p-, because the first clauses are negative), I command,(mh/) tina gh=s th=sde that no one belonging to this land, mh/t' e)sde/xesqai mh/te prosfwnei=n shall either entertain or accost, to
 a)/ndra tou=ton, o(/stis e)sti/. For the gen. gh=s, cp. Plat. Prot. 316b *(ippokra/ths o(/de e)sti\ me
 tw=n e)pixwri/wn, *)apollodw/rou ui(o/s, oi)ki/as mega/lhs kai\ eu)dai/monos. Since mh/temh/te in 238 connect e)sde/xesqai and prosfwnei=n, we require either (a) separate verbs for eu)xai=si and qu/masin, or (b) as Elms. proposed, mhde\ instead of mh/te before qu/masin. Cp. Soph. OC 1297, where in a similar, though simpler, sentence I receive Hermann's ou)d' for ou)/t'. Here, however, I hesitate to alter, because the very fact that mh/te has already been thrice used might so easily have prompted its use (instead of mhde/) before qu/masin. As the MS. text stands, we must suppose a mh/te suppressed before eu)xai=si, the constr. being mh/te koino
 poiei=sqai[mh/te] e)neu)xai=si mh/te qu/masin. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 532 *pa/ris ga ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis: Aesch. Lib. 294 de/xesqai d' ou)/te sullu/ein tina/.

div2.p:
koino
 here = koinwno/n, cp. Soph. Aj. 267 h)= koino\s e)n koinoi=si lupei=sqai cunw/n. Plat. Laws 868e (the slayer) cune/stios au)toi=s mhde/pote gigne/sqw mhde\ koinwno\s i(erw=n. xe/rnibos (partitive gen.) is more suitable than xe/rnibas to the idea of exclusion from all fellowship in ordinary worship: xe/rnibas ne/mein would rather suggest a special ka/qarsis of the homicide. When sacrifice was offered by the members of a household(koinwno
 ei(=nai xerni/bwnkthsi/ou bwmou= pe/las Aesch. Ag. 1037) or of a clan(xe/rniy frate/rwn Aesch. Eum. 656), a brand taken from the altar was dipped in water, and with the water thus consecrated(xe/rniy) the company and the altar were sprinkled: then holy silence was enjoined(eu)fhmi/a e)/stw): and the rite began by the strewing of barley meal(ou)loxu/tai) on altar and victim. (Athen. 409: Eur. Her. 922 ff.) Acc. to Dem. 20.158 a law of Draco prescribed xe/rnibos [so the best MSS.: v. l. xerni/bwn] ei)/rgesqai to
 a)ndrofo/non, spondw=n, krath/rwn, i(erw=n, a)gora=s. This was a sentence of excommunication (1) from the life of the family and the clan, (2) from the worship common to all Hellenes, who, as opposed to ba/rbaroi, are (Aristoph. Lys. 1129) oi(\ mia=s e)k xe/rnibos | bwmou\s perirrai/nontes, w(/sper cuggenei=s, | *)olumpi/asin, e)n *pu/lais, *puqoi=. The mere presence of the guilty could render sacrifice inauspicious: Antiph. 5.82 i(eroi=s parasta/ntes polloi\ dh\ katafanei=s e)ge/nonto ou)x o(/sioi o)/ntes kai\ diakwlu/ontes ta\ i(era\ mh\ gi/gnesqai (bene succedere) ta\ nomizo/mena.
w)qei=n de\ sc. au)dw=, understood from the negative a)paudw=: cp. Hdt. 7.104 ou)k e)w=n feu/geina)lla\ e)pikrate/ein.
These six verses are placed by some editors between 272 and 273. See Appendix.

kateu/xomai Suidas kateu/xesqai: to\ katara=sqai. ou(/tw *pla/twn. kai\ *sofoklh=s, kateu/xomai de\ to\n dedrako/ta ta/de. Phot. Lex. p. 148. 7 kateu/xesqai tw=n *)axaiw=n: a)nti\ tou= kata\ tw=n *)axaiw=n eu)/xesqai. ou(/tws *sofoklh=s. Here the ref. is to Plato Plat. Rep. 393e to\n de\ (the Homeric Chryses, priest of Apollo) kateu/xesqai tw=n *)axaiw=n pro\s qeo/n. But Photius prefixes the words, kateu/xesqai: to\ katara=sqai. ou(/tws *pla/twn. It is clear, then, that in Photius ou(/tws *sofoklh=s and ou(/tws *pla/twn have changed places. The “Soph. fr. 894,” quoted by Lidd. and Scott under kateu/xomai as= imprecari, thus vanishes (Nauck Fragm. Trag. (2) p. 357). Cp. Aesch. Seven 632 po/lei | oi(/as a)ra=tai kai\ kateu/xetai tu/xas. But where, as here kateu/xomai is used without gen. (or dat.), it is rather to pray solemnly: often, however, in a context which implies imprecation: e.g. Plat. Laws 935a kateu/xesqai a)llh/lois e)parwme/nous: Plat. Rep. 394a kateu/xeto ti=sai tou\s *)axaiou\s ta\ a)\ da/krua. ei)/te tis: whether the unknown man (tis) who has escaped discovery is ei(=s, alone in the crime, or one of several. tis, because the person is indefinite: cp. 107.

nin a)/moron Porson (praef. Hec. p. ix.) defends the redundant nin by Soph. Trach. 287 au)to
 d' e)kei=non, eu)=t' a)
 a(gna\ qu/mata | r(e/ch| patrw/|w| *zhni\ th=s a(lw/sews, | fro/nei nin w(s h(/conta. The form a)/moros occurs in Eur. Med. 1395 (where a)/moiros is a v. l.); a)/mmoros in Eur. Hec. 421, Soph. Phil. 182. kako
 kakw=s: Soph. Phil. 1369 e)/a kakw=s au)tou\s a)po/llusqai kakou/s. Aristoph. Pl. 65 a)po/ s' o)lw= kako
 kakw=s.

e)peu/xomai imprecate on myself: Plat. Criti. 120b tau=ta e)peuca/menos e(/kastos au)tw=n au(tw=| kai\ tw=| a)f' au(tou= ge/nei. oi)/koisincune/stios: not tautological, since cune/stios is more than e)/noikos, implying admission to the family worship at the e(sti/a and to the spondai/ at meals. Plat. Laws 868e i(erw=n mh\ koinwnei/tw mhde\cune/stios au)toi=s mhde/pote gigne/sqw mhde\ koinwno\s i(erw=n. Plat. Euthyph. 4b kai\ ei) me\n e)n di/kh| [e)/kteinen], e)a=n, if he slew the man justly, forbear; ei) de\ mh/, e)pecie/nai (prosecute the slayer), e)a/nper o( ktei/nas sune/stio/s soi kai\ o(motra/pezos h)=|. i)/son ga\r to\ mi/asma gi/gnetai, e)a\n cunh=|s tw=| toiou/tw| cuneidw\s kai\ mh\ a)fosioi=s seauto/n te kai\ e)kei=non th=| di/kh| e)peciw/n.
toi=sd' the slayer or slayers (247): see on 246.
a)ka/rpws ka)qe/ws Soph. El. 1181 w)= sw=m' a)ti/mws ka)qe/ws e)fqarme/non: below 661 a)/qeos, a)/filos, forsaken by gods and men.

ei)ko\s h)=n The imperfect indic. of a verb denoting obligation(e)/dei, xrh=n, prosh=ken, ei)ko\s h)=n), when joined without a)/n to an infinitive, often implies a conditional sentence with imperfect indic. in protasis and apodosis: e.g. ou)k ei)ko\s h)=n e)a=n = ou)k a)
 ei)a=te (ei) ta\ de/onta e)poiei=te), you would not (now) be neglecting it (if you did your duty): Xen. Mem. 2.7.10 ei) me
 toi/nun ai)sxro/n ti e)/mellon e)rga/sesqai [if I were now intending—as I am not], qa/naton a)nt' au)tou= proairete/on h)=n, = proh|rou/mhn a)
 (ei) ta\ de/onta e)poi/oun). Thuc. 6.78 kai\ ma/lista ei)ko\s h)=n u(ma=sproora=sqai, = proewra=te a)
 ei) ta\ ei)ko/ta e)poiei=te. So e)boulo/mhn, h)ci/oun, without a)/n, of that which one wishes were true, but which is not so.
ou(/tws in this (careless) manner: cp. Soph. OC 1278 w(s mh/ m' a)/timon| ou(/tws a)fh=| me: Soph. Ant. 315, Soph. Phil. 1067.

basile/ws t' te is to be retained after basile/ws, because (1) there is a climax, which is destroyed if basile/ws stands merely in apposition with a)ndro\s a)ri/stou: (2) a)ndro\s a)ri/stou represents the claim of birth and personal merit, as basile/ws represents the special claim of a king on his people. Cp. Soph. Phil. 1302 a)/ndra pole/mion | e)xqro/n te.
kurw= t' e)gw\ = e)gw/ te kurw=, answered by koinw=n te, k.t.l. For te so placed cp. Soph. El. 249 e)/rroi t' a)\n ai)dw\s | a(pa/ntwn t' eu)se/beia qnatw=n.

o(mo/sporon = o(moi/ws speirome/nhn, i. e. h(
 kai\ e)kei=nos e)/speire: but in 460 patro\s | o(mo/sporos = o)moi/ws (th
 au)th
) spei/rwn. o(mogenh/s in 1361 is not similar.

koinw=n pai/dwn koina\ h)=n a)
 e)kpefuko/ta common things of ( = ties consisting in) kindred children would have been generated: = koinw=n pai/dwn koinh\ fu/sis e)ge/neto a)/n, a brood, common to Laius and Oedipus, of children akin to each other (as having the same mother, Iocasta) would have issued: “children born of one mother would have made ties between him and me.” For a)/n doubled cp. 139, 339. koinw=n = a)delfw=n, o(mai/mwn(Soph. Ant. 1 w)= koino
 au)ta/delfon *)ismh/nhs ka/ra). The language of this passage is carefully framed so as to bear a second meaning, of which the speaker is unconscious, but which the spectators can feel: Iocasta has actually borne children to her own son Oedipus: thus in koinw=n pai/dwn koina\e)kpefuko/ta, the obvious sense of koina/, “common to Laius and Oedipus,” has behind it a second sense, in which it hints at a brood who are brothers and sisters of their own sire: see below 1403 f. This subtle emphasis—so ghastly, cunetoi=sin— of the iteration in koinw=n koina/ must not be obliterated by amending koi/n' a)/n into ku/mat' (Nauck) or spe/rmat' (Blaydes). Similarly, ei) kei/nw| ge/nos | mh\ dustu/xhsen, is susceptible of the sense—“if his son (Oed. himself) had not been ill-fated.” kei/nw| ge/nos e)dustu/xhse (his hope of issue was disappointed) is here a bold phrase for kei=nos e)dustu/xhse ta\ peri\ ge/nos: for Oed. is not now supposed to know the story of the exposed babe (see 717 f.). Cp. Eur. Andr. 418 pa=si d' a)nqrw/pois a)/r' h)=n | yuxh\ te/kn': o(/stis d' au)/t' a)/peiros w)
 ye/gei, | h)=sson me
 a)lgei=, dustuxw=n d' eu)daimonei=: Eur. Andr. 711 h(\ stei=ros ou)=sa mo/sxos ou)k a)ne/cetai | ti/ktontas a)/llous, ou)k e)/xous' au)th\ te/kna: | a)ll' ei) to\ kei/nhs dustuxei= pai/dwn pe/ri, k.t.l.: Eur. Supp. 66 eu)tekni/a opp. to dustuxi/a.

nu=n d' “but as it is,” with aor. equivalent to a perf., as Soph. OC 84, 371. Cp. below 948 kai\ nu=n o(/de | pro\s th=s tu/xhs o)/lwle. So with historic pres., Lys. 12.36 ei) me
 ou)=n e)n tw=| dikasthri/w| e)kri/nonto, r(a|di/ws a)
 e)sw/zonto:nu=n d' ei)s th
 boulh
 ei)sa/gousin.

e)nh/lato i.e. he was cut off by a timeless fate, leaving no issue, cp. 1300: Soph. Ant. 1345 e)pi\ krati/ moi | po/tmosei)sh/lato: so the Erinyes say, ma/la ga\r ou)=n a(lome/na | a)ne/kaqen bapuresh= | katafe/pw rodo\s a)kma/n Aesch. Eum. 369, Aesch. Ag. 1175 dai/mwn u(perbarh\s e)mpi/tnwn: Aesch. Pers. 515 w)= duspo/nhte dai=mon, w(s a)/gan baru\s | podoi=n e)nh/llou panti\ *persikw=| ge/nei. The classical constr. with e)na/llomai, as with e)nqrw/skw and e)mphda/w, is usually the dat., though ei)s with accus. occurs in later Greek; a point urged by Deventer in his objections to this verse, which is, however, clearly sound.

a)nq' w(=n properly wherefore (Soph. OC 1295): here, therefore. The protasis e)pei\ kurw= (258) required an apodosis introduced by a)nti\ tou/twn: but the parenthesis nu=n d' e)s to\ kei/nou k.t.l. (263) has led to w)=n being irregularly substituted for tou)twn. Cp. 1466: Antiphon 5.11 de/on se diomo/sasqai k.t.l.a(\ su\ parelqw/n, where the length of the protasis has similarly caused a(/ to be substituted for tau=ta. Distinguish from this the use of a)nq' w(=n, by ordinary attraction, for a)nti\ tou/twn a(/ or o(/ti,= because, Soph. Ant. 1068.

ta/d' cogn. acc. to u(permaxou=mai as Soph. Aj. 1346 su\ tau=t' *)odusseu= tou=d' u(permaxei=s e)moi/; Cp. Hom. Il. 5.185 ou)x o(/ g' a)/neuqe qeou= ta/de mai/netai. Brunck, Nauck and Blaydes adopt Mudge's conj. tou=d'. But the MSS. agree in the harder and more elegant reading.

u(permaxou=mai only here: in Soph. Ant. 194, Soph. Aj. 1346 Soph. uses u(permaxei=n. But we need not therefore, with Elms. and Blaydes, read u(pe\r maxou=mai. The derivative form u(permaxe/w, to be a champion, implies u(pe/rmaxos, as summaxe/w is from su/mmaxos, promaxe/w from pro/maxos: u(perma/xomai is a simple compound, like summa/xomai (Plat., Xen.), proma/xomai (Iliad, Dio. Sic., Plut.).

ka)pi\ pa/nt' a)fi/comai with zhtw=n, will leave nothing untried in seeking: a poetical variation of e)pi\ pa=n e)lqei=n (Xen. Anab. 3.1.18 a)=r' ou)k a)\n e)pi\ pa=n e)/lqoiw(s fo/bon para/sxoi), as in Eur. Hipp. 284 ei)s pa/nt' a)fi=gmai, “I have tried all means.” In prose a)fiknei=sqai ei)/s ti usu. = to be brought to a situation, as Hdt. 8.110 e)s pa=san ba/sanon a)pikneome/noisi, though put to any torment; Plat. Euthyd. 292e ei)s pollh/n ge a)pori/an a)fi/kesqe.

tw=| *labdakei/w| paidi\ a dat. following zhtw=n k.t.l. as = timwrou/menos. For *labdakei/w|—*poludw/rou te cp. Eur. Med. 404 toi=s *sisufei/ois toi=s t' *)ia/sonos ga/mois: for the adj., Hom. Od. 3.190 *filokth/thn *poia/ntion [= *poi/antos] a)glao
 ui(o/n: Hdt. 7.105 toi=s *maskamei/oisi e)kgo/noisi: Soph. Phil. 1131: Soph. Trach. 1219. Herodotus (Hdt. 5.59) saw in the temple of the Ismenian Apollo at Thebes an inscription which he assigns to the age of Laius: tau=ta h(liki/hn a)
 ei)/h kata\ *la/i+on to
 *labda/kou tou= *poludw/rou tou= *ka/dmou. Cadmus, in the myth, is the son of Agenor king of Phoenicia, whence Carthage is “Agenor's city” (Verg. Aen. 1.338): Polydorus, son of Cadmus and Harmonia, was king of Thebes.

construe: kai\ eu)/xomai toi=s tau=ta mh\ drw=sin [for them, Soph. Phil. 1019 kai/ soi polla/kis to/d' hu)camhn] qeou\s a)nie/nai au)toi=s mh/t' a)/roto/n tina gh=s, mh/t' ou)=n gunaikw=n pai=das. The acc. qeou\s as subject to a)nie/nai is better than a dat. qeoi=s with eu)/xomai would be: Xen. Anab. 6.1.26 eu)/xomai dou=nai/ moi tou\s qeou\s ai)/tio/n tinos u(mi=n a)gaqou= gene/sqai: Aristoph. Thes. 350 tai=s d' a)/llaisin u(mi=n tou\s qeou\s | eu)/xesqe pa/sais polla\ dou=nai ka)gaqa/.

mh/t' ou)=n “no, nor.” Aesch. Ag. 474 mh/t' ei)/hn ptolipo/rqhs, | mh/t' ou)=n au)to\s a(lou/s, k.t.l. Soph. Phil. 345 ei)/t' a)lhqe\s ei)/t' a)/r' ou)=n ma/thn: cp. above v. 90. But ou)=n with the first clause, below, 1049: Soph. El. 199, 560: see on 25.

fqerei=sqai a fut. found also in Eur. Andr. 708(fqerei= 2 sing.): Thuc. 7.48 fqerei=sqai: Ionic fqare/omai: Hdt. 9.42, 8. 108(fqarh/somai in Hippocr., Arist., Plut.). The schol. says, fqarh=nai dei= gra/fein, ou) fqerei=sqai, distinguishing eu)/xomai with fut. infin., “I vow” (to do), from eu)/xomai with pres. or aor. infin., “I pray.” But verbs of wishing or praying sometimes take a fut. infin. instead of pres. or aor.: Thuc. 6.57 e)bou/lontoprotimwrh/sesqai: 6. 6 e)fie/menoi me\nth=s pa/shs a)/rcein: 1. 27 e)deh/qhsancumprope/myein: 7. 56 dienoou=nto klh/|sein. See Goodwin, Moods and Tenses sect. 113 (new ed.).
toi=s a)/lloisi The loyal, as opp. to oi( mh\ tau=ta drw=ntes (269).

e)/st' a)re/skont' cp. 126. h(/ te su/mmaxos *di/kh, Justice who ever helps the righteous cause; Blaydes needlessly writes h( *di/kh te su/mmaxos. Soph. OC 1012 e)lqei=n a)rwgou\s summa/xous te (ta\s qea/s).
eu)= cf. Soph. Trach. 229 a)ll' eu)= me\n i(/gmeq', eu)= de\ prosfwnou/meqa.

w(/sper m' a)rai=on k.t.l. As you have brought me into your power under a curse [if I speak not the truth], so (w(=de, i.e. e)/norkos) I will speak. Aeschin. 3.90 mi/an e)lpi/da loiph
 katei=de swthri/as, e)/norkon labei=n to
 *)aqhnai/wn dh=monbohqh/sein, to bind them by an oath that they would help. labei=n here has nearly the same force as in labei=n ai)xma/lwton etc.: Lys. 4.5 u(poxei/rion labw
 to\ sw=ma, having got his person into my power.

a)rai=on = th=| a)ra=| e)/noxon, cp. o(/rkiosle/gw Soph. Ant. 305. The paraphrase of Eustath. 1809. 14 w(/sper me ei)=les dia\ th=s a)ra=s is substantially right. The use of katalabei=n is not really similar (Hdt. 9.106 pi/sti te katalabo/ntes kai\ o(rki/oisi, Thuc. 4.85 o(/rkoiskatalabw\n ta\ te/lh), since the kata/ in comp. gives the sense of overtaking, and so of binding. Nor can we compare Soph. OC 284 w(/sper e)/labes to\n i(ke/thn e)xe/gguon, where the sense is, “As thou hast received the (self-surrendered) suppliant under thy pledge.”
ga\r after e)/ktanon merely prefaces the statement: Plat. Prot. 320c dokei= toi/nunmu=qon u(mi=n le/gein. h)=n ga/r pote k.t.l.

dei=cai “point to.” Note the emphatic place of the word: the speaker knows not that he is face to face with the slayer. to\ zh/thma, acc. of general reference. The simpler form would have been, h)=n tou= pe/myantos to\ zh/thma kai\ lu=sai: but, instead of a verb which could govern zh/thma, to/d' ei)pei=n is substituted, because it conveniently introduces the clause o(/stis ei)/rgastai, explaining what the zh/thma itself was. to\ zh/thma is then left much as a(\ ai)tei=s is left in 216 when the insertion of a)lkh\n k.t.l. has modified the construction.

a(
 mh\ qe/lwsin k.t.l. Cp. Soph. Phil. 1368 ka)/m' a)nagka/zeis to/de. a(
 as 580, 749: Soph. OC 13, Soph. Ant. 1057, Soph. Phil. 1276, Soph. Aj. 1085. ou)d' a)
 ei(=s: Soph. Ant. 884 ou)d' a)
 ei(=s pau/sait' a)/n: Soph. OC 1656 ou)d' a)
 ei(=s | qnhtw=n fra/seie. In this emphatic form even a prep. could be inserted (Xen. Hell. 5.4.1 ou)d' u(f' e(no/s, Xen. Cyrop. 4.1.14 mhde\ pro\s mi/an), and in prose ou)de\ ei(=s stood without elision: in Aristoph. Frogs 927 etc., where the MSS. have ou)de\ e(/n (Dind. writes ou)dee
), ou)d' a)
 e(/n is a possible v. l.

e)k tw=nde = meta\ ta/de: Dem. 18.313 lo/gon e)k lo/gou le/gwn. —For deu/tera, second-best, cp. the proverb deu/teros plou=s: Plat. Laws 943c th\n tw=n a)ristei/wn kri/sinkai\ th\n tw=n deute/rwn kai\ tri/twn.
a)\n le/goimi see on 95.

to\ mh\ ou) not to\ mh/, because the sentence is negative: below, 1232: Soph. Ant. 544 mh/ m' a)tima/sh|s to\ mh\ ou) | qanei=n. But even in such a negative sentence the simple to\ mh/ occurs: below, 1388: Soph. Ant. 443.

tau)ta\ o(rw=nta not = tau)ta\ fronou=nta or gignw/skonta, “taking the same views,” but seeing in the same manner, i.e. with equal clearness: o(rw=nta absol., as Soph. OC 74 o(/s' a)\n le/goimi, pa/nq' o(rw=nta le/comai: tau)ta\ adverbial = kata\ tau)ta/: the dat. a)/nakt' as Soph. OC 1358 e)n po/nw| | tau)tw=| bebhkw\se)moi/. Hdt. 4.119 twu)to\ a)\n u(mi=n e)prh/ssomen.

ou)k e)n a)rgoi=s tou=to kate/lipon would have meant, “I did not leave this among things neglected.” Soph. fuses the negative form with the positive, and instead of kate/lipon writes e)praca/mhn: “I saw to this (midd.) in such a manner that it also should not be among things neglected.” pra/ssesqai (midd.) elsewhere usu. = “to exact” (Thuc. 4.65 etc.): here = diapra/ssesqai, effect for oneself. Cp. Soph. Aj. 45 e)cepra/cato (effected his purpose). G. Wolff, sharing Kviecpala's objections to the phrase e)n a)rgoi=s pra/ssesqai, places a point after tou=t' (“but neither is this among things neglected: —I did it”). The extreme harshness of the asyndeton condemns this; and the suggested e)/praca mh/n is no remedy. For e)n cp. ou)k e)n e)lafrw=| e)poieu/mhn (Hdt. 1.118), e)n eu)xerei= | e)/qou (tau=ta) Soph. Phil. 875, tau=t' ou)=n e)n ai)sxrw=| qe/menos Eur. Hec. 806. a)rgoi=s, not things undone, but things at which the work is sluggish or tardy; Soph. OC 1605 kou)k h)=n e)/t' ou)de
 a)rgo
 w(=n e)fi/eto: Eur. Phoen. 776 e(
 d' e)sti
 h(mi=n a)rgo/n, ei)/ ti qe/sfaton | oi)wno/mantis *teiresi/as e)/xei fra/sai, i.e. “in one thing our zeal has lagged, —the quest whether” etc.: Theognis however (583 Bergk 3rd ed.) has ta\ me
 probe/bhken a)mh/xano/n e)sti gene/sqai | a)rga/, = a)poi/hta, infecta.

diplou=s | pompou/s he had sent two successive messages—one messenger with each. pompo/s = one who is sent to escort(pe/mpein) or fetch a person (Soph. OC 70). The words could mean (as Ellendt takes them) “two sets of messengers”: but the other view is simpler, and consists equally well with oi(/de in 297.

mh\ parw\n qauma/zetai = qauma/zw ei) mh\ pa/resti; but with ou), = qauma/zw o(/ti ou) pa/resti: differing nearly as “I wonder why”and “I wonder that.”Xen. Anab. 4.4.15 (he spoke of) ta\ mh\ o)/nta w(s ou)k o)/nta: i.e. ei)/ ti mh\ h)=n, e)/legen o(/ti ou)k h)=n.

ta/ g' a)/llae)/ph the rumours which were current —apart from the knowledge which the seer may have to give us. Not “the other rumours.” Cp. Plat. Phaedo 110e kai\ li/qois kai\ gh=| kai\ toi=s a)/llois zw/|ois te kai\ futoi=s. kwfa\: the rumour has died down; it no longer gives a clear sound. Cp. fr. 604 lh/qhn te th\n a(/pant' a)pesterhme/nhn, | kwfh/n, a)/naudon. Soph. Aj. 911 o( pa/nta kwfo/s, o( pa/nt' a)/i+dris, reft of all sense and wit.
ta\ poi=a cp. 120.

o(doipo/rwn the survivor had spoken of lh|stai/, 122. The word now used comes nearer to the truth (cp. 801 o(doiporw=n); but, as the next v. shows, Oed. does not regard this rumour as a different one from that which Creon had mentioned.

to\n d' i)do/nt' the surviving eyewitness: cp. 119 w)=n ei)=de, plh\n e(/n k.t.l. Oed. has not yet learned that this witness could be produced: cp. vv. 754 ff. i)do/nta is better than the conj. drw=nta (1) as expressing, not merely that the culprit is unknown, but that no eyewitness of the deed is now at hand: (2) because, with o(ra=|, it has a certain ironical point, —expressing the king's incredulity as to anything being made of this clue. Cp. 105, 108.

The subject to e)/xei is the murderer, who is foremost in the thoughts of the Chorus, —not the eye-witness(o( i)dw/n, 293). The reversion from plural(o(doipo/rwn, 292) to singular is unconscious, just as in 124 we have o( lh|sth/s, after lh|sta/s in 122.

dei/mato/s g' dei=ma, prop. “an object of fear,” is used by Herodotus and the poets as = de/os: Hdt. 6.74 *kleome/neadei=ma e)/labe *spartihte/wn: Aesch. Supp. 566 xlwrw=| dei/mati qumo\n | pa/llont': Eur. Supp. 599 w(/s moi u(f' h(/pati dei=ma xloero\n tara/ssei: id. Soph. El. 767 e)k dei/matos, from fear. Cp. above, 153. The ge gives emphasis: the a)rai/ of Oed. were enough to scare the boldest. Hartung conjectures deima/twn e)/xei me/ros. The plur. dei/mata means either (a) objects of fear, or (b) much more rarely, fears, with reference to some particular objects already specified: as in Soph. El. 636 deima/twn a(\ nu=n e)/xw, “the terrors which I now suffer,” alluding to the dreams. Here we seem to need the sing., “fear.”
ta\s sa\sa)ra/s thy curses: toia/sde, being such as they are.

ou(cele/gcwn The present ou(cele/gxwn would mean, “there is one who convicts him”: i.e. the supposed criminal, whom threats scare not, is already detected; for the prophet has come. Cp. Isoc. 8.139 w(/st' ou)k a)porh/somen meq' w(=n kwlu/somen tou\s e)camarta/nontas, a)lla\ pollou\s e(/comen tou\s e(toi/mws kai\ proqu/mws sunagwnizome/nous h(mi=n: where, however, the present part. sunagwnizome/nous is relative to the future e(/comen. To this it may be objected: (1) the present participle with e)/stin would not be suitable unless the conviction were in act of taking place: (2) the fut. partic. not only suits the context better—“one to convict him” [supposing he is here]—but also agrees with the regular idiom: e.g. Soph. Phil. 1242 ti/s e(/stai m' ou(pikwlu/swn ta/de; Soph. El. 1197 ou)d' ou(parh/cwn ou)d' o( kwlu/swn pa/ra; (cp. Soph. Ant. 261:) Aesch. PB 27 o( lwfh/swn ga\r ou) pe/fuke/ pw: Xen. Anab. 2.4.5 o( h(ghso/menos ou)dei\s e)/stai.
w(=| this pron. ends a v. Soph. OC 14, Soph. Trach. 819, Soph. El. 873.
e)mpe/fuken a divine gift of prophecy: Hdt. 9.94 (of the seer Evenius) kai\ meta\ tau=ta au)ti/ka e)/mfuton mantikh\n ei)=xe.

a)nqrw/pwn mo/nw| above all other men: cp. Soph. OC 261 mo/nas| sw/zein oi(/as te k.t.l., Athens, above all other cities, can save: Isoc. 14.57 o)fei/lete de\ mo/noi tw=n *(ellh/nwn tou=ton to\n e)/ranon, unice (though others owe it also).

w)= pa/nta nwmw=n nwma/w (nem) means (1) to distribute, (2) to dispose, and so to wield, ply, (3) figuratively, to ponder, animo versare: e)ni\ fresi\ ke/rde' e)nw/mas Hom. Od. 18.216: e)n w)si\ nwmw=n kai\ fresi\n puro\s di/xa | xrhsthri/ous o)/rniqas a)yeudei= te/xnh| Aesch. Seven 25 (of Teiresias): (4) then, absolutely, to observe: Hdt. 4.128 nwmw=ntessi=ta a)naireome/nous, observing the moment when they were cutting forage. Similarly here, —with the idea of mental grasp unaided by eyesight. Plato (Plat. Crat. 411d) fancifully connects gnw/mh with nw/mhsis, —to\ ga\r nwma=n kai\ to\ skopei=n tau)to/n.
didakta/ te—a)/rrhta/ te cp. the colloquial r(hto\n a)/rrhto/n t' e)/pos(Soph. OC 1001 dicenda tacenda): a)/rrhta = a)po/rrhta: Hdt. 6.135 a)/rrhta i(ra\ e)kfh/nasan.

ou)ra/nia/ te kai\ xqonostibh= not in apposition with a)/rrhta and didakta/ respectively, but both referring to each, lore that may or that may not be told, whether of the sky or of the earth. Dindorf cp. Nicephorus Gregoras Hist. Byz. 695d a)/ktista gene/sqai pa/nta ta/ t' ou)ra/nia ta/ te xqonostibh= kai\ u(drai=a ge/nh: where, however, xqonostibh= has its literal sense, —“walking the earth”: here it is poet. for e)pi/geia, “the lowly things of earth.” Cp. HH 29.2 a)qana/twn te qew=n xamai\ e)rxome/nwn t' a)nqrw/pwn.

me/n is not balanced by fronei=s d' (as if we had ou) ble/peis me/n), but by the thought of the expected healer (310). The de\ after fronei=s introduces the apodosis after a concessive protasis, as Hdt. 8.22 ei) de\ u(mi=n e)sti tou=to mh\ dunato\n poih=sai, u(me/es de\(then) e)/ti kai\ nu=n e)k tou= me/sou h(mi=n e(/zesqe. Xen. Cyrop. 5.5.21 a)ll' ei) mhde\ tou=tobou/lei a)pokri/nasqai, su\ de\ tou)teu=nqen le/ge.

h(=s sc. no/sou. prosta/thn no/sou, a protector from a plague: strictly, one who stands in front of, shields, the city's distempered state. Cp. Soph. Aj. 803 pro/stht' a)nagkai/as tu/xhs, shelter my hard fate. In Eur. Andr. 220 xei/ron' a)rse/nwn no/son | tau/thn nosou=men, a)lla\ prou)/sthmen kalw=s, “we suffer this distemper more cruelly than men, but ever rule it well,” the idea is that of administering (not protecting), as in proi/+stasqai th=s h(liki/as, to regulate one's own early years, Isoc. 15.290. Cp. 882.

mou=non this Ionic form (like kou=ros, douri/, cei=nos, gou/nata) is used in dialogue by Soph.: Aesch. has not mou=nos, though in Aesch. PB 804 to/n te mounw=pa strato/n. In Eur. Rh. 31 mo/narxoi is now restored for mou/narxoi.

ei) kai\ mh\ klu/eis “if indeed,”implying that he probably has heard it. Soph. Aj. 1127 deino/n g' ei)=pas, ei) kai\ zh=|s qanw/n. On ei) kai/ and kai\ ei) see Appendix. Others would render, “if you have not heard from the messengers also,”supposing it to be a hyperbaton for ei) mh\ klu/eis kai\ tw=n a)gge/lwn. This is impossible. Prof. Campbell compares Thuc. 5.45 kai\ h)
 e)s to
 dh=mon tau=ta le/gwsin, as if put for h)
 kai\ e)s to
 dh=mon: but there the passage runs thus; (Spartan envoys had been pleading with effect before the Athenian *boulh/:) —to
 *)alkibia/dhn e)fo/boun mh\ kai/, h)
 e)s to
 dh=mon tau)ta\ le/gwsin, e)paga/gwntai to\ plh=qos kai\ a)pwsqh=| h( *)argei/wn summaxi/a: where the kai/ before h)/n goes with e)paga/gwntai. Some adopt the conj. ei)/ ti mh/, “unless perchance”: for ti so used, see below 969, Soph. OC 1450, Soph. Trach. 586, 712: but no change is required. —For the pres. klu/eis, cp. Soph. Phil. 261.

maqo/ntes eu)= eu)= = “with care,” “aright”: cp. Soph. Aj. 18 e)pe/gnws eu)=: Soph. Aj. 528 e)a\n to\ taxqe\n eu)= tolma=| telei=n. Meineke's conj. h)\, adopted by Nauck, is weak, and against the rhythm.
a)p' oi)wnw=n fa/tin for a)po/, see 43: fa/tin, 151.
a)/llhn o(do/n as divination by fire (see on 21), to which Teiresias resorts (Soph. Ant. 1005) when the voice of birds fails him.

r(u=sai seauto\n k.t.l. r(u/esqai/ ti is to draw a thing to oneself, and so to protect it. r(u=sai mi/asma here = literally, “take the defilement under thy care”; i.e. “make it thy care to remove the defilement.” Cp. pro/stht' a)nagkai/as tu/xhs (Soph. Aj. 803), shelter my hard fate, (instead of, “shelter me from it.”)
pa=n mi/asma the whole defilement, as affecting not only human life but also the herds and flocks and the fruits of the earth: cp. 253.

tou= teqnhko/tos gen. of the source from which the mi/asma springs, —more pathetic than tou= fo/nou, as reminding the hearer that vengeance is due for innocent blood. Both pa=n and the usual sense of mi/asma forbid us to understand, “avenge the uncleanness [i.e. the unpunished murder] of the dead man.” For r(u=sai de\ Blaydes conj. lu=son de\, comparing Eur. Orest. 598 mi/asma lu=sai. But the triple r(u=sai is essential to the force.
e)n soi\ = penes te: Soph. OC 248 e)n u(mi=n w(s qew=| | kei/meqa tla/mones: Eur. Alc. 278 e)n soi\ d' e)sme\n kai\ zh=n kai\ mh/.

a)/ndra accus. before, not after, w)felei=n, as in Soph. Ant. 710 a)ll' a)/ndra, kei)/ tis h)=| sofo/s, to\ manqa/nein | po/ll' ai)sxro
 ou)de/n. In both places a)/ndra has a certain stress—“for mortal man.” But in Soph. Aj. 1344 a)/ndra d' ou) di/kaion, ei) qa/noi, | bla/ptein to
 e)sqlo/n, a)/ndra is the object, agreeing with to
 e)sqlo/n. a)f' w)=n e)/xoi te kai\ du/naito, by means of all his resources and faculties. The optat. is thus used in universal statements, and therefore especially in gnw=mai: cp. 979: Soph. Ant. 666 a)ll' o(
 po/lis sth/seie, tou=de xrh\ klu/ein: Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19 a)lla\ tou= me
 au)to
 le/gein, a(\ mh\ safw=s ei)dei/h, fei/desqai dei=. So here we supply e)sti/ (not a)
 ei)/h) with ka/llistos. The difference between a)f' w(=n a)
 e)/xh| (“may have”), and e)/xoi (“might have”), is that the latter form treats the “having” as an abstract hypothesis(ei)/ ti e)/xoi).

lu/h| for subjunct. without a)/n, cf. Soph. OC 395 o(\s ne/os pe/sh|: Soph. Aj. 1074 e)/nqa mh\ kaqesth/kh| de/os: Soph. Trach. 1008 o(/ ti kai\ mu/sh|. The subjunct., e)/nqa mh\ lu/h|,= “in a case where it may not profit”: the indic., e)/nqa mh\ lu/ei, = “in a case where it does not profit.” The use of mh/, whether with subjunct. or with indic., generalises the statement. Cp. Soph. OC 839 mh\ pi/tass' a(\ mh\ kratei=s: Soph. OC 1442 mh\ pei=q' a(\ mh\ dei=. But L has lu/hi, and some other MSS. have lu/h: and it is much more likely that this should have become lu/ei than vice versa. te/lh lu/h| = lusitelh=|, only here: cp. Eur. Alc. 627 fhmi\ toiou/tous ga/mous | lu/ein brotoi=s.

tau=ta ga\r (I have to bewail this now), for, though I once knew it, I had forgotten it. Teiresias, twice summoned (288), had come reluctantly. Only now, in the presence of Oedipus, does he realise the full horror of the secret which he holds.

diw/les' = let slip out of my memory; cp. sw/|zesqai to remember, Soph. El. 993, 1257, Soph. Trach. 682: Plat. Theaet. 153b kta=tai/ te maqh/mata kai\ sw/|zetai: Plat. Rep. 455b a(\ e)/maqe, sw/|zetai. So Teren. Phorm. 2.3.39 perii hercle: nomen perdidi, “have forgotten.” —Some explain, “suppressed the thought.”

ti/ d' e)/stin; Soph. El. 920 feu= th=s a)noi/as*x*r*u*s. ti/ d' e)/stin; and so often in Soph. (as 1144, Soph. Trach. 339, Soph. El. 921): de/ marking that the attention is turned to a new point, as in ti/ d'; quid vero? (941), or to a new person: Isaeus 8.24 su\ de\ ti/s ei)=;

dioi/sw bear to the end: Eur. Hipp. 1143 da/krusi dioi/sw | po/tmon a)/potmon, live out joyless days: Thuc. 1.11 ei) cunexw=s to\n po/lemon die/feron. diafe/rein could not mean “to bear apart”(from each other), though that is implied.
pi/qh|, i.e. obey me by letting me go home.
ou)/t' e)/nnom' k.t.l.: not in conformity with usage, which entitled the State to benefit by the wisdom of its ma/ntis. The king's first remonstrances are gentle.
a)posterw=n “withholding”: Aristot. Rh. 2.6.3 a)posterh=sai parakataqh/khn, depositum non reddere.
fa/tin of a divine message, 151.
o(rw= ga\r k.t.l.: (I do not speak), for I see that neither dost thou speak opportunely: (I am silent) therefore, lest I too should speak unseasonably.
pro\s kairo/n = kairi/ws, as Soph. Phil. 1279, Soph. Trach. 59.

w(s ou)=n k.t.l.: “(I do not speak), then, in order that neither (mhde/) may I share your mishap (of speaking amiss).” If he speaks not, neither will he speak wrongly. Cp. Thuc. 2.63 ei)ko\smh\ feu/gein tou\s po/nous, h)\ mhde\ ta\s tima\s diw/kein. I now prefer this view to taking mhd' e)gw/ as irregular for mh\ kai\ e)gw/ (“lest I too”), —revolving mhde/ into mh/ not, de/ on the other hand; though the place of e)gw/ suggests this. Kviecpala's mh\ le/gwn is ingenious and attractive; it may, indeed, be right; but seems hardly necessary.
mh\ pro\s qew=n k.t.l. The attribution of these two verses to the Chorus in some MSS. is probably due to the plur. in 327 having misled those who did not see that the king speaks for all Thebes.

fronw=n g' if thou hast understanding (of this matter): cp. 569 e)f' oi(=s ga\r mh\ fronw= siga=n filw=: not, “if thou art sane.” But in 328 ou) fronei=te= “are without understanding,” “are senseless.”

e)gw\ d' ou) mh/ pote e)kfh/nw ta\ e)ma\ (w(s a)
 mh\ ei)/pw ta\ sa\) kaka/ I will never reveal my (not to call them thy) griefs. ta\ e)ma\ kaka/,= those secrets touching Oedipus which lie heavy on the prophet's soul: ta\ sa\ kaka/, those same secrets in their import for Oedipus. We might render w(s a)
 ei)/pw mh\ ta\ s' either (i) as above, or (ii) “in order that I may not utter thy griefs.” But (i) is preferable for these reasons: —(1) The subjunct. ei)/pw with mh/ was familiar in such phrases. Plat. Rep. 487d tou\s me
 plei/stous kai\ pa/nu a)lloko/tous gignome/nous, i(/na mh\ pamponh/rws ei)/pwmen, “becoming very strange persons, —not to use a more unqualified epithet”: Plat. Rep. 507d ou)d' a)/llais pollai=s, i(/na mh\ ei)/pw o(/ti ou)demia=|, toiou/tou prosdei= ou)deno/s, i.e. few, —not to say none: Plat. Hippias Min. 372d toiou=to/s ei)mi oi(=o/s pe/r ei)mi, i(/na mhde
 e)mauto
 mei=zon ei(/pw,—to say nothing more of myself. The substitution of w(s a)
 for the commoner i(/na in no way alters the meaning. For w(s a)
 mh/, cp. Aristoph. Birds 1508 touti	o\ skia/deion u(pe/rexe | a)/nwqen, w(s a)
 mh/ m' i)/dwsin oi( qeoi/. For w(s a)
 ei)/pw mh\ instead of w(s a)
 mh\ ei)/pw, cp. 255, Soph. Phil. 66 ei) d' e)rga/sei | mh\ tau=ta. Soph. OC 1365 ei) d' e)ce/fusa ta/sde mh\ 'mautw=| trofou/s. Hdt. 7.214 ei)dei/h ga a)
 kai\ e)w
 mh\ *mhlieu\sth
 a)trapo/n. (2) The emphatic position of ta)/m' suits this version. (3) e)kfh/nw is more forcible than ei)/pw. If the meaning were, “I will not reveal my griefs, in order that I may not mention (ei)/pw) thy griefs,” the clauses would be ill-balanced. See Appendix, n. on vv. 328 f.

cuneidw\s because e)kfh/nw implied that he knew. Cp. 704 au)to\s cuneidw/s, h)\ maqw\n a)/llou pa/ra; i.e. of his own knowledge, or on hearsay? Not, “being an accomplice” (as Soph. Ant. 266 cuneide/nai | to\ pra=gma bouleu/santi): Oed. can still control his rising anger.

e)gw\ ou)/t' synizesis. The rugged verse is perh. designed to express agitation. Cp. 1002 e)gw\ ou)xi/: Soph. OC 939 e)gw\ ou)/t' a)/nandron, 998 e)gw\ ou)de/, 1436 telei=t', e)pei\ ou)/ moi: Soph. Ant. 458 e)gw\ ou)k e)/mellon: Soph. Phil. 1390 e)gw\ ou)k *)atrei/das.
tau=t', 29 n.

pe/trou | fu/sin Eur. Med. 1279 w)= ta/lain', w(s a)/r' h)=sqa pe/tros h)\ si/da|ros. For the periphrasis cp. Plat. Phaedrus 251b h( tou= pterou= fu/sis, = to\ ptero/n, pefuko\s w(/sper pe/fuke, being constituted as it is: Plat. Tim. 45b th
 tw=n blefa/rwn fu/sin: Plat. Tim. 74d th
 tw=n neu/rwn fu/sin: Plat. Tim. 84c h( tou= muelou= fu/sis: Plat. Laws 145d th
 u(/datos fu/sin. And so often in Arist., e.g. h( tou= pneu/matos fu/sis Aristot. Meteor. 2.8: h( tw=n neu/rwn fu/sis Aristot. Hist. An. 3.5.
pote/ tandem aliquando: Soph. Phil. 816 me/qes pote/: Soph. Phil. 1041 ti/sasq' a)lla\ tw=| xro/nw| pote/.

a)teleu/thtos not brought to an end: Hom. Il. 4.175 a)teleuth/tw| e)pi\ e)/rgw|. Plut. Mor. 114f to\ ga\r dh\ a)teleu/thton nomi/zein to\ pe/nqos a)noi/as e)sti\n e)sxa/ths. Here, a man “with whom one cannot make an end,” —who cannot be brought to the desired issue. In freely rendering, “Wilt thou never make an end?” we remember, of course, that the adj. could not literally mean “not finishing.” Possibly it is borrowed from the colloquial vocabulary of the day: the tone is like that of the Latin odiosus.

e)me/myw aor. referring to the moment just past: so oft. e)ph/|nesa, cunh=ka, hsqhn: e)\pthca(Soph. OC 1466): e)/frica(Soph. Aj. 693): e)deca/mhn (Soph. El. 668): a)pe/ptusa (Eur. Hec. 1276). o(mou= | nai/ousan, while (or though) it dwells close to thee, —possesses and sways thee. So Soph. OC 1134 khli\s kakw=n cu/noikos: Soph. El. 784 bla/bh | cu/noikos: Soph. Aj. 639 suntro/fois | o)rgai=s. But (as Eustathius saw, 755. 14) the words have a second meaning: “thou seest not that thine own [th
 sh/n, thy kinswoman, thy mother] is dwelling with thee [as thy wife].” The ambiguity of th
 sh
, the choice of the phrase o(mou= nai/ousan, and the choice of katei=des, leave no doubt of this. Cp. 261.

a)ll' e)me\ ye/geis the thought of o)rgh\n e)me/myw th\n e)mh/n returns upon itself, as if from a sense that the contrast between e)me/myw and katei=des would be imperfectly felt without such an iteration. This is peculiarly Sophoclean; cp. above 166(e)/lqete kai\ nu=n): Schneidewin cp. also Soph. Aj. 1111 ou)th=s sh=s ou(/nek'| a)ll' ou(/nex' o(/rkwn| sou= d' ou)de/n: and similarly Soph. Ant. 465 ff., Soph. Trach. 431 ff., Soph. El. 361 ff.

The emphasis on toiau=ta as well as on ou)k warrants the repeated a)
: cp. 139: Soph. Ant. 69 ff.: Eur. Andr. 934 ou)k a)
 e)/n g' e)moi=s do/mois | ble/pous' a)
 au)ga\s ta)/m' e)karpou=t' a)
 le/xh.

a(\a)tima/zeis po/lin a(/ cogn. accus.: Soph. Aj. 1107 ta\ se/mn' e)/ph | ko/laz' e)kei/nous: Soph. Ant. 550 ti/ tau=t' a)nia=s m'; a)tima/zeis, by rejecting the request that he would speak: Soph. Ant. 544.

h(/cei ga\r au)ta/ The subject to h(/cei is designedly left indeterminate: “(the things of which I wot) will come of themselves.” The seer is communing with his own thought, which dwells darkly on the kaka/ of v. 329. au)ta/ = au)to/mata: Hom. Il. 17.252 a)rgale/on de/ moi/ e)sti diaskopia=sqai e(/kaston| a)lla/ tis au)to\s i)/tw. Cp. the phrase au)to\ dei/cei, res ipsa arguet, the result will show: Soph. fr. 355 taxu\ d' au)to\ dei/cei tou)/rgon.

ou)kou=n a(/ g' h(/cei Elmsley, Nauck and Hartung read ou)k ou)=ne)moi/; but the positive xrh\ is stronger without the query. “Then, seeing that they will come, thou on thy part (kai\ se\) shouldest tell them to me.” The stress of kai\ falls primarily on se\, but serves at the same time to contrast le/gein with h(/cei. In a(/ g' h(/cei the causal force of the relative is brought out by ge: quippe quae ventura sint.
ou)k a)\n pe/ra fra/saimi The courteous formula (95, 282), just because it is such, here expresses fixed resolve.

h(/tis a)griwta/th: Hom. Il. 17.61 o(/te ti/s te le/wnbou=n a(rpa/sh| h(/tis a)ri/sth: Plat. Apol. 23a pollai\ a)pe/xqeiaikai\ oi)=ai xalepw/tatai: Dem. 2.18 ei) me\n ga/r tis a)nh/r e)stin e)n au)toi=s oi(=os e)/mpeiros pole/mou kai\ a)gw/nwn [sc. e)sti/], tou/tous, k.t.l.

kai\ mh
 with ge, “aye verily”: cp. Soph. El. 554, where h)
 e)fh=|s moi is answered (556) by kai\ mh
 e)fi/hm'. (For a slightly different kai\ mh/nge, see Soph. OC 396.)

w(s o)rgh=s e)/xw = e)/xwn o)rgh=s w(s e)/xw, being so wroth as I am. Thuc. 1.22 w(s e(kate/rwn tis eu)noi/as h)\ mnh/mhs e)/xoi: Eur. Hel. 313 pw=s d' eu)menei/as toisi/d' e)n do/mois e)/xeis; parh/swou)de\n(tou/twn) a(/per cuni/hm', I will leave unsaid nothing (of those things) which I comprehend, i.e. I will reveal my whole insight into the plot. cuni/hmi suits the intellectual pride of Oedipus: he does not say “think” or “suspect”: cp. 628. For ga\r after i)/sqi cp. 277.

kai\ cumfuteu=saiei)rga/sqai q'. kai/te could no more stand for ‘and’‘both’ than etque could. kai/ here (adeo) implies, “no mere sympathiser, but actually the plotter.”Cp. Soph. OC 1394 kai\ (e'en) pa=si *kadmei/oisi toi=s sautou= q' a(/ma. cumfuteu=sai: Pind. I. 5.12 su/n te/ oi( dai/mwn futeu/ei do/can: Soph. Aj. 953 *palla\s futeu/ei ph=ma: Soph. El. 198 deina\n deinw=s profuteu/santes | morfa/n (of crime). Hermann preferred d' to t' after ei)rga/sqai, as meaning, “but hast done it (only) by another's hands” (i.e. “though thou hast not executed it thyself”): this, however, besides being forced, destroys the climax.

o(/son(ei)=xes ei)rga/sqai) mh\ kai/nwn, so far as you could be the author of the deed without slaying: Thuc. 4.16 fula/ssein de\ kai\ th
 nh=son *)aqhnai/ous mhde
 h(=sson, o)/sa mh\ a)pobai/nontas: 1. 111 th=s gh=s e)kra/toun o)/sa mh\ proi+o/ntes polu\ e)k tw=n o(/plwn: Soph. Trach. 1214 | o(/son g' a)
 (sc. drw/|hn tou=to) au)to\s mh\ potiyau/wn xeroi=n.
kai\ tou)/rgontou=to the doing of this thing also, au)th\n th\n pra=cin, as dist. from the plotting and the direction of the act.

a)/lhqes; k.t.l. The same word marks the climax of Creon's anger in Soph. Ant. 758: cp. Aristoph. Birds 393 e)teo/n; etc. e)nne/pw se\e)mme/nein, I command that thou abide: so Soph. Phil. 101 le/gw selabei=n.

w)=|per proei=pas (sc. e)mme/nein), by which thou didst proclaim that (all) should abide: this is better than taking w)=|per as by attraction for o(/per, since proei=pon could take an acc. of the thing proclaimed (e.g. ceni/an, po/lemon, qa/naton), but not of the edict itself (as kh/rugma).

w(s o)/ntimia/stori an anacolouthon for w(s o)/ntamia/stora, as if e)nne/pw soi/ had preceded. e)me/ just before made this necessary. In Eur. Med. 57 most MSS. give w(/sq' i(/mero/s m' u(ph=lqe gh=| te kou)ranw=| | le/cai molou/sh| deu=ro despoi/nhs tu/xas, where Porson, reading molou=san, admits that the dat. stands in Philemon's parody (Athenaeus 288 D), w(s i(/mero/s m' u(ph=lqe gh=| te kou)ranw=| | le/cai molo/nti tou)=yon w(s e)skeu/asa. Elms. cp. Eur. IA 491 a)/llws te/ m' e)/leos th=s talaipw/rou ko/rhs | ei)sh=lqe sugge/neian e)nnooume/nw|. Conversely Thuc. 6.85 sect. 2(toi=s e)kei= cumma/xois followed by *xi/ous, etc., in appos.).

e)ceki/nhsas e)kkinei=n is used of starting game, Soph. El. 567 e)ceki/nhsen podoi=n |e)/lafon: of rousing one from rest, Soph. Trach. 1242, and fig. of exciting pain which had been lulled, Soph. Trach. 979. Here the notion is that of a startling utterance. Cp. the use of kinei=n in the sense of mooting subjects which should not have been touched: Eur. El. 302 e)pei\ de\ kinei=s mu=qon, i.e. since thou hast broached this theme: cp. Soph. OC 1526 a(\ d' e)ca/gista mhde\ kinei=tai lo/gw|. In Eur. Med. 1317 ti/ ta/sde kinei=s ka)namoxleu/eis pu/las; Porson, with the author of the Christus Patiens, reads lo/gous, thinking that Aristoph. Cl. 1399 w)= kainw=n e)pw=n | kinhta\ kai\ moxleuta/ alluded to that place. So a)ki/nhta (e)/ph) = a)po/rrhta Soph. OC 624, Soph. Ant. 1060 o)/rseis me ta)ki/nhta dia\ frenw=n fra/sai. | ki/nei, k.t.l.

kai\ pou= k.t.l. And on what ground dost thou think to escape (punishment for) this thing? For pou= cp. 390: Soph. Aj. 1100 pou= su\ strathgei=s tou=de; Distinguish kai/ (1) prefixed to interrogative particles, when it expresses an objection: Aesch. Ag. 280 kai\ ti/s to/d' e)ci/koit' a)\n a)gge/lwn ta/xos; Dem. 19.257 (with Shilleto's note), and kai\ pw=s; passim: (2) suffixed, where, granting a fact, it asks for further information: Aesch. Ag. 278 poi/ou xro/nou de\ kai\ pepo/rqhtai po/lis; (assuming it to be taken, when was it taken?) Eur. Alc. 834 pou= kai/ sfe qa/ptei; tou=to feu/gein here = tou/tou th\n di/khn e)kfeu/gein: Eur. Med. 795 pai/dwn fo/non | feu/gousa, fleeing from (the penalties of) the murder: Cic. Pro Cluent. 59.163 calumniam ( = crimen calumniae) non effugiet. But in Lys. 12.34 tou=toou) feu/gw = “I do not avoid this point.”
i)sxu=on expresses the living strength of the divine instinct within him: cp. zw=nta 482.
tre/fw see on e)mpe/fuken 299.
te/xnhs slightly contemptuous; cp. 388, 562, 709.
prou)tre/yw the midd., as 1446: but the act., Soph. Ant. 270, Soph. El. 1193.

h)\ kpeira=| le/gwn; or (while you do understand my meaning already) are you merely trying by your talk (le/gwn) to provoke a still fuller statement of it? Hdt. 3.135 dei/sas mh/ eu( e)kpeirw=|to *darei=os, was making trial of him: Aristoph. Kn. 1234 kai/ sou tosou=to prw=ton e)kpeira/somai, “thus far make trial of thee” (test thee by one question). The notion of e)k in the compound is that of drawing forth something from the person tested. le/gwn here implies idle talk, cp. 1151 le/gei ga\r ei)dw\s ou)de/n: Soph. Phil. 55 th\n *filokth/tou se dei= | yuxh\n o(/pws lo/goisin e)kkle/yeis le/gwn: where, as here, the partic. denotes the process. If we read le/gein, we must supply w(/ste: “tempting me so that I should speak”: a weak sense. lo/gw| could only mean, “by thy talk”: whereas it would naturally mean “in word” (only, and not e)/rgw|). Musgrave conj. loxw=n (laying a snare for me); Arndt m' e(lei=n; (to catch me): Madvig e)k pei/ras le/geis; But, with le/gwn, all is, I think, sound.

ou)x w(/ste g' k.t.l. ou) (cunh=ka) ou(/tw g' a)kribw=s w(/ste ei)pei=n: cp. 1131. gnwsto/n: “known.” So the MSS.: but gnwta\ 58, gnwto\n 396. In fr. 262 e)k ka/rta baiw=n gnwto\s a)\n ge/noit' a)nh/r, gnwto/s= “well-known,” gnw/rimos: but Soph. used gnwsto/s in the same sense in the Hermione (Antiatticista 87.25). It has been held that, where a sigmatic form of the verbal (as gnwsto/s) existed along with the non-sigmatic (as gnwto/s), Attic usage distinguished gnwsto/s as = “what can be known” from gnwto/s as = “what is known.” But there is no ground for assuming that such a distinction was observed. See Appendix, n. on v. 361.

p.foreign: k.t.l. fhmi/ se fone/a kurei=n (o)/nta) tou= a)ndro\s ou)= (to\n fone/a) zhtei=s.

div2.p: a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn cp. Soph. Phil. 1299 (n.). phmona\s: i.e. such charges are downright calamities, infamies. There is something of a colloquial tone in the phrase: cp. Soph. Aj. 68 mhde\ sumfora\n de/xou | to\n a)/ndra: Soph. El. 301 o( pa/nt' a)/nalkis ou(=tos, h( pa=sa bla/bh. Cp. 336 a)teleu/thtos.
ei)/pw delib. subjunct.: Eur. Ion 758 ei)/pwmen, h)\ sigw=men, h)\ ti/ dra/somen;

su\n toi=s filta/tois k.t.l. = su\n th=| filta/th| (Iocasta): since o(milou=nt' implies wedlock, and not merely the companionship denoted by cunw/n in 457: for the allusive plural, cp. Soph. Trach. 335 ou(/stinas (meaning Iole): Soph. El. 652 fi/loisi (Aegisthus).
i(/n' ei)= kakou= cp. 413, 1442. Soph. Trach. 375 pou= pot' ei)mi\ pra/gmatos;
h)= kai\ “dost thou indeed?”Aesch. Eum. 402 h)= kai\ toiau/tas tw=|d' e)pirroizei=s fuga/s;

plh
 soi/: soi\ de\ k.t.l. Note in these two vv. (1) the rhetorical iteration(e)panafora/) of the pers. pron., as in Soph. OC 250 pro/s s' o(/ ti soi fi/lon e)k se/qen: Soph. OC 787 ou)k e)/sti soi tau=t', a)lla/ soi tau=t' e)/st': Soph. Phil. 1054 plh
 ei)s se/: soi\ de/: Isoc. 15.41 kinduneu/wn ta\ me
 u(f' u(mw=n ta\ de\ meq' u(mw=n ta\ de\ di' u(ma=s ta\ d' u(pe u(mw=n. (2) the ninefold t (parh/xhsis) in 371; cp. 425: Soph. OC 1547: Soph. Aj. 528 e)a
 to\ taxqe
 eu)= tolma=| telei=n. Similarly p, Soph. El. 210, Soph. Aj. 1112: s, Eur. Med. 476 e)/swsa/ s': w(s i)/sasin *(ellh/nwn o)/soi, k.t.l.: Ennius Ann. 1.151 O Tite tute Tati tibi tanta tyranne tulisti: Cic. Pro Cluent. 35.96 non fuit igitur illud iudicium iudicii simile, iudices.
a)/qlios of wretched folly. Cp. the use of a)/nolbos, Soph. Aj. 1156, Soph. Ant. 1025 (joined with a)/boulos), me/leos (Soph. Aj. 621), kakodai/mwn, k.t.l.

ou)dei\s (e)/stin) o(\s ou)xi\ = pa=s tis: [Plat.] Eur. Alc. 1. 103 B ou)dei\s o(\s ou)x u(perblhqei\spe/feuge. Soph. Aj. 725 h)/rassonou)/tis e)/sq' o(\s ou). More properly ou)dei\s o(/stis ou), declined (by attraction) in both parts, as Plat. Phaedo 117d ou)de/na o(/ntina ou) kate/klase tw=n paro/ntwn.

mia=s tre/fei pro\s nukto/s thou art cherished by (thy life is passed in) one unbroken night: the pass. form of mi/a nu/c se tre/fei. Cp. fr. 524 (N.(2)), terpnw=s ga\r a)ei\ pa/ntas a(noi/a tre/fei, folly ever gives a joyous life: fr. 532. 4 bo/skei de\ tou\s me\n moi=ra dusameri/as, | tou\s d' o)/lbos h(mw=n: Eur. Hipp. 367 w)= po/noi tre/fontes brotou/s, cares that make up the life of men. mia=s might be simply mo/nhs, but, in its emphatic place here, rather = “unbroken,” unvaried by day: cp. Aristot. Rh. 3.9.1 (le/cin) ei)rome/nhn kai\ tw=| sundesmw=| mi/an, forming one continuous chain. The ingenious conj. mai/as (nurse) seems to me far less forcible.
(ou)k e)gw/ se bla/yw), ou) ga\r moi=ra se pesei=n k.t.l.
e)kpra=cai “to accomplish” (not to “exact”); ta/de has a mysterious vagueness (cp. 341), but includes to\ pesei=n se, as in 1158 to/d' refers to o)le/sqai.
*kre/wn de\ = “Nay, Creon,” —introducing an objection, as Soph. Trach. 729 toiau=ta d' a)\n le/ceien k.t.l.: Soph. OC 395 ge/ronta d' o)rqou=n flau=ron: and Soph. OC 1443.

tw=| poluzh/lw| bi/w| locative dative, defining the sphere of u(perfe/rousa, like e)/ti me/gas ou)ranw=| | *zeu/s Soph. El. 174. poluzh/lw|= full of emulation(zh=los). Others understand, “in the much admired life” (of princes). This is the sense of polu/zhlon (po/sin) in Soph. Trach. 185. But (1) bi/w| seems to denote life generally, rather than a particular station: (2) the phrase, following plou=te kai\ turanni/, would be a weak addition. te/xnh te/xnhs | u(perfe/rousa refers to the view that the art of ruling is the highest of arts: cp. Soph. Phil. 138 te/xna ga\r te/xnas e(te/ras prou)/xei | kai\ gnw/ma, par' o(/tw| to\ qei=on | *dio\s skh=ptron a)na/ssetai: for skill and wit(gnw/mh), surpassing those of other men, belong to him by whom is swayed the godlike sceptre which Zeus gives. Xen. Mem. 4.2.11 megi/sths e)fi/esai te/xnhs: e)/sti ga\r tw=n basile/wn au(/th, kai\ kalei=tai basilikh/. But there is also an allusion to the skill shown in solving the riddle, by which Oed. surpassed the mantikh\ te/xnh of Teiresias (cp. 357).

par' u(mi=nfula/ssetai is guarded, stored, in your keeping: i.e. how much envy do ye tend to excite against those who receive your gifts. fula/ssetai, stronger than tre/fetai, represents envy as the inseparable attendant on success: cp. Soph. OC 1213 skaiosu/nan fula/sswn, stubborn in folly: Eur. Ion 735 a)/ci' a)ci/wn gennhto/rwn | h)/qh fula/sseis.

dwrhto/n, ou)k ai)thto/n feminine. The adjectives might be neuter: “a thing given, not asked.” But this use of the neuter adj., when the subject is regarded in its most general aspect, is far most common in simple predications, as Hom. Il. 2.204 ou)k a)gaqo\n polukoirani/h: Eur. Hipp. 109 terpno\n e)k kunagi/as | tra/peza plh/rhs. And gnwto/n in 396—which must agree with h(/n— favours the view that here also the adjectives are fem. Cp. Hom. Il. 2.742 kluto\s *(ippoda/meia: Thuc. 2.41 gh=n e)sbato/n: Thuc. 7.87 o)smai\ ou)k a)nektoi/: Plat. Rep. 573b mani/ase)paktou=: Plat. Eryx. 398d a)reth\ didakto/s: Soph. OC 1460 pterwto\s bronth/: Soph. Trach. 446 ei)mempto/s ei)mi (Deianeira).
tau/ths redundant, for emphasis: Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.9 to\ de\ probouleu/ein kai\ to\ h(gei=sqai, e)f' o(/ti a)\n kairo\s dokh=| ei(=nai, tou=to prosta/ttw.

u(fei\s having secretly sent as his agent, “having suborned.” Plat. Axioch. 368e proe/drous e)gkaqe/tous u(fe/ntes, “having privily brought in suborned presidents.” The word ma/gos expresses contempt for the rights of divination practised by Teiresias: a)gu/rths taunts him as a mercenary impostor. So Plut. Mor. 165f joins a)gu/rtas kai\ go/htas, Zosimus 1.11 ma/gois te kai\ a)gu/rtais. The passage shows how Asiatic superstitions had already spread among the vulgar, and were scorned by the educated, in Greece. The Persian ma/gos (as conceived by the Greeks) was one who claimed to command the aid of beneficent deities(dai/mones a)gaqoergoi/), while the go/hs was properly one who could call up the dead (Suid. 1. 490: cp. Plut. De Defect. Orac. 10). So Eur. Orest. 1496 (Helen has been spirited away), h)\ farma/koisin (by charms), h)\ ma/gwn | te/xnaisin, h)\ qew=n klopai=s.

a)gu/rthn (a)gei/rw), a priest, esp. of Cybele(mhtragu/rths, or, when she had the lunar attributes, mhnagu/rths), who sought money from house to house(e)pi\ ta\s tw=n plousi/wn qu/ras i)o/ntes, Plat. Rep. 364b), or in public places, for predictions or expiatory rites: Maximus Tyrius 19. 3 tw=n e)n toi=s ku/klois a)geiro/ntwn, oi(\ duoi=n o)boloi=n tw=| prostuxo/nti a)poqespi/zousin.

e)n toi=s ke/rdesin in the case of gains: cp. Soph. Aj. 1315 e)n e)moi\ qrasu/s; rather than, “on opportunities for gain”(= o(/tan h)=| kerdai/nein) as Ellendt takes it. Cicero's videbat in litteris (Cic. Tusc. 5.38.112, quoted by Schneid.) seems not strictly similar, meaning rather “in the region of letters” (like in tenebris).
e)pei\ = “for” (if this is not true): Soph. El. 351 ou) tau=tadeili/an e)/xei | e)pei\ di/dacon, k.t.l.; so Soph. OC 969.
pou=; where? i.e. in what sense? Eur. Ion 528 pou= de/ moi path\r su/;
ei)= safh/s = pe/fhnas w)/n: cp. 355.

ku/wn esp. because the Sphinx was the watchful agent of Hera's wrath: cp. 36. Aristoph. Frogs 1287 has a line from the *sfi/gc of Aesch., *sfi/gga dusameria=n [vulg. dusamerian] pru/tanin ku/na pe/mpei, “the watcher who presides over evil days” (for Thebes).

r(ayw|do\s chanting her riddle (in hexameter verse), as the public reciters chanted epic poems. The word is used with irony: the baneful lay of the Sphinx was not such as the servant of Apollo chants. Cp. 130.

to/ g' ai)/nigm' is nominative: the riddle did not belong to (was not for) the first comer, that he should solve it. Soph. OC 751 ou) ga/mwn | e)/mpeiros, a)lla\ tou)pio/ntos a(rpa/sai. Thuc. 6.22 pollh\ ga\r ou)=sa h( stratia\ ou) pa/shs e)/stai po/lews u(pode/casqai. o( e)piw/n, any one who comes up; cp. Plat. Rep. 372d w(s nu=n o( tuxw\n kai\ ou)de\n prosh/kwn e)/rxetai e)p' au)to/.
dieipei=n “to declare,” “to solve”: cp. 854. dia/ implies the drawing of clear distinctions; cp. Soph. OC 295 dieide/nai, diiudicare, n.

h(\n oi)/t' a)p' oi)wnw=n e)/xwn ou)/t' e)k qew=n tou gnwto\n (e)/xwn) prou)fa/nhs: and thou wast not publicly seen to have this art, either from (a)p') birds, or as known through the agency of (e)k) any god. prou)fa/nhs. when brought to a public test. For a)po/ cp. 43: e)k with qew=n tou, of the primary or remoter agent (Xen. Hell. 3.1.6 e)k basile/ws e)do/qh), meaning by a fh/mh (43) or other sign. gnwto/n: cp. on 384.
molw/n he was a mere stranger who chanced to arrive then.

o( mhde\n ei)dw\s = o(/stis mhde\n h)/|dh, “I, a man who knew nothing,” the generic mh/, here with concessive force, —“though I knew nothing, I silenced her” (qui nihil scirem, vici tamen). So in Dem. 19.31 the generic mh/ has a causal force: h( boulh\ de/, h( mh\ kwluqei=sa a)kou=sai ta)lhqh= par' e)mou=, ou)/t' e)ph/|nese tou/tous, k.t.l. (“the senate, a body which had not been prevented.” etc.). See Whitelaw in Trans. Camb. Phil. Soc., 1886, p. 17. Cp. 638, 875, 1019.
pe/las adv., so Aesch. Seven 669 parastatei=n pe/las.
klai/wn cp. 368, 1152: Soph. Ant. 754 klai/wn frenw/seis.
o( sunqei\s Creon, as whose agent (387) Teir. is regarded: so in Thuc. 8.68 o( th\n gnw/mhn ei)pw/n is contrasted with o( to\ pra=gma cunqei/s.

a)ghlatei=n = to\ a)/gos e)lau/nein(see on 98), in this case a)ndrhlatei=n (100), to expel the mia/stwr. Hdt. 5.72 *kleome/nhsa)ghlate/ei e(ptako/sia e)pi/stia (households) *)aqhnai/wn. The smooth breathing is supported by Hesychius, by the grammarians in Bekker's Anecd. 1.328.32, and by most MSS. of Soph.; while the aspirate is given by L here, by Eustathius (1704, 5), and by Suidas, who quotes this verse. Curtius distinguishes (1) a)g-, a)/g-os, guilt, object of awe, whence e)nagh/s: Skt. ag-as, vexation, offence: Etym. sect. 116: (2) root a(/g, a(/z-o-mai reverence, a(/g-io-s holy, a(g-no/-s pure: Skt. jage(jaegea_-mi), reverence, consecrate: Etym. sect. 118. In Aesch. Lib. 154 and Soph. Ant. 775 he would with Herm. write a(/gos as = “consecrated offering.” In both places, however, a)/gos(= piaculum) satisfies the sense (see n. on Soph. Ant. 775); and for a(/gos there is no other evidence. But this, at least, seems clear: the compound synonym for to\ a)/gos e)lau/nein(Thuc. 1.126) should be written a)ghlatei=n. do/keis is the scornful phrase of an angry man; I know little concerning thee, but from thine aspect I should judge thee to be old: cp. 562 where Oed. asks, to/t' ou)=n o( ma/ntis ou(=tos h)=n e)n th=| te/xnh|; Not (1) “seemed,” as opposed to really being; nor (2) “wast felt by me” to be old: a sense which the word surely could not yield.
paqw\n by bodily pain, and not merely maqw/n, by reproof: cp. 641.
oi)=a/ per fronei=s: see on 624 oi)=o/n e)sti to\ fqonei=n.
o)rgh=| modal dat., cp. Soph. OC 659 qumw=|.
kai\ ta\ s' k.t.l., the elision as in 329: see on 64.
to/de emphatically resumes o(/pws lu/somen, this we must consider: cp. 385 tau/ths: so Soph. Trach. 458 to\ mh\ puqe/sqai, tou=to/ m' a)lgu/neien a)/n: Soph. Phil. 913.
ei) kai\ k.t.l. For ei) kai\ see on 305.

e)ciswte/on k.t.l. = dei= e)cisou=n to\ gou=n i)/sa a)ntile/cai, one must equalize the right at least of like reply; i.e. you must make me so far your equal as to grant me the right of replying at the same length. The phrase is a pleonastic fusion of (1) e)ciswte/on to\ a)ntile/cai with (2) sugxwrhte/on to\ i)/sa a)ntile/cai.
*loci/a| see note to 853.

w(/st' ou) Kre/ontos k.t.l. “You charge me with being the tool of Creon's treason. I have a right to plead my own cause when I am thus accused. I am not like a resident alien, who can plead before a civic tribunal only by the mouth of that patron under whom he has been registered.” Every me/toikos at Athens was required e)pigra/fesqai prosta/thn, i.e. to have the name of a citizen, as patron, inscribed over his own. In default, he was liable to an a)prostasi/ou grafh/. Aristoph. Peace 684 au(tw=| ponhro\n prosta/thn e)pegra/yato: Aristoph. Ach. 1095 e)pegra/fou th\n *gorgo/na, you took the Gorgon for your patron: Lys. 31.9 e)n *)wrwpw=| metoi/kion katatiqei\s (paying the alien's tax) e)pi\ prosta/tou w)/|kei.

gegra/yomai will stand enrolled: cp. Aristoph. Kn. 1370 ou)dei\s kata\ spouda\s meteggrafh/setai, | a)ll' w(/sper h)=n to\ prw=ton e)ggegra/yetai: Theocr. 18. 47 gra/mmata d' e)n floiw=| gegra/yetai, remain written. —For the gen. *kre/ontos cp. Aristoph. Kn. 714 to\n dh=mon seautou= neno/mikas.
le/gw d' a solemn exordium, bespeaking attention: cp. 449.

tuflo/n m' w)nei/disas As w)nei/disas could not stand for a)peka/lesas, “called me reproachfully,” tuflo/n must stand for w(s tuflo\n o)/nta. For the ellipse of o)/nta, cp. Soph. El. 899 w(s d' e)n galh/nh| pa/nt' e)derko/mhn to/pon: for that of w(s, Soph. OC 142 mh/ m', i(keteu/w, prosi/dht' a)/nomon.

su\ kai\ de/dorkas “Thou both has sight and dost not see,” i.e. thou hast sight, and at the same time dost not see. The conject. of Reiske and Brunck, su/, kai\ dedorkw/s(though having sight), ou) ble/peis, spoils the direct contrast with tuflo/n.

e)/nqa nai/eis might mean, “in what a situation thou art”: but, as distinguished from the preceding and following clauses, is best taken literally: “where thou dwellest,”—viz., in thy murdered father's house.
a)=r' oi)=sqa k.t.l. Thy parents are unknown to thee. Yea. and (kai\) thou knowest not how thou hast sinned against them, —the dead and the living.

a)mfiplh\c as in Soph. Trach. 930 a)mfiplh=gi fasga/nw|= a sword which smites with both edges, so here a)mfiplh\c a)ra/ is properly a curse which smites on both sides, — on the mother's and on the father's part. The pursuing *)ara/ must be conceived as bearing a whip with double lash(diplh= ma/stic, Soph. Aj. 242). Cp. a)mfi/puros, carrying two torches (Soph. Trach. 214). The genitives mhtro/s, patro/s might be causal, with a)mfiplh/c, “smiting twice— for mother and for sire,” but are better taken with a)ra/, which here = *)erinu/s: cp. Aesch. Seven 70 *)ara/ t', *)erinu\s patro\s h( megasqenh/s.

deino/pous with dread, untiring chase: so the Fury, who chases guilt “as a hound tracks a wounded fawn” (Aesch. Eum. 246), is xalko/pous(Soph. El. 491), tanu/pous(Soph. Aj. 837), kamyi/pous (“fleet,” Aesch. Seven 791).

*ble/ponta k.t.l., i.e. to/te sko/ton ble/ponta, ei) kai\ nu=n o)rqa\ ble/peis. The Greek love of direct anthithesis often coordinates clauses where we must subordinate one to the other: cp. below, 673: Isoc. 6.54 pw=s ou)k ai)sxro/n,th
 me
 *eu)rw/phn kai\ th
 *)asi/an mesth
 pepoihke/nai tropai/wn,u(pe de\ th=s patri/dosmhde\ mi/an ma/xhn fai/nesqai memaxhme/nous; ble/pein sko/ton, like e)n sko/tw|| o)yoi)ato (1273), Eur. Ba. 510 sko/tion ei)sora=| kne/fas.

boh=s de\ k.t.l. Of thy cry what haven shall there not be (i.e. to what place shall it not be borne), —what part of Cithaeron shall not be resonant with it(su/mfwnos e)/stai sc. au)th=|), re-echo it? If we took su/mfwnos e)/stai (and not e)/stai alone) with limh/n as well as with *kiqairw/n, the figurative force of limh/n would be weakened. We must not understand: What haven of the sea or what mountain (as if Cithaeron stood for o)/ros) shall not resound? limh/n, poet. in the sense of u(podoxh/, for that in which anything is received: Aesch. Pers. 250 w)= *persi\s ai)=a kai\ me/gas plou/tou limh/n (imitated by Eur. Orest. 1077): the augural seat of Teiresias is panto\s oi)wnou= limh/n, Soph. Ant. 1000: the place of the dead is *(/aidou limh/n, Soph. Ant. 1284: cp. below, 1208.
poi=os *kiqairw\n vigorous for poi=on me/ros *kiqairw=nos.

to\n u(me/naion o(\n ei)se/pleusas the marriage into which thou didst sail: do/mois, in the house, local dat. (381): the marriage(u(me/naios, here = ga/mos) was the haven into which he sailed, —a haven which seemed secure, but which, in reality, was for him a o(/rmos a)/normos.

eu)ploi/as tuxw/n because Oed. seemed to have found o)/lbos, and also because the gale of fortune had borne him swiftly on: cp. ou)/q' o(rw=n ou)/q' i(storw=n, 1484. —The u(me/naios was the song sung while the bride and bridegroom were escorted to their home, Hom. Il. 18.492 nu/mfas d' e)k qala/mwn dai/+dwn u(po\ lampomena/wn | h)gi/neon a)na\ a)/stu, polu\s d' u(me/naios o)rw/rei, as distinguished from the e)piqala/mion afterwards sung before the bridal chamber: Soph. Ant. 813 ou)/q' u(menai/wn | e)/gklhron, ou)/t' e)pinu/mfeio/s | pw/ me/ tis u(/mnos u(/mnhsen.

a)/llwn de\ k.t.l. Verses 422-425 correspond with the actual process of the drama. The words katai/sqh| to\n u(me/naion refer to the first discovery made by Oed., —that his wife was the widow of one whom he had himself slain: cp. 821. The a)/llwn plh=qos kakw=n denotes the further discovery that this wife was his mother, with all the horrors involved (1405).

a(/ s' e)cisw/sei which shall make thee level with thy (true) self, —by showing thee to be the son of Laius, not of Polybus; —and level with thine own children, i.e. like them, the child of Iocasta, and thus at once a)delfo\s kai\ path/r (458). For a(/ s' Markland conject. o(/s', which shall be made equal for thee and for thy children: and so Porson interpreted, conjecturing a(/ss' from Agathon fr. 5 a)ge/nhta poiei=n a(/ss' a)\n h)=| pepragme/na. Nauck ingeniously conj. a(/ s' e)cisw/sei sw=| tokei= kai\ soi=s te/knois. But the vulgate is sound: for the parh/xhsis cp. 371.
tou)mo\n sto/ma i.e., it is Apollo who speaks by my mouth, which is not, as thou deemest, the u(po/blhton sto/ma (Soph. OC 794) of Creon.

prophla/kize acc. to Aristot. Top. 6.6 prophlakismo/s was defined as u(/bris meta\ xleuasi/as, insult expressed by scoffing: so in Aristot. Nic. Eth. 5.2.13 kakhgori/a, prophlakismo/s= libellous language, gross abuse: and in Aristoph. Thes. 386 prophlakizome/nas is explained by polla\ kai\ pantoi=' a)kouou/sas kaka/. Dem. 21.72 has a)h/qeistou= prophlaki/zesqai as = “unused to gross contumely” (generally, but with immediate ref. to a blow).
e)ktribh/setai rooted out. Eur. Hipp. 683 *zeu/s se gennh/twr e)mo\s | pro/rrizon e)ktri/yeien.

ou)k ei)s o)/leqron; cp. 1146: Aristoph. Pl. 394 ou)k e)s ko/rakas; Soph. Trach. 1183 ou) qa=sson oi)/seis; Cratinus *no/moi fr. 6 (Meineke p. 27) ou)k a)perrh/seis su\ qa=tton; Aesch. Seven 252 ou)k e)s fqo/ron sigw=s' a)nasxh/sei ta/de;
pa/lin a)/yorros like Soph. El. 53 a)/yorron h)/comen pa/lin: the gen. oi)/kwn tw=nd' with a)postrafei/s.
i(ko/mhne)ka/leis cp. 125, 402.

sxolh=| s' a)/n The simple sxolh=| is stronger than sxolh=| ge would be: Soph. Ant. 390 sxolh=| poq' h(/cein (where sxolh=| g' a)/n is an inferior v. l.), Plat. Soph. 233b sxolh=| pot'h)/qelen a)/n, Plat. Prot. 330e sxolh=| me/nt' a)\n a)/llo ti o(/sion ei)/h and often
oi)/kous: Soph. OC 643 do/mous stei/xein e)mou/s.

e)steila/mhn = metesteila/mhn, metepemya/mhn. Distinguish ste/llesqai, to summon to oneself, from ste/llein said (1) of the messenger, below 860 pe/myon tina\ stelou=nta: (2) of him who sends word by a messenger, Soph. Phil. 60 oi(/ s' e)n litai=s stei/lantes e)c oi)/kou molei=n: having urged thee with prayers to come: Soph. Ant. 164 u(ma=spompoi=sin| e)/steil' i(ke/sqai, sent you word to come.

toioi/d' refers back to the taunt implied in mw=ra fwnh/sont', and is then made explicit by mw=roie)/mfrones: cp. Soph. Phil. 1271 toiou=tos h)=sqa (referring to what precedes—thou wast such as thou now art) toi=s lo/goisi xw(/te mou | ta\ to/c' e)/kleptes, pisto/s, a)thro\s la/qra. In fr. 700 (quoted by Nauck), kai\ to
 qeo
 toiou=ton e)cepi/stamai, | sofoi=s me
