 ai)nikth=ra,| skaioi=s de\ fau=lon, we have not the preceding words, but doubtless toiou=ton referred to them.

w(s me
 soi\ dokei=. soi\ must be accented; else the contrast would be, not partly between soi\ and goneu=si, but solely between dokei= and some other verbal notion. soi\ does not, however, cohere so closely with dokei= as to form a virtual cretic. It is need. less, then, to read (as Elms. proposed) w(s me/n soi or w(s soi\ me
. Cp. Soph. OC 1543 w(/sper sfw\ patri/: Eur. Heraclid. 641 swth nw=|n bla/bhs. As neither sfw\ nor nw=|n adheres to the following rather than to the preceding word, it seems unnecessary to read with Porson w(s pri
 sfw\ or nw=|n swth/r. Here we have w(s me
 soi\ instead of w(s soi\ me
, because, besides the contrast of persons, there is also a contrast between semblance (w(s dokei=) and fact.
goneu=si “ for” them, i.e. in their judgment: Soph. Ant. 904 kai/toi s' e)gw\ ti/mhsa, toi=s fronou=sin, eu)=. Aristoph. Birds 445 pa=si nika=n toi=s kritai=s.

e)kfu/ei (u^). The pres. is not historic (for e)ce/fuse), but denotes a permanent character: “is my sire.” Eur. Ion 1560 h(/de ti/ktei s', is thy mother: so perh. Eur. Heraclid. 208 path\r d' e)k th=sde genna=tai se/qen. Xen. Cyrop. 8.2.27 o( de\ mh\ nikw=n (he who was not victorious) toi=s me\n nikw=sin e)fqo/nei: and so feu/gein = fuga\s ei)=nai passim. Shilleto thus takes oi( e)pago/menoi in Thuc. 2.2, oi( prodido/ntes Thuc. 2.5, oi( diaba/llontes Thuc. 3.4; which, however, I should rather take simply as imperfect participles, = oi(\ e)ph/gonto, prou)di/dosan, die/ballon. He well compares Verg. Aen. 9.266 quem dat Sidonia Dido (is the giver): in Persius 4.2 sorbitio tollit quem dira cicutae, I find rather a harsh historic pres.
ou)/koun k.t.l. Well (ou)=n— if I do speak riddles), art not thou most skilled to read them?

toiau=t' o)nei/dize/ (moi ), make those things my reproach, in which [oi(=s, dat. of circumstance] thou wilt find me great: i.e. mock my skill in reading riddles if thou wilt; but thou wilt find (on looking deeper) that it has brought me true honour.
toiau=taoi(=s as Soph. OC 1353 (n.), Soph. Ant. 691, etc.

au(/th ge me/ntoi It was just (ge)that fortune, however (me/ntoi),that ruined thee. ge emphasises the preceding word: so 778, 1292: Soph. Phil. 93 pemfqei/s ge me/ntoi (since I have been sent), 1052 nika=n ge me/ntoi: Soph. Ant. 233 te/los ge me/ntoi, Soph. Ant. 495 misw= ge me/ntoi.
tu/xh implies some abatement of the king's boast, gnw/mh| kurh/sas, 398.
e)ce/sws' 1st pers., not 3rd.
komize/tw dh=q' dh=ta in assent, as Aesch. Supp. 206 *zeu\s de\ gennh/twr i)/doi. *d*a*n. i)/doito dh=ta.

e)mpodw
 with parw
, —present where thy presence irks: cp. 128. su/ ge here gives a scornful force: the use of su/ ge in 1101 (n.) is different. The reading ta/ g' e)mpodw
 (found in B) is explained by Brunck and Erfurdt (with Thomas Magister) “thou hinderest the business before us,” comparing Eur. Phoen. 706 a(\ d' e)mpodw
 ma/lista (“most urgent”) tau=q' h(/kw fra/swn.

a)lgu/nois suits the continuing action better than a)lgu/nais. The aor. occurs Soph. Trach. 458(a)lgu/neien) and Eur. IA 326(a)lgu=nai): but ais and ai, as optative endings, are not elsewhere found in Soph.

pro/swpon “thy face,”—thy angry presence: the blind man speaks as though he saw the “vultus instantis tyranni.” Not, “thy person” (i.e. thy royal quality): pro/swpon is not classical in this sense, for which cp. the Hellenistic proswpolhptei=n,“ to be a respecter of persons,” and the spurious Phocylidea 10 (Bergk Poet. Lyr. p. 361) mh\ r(i/yh|s peni/hn a)di/kws: mh\ kri=ne pro/swpon.
ou)k e)/sq' o(/pou there is no case in which: cp. 355, 390.
le/gw de/ soi cp. 412.

to
 a)/ndra tou=tonou(=to/s e)stin k.t.l. The antecedent, attracted into the case of the relative, is often thus prefixed to the relative clause, to mark with greater emphasis the subject of a coming statement: Soph. Trach. 283 ta/sde d' a(/sper ei)sora=|s |xwrou=si: Hom. Il. 10.416 fulaka\s d' a(\s ei)/reai, h(/rws, | ou)/tis kekrime/nh r(u/etai strato/n: HH Dem. 66 kou/rhn th
 e)/tekon| th=s a)dinh
 o)/p' a)/kousa: Aristoph. Pl. 200 th
 du/namin h(
 u(mei=s fate\ | e)/xein me, tau/ths despo/ths genh/somai. Plaut. Trinum. 985 Illum quem ementitu's, is ego sum ipse Charmides.
a)nakhru/sswn fo/non proclaiming (a search into) the murder: cp. Xen. Mem. 2.10.2 sw=stra tou/tou a)nakhru/ttwn: Andoc. 1.40 zhthta/s te h)/dh h(|rhme/nouskai\ mh/nutra kekhrugme/na e(kato\n mna=s.
to\n *lai/+eion cp. 267.

ce/nos me/toikos a foreign sojourner: ce/nos, because Oed. was reputed a Corinthian. In poetry me/toikos is simply one who comes to dwell with others: it has not the full technical sense which belonged to it at Athens, a resident alien: hence the addition of ce/nos was necessary. Cp. Soph. OC 934 me/toikos th=sde gh=s: Soph. Ant. 868 pro\s ou(\s (to the dead) a(/d' e)gw\ me/toikos e)/rxomai.
ei)=ta de\ opp. to nu=n me/n, implied in e)nqa/de. —e)ggenh\s, “native,” as gennhto/s is opp. to poihto/s (adoptivus).
th=| cumfora=| the (seemingly happy) event: cp. Soph. El. 1230 ka)pi\ sumforai=si/ moi | geghqo\s e(/rpei da/kruon.
ce/nhn e)/pi sc. gh=n: Soph. OC 184 cei=nos e)pi\ ce/nhs: Soph. Phil. 135 e)n ce/na| ce/non.

gai=an with prodeiknu\s only: pointing to, i.e. feeling, yhlafw=n, the ground before him: so of a boxer, xersi\ prodeiknu/s, sparring, Theocr. 22.102. Cp. Lucian Hercules 1 to\ to/con e)ntetame/non h( a)ristera\ prodei/knusi, i.e. holds in front of him: id. Hermotimus 68 qallw=| prodeixqe/nti a)kolouqei=n, w(/sper ta\ pro/bata. Seneca Oed. 656 repet incertus viae, | Baculo senili triste praetentans iter. The order of words is against taking ce/nhn with gai=an (when we should write e)pi\), and supplying th\n o(do/n with prodeiknu/s.
cunw\n the idea of daily converse under the same roof heightens the horror. Cp. Andoc. 1.49 oi(=se)xrw= ka62 oi(=s sunh=sqa, your friends and associates.

a)delfo\s au(to\s If a)delfo\s stood alone, then au)to\s would be right: himself the brother of his own children: but with a)delfo\s kai\ path\r we should read au(to/s at once sire and brother of his own children. Cp. Soph. Phil. 119 sofo/s t' a)\n au(to\s ka)gaqo\s keklh=|' a(/ma: Eur. Alc. 143 kai\ pw=s a)\n au(to\s katqa/noi te kai\ ble/poi;

o(mo/sporos here act., = th\n au)th\n spei/rwn: but passive above, 260. Acc. to the general rule, verbal derivatives with a short penult. are paroxytone when active in meaning (see on bouno/mois, v. 26). But those compounded with a preposition (or with a privative) are excepted: hence dia/bolos, not diabo/los. So o(mo/sporos here, no less than in 260. On the other hand prwtospo/ros= “sowing first,” prwto/sporos = “fipst sown.”
la/bh|s e)y. without me: cp. Soph. Phil. 768(a)ll' e)a=n etc.), 801(e)/mprhson).
fa/skein inf. for imperat., “say,” i.e.” deem,” as in Soph. Phil. 1411, Soph. El. 9. Cp. Hdt. 3.35 h)\n de\ a(ma/rtw, fa/nai *pe/rsas te le/gein a)lhqe/a kai/ me mh\ swfrone/ein.
mantikh=|: in respect to seer-craft: for dat., cp. Eur. IA 338 tw=| dokei=n me\n ou)xi\ xrh/|zwn, tw=| de\ bou/lesqai qe/lwn.

div1.p: First sta/simon. Teiresias has just denounced Oedipus. Why do not the Chorus at once express their horror? This ode is the first since v. 215, and therefore, in accordance with the conception of the Chorus as personified reflection, it must comment on all that has been most stirring in the interval. Hence it has two leading themes: (1) “Who can be the murderer?”: 1st strophe and antistrophe, referring to vv. 216-315. (2) “I will not believe that it is Oedipus”: n)d strophe and antistrophe, referring to vv. 316-462. 1st strophe (463-472). Who is the murderer at whom the Delphic oracle hints? He should fly: Apollo and the Fates are upon him. 1st antistrophe (473-482). The word has gone forth to search for him. Doubtless he is hiding in waste places, but he cannot flee his doom. 2nd strophe (483-497). Teiresias troubles me with his charge against Oedipus: but I know nothing that confirms it. 2nd antistrophe (498-512). Only gods are infallible; a mortal, though a seer, may be wrong. Oedipus has given proof of worth. Without proof, I will not believe him guilty.

div2.p: qespie/peia giving divine oracles(e)/ph), fem. as if from qespieph/s (not found): cp. a)rtie/peia, h(due/peia. Since qe/-sp-i-s already involves the stem sep (Curt. E. sect. 632), the termination, from vep(ib. 620), is pleonastic.

Delfi\s pe/tra The town and temple of Delphi stood in a recess like an amphitheatre, on a high platform of rock which slopes out from the south face of the cliff: Strabo 9. 418 oi( *delfoi/, petrw=des xwri/on, qeatroeide/s, kata\ korufh\n(i.e. at the upper part of the rocky platform, nearest the cliff) e)/xon to\ mantei=on kai\ th\n po/lin, stadi/wn e(kkai/deka ku/klon plhrou=san: i.e. the whole sweep of the curve extends nearly two miles. HH Apoll. 283 u(/perqen | pe/trh e)pikre/matai (the rocky platform overhangs the Crisaean plain) koi/lh d' u(pode/drome bh=ssa (the valley of the Pleistus).

ei)=pe tele/santa (for ei)=pe tele/sai) is somewhat rare, but is not “a solecism” (as Kennedy calls it): cp. Soph. OC 1580 le/cas *oi)di/poun o)lwlo/ta: Eur. Rhes. 755 au)da=| cumma/xous o)lwlo/tas: Plat. Gorg. 481c po/tero/n se fw=men nuni\ spouda/zonta h)\ pai/zonta;

a)/rrht' a)rrh/twn Blaydes cp. Soph. OC 1237 pro/panta | kaka\ kakw=n, Soph. Phil. 65 e)/sxat' e)sxa/twn, Aesch. Pers. 681 w)= pista\ pistw=n h(/like/s t' h(/bhs e)mh=s, | *pe/rsai ge/rontes. Cp. also 1301 mei/zona tw=n maki/stwn. (But Soph. El. 849 deilai/a deilai/wn [kurei=s], cited by Blaydes, and by Jelf sect. 139, is not in point.)

a)ella/dwn Soph. OC 1081 a)ellai/a taxu/rrwstos peleia/s: fr. 621 a)ella/des fwnai/. Not, “daughters of the storm,” as if alluding to the mares impregnated by Boreas, Hom. Il. 20.221. For the form, cp. qusta/das lita/s Soph. Ant. 1019.
i(/ppwn instead of i(/ppwn podo/s: Hdt. 2.134 purami/da de\ kai\ ou(=tos a)peli/peto pollo\n e)la/ssw tou= patro/s: Xen. Cyrop. 3.3.41 xw/ran e)/xete ou)de\n h(=tton e)/ntimon tw=n prwtostatw=n.
steropai=s The oracular Apollo is *dio\s profh/ths. As punisher of the crime which the oracle denounced, he is here armed with his father's lightnings, not merely with his own arrow (205).

gene/tas, one concerned with ge/nos, either passively, = “son,” as here (cp. ghgene/ta| Eur. Phoen. 128), or actively, = “father.” Eur. has both senses. Cp. gambro/s, sonin-law, brother-in-law, or father-in-law: and so khdesth/s or penqero/s could have any one of these three senses.

*kh=res avenging spirits, identified with the Furies in Aesch. Seven 1055 *kh=res *)erinu/es, ai(/ t' *oi)dipo/da | ge/nos w)le/sate. Hes. Th. 217 (*nu\c) kai\ *moi/ras kai\ *kh=ras e)gei/nato nhleopoi/nous| ai(/ t' a)ndrw=n te qew=n te paraibasi/as e)fe/pousai | ou)de/pote lh/gousi qeai\ deinoi=o xo/loio, | pri/n g' a)po\ tw=| dw/wsi kakh\n o)/pin, o(/stis a(ma/rth|. The *moi=rai decree, the *kh=res execute. In Soph. Trach. 133 kh=res = calamities.

a)napla/khtoi not erring or failing in pursuit: cp. Soph. Trach. 120 a)lla/ tis qew=n | ai)e\n a)nampla/khton *(/aida sfe do/mwn e)ru/kei, some god suffers not Heracles to fail, but keeps him from death. Metre requires here the form without m. a)mplakei=n is prob. a cognate of pla/zw (from stem plag for plak, Curt. Etym. 367), strengthened with an inserted m; cp. a)/brotos, a)/mbrotos.
e)/lamye see on 186.

tou= nifo/entos the message flashed forth like a beacon from that snow-crowned range which the Thebans see to the west. I have elsewhere noted some features of the view from the Dryoscephalae pass over Mount Cithaeron:—“At a turn of the road the whole plain of Boeotia bursts upon the sight, stretched out far below us. There to the north-west soars up Helicon, and beyond it, Parnassus; and though this is the middle of May, their higher cliffs are still crowned with dazzling snow. Just opposite, nearly due north, is Thebes, on a low eminence with a range of hills behind it, and the waters of Lake Copais to the north-west, gleaming in the afternoon sun.” (Modern Greece, p. 75.)

Join to\n a)/dhlon a)/ndra, and take pa/nta as neut. plur., “by all means.” The adverbial pa/nta is very freq. in Soph., esp. with adj., as Soph. Aj. 911 o( pa/nta kwfo/s, o( pa/nt' a)/i+dris: but also occurs with verb, as Soph. Trach. 338 tou/twn e)/xw ga\r pa/nt' e)pisth/mhn e)gw/: Here, the emphasis on pa/nta would partly warrant us in taking it as acc. sing. masc., subject to i)xneu/ein. But, though the masc. nominative pa=s sometimes = pa=s tis, it may be doubted whether Soph. would have thus used the ambiguous pa/nta alone for the acc. sing. masc. Ellendt compares 226, but there pa/nta is acc. plur. neut.

pe/tras i)so/tauros is J. F. Martin's and E. L. Lushington's brilliant emendation of petrai=os o( tau=ros, the reading of the first hand in L. It is at once closer to the letters, and more poetical, than pe/tras a(/te tau=ros (Dorville, —where the use of a(/te is un-Attic), pe/tras i)/sa tau/rois (M. Schmidt), or pe/tras w(s tau=ros, which last looks like a prosaic correction. I suppose the corruption to have arisen thus. A transcriber who had before him *p*e*t*r*a*s*i*s*o*t*a*u*r*o*s took the first O for the art., and then amended *p*e*t*r*a*s*i*s into the familiar word *p*e*t*r*a*i*o*s. With a cursive MS. this would have been still easier, since in petrasisotauros the first s might have been taken for o (not a rare mistake), and then a simple transposition of i and the supposed o would have given petraios. It is true that such compounds with i)so usu. mean, not merely “like,” but “as good as” or “no better than”: e.g. i)sodai/mwn, i)so/qeos, i)so/nekus, i)so/neiros, i)so/pais, i)so/presbus. Here, however, i)so/tauros can well mean “wild” or “fierce of heart” as a bull. And we know that in the lost *kre/ousa Soph. used i)soqa/natos in a way which seemed too bold to Pollux (6. 174 ou) pa/nu a)nekto/n), —probably in the sense of “dread as death” (cp. Soph. Aj. 215 qana/tw| ga i)/son pa/qos e)kpeu/sei). The bull is the type of a savage wanderer who avoids his fellows. Soph. in a lost play spoke of a bull “that shuns the herd,” Bekk. Anecd. 459.31 a)timage/lhs: o( a)posta/ths th=s a)ge/lhs tau=ros: ou(/tw *sofoklh=s. Verg. Georg. 3.225 (taurus) Victus abit, longeque ignotis exulat oris. Theocr. 14.43 ai)=no/s qhn le/getai/ tis, e)/ba kai\ tau=ros a)n' u(/lan: a proverb e)pi\ tw=n mh\ a)nastrefo/ntwn(schol.). The image also suggests the fierce despair of the wretched outlaw: Aesch. Lib. 275 a)poxrhma/toisi zhmi/ais taurou/menon, “stung to fury by the wrongs that keep me from my heritage”: Eur. Med. 92 o)/mma tauroume/nhn: Aristoph. Frogs 804 e)/bleye gou=n taurhdo
 e)gku/yas ka/tw: Plat. Phaedo 117b taurhdo
 u(poble/yas pro\s to
 a)/nqrwpon. With regard to the reading petrai=os o( tau=ros, see Appendix.

xhreu/wn solitary, as one who is a)frh/twr, a)qe/mistos, a)ne/stios(Hom. Il. 9.63): he knows the doom which cuts him off from all human fellowship (236 f.). Aesch. Eum. 656 poi/a de\ xe/rniy frate/rwn prosde/cetai;

ta\ meso/mfala ga=s mantei=a = ta\ a)po\ me/sou o)mfalou= ga=s: Soph. El. 1386 dwma/twn u(po/stegoi = u(po\ ste/gh| dwma/twn: Eur. Phoen. 1351 leukoph/xeis ktu/pous xeroi=n. The o)mfalo/s in the Delphian temple (Aesch. Eum. 40), a large white stone in the form of a half globe, was held to mark the spot at which the eagles from east and west had met: hence Pindar calls Delphi itself me/gan o)mfalo\n eu)ruko/lpou |xqono/s(Pind. N. 7.33): Liv. 38.48 Delphos, umbilicum orbis terrarum.

a)ponosfi/zwn trying to put away (from himself): the midd. (cp. 691) would be more usual, but poetry admits the active: 894 yuxa=s a)mu/nein: Eur. Orest. 294 a)naka/lupteka/ra: Pind. P. 4.106 komi/zwn = komizo/menos (seeking to recover): Soph. OC 6 fe/ronta = fero/menon. In Soph. Phil. 979 a)ponosfi/zein tina/ tinos= to rob one of a thing: but here we cannot render “frustrating.”
zw=nta “ living,” i.e. operative, effectual; see on 45 zw/sas.

peripota=tai the doom pronounced by Apollo hovers around the murderer as the oi(=stros around some tormented animal: he cannot shake off its pursuit. The haunting thoughts of guilt are objectively imaged as terrible words ever sounding in the wanderer's ears.

The Chorus have described the unknown murderer as they imagine him—a fugitive in remote places. They now touch on the charge laid against Oedipus, —but only to say that it lacks all evidence. deina\ me
 ou)=n. ou)=n marks the turning to a new topic, with something of concessive force: “ it is true that the murderer is said to be here”: me
 is answered by de\ after le/cw. For me
 ou)=n with this distributed force, cp. Soph. OC 664, Soph. Ant. 65: for the composite me
 ou)=n( = “nay rather”), below, 705.

deina\ is adverbial: for (1) tara/ssei could not mean kinei=, stirs up, raises, dread questions: (2) dokou=nta, a)pofa/skonta are acc. sing. masc., referring to me understood. The schol., ou)/te pista\ ou)/te a)/pista, has favoured the attempt to take the participles as acc. neut. plur., a)pofa/skonta being explained as “negative” in the sense of “admitting of negation,” a)po/fasin kai\ a)pisti/an dexo/mena (Triclinius). This is fruitless torture of language. Nor will the conj. a)pare/skont' (Blaydes) serve: for, even if the Chorus found the charge credible, they would not find it pleasing. dokou=nta is not “believing,” but “approving.” Cp. Soph. Ant. 1102 kai\ tau=t' e)painei=s kai\ dokei=s pareikaqei=n; “and you recommend this course, and approve of yielding?” The pregnant force of dokou=nta is here brought out by the direct contrast with a)pofa/skonta. In gauging the rarer uses of particular words by an artist in language so subtle and so bold as Soph. we must never neglect the context.
le/cw probably deliberative aor. subj.: though it might be fut. indic. (cp. 1419, and n. on Soph. OC 310).

e)nqa/de the actual situation, implies the known facts of the past; o)pi/sw refers to the seer's hint of the future (v. 453 fanh/setai k.t.l.): cp. Hom. Od. 2.482 sei=o d', *)axilleu=, | ou)/tis a)nh\r propa/roiqe maka/rtatos, ou)/t' a)/r' o)pi/ssw (nor will be hereafter).

h)\ *labdaki/dais h)\ tw=| *polu/bou A quarrel might have originated with either house. This is what the disjunctive statement marks: since e)/keito, “had been made,” implies “had been provoked.” But we see the same Greek tendency as in the use of te kai/ where kai/ alone would be more natural: Aesch. PB 927 to/ t' a)/rxein kai\ to\ douleu/ein di/xa : cp. Hor. Ep. 1.2.12 Inter Hectora Priamiden animosum atque inter Achillen.

pro\s o(/tou In the antistr., 509, the words ga\r e)p' au)tw=| are undoubtedly sound: here then we need to supply ¯¯ ˘˘ or ˘ ¯¯ ˘. I incline to believe that the loss has been that of a participle going with basa/nw|. Had this been basani/zwn, the iteration would help to account for the loss. Reading pro\s o(/tou dh\ basani/zwn basa/nw|, I should take pro\s with basa/nw|: “testing on the touchstone whereof” —“using which(nei=kos) as a test.” [Receiving my basani/zwn, Kennedy (ed. 1885) replaces the word basa/nw| by piqanw=s.] To Brunck's basa/nw| xrhsa/menos (Plat. Laws 946c basa/nois xrw/menoi) the objections are (1) the aorist part. where we need the pres., (2) the tame and prosaic phrase. Wolff writes, pro\s o(/tou dh/, basa/nw| <pi/stin e)/xwn>: Wecklein and Mekler (in his recension of Dindorf's ed., Teubner, 1885) indicate a lacuna, ¯˘˘¯, after basa/nw|. Two other courses of emendation are possible: (i) To supply after e)/maqon something to express the informant, as tinos a)stw=n or, profe/rontos, when pro\s o(/tou would mean “at whose suggestion.” This remedy seems to me improbable. (ii) To supply su/n and an adj. for basa/nw|, as su\n a)lhqei= b., or b. su\n fanera=|. As the mutilated verse stands in the MSS., it cannot, I think, be translated without some violence to Greek idiom. The most tolerable version would be this: —“setting out from which(pro\s o(/tou neut., referring to nei=kos), I can with good warrant(basa/nw|) assail the public fame of Oed.” Then basa/nw| would be an instrumental dative equivalent to ba/sanon e)/xwn: and pro\s o(/tou would be like 1236 pro\s ti/nos pot' ai)ti/as; Soph. Ant. 51 pro\s au)tofw/rwn a)mplakhma/twn: pro/s denoting the source back to which the act can be traced.

e)pi\ fa/tin ei)=mi a phrase from war: it is unnecessary to suppose tmesis: Hdt. 1.157 strato\n e)p' e(wuto\n i)o/nta: Eur. IA 349 tau=ta me/n se prw=t' e)ph=lqon, i(/na se prw=q' hu(=ron kako/n, censured thee: Eur. Andr. 688 tau=t' eu)= fronw=n s' e)ph=lqon, ou)k o)rgh=s xa/rin.

The gen. qana/twn after e)pi/kouros is not objective, “against” (as Xen. Mem. 4.3.7 pu=re)pi/kouronyu/xous), but causal, “on account of”; being softened by the approximation of e)pi/kouros to the sense of timwro/s: Eur. El. 135 e)/lqois tw=nde po/nwn e)moi\ ta=| mele/a| luth/r, |patri/ q' ai(ma/twn | e)xqi/stwn e)pi/kouros(= “avenger”). The allusive plur. *qana/twn is like ai(ma/twn there, and despotw=n qana/toisi Aesch. Lib. 52: cp. above 366, toi=s filta/tois.

It is true (ou)=n, cp. 483) that gods indeed (me/n) have perfect knowledge. But there is no way of deciding in a strict sense (a)lhqh/s) that any mortal who essays to read the future attains to more than I do— i.e. to more than conjecture: though I admit that one man may excel another in the art of interpreting omens according to the general rules of augural lore (sofi/a|: cp. sofo\s oi)wnoqe/tas 484). The disquieted speaker clings to the negative argument: “Teiresias is more likely to be right than a common man: still it is not certain that he is right.”
ple/on fe/retai achieves a better result, —deserves to be ranked above me: Hdt. 1.31 doke/wn pa/gxu deuterei=a gw=n oi)/sesqai, “thinking that he was sure of the second place at least.”

cit.quote: mh/ ti/s se la/qh| | troxaloi=sin o(/xois parameiyame/nh |a)ph/nh.

div2.p:
pri
 i)/doim' After an optative of wish or hypothesis in the principal clause, pri/n regularly takes optat.: Soph. Phil. 961 o)/loio mh/pw pri
 ma/qoim' ei) kai\ pa/lin | gnw/mhn metoi/seis. So after o(/pws, o(/stis, i(/na, etc.: Aesch. Eum. 297 e(/lqoi| o(/pws ge/noito: Eur. Hel. 435 ti/s a)
mo/loi | o)/stis diaggei/leie;

o)rqo)n the notion is not “upright,” established, but “straight,” — justified by proof, as by the application of a rule: cp. Aristoph. Birds 1004 o)rqw=| metrh/sw kano/ni prostiqei/s: so below, 853, Soph. Ant. 1178 tou)/pos w(s a)/r' o)rqo\n h)/nusas. Hartung (whom Wolff follows) places the comma ofter o)rqo/n, not after e)/pos: “ until I see (it) established, I will not approve the word of censurers”: but the acc. e)/pos could not be governed by katafai/hn in this sense.

cit.quote: a)du/naton a(/ma katafa/nai kai\ a)pofa/nai a)lhqw=s.
a)lh/qeia e(/cis e)n katafa/sei kai\ a)pofa/sei.

div2.p: e)p' au)tw=| against him: cp. Soph. OC 1472.
ptero/essako/ra the Sphinx having the face of a maiden, and the winged body of a lion: Eur. Phoen. 1042 a( pterou=ssa parqe/nos. See Appendix, n. on v. 508.

*basa/nw| with a(du/polis only, which, as a dat. of manner, it qualifies with nearly adverbial force: commending himself to the city under a practical test. — i.e. e)/rgw| kai\ ou) lo/gw|. Pind. P. 10.67 peirw=nti de\ kai\ xruso\s e)n basa/nw| pre/pei | kai\ no/os o)rqo/s: “an upright mind, like gold, is shown by the touchstone, when one assays it”: as base metal tri/bw| te kai\ prosbolai=s | melampagh\s pe/lei | dikaiwqei/s Aesch. Ag. 391.

a(du/polis in the sense of a(nda/nwn th=| po/lei (cp. Pind. N. 8.38 a)stoi=s a)dw/n): boldly formed on the analogy of compounds in which the adj. represents a verb governing the accus., as filo/polis = filw=n th
 po/lin, o)rqo/polis (epithet of a good dynasty) = o)rqw=n th
 po/lin (Pind. O. 2.7). In Soph. Ant. 370 u(yi/polis is analogous, though not exactly similar, if it means u(yhlo\s e)n po/lei, and not u(yhlh
 po/lin e)/xwn (like dikaio/polis = dikai/as po/leis e)/xousa, of Aegina, Pind. P. 8.22).
tw=| “therefore,” as Hom. Il. 1.418 etc.; joined with nu/, Hom. Il. 7.352 etc.: Plat. Theaet. 179d tw=| toi, w)= fl*/)e *qeo/dwre, ma=llon skepte/on e)c a)rxh=s.

a)p' on the part of: Soph. Trach. 471 ka)p' e)mou= kth/sei xa/rin. The hiatus after tw=| is an epic trait, occasionally allowed in tragic lyrics, as in the case of interjections (cp. Soph. Phil. 832 n.). Here the stress on tw=|, and the caesura, both excuse it. Cp. Soph. Aj. 194 a)ll' a)/na e)c e(dra/nwn: Soph. El. 148 a(\ *)/itun: Soph. El. 157 oi(/a *xruso/qemis zw/ei kai\ *)ifia/nassa (cp. Hom. Il. 9.145). Neither pro\s (Elmsley) nor par' (Wolff) is desirable.

div1.p: e)peiso/dion deu/teron, with kommo/s (649-697). Oedipus upbraids Creon with having suborned Teiresias. The quarrel is allayed by Iocasta. As she and Oedipus converse, he is led to fear that he may unwittingly have slain Laius. It is resolved to send for the surviving eye-witness of the deed. Oedipus had directly charged Creon with plotting to usurp the throne (385). Creon's defence serves to bring out the character of Oedipus by a new contrast. Creon is a man of somewhat rigid nature, and essentially matter-of-fact. In his reasonable indignation, he bases his argument on a calculation of interest (583), insisting on the substance in contrast with the show of power, as in the Antigone his vindication of the written law ignores the unwritten. His blunt anger at a positive wrong is softened by no power of imagining the mental condition in which it was done. He cannot allow for the tumult which the seer's terrible charge excited in the mind of Oedipus, any more than for the conflict of duties in the mind of Antigone.

div2.p: a)tlhtw=n The verb a)tlhte/w, found only here, implies an active sense of a)/tlhtos, impatiens: as mempto/s, pass. in Soph. OC 1036, is active in Soph. Trach. 446. So from the act. sense of the verbal adj. come a)laste/w, a)naisqhte/w, a)naisxunte/w, a)nelpiste/w, a)prakte/w.

pro/s g' e)mou= Soph. Trach. 738 ti/ d' e)sti/n, w)= pai=, pro/s g' e(mou= stugou/menon; The conj. pro/s ti/ mou was prompted by the absence of ti with fe/ron: but cp. Aesch. Ag. 261 su\ d' ei)/te (v. l. ei)/ ti) kedno
 ei)/te mh\ pepusme/nh: Plat. Soph. 237c xalepo
 h)/rou: Plat. Meno 97e tw=n e)kei/nou poihma/twn lelume/non me
 e)kth=sqai ou) pollh=s tinos a)/cio/n e)sti timh=s.
For the single ei)/te, cp. Soph. Trach. 236: Plat. Laws 907d e)a/n tis a)sebh=| lo/gois ei)/t' e)/rgois: Pind. P. 4.78 cei=nos ai)/t' w)\n a)sto/s.

fe/ron 519 fe/ronti: 520 fe/rei: such repetitions are not rare in the best Greek and Latin writers. Cp. 158, 159 (a)/mbrot'), 1276, 1278 (o(mou=), Lucr. 2.54-59 tenebris—tenebris—tenebris—tenebras. See on Soph. OC 554, Soph. Ant. 76.

bi/ou tou= makr Soph. Aj. 473 tou= makrou= xrh/|zein bi/ou: Soph. OC 1214 ai( makrai\ | a(me/rai, where the art. refers to the normal span of human life. For bi/os makrai/wn cp. Soph. Trach. 791 duspa/reunon le/ktron.

ei)s a(plou=n The charge does not hurt him in a single aspect only,—i.e. merely in his relation to his family and friends (i)di/a|). It touches him also in relation to the State (koinh=|), since treachery to his kinsman would be treason to his king. Hence it “tends to the largest result” (fe/rei e)s me/giston), bearing on the sum of his relations as man and citizen. The thought is, h( zhmi/a ou)x a(plh= e)stin a)lla\ polueidh/s (cp. Plat. Phaedrus 270d a(plou=n h)\ polueide/s e)stin): but the proper antithesis to a(plh= is merged in the comprehensive me/giston.
a)lla\me\n dh\ cp. Soph. Trach. 627.

h)=lqeta/x' a)
, “might perhaps have come.” h(=lqen a)
 is a potential indicative, denoting for past time what e)/lqoi a)
 denotes for future time. That is, as e)/lqoi a)
 can mean, “it might come,” so h)=lqen a)
 can mean, “it might have come.” h)=lqen a)
 does not necessarily imply that the suggested possibility is contrary to fact; i.e., it does not necessarily imply, a)ll' ou)k h)=lqen. Cp. Dem. 37.57 pw=s a)
 o( mh\ parw
e)gw/ ti/ se h)di/khsa; “how was I likely to do you any wrong?” [This was the view taken in my first edition. Goodwin, in the new ed. of his Moods and Tenses (1889), has illustrated the “potential” indicative with a)/n (sect. 244), and has also shown at length that h)=lqen a)
 does not necessarily imply the unreality of the supposition (sect. 412). This answers the objection which led me, in a second edition, to suggest that tax' a)
 was here no more than ta/xa, and that the usage arose from an ellipse (h)=lqe, ta/xa d' a)
 e)/lqoi). In Soph. OC 964 ff. also I should now take h)=nta/x' a)
 as = “perchance it may have been.”]

I formerly kept tou= pro\s d', with L. But the anastrophe of pro/s seems to be confined to instances in which it is immediately followed by an attributive genitive, equiv. to an epithet: see on 178. For pro\s tou= d' we could indeed cite Aesch. Eum. 593 pro\s tou= d' e)pei/sqhs kai\ ti/nos bouleu/masin; But I now prefer tou)/pos d', because (1) Creon seems to ask the Chorus for a confirmation of the almost incredible report that Oed. had brought such a charge: he would naturally be less concerned to know whether any one had uttered it before Oed. (2) Verse 527 favours tou)/pos. —Cp. 848 a)ll' w(s fane/n ge tou)/pos.
hu)da=to these things were said (by Oedipus); but I do not know how much the words meant; i.e. whether he spoke at random, or from information which had convinced his judgment.

The reading e)c o)mma/twn d' o)rqw=n te gives a fuller emphasis than e)c o)mma/twn o)rqw=n de\: when d' had been omitted, te was naturally changed to de/. The place of te (as to which both verse and prose allowed some latitude) is warranted, since o)mma/twn-o)rqw=n opposed to o)pqh=s freno/s forms a single notion. e)c= “with”: Soph. El. 455 e)c u(perte/ras xero/s: Soph. Trach. 875 e)c a)kinh/tou podo/s. o)mma/twn o)rqw=n: cp. 1385: Soph. Aj. 477 kei) mh\ to/d' o)/mma kai\ fre/nes dia/strofoi | gnw/mhs a)ph=|can th=s e)mh=s: Eur. Her. 931 (when the frenzy comes on Heracles) o( d' ou)ke/q' au(to\s h)=n, | a)ll' e)n strofai=sin o)mma/twn e)fqarme/nos, k.t.l. In Hor. Carm. 1.3.18 Bentley gave rectis oculis for siccis.

ou)k oi)=d' Creon has asked: “Did any trace of madness show itself in the bearing or in the speech of Oedipus?” The Chorus reply: “Our part is only to hear, not to criticise.” These nobles of Thebes (1223) have no eyes for indiscretion in their sovereign master.
Join ou(=tos su/: cp. 1121: Eur. Hec. 1280 ou(=tos su/, mai/nei kai\ kakw=n e)ra=|s tuxei=n; where ou(=tos, su\ mai/nei is impossible.
to/lmhs gen. of quality (or material); cp. Soph. Ant. 114 xio/nos pte/rugi: Soph. El. 19 a)/strwn eu)fro/nh.
toso/nde to/lmhs-pro/swpon like tou)mo\n frenw=n-o)/neiron (Soph. El. 1390), nei=kos-a)ndrw=n cu/naimon (Soph. Ant. 793).

th=s e)mh=s closely follows tou=de ta)ndro/s, as Soph. OC 1329: so Soph. Aj. 865 muqh/somai immediately follows *ai)/as qroei=. If a Greek speaker rhetorically refers to himself in the third person, he usu. reverts as soon as possible to the first.

e)/n moi The MSS. have e)n e)moi/, making a verse like Soph. Trach. 4, e)gw\ | de\ to
 e)m|o/n, kai\ pri
 ei)s *(/aidou molei=n. But such a verse is rare, and unpleasing. When a tribrach holds the second place in a tragic senarius, we usually find that (a) the tribrach is a single word, as Soph. Phil. 1314 h(/sqhn | pate/ra | to
 a)mo
 eu)logou=nta/ se: or (b) there is a caesura between the first and the second foot, as Soph. OC 26 a)ll' o(/s|tis o( to/p|os: Soph. Phil. 1232 par' ou)=per e)/labon: Eur. Tro. 496 truxhr|a\ peri\ | truxhro
 ei(me/nhn xro/a: Eur. Phoen. 511 e)lqo/nt|a su
 o(/pl|ois to/nde kai\ porqou=nta gh=n, —if there we should not read e)lqo/nt' e)n o(/plois. On such a point as e)moi\ versus moi the authority of our MSS. is not weighty. And the enclitic moi suffices: for in this verse the stress is on the verbal notion (i)dw/n), — Creon's supposed insight: the reference to Oedipus is drawn out in the next two verses by the verbs in the 1st person, gnwrioi=mi—a)lecoi/mhn.

i)dw/ne)n prose would say e)nidw/n, either with or without e)n (Thuc. 1.95: o(/per kai\ e)n tw=| *pausani/a| e)nei=don: 3. 30 o(\toi=s polemi/ois e)norw=n): cp. Hdt. 1.37 ou)/te tina\ deili/hn paridw/n moi (remarked in me) ou)/te a)qumi/hn. poei=n; Attic inscrr. of c. 450-300 B.C. omit the i before e or h (not before o or w), as L usu. does, when the 1st syll. is short: Soph. Phil. 120 n.

h)\ tou)/rgon k.t.l. Supply nomi/sas or the like from i)dw/n: “thinking that either I would not see,or would not ward it off”: an example of what Greek rhetoric called xiasmo/s (from the form of X), since the first clause corresponds with mwri/a, and the second with deili/a.

gnwrioi=mi “Futures in -i)sw are not common in the good Attic period: but we have no trustworthy collections on this point”: Curtius, Verb 11.312, Eng. tr. 481. On the other hand, as he says, more than 20 futures in -iw= can be quoted from Attic literature. And though some ancient grammarians call the form “Attic,” it is not exclusively so: instances occur both in Homer (as Hom. Il. 10.331 a)glai+ei=sqai, cp. Monro, Hom. Gram. §63) and in Herodotus (as Hdt. 8.68 a)tremiei=n, besides about ten other examples in Hdt.). Thus the evidence for gnwrioi=mi outweighs the preference of our MSS. for gnwri/soimi.

h)\ ou)k The kou)k of the MSS. cannot be defended here—where stress is laid on the dilemma of deili/a or mwri/a— by instances of h)/te carelessly put for h)/—h)/ in cases where there is no such sharp distinction of alternatives: as Hom. Il. 2.289 h)\ pai=des nearoi\ xh=rai/ te gunai=kes: Aesch. Eum. 524 h)\ po/lis broto/s q' o(moi/ws.
a)lecoi/mhn see on 171.

plh/qous refers to the rank and file of the aspirant's following, —his popular partisans or the troops in his pay; *fi/lwn, to his powerful connections, —the men whose wealth and influence support him. Thus (542) xrh/masin is substituted for fi/lwn. Soph. is thinking of the historical Greek tu/rannos, who commonly began his career as a demagogue, or else “arose out of the bosom of the oligarchies” (Grote, vol. 3 p. 25).

o(\ a thing which, marking the general category in which the turanni/s is to be placed: cp. Xen. Mem. 3.9.8 fqo/non de\ skopw=n o(/ ti ei)/h. So the neut. adj. is used, Eur. Hipp. 109 terpno\n| tra/peza plh/rhs: Eur. Hel. 1687 gnw/mhs, o(\ pollai=s e)n gunaici\n ou)k e)/ni.

oi)=sq' w(s po/hson; In more than twelve places of the tragic or comic poets we have this or a like form where a person is eagerly bespeaking attention to a command or request. Instead of oi)=sq' w(s dei= se poih=sai; or oi)=sq' w(/s se keleu/w poih=sai; the anxious haste of the speaker substitutes an abrupt imperative: oi)=sq' w(s poi/hson; That the imperative was here felt as equivalent to “you are to do,” appears clearly from the substitutes which sometimes replace it. Thus we find (1) fut. indic.; Eur. Cycl. 131 oi)=sq' ou)=n o(\ dra/seis; Eur. Med. 600 oi)=sq' w(s meteu/cei kai\ sofwte/ra fanei=; where the conjectures dra=son (Canter) and me/teucai (Elmsley) are arbitrary: so with the 1st pers., Eur. IT 759 a)ll' oi)=sq' o(\ dra/sw; (2) a periphrasis: Eur. Supp. 932 a)ll' oi)=sq' o(\ dra=n se bou/lomai tou/twn pe/ri; Only a sense that the imperat. had this force could explain the still bolder form of the phrase with 3rd pers.: Eur. IT 1203 oi)=sqa/ nun a(/ moi gene/sqw = a(\ dei= gene/sqai moi: Aristoph. Ach. 1064 oi)=sq' w(s poiei/tw = w(s dei= poiei=n au)th/n, where poiei=te is a conjecture. There is no reason, in logic or in grammar, against this “subordinate imperative,” which the flexible Greek idiom allowed. Few would now be satisfied with the old theory that oi)=sq' w(s poi/hson stood, by transposition, for poi/hson, oi)=sq' w(s;

For kako\s with inf., cp. Thuc. 6.38 sect. 2 h(mei=s de\ kakoi\profula/casqai. sou=, emphatic by place and pause: cp. Soph. El. 1505 xrh=n d' eu)qu\s ei)=nai th/nde toi=s pa=sin di/khn | o(/stis pe/ra pra/ssein ge tw=n no/mwn qe/lei, | ktei/nein: to\ ga\r panou=rgon ou)k a)\n h)=n polu/.
hu(/rhk' as to the augment, cp. 68 n.

tou=t' au)to\ k.t.l. Oedipus flings back Creon's phrases, as the Antigone of Aeschylus bitterly echoes those of the kh=ruc (au)dw=—au)dw=—traxu/s—tra/xun', Aesch. Seven 1042 ff.). An accent of rising passion is similarly given to the dialogue between Menelaus and Teucer (Soph. Aj. 1142 h)/dh pot' ei)=don a)/ndr' e)gw/— 1150 e)gw\ de/ g' a)/ndr' o)/pwpa). Aristophanes parodies this style, Aristoph. Ach. 1097 *l*a*m*a*x*o*s. pai=, pai=, fe/r' e)/cw deu=ro to\n gu/lion e)moi/. *d*i*k*a*i*o*p*o*l*i*s. pai=, pai=, fe/r' e)/cw deu=ro th\n ki/sthn e)moi/.
w(s e)rw= how I will state this very matter (my supposed hostility to you): i.e. in what a light I will place it, by showing that I had no motive for it.
kth=ma cp. Soph. Ant. 1050 o(/sw| kra/tiston kthma/twn eu)bouli/a.
au)qadi/an poet. for au)qa/deian (Aesch. PB 79, etc.).
tou= nou= xwri/s for au)qa/deia is not necessarily devoid of intelligence: as Heracles says (Eur. Her. 1243) au)/qades o( qeo/s: pro\s de\ tou\s qeou\s e)gw/.

h)\ ou)k Aesch. Seven 100 a)kou/et' h)\ ou)k a)kou/et' a)spi/dwn ktu/pon; Hom. Od. 4.682 h)\ ei)pe/menai dmwh=|sin *)odussh=os qei/oio. Such “synizesis” points to the rapidity and ease of ancient Greek pronunciation: see J. H. H. Schmidt, Rhythmik und Metrik §3 (p. 9 of Eng. tr. by Prof. J. W. White).

While such words as a)risto/mantis, o)rqo/mantis are seriously used in a good sense, semno/mantis refers ironically to a solemn manner: cp. semnologei=n, semnoproswpei=n, semnopanou=rgos, semnopara/sitos, etc.

au(to/s “I am the same man in regard to my opinion” (dat. of respect): not, “am identical with my former opinion” (when the dat. would be like *foi/bw| in 285). Thuc. can dispense with a dative, 2. 61 kai\ e)gw\ me\n o( au)to/s ei)mi kai\ ou)k e)ci/stamai: though he adds it in 3. 38 e)gw\ me\n ou)=n o( au)to/s ei)mi th=| gnw/mh|.
de/drake Creon has heard only what Oedipus said of him: he does not yet know what Teiresias said of Oedipus (cp. 574). Hence he is startled at the mention of Laius.
ou) ga\r e)nnow= i.e. “I do not understand what Laius has to do with this matter.”

xeirw/mati deed of a (violent) hand: Aesch. Seven 1022 tumbo/xoa xeirw/mata= service of the hands in raising a mound. In the one other place where Aesch. has the word, it means “prey” (Aesch. Ag. 1326 dou/lhs qansu/shs eu)marou=s xeirw/matos): Soph. uses it only here (though he has dusxei/rwma Soph. Ant. 126): Eur. never.

makroi\ k.t.l.: long and ancient times would be measured; i.e. the reckoning of years from the present time would go far back into the past; makroi\ denoting the course, and palaioi/ the point to which it is retraced. Some sixteen years may be supposed to have elapsed since the death of Laius.

e)n th=| te/xnh| slightly contemptuous. e)n of a pursuit or calling: Hdt. 2.82 tw=n *(ellh/nwn oi( e)n poih/sei geno/menoi: Thuc. 3.28 oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasi: Isoc. 2.18 oi( e)n tai=s o)ligarxi/ais kai\ tai=s dhmokrati/ais (meaning, the administrators thereof): Plat. Phaedo 59a w(s e)n filosofi/a| h(mw=n o)/ntwn: Plat. Laws 762a tw=n e)n tai=s gewrgi/ais: Plat. Prot. 317c (Protagoras of himself as a sofisth/s) polla/ ge e)/th h)/dh ei)mi\ e)n th=| te/xnh|.

ou)damou= with e(stw=tos pe/las, “when I was standing anywhere near”; but equivalent in force to, “on any occasion when I was standing near”: cp. Soph. Aj. 1281 o(\n ou)damou= fh\s ou)de\ sumbh=nai podi/.

pare/sxomen we held it, as in duty bound: pare/xein, as distinct from e)/xein, expressing that it was something to be expected on their part. Cp. Soph. OC 1498 dikai/an xa/rin parasxei=n paqw/n. For pare/sxomen after e)/sxomen cp. 133 e)paci/wsa)ci/ws: 575 maqei=n: 576 e)kma/nqan.

toso/nde g' If we read to\ so
 de/ g', the coarse and blunt to\ so
 would destroy the edge of the sarcasm. Nor would to\ so
 consist so well with the calm tone of Creon's inquiry in 571. toso/nde does not need de/ after it, since oi)=sqa is a mocking echo of oi)=da. Cp. Eur. IT 554 OP. pau=sai/ nun h)/dh, mhd' e)rwth/sh|s pe/ra. *i*f. toso/nde g', ei) zh=| tou= talaipw/rou da/mar. Against the conject. to/son de/ g' it is to be noted that Soph. has to/sos only in Soph. Aj. 185 (lyric, to/sson), 277 (di\s to/s'), and Soph. Trach. 53 fra/sai to\ so/n.

The simple answer would have been: —“that you prompted him to make his present charge”: but this becomes: —“that, if you had not prompted him, he would never have made it.” cunh=lqe: Aristoph. Kn. 1300 fasi\n a)llh/ais sunelqei=n ta\s trih/reis e)s lo/gon, “the triremes laid their heads together”: Aristoph. Kn. 467 i)di/a| d' e)kei= toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois cuggi/gnetai.
ta\s e)ma\s the conject. ta/sd' e)ma\s mars the passage: “he would never have described this slaying of L. as mine.”

ou)k a)
 ei)=pe ta\s e)ma\s *lai/+ou diafqora/s = ou)k a)
 ei)=pen o)/ti e)gw\ *la/i+on die/fqeira, but with a certain bitter force added;—“we should never have heard a word of this slaying of Laius by me.” Soph. has purposely chosen a turn of phrase which the audience can recognise as suiting the fact that Oed. had slain Laius. For diafqora/s instead of a clause with diafqei/rein, cp. Thuc. 1.137 gra/yas th
 e)k *salami=nos proa/ggelsin th=s a)naxwrh/sews kai\ th
 tw=n gefurw=nou) dia/lusin.

To write sou= instead of sou is not indeed necessary; but we thus obtain a better balance to ka)mou=. —maqei=n tau)/q', to question in like manner and measure. tau=q' (MSS.) might refer to the events since the death of Laius, but has less point.
ou) ga\r dh\ rejects an alternative: here, without ge, as Soph. Ant. 46: more often with it, as Soph. OC 110 (n.).

gh/mas e)/xeis simply, I think, =gega/mhkas, though the special use of e)/xein (Hom. Od. 4.569 e)/xeis *(ele/nhn kai/ sfin gambro\s *dio/s e)ssi) might warrant the version, “hast married, and hast to wife.”

gh=s with a)/rxeis: i)/son ne/mwn explains tau)ta/,— “with equal sway” (cp. 201 kra/th ne/mwn, and 237): gh=s i)/son ne/mwn would mean, “assigning an equal share of land.” The special sense of ne/mwn is sufficiently indicated by the context; cp. Pind. P. 3.70 o(\s *surako/ssaisi ne/mei basileu/s (rules at S.).

tri/tos marking the completion of the lucky number, as Soph. OC 8, Soph. Aj. 1174, Aesch. Eum. 759 (tri/tou | *swth=ros): Menand. Sent. 231 qa/lassa kai\ pu=r kai\ gunh\ tri/ton kako/n. For the gen. e)mou=, cp. 1163 (tou).
e)ntau=qa ga\r (yes indeed:) for otherwise your guilt would be less glaring; it is just this fact that deprives it of excuse.

didoi/hs lo/gon Hdt. 3.25 lo/gon e(wutw=| dou\s o(/tie)/melle k.t.l. “on reflecting that,” etc.: Dem. 45.7 (the speech prob. belongs to the time of Dem.) lo/gon d' e)mautw=| didou\s eu(ri/skw k.t.l. Distinguish the plur. in Plato's poiki/lh| poiki/lous yuxh=|didou\s lo/gous, applying speeches (Plat. Phaedrus 277c).
ou)/t' au)to\s would have been naturally followed by ou)/t' a)/llw| parainoi=m' a)/n, but the form of the sentence changes to ou)/t' a)/llos (i(mei/rei).
e)k sou= e)k is here a correct substitute for para/, since the king is the ultimate source of benefits: Xen. Hell. 3.1.6 e)kei/nw| d' au(/th h( xw/ra dw=ron e)k basile/ws e)do/qh.
fe/rw = fe/romai, as 1190, Soph. OC 6 etc.
ka)\n a)/kwn he would do much of his own good pleasure, but much also (kai\) against it, under pressure of public duty.
ou)/pw ironical: see on 105.

ta\ su
 ke/rdei kala/: honours which bring substantial advantage (real power and personal comfort), as opp. to honours in which outward splendour is joined to heavier care. Soph. El. 61 dokw= me/n, ou)de
 r(h=ma su
 ke/rdei kako/n: i.e. the sound matters not, if there is ke/rdos, solid good.

pa=si xai/rw “all men wish me joy”: lit. “I rejoice with the consent of all men”: all are content that I should rejoice. Cp. Soph. OC 1446 a)na/ciai ga\r pa=si/n e)ste dustuxei=n, all deem you undeserving of misfortune: Aristoph. Birds 445 pa=si nika=n toi=s kritai=s | kai\ toi=s qeatai=s pa=si. The phrase has been suggested by xai=re/ moi, but refers to the meaning rather than to the form of the greeting: i.e. pa=si xai/rw is not to be regarded as if it meant literally, “I have the word xai=re said to me by all.” This is one of the boldly subtle phrases in which the art of Soph. recalls that of Vergil. Others understand: (1) “I rejoice in all,” —instead of suspecting some, as the tu/rannos does, who fqone/eitoi=si a)ri/stoisixai/rei de\ toi=si kaki/stoisi tw=n a)stw=n Hdt. 3.80: (2) “I rejoice in relation to all”— i.e. am on good terms with all: (3) “I rejoice in the sight of all”: i.e. enjoy a happiness which is the greater because men see it: (4) “I rejoice in all things.” This last is impossible. Of the others, (1) is best, but not in accord with the supposed position of Oedipus o( pa=si kleino/s.

e)kkalou=si Those who have a boon to ask of Oed. come to the palace (or to Creon's own house, see on 637) and send in a message, praying Creon to speak with them. Seneca's Creon says (Oed. 687) Solutus onere regio, regni bonis Fruor, domusque civium coetu viget. In Greek tragedy the king or some great person is often thus called forth. Cp. Aesch. Lib. 663: Orestes summons an oi)ke/ths by knocking at the e(rkei/a pu/lh, and, describing himself as a messenger, says —e)celqe/tw tis dwma/twn telesfo/ros | gunh\ to/parxos, —when Clytaemnestra herself appears. So in Eur. Ba. 170 Teiresias says —ti/s e)n pu/laisi *ka/dmon e)kkalei= do/mwn; “where is there a servant at the doors to call forth Cadmus from the house?” —i)/tw tis, ei)sa/ggelle *teiresi/as o(/ti | zhtei= nin: then Cadmus comes forth. The active e)kkalei=n is properly said (as there) of him who takes in the message, the middle e)kkalei=sqai of him who sends it in (Hdt. 8.19): but in Soph. Phil. 1264 e)kkalei=sqe (n.) is an exception. Musgrave's ai)ka/llousi is not a word which a man could complacently use to describe the treatment of himself by others. ai)/kalos. ko/lac Hesych. (for a)k-i/alos, from the same rt., with the notion of soothing or stilling, as a)kei=sqai, h)=ka, a)ke/wn, a)/kaska, a)kaskai=os): Aristoph. Kn. 47 u(popesw\n to\n despo/thn | h)/|kall', e)qw/peu', e)kola/keu', “fawned, wheedled, flattered”: in tragedy only once, Eur. Andr. 630 fi/lhm' e)de/cw, prodo/tin ai)ka/llwn ku/na.

to\tuxei=n sc. w(=n xrh/|zousin. The reading a(/pant', whether taken as accus. after tuxei=n (“to gain all things”), or as accus. of respect (“to succeed in all”) not only mars the rhythm but enfeebles the sense. When au)toi=si was corrupted into au)toi=s, pa=n was changed into a(/pan, as it is in L. e)ntau=qa = e)n tw=| e)kkalei=n me, in gaining my ear: cp. Soph. OC 585 e)ntau=qa ga/r moi kei=na sugkomi/zetai, in this boon I find those comprised.

pw=s dh=t' Cp. Hdt. 5.106 (Histiaeus to Dareius) basileu=, koi=on e)fqe/gcao e)/pos; e)me\ bouleu=sai prh=gma e)k tou= soi/ ti h)\ me/ga h)\ smikro
 e)/melle luphro
 a)nasxh/sein; ti/ d' a)
 e)pidizh/menos poie/oimi tau=ta; teu= de\ e)ndeh\s e)w/n, tw=| pa/ra me
 pa/nta o(/saper soi/, pa/ntwn de\ pro\s se/o bouleuma/twn e)pakou/ein a)cieu=mai:

ou)k a)\n ge/noito k.t.l. Creon has been arguing that he has no motive for treason. He now states a general maxim, “No mind would ever turn to treason, while it was sound.” As a logical inference, this holds good only of those who are in Creon's fortunate case. If, on the other hand, kalw=s fronw=n means “alive to its own highest good,” and not merely to such self-interest as that of which Creon has spoken, then the statement has no strict connection with what precedes: it becomes a new argument of a different order, which might be illustrated from Plato's kako\s e(kw\n ou)dei/s. It would be forcing the words to render: “A base mind could not approve itself wise,” i.e. “such treason as you ascribe to me would be silly.”
e)/legxon accus. in apposition with the sentence: Eur. Her. 57 h( duspraci/a | h)=s mh/poq', o(/stis kai\ me/sws eu)/nous e)moi/, | tu/xoi, fi/lwn e)/legxon a)yeude/steton.
tou=t' a)/llo = tou=to de/. Soph. has tou=to me/n irregularly followed by tou=t' au)=qis (Soph. Ant. 165), by ei)=ta (Soph. Phil. 1345), by de/ (Soph. Aj. 670, Soph. OC 440).

tw=| terasko/pw| This title (given to Apollo, Aesch. Eum. 62) has sometimes a shade of scorn, as when it is applied by the mocking Pentheus to Teiresias (Eur. Ba. 248), and by Clytaemnestra to Cassandra (Aesch. Ag. 1440).
xwri\s “apart”: i.e. solely on the strength of your own guess (gnw/mh a)/dhlos), without any evidence that I falsified the oracle or plotted with the seer.

to\n par' au(tw=| bi/oton k.t.l.: the life is hospes comesque corporis, dearest guest and closest companion: cp. Plat. Gorg. 479b mh\ u(giei= yuxh=| sunoikei=n: and the address of Archilochus to his own qumo/s as his trusty ally (Bergk fr. 66), —qume/, qu/m' a)mhxa/noisi kh/desin kukw/mene, | e)na/deu, dusmenw=n d' a)le/ceu prosbalw\n e)nanti/on | ste/rnon.
filei= sc. tis, supplied from au(tw=|: Hes. WD 12 th\n me/n ken e)painh/seie noh/sas | h( d' e)pimwmhth/.
xro/nos cp. Pind. fr. 132 a)ndrw=n dikai/wn xro/nos swth\r a)/ristos: Pind. O. 2.53 o(/ t' e)cele/gxwn mo/nos | a)la/qeian e)th/tumon | xro/nos.

kako
 de\ the sterling worth of the upright man is not fully appreciated until it has been long tried: but a knave is likely (by some slip) to afford an early glimpse of his real character. The Greek love of antithesis has prompted this addition, which is relevant to Creon's point only as implying, “if I had been a traitor, you would probably have seen some symptom of it ere now.” Cp. Pind. P. 2.90 (speaking of the fqoneroi/): sta/qmas de/ tinos e(lko/menoi | perissa=s e)ne/pacan e(/lkos o)dunaro
 e(a=| pro/sqe kardi/a|, | pri
 o(/sa fronti/di mhti/ontai tuxei=n. Soph. Ant. 493 filei= d' o( qumo\s pro/sqen h(|rh=sqai klopeu\s | tw=n mhde
 o)rqw=s e)n sko/tw| texnwme/nwn.
The infin. *fronei=n is like an accus. of respect (e.g. boulh/n) construed with both adjectives: “in counsel, the quick are not sure.” Cp. Thuc. 1.70 e)pinoh=sai o)cei=s.
taxu/s tis xwrh=| advances in quick fashion; nearly = taxe/ws pws. Soph. Aj. 1266 feu=, tou= qano/ntos w(s taxei=a/ tis brotoi=s | xa/ris diarrei=, in what quick sort does it vanish.

ti/ dh=ta xrh/|zeis;to\ gou=n e)mo/n. (1) Verse 624, o(/tan prodei/ch|s k.t.l., which the MSS. give to Creon, belongs to Oedipus: and for o(/tan we should (I think) read w(s a)\n. The argument that the stichomuthia should not be broken shows inattention to the practice of Soph. He not seldom breaks a stichomuthia, when a weighty utterance (as here, the king's threat) claims the emphasis of two verses. See (e.g.) 356-369, broken by 366 f. (the seer's denunciation): Soph. Ant. 40-48, broken by 45 f. (Antigone's resolve): Soph. OC 579-606, broken by 583 f. (where Theseus marks the singularity in the proposal of Oed.). (2) Verse 625 w(s ou)x u(pei/cwn k.t.l., which the MSS. give to Oedipus, belongs to Creon. (3) Between 625 and 626 a verse spoken by Oedipus has dropped out, to such effect as ou) ga/r me pei/qeis ou(/nek' ou)k a)/pistos ei)=. The fact of the next verse, our 626, also beginning with ou) ga\r may have led to the loss by causing the copyist's eye to wander. The echoed ou) ga\r would suit angry dialogue: cp. 547, 548 KP. tou=t' au)to\ nu=n mou prw=t' a)/kouson w(s e)rw=. *o*i. tou=t' au)to\ mh/ moi fra/z'. (See also on Soph. Phil. 1252.) The traditional interpretations fail to justify (1) oi(=o/n e)sti to\ fqonei=n, as said by Creon: (2) pisteu/swn, as said by Oed. See Appendix.

a)rkte/on = dei= a)/rxein, one must rule: cp. Soph. Ant. 677 a)munte/' e)sti\ toi=s kosmoume/nois. Isoc. 14.10 ou) tw=n a)/llwn au)toi=s a)rkte/on (they ought not to rule over others) a)lla\ polu\ ma=llon *)orxomeni/ois fo/ron oi)ste/on. In Plat. Tim. 48b a)rkte/on = dei= a)/rxesqai, one must begin; in Soph. Aj. 853 a)rkte/on to\ pra=gma = must be begun. Some understand— “one must be ruled,” and ou)/toi kakw=s g' a)/rxontos,“ No, not by one who rules ill”: but (a) though a)rkte/a po/lis might mean, “the city is to be ruled,” an absolute passive use of a)rkte/on is certainly not warranted by such an isolated example as ou) kataplhkte/on e)sti/n (“we must not be unnerved”) in Din. 1.108: (b) a)/rxomai/ tinos, “I am ruled by one” (instead of e)k or u(po/), could only plead the analogy of a)kou/w tino/s, and lacks evidence.

a)/rxontos when one rules. a)rkte/on being abstract, “it is right to rule,” there is no harshness in the gen. absol. with tino/s understood (cp. 612), which is equivalent to e)a/n tis a)/rxh|: cp. Dem. 6.20 le/gontos a)/n tinos pisteu=sai oi)/esqe; “think you that, if any one had said it, they would have believed?” = oi)/esqe, ei)/ tis e)/lege, pisteu=sai a)\n (au)tou/s);

w(= po/lis po/lis here, an appeal: in Attic comedy, an exclamation like o tempora, o mores: Blaydes cp. Eupolis ap. Athen. 424b w)=| po/lis, po/lis | w(s eu)tuxh\s ei)= ma=llon h)\ kalw=s fronei=s: and so Aristoph. Ach. 27.

po/lews Most of the MSS. have me/testi th=sd' ou)xi/. Had they me/testi th=sd' ou) (which appears only in a few inferior MSS.) we should hardly be warranted in ejecting th=sd': but, having the choice, we may safely prefer me/testin ou)xi\ to me/testi th=sd' ou). “I have some right in Thebes, as well as you.” Creon speaks not as a brother of Iocasta, but as a Theban citizen who denies that “the city belongs to one man” (Soph. Ant. 737). Plat. Laws 768b dei= de\ dh\ kai\ tw=n i)di/wn dikw=n koinwnei=n kata\ du/namin a(/pantas' o( ga\r a)koinw/nhtos w)\n e)cousi/as tou= sundika/zein h(gei=tai to\ para/pan th=s po/lews ou) me/toxos ei)=nai.
oi)/kous (the king's palace), acc. after ei)= (cp. 533); kata\ with ste/gas only, referring to the house of Creon, who is not supposed to be an inmate of the palace: see 515, 533.

to\ mhde
 a)/lgos the generic use of mh/ (“a grief such as to be naught,” —quod nihili sit), here giving a causal force (“seeing that it is naught”): cp. 397, 1019; Soph. El. 1166 de/cai| th
 mhde
 e)s to\ mhde/n: ei)s me/ga fe/rein, make into a great matter: cp. (Soph. Phil. 259) no/sos | a)ei\ te/qhle ka)pi\ mei=zon e)/rxetai.

duoi=na)pokri/nas kakoi=n The traditional reading, dra=saiduoi=n, is the only extant example of duoi=n scanned as one syllable, though in the tragic poets alone the word occurs more than 50 times. Synizesis of u is rare in extant Greek poetry: Pind. P. 4.225 genu/¯wn: Anthol. 11.413 (epigram by Ammianus, 1st century A.D.) w)/kimon, h(du/¯osmon, ph/ganon, a)spa/ragos. Eur. IT 970 o(/sai d' *)erinu/¯wn ou)k e)pei/sqhsan no/mw|, and Eur. IT 1456 oi)/strois *)erinu/¯wn, where most editors write *)erinu=n, as Eur. IT 299 *)erinu=s (acc. plur.). Hes. Sh. 3 *)hlektru/¯wnos. It might be rash to say that Soph. could not have used duoi=n as a monosyllable; for he has used the ordinary synizesis in a peculiarly bold way, Soph. Aj. 1129 mh/ nun a)ti/ma qeou\s qeoi=s seswme/nos: but at least it moves the strongest suspicion. a)pokri/nas, on the other hand, seems genuine. a)pokri/nein is properly secernere to set apart: e.g. gh=n (Plat. Rep. 303d): or to select: Plat. Laws 946a plh/qei tw=n yh/fwn a)pokri/nantas, having selected (the men) according to the number of votes for each. Here, “having set apart (for me) one of two ills” is a phrase suitable to the arbitrary rigour of doom which left a choice only between death and exile. For duoi=n Elms. proposed toi=nd' or toi=nde/ g': Herm., toi=nd' e(/n: A. Spengel, dei/n'. I should rather believe that dra=n was altered into dra=sai by a grammarian who looked to a)pw=sai, ktei=nai, and perh. also sought a simpler order. But for pres. infin. combined with aor. infin. cp. 623 qnh/|skeinfugei=n: Soph. Ant. 204 mh/te kteri/zein mh/te kwku=sai. See also Soph. OC 732 h(/kw ga\r ou)x w(s dra=n ti boulhqei/s, where in prose we should have expected dra=sai. The quantity of a)po-kri/nas is supported by Aesch. PB 24 a)po-kru/yei: a)po-troph/ and its cognates in Aesch. and Eur.: e)pi-kru/pteinEur. Supp. 296: e)pi-kra/nwn Eur. IT 51. Blaydes conj. dou\s duoi=n kri=nai kakoi=n (i.e. “giving me my choice of two ills”; cp. Soph. OC 640 tou/twndi/dwmi/ soi | kri/nanti xrh=sqai): Dindorf, qa/teron duoi=n kakoi=n (where I should at least prefer kako/n): “but since, with either of these supposed readings, the construction would have been perfectly clear, it is hard to see how a)pokri/nas— a far-sought word—could have crept in as an explanatory gloss. That, however, is Whitelaw's view, who suggests that the original may have been something like fau=lon ai(/resi/n g' e)moi/. Wolff would compress vv. 640 f. into one, thus: dra=sai dikaioi=, dei/n', a)poktei=nai labw/n.

drw=nta kakw=s tou)mo\n sw=ma would properly describe bodily outrage: here it is a heated way of saying that Creon's supposed plot touched the person of the king (who was to be dethroned), and not merely the no/moi po/lews.
a)rai=os = w(/sper au)to\s e)parw=mai.

o(/rkon qew=n (object. gen.), an oath by the gods (since one said o)mnu/nai qeou/s): Hom. Od. 2.377 qew=n me/gan o(/rkon a)pw/mnu: 10. 299 maka/rwn me/gan o(/rkon o)mo/ssai: Eur. Hipp. 657 o(/rkois qew=n. But in Soph. OC 1767 *dio\s *(/orkos is personified.
The kommo/s (see p. 9) has a composite strophic arrangement: (1) 1st strophe, 649-659, (2) 2nd strophe, 660-668; answering respectively to (3) 1st antistr., 678-688, (4) 2nd antistr., 689-697.

qelh/sas having consented (pisteu/ein). Soph. OC 757 kru/yon (hide thy woes), qelh/sas a)/stu kai\ do/mous molei=n.Isaeus 8.11 tau=ta poih=sai mh\ qelh/sas. Plut. Mor. 149f sundeipnei=n mh\ qelh/santos.
fronh/sas having come to a sound mind. Isoc. 8.141 kalo/n e)stin e)n tai=s tw=n a)/llwn a)diki/ais kai\ mani/ais prw/tous eu)= fronh/santas prosth=nai th=s tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)leuqeri/as.

ei)ka/qw the aor. subj. is certainly most suitable here: Soph. Phil. 761 bou/lei la/bwmai; Soph. El. 80 qe/leis | mei/nwmen; In such phrases the pres. subj. (implying a continued or repeated act) is naturally much rarer: bou/lei e)piskopw=men Xen. Mem. 3.5.1. As regards the form of ei)ka/qw, Curtius (Verb 11. 345, Eng. tr. 505), discussing presents in -qw and past tenses in -qon from vowel stems, warns us against “looking for anything particularly aoristic in the q” of these verbs. In Greek usage, he holds, “a decidedly aoristic force” for such forms as sxeqei=n and ei)kaqei=n“ never established itself”: and he justly cites Soph. El. 1014 as a place where ei)kaqei=n is in no way aoristic. He would therefore keep the traditional accent, and write sxe/qein, ei)ka/qein, with Buttmann. Now, while believing with Curtius that these forms were prob. in origin presents, I also think that in the usage of the classical age they were often aorists: as e.g. sxeqei=n in Aesch. Seven 429 distinctly is.
ou)/te pri\nnu=n te cp. Soph. OC 1397 ff.

me/gan “great,” i.e. strong, worthy of reverence, e)n o(/rkw|, by means of, in virtue of, his oath: Eur. Tro. 669 cune/sei ge/nei plou/tw| te ka)ndrei/a| me/gan: for e)n, cp. Soph. Phil. 185 e)/n t' o)du/nais o(mou= | limw=| t' oi)ktro/s.

“That thou shouldest never lay under an accusation (e)n ai)ti/a| balei=n), so as to dishonour him (a)/timon), with the help of an unproved story (su
 a)fanei= lo/gw|), the friend who is liable to a curse (e)nagh=)”: i.e. who has just said (644) a)rai=os o)loi/man k.t.l. Aeschin. 3.110 ge/graptai ga ou(/tws e)n th=| a)ra=|: ei(/ tis ta/de, fhsi/, parabai/noi,e)nagh/s, fhsin, e)/stw tou= *)apo/llwnos, “let him rest under the ban of Apollo”: as Creon would rest under the ban of the gods by whom he had sworn. Hdt. 6.56 e)n tw=| a)/gei+ e)ne/xesqai, to be liable to the curse. e)n ai)ti/a| balei=n: Plat. Letter 7.341a w(s mhde/pote balei=n e)n ai)ti/a| to
 deiknu/nta a)ll' au)to
 au(to/n, “so that he may never blame his teacher, but only himself,” equiv. to e)mbalei=n ai)ti/a|: cp. the prose phrases e)mba/llein ei)s sumfora/s, grafa/s, e)/xqran, k.t.l. Eur. Tro. 305 ei)s e)/m' ai)ti/an ba/lh|. Seidler's su/ g' a)fanei= lo/gwn, which Wolff adopts, is specious.
ou) to\n = ou) ma\ to\n, as not seldom; usu. followed by a second negative (as if here we had ou)k e)/xw ta/nde fro/nhsin): 1088, Soph. Ant. 758, etc.

pro/mon standing foremost in the heavenly ranks, most conspicuous to the eyes of men: the god “who sees all things and hears all things” (Hom. Il. 3.277 o(\s pa/nt' e)fora=|s kai\ pa/nt' e)pakou/eis): invoked Soph. Trach. 102 as w)= kratisteu/wn kat' o)/mma.
o(/ ti pu/mato/n (e)sti), (tou=to) o)loi/man: schol. fqarei/hn o(/per e)/sxaton, h)/goun a)pw/leian h(/tis e)sxa/th.

ta\ d'—sfw=|n and, on the other hand, if the ills arising from you two are to be added to the former ills. Prof. Kennedy gives ta\ d', rightly, I think: for ga= fqi/nousa refers to the blight and plague (25): ta/d' would obscure the contrast between those troubles and the new trouble of the quarrel.

prosa/yei intrans., as perh. only here and in fr. 348 kai/ moi tri/ton r(i/ptonti| a)gxou= prosh=yen, “he came near to me.” Eur. Hipp. 188 to\ me/n e)stin a(plou=n: tw=| de\ suna/ptei | lu/ph te frenw=n xersi/n te po/nos, “is joined.” It is possible, but harsh, to make prosayei act. with gh= as subject. Since in 695 a)lu/ousan kat' o)rqo\n ou)ri/sas is clearly sound, Herm. rightly struck out kai\ before ta\ d' here. See on 696.
o( d' ou)=n then let him go: Soph. Aj. 114 su\ d' ou)=n| xrw= xeiri/.

e)leino/n tertiary predicate: “I compassionate thy words, piteous as they are.” Where a possessive pron. with art. has preceded the subst., Soph. sometimes thus subjoins and adj., which really has the predicative force to which its position entitles it, though for us it would be more natural to translate it as a mere attributive: Soph. Ant. 881 to
 d' e)mo
 po/tmon a)da/kruton | ou)dei\sstena/zei: Soph. Phil. 1456 tou)mo
 e)te/gxqh | kra=t' e)ndo/muxon: Soph. El. 1143 th=s e)mh=s pa/lai trofh=s | a)nwfelh/tou. In 1199 (where see note) ta
 gamy. parq. xrhsmw|do/n is not a similar case. Prof. Kennedy, placing a comma after e)poi/ktei/rw, but none after tou=d', construes: to\ so
 sto/ma e)leino/n (e)sti), ou)k e)poiktei/rw to\ tou=de.

stugh/setai pass. Other examples in Soph. are 1500 o)neidiei=sqe: Soph. OC 581 dhlw/setai, 1186 le/cetai: Soph. Ant. 210 timh/setai, 637 a)ciw/setai: Soph. El. 971 kalei=: Soph. Phil. 48 fula/cetai: among many found in prose as well as in verse are a)dikh/somai, a(lw/somai, e)a/somai, zhmiw/somai, timh/somai, w)felh/somai. The middle forms of the aorist were alone peculiar to that voice; the so-called “future middle,” like the rest, was either middle or passive.

stugno\spera/sh|s “thou art seen to be sullen when thou yieldest, but fierce when thou hast gone far in wrath”: i.e., as thou art fierce in passion, so art thou sullen in yielding. Greek idiom co-ordinates the clauses, though the emphasis is on stugno\s me\n ei)/kwn, which the other merely enforces by contrast: see on 419.

baru\s bearing heavily on the object of anger, and so, “vehement,” “fierce”: Soph. Aj. 1017 du/sorgos, e)n gh/ra| baru/s, Soph. Aj. 656 mh=nin barei=an: Soph. Phil. 1045 baru/s te kai\ barei=an o( ce/nos fa/tin th/nd' ei)=pe: Soph. Ant. 767 nou=s d' e)sti\ thlikou=tos a)lgh/sas baru/s.
pera/sh|s absol., = pro/sw e)/lqh|s: Soph. OC 154 pera=|as, (you go too far), Soph. OC 885 pe/ran | perw=s' oi(/de dh/.

qumou=, partitive gen.: cp. Hom. Il. 2.785 die/prhsson pedi/oio: Hdt. 3.105 prolamba/neinth=s o(dou=: sometimes helped by a prep. or adverbial phrase, as Xen. Apol. 30 probh/sesqai po/rrw moxqhri/as: 2 Epist. Tim. 2.16 e)pi\ plei=on ga\r proko/yousin a)sebei/as. —Others render: “resentful [or “remorseful”] even when thou hast passed out of wrath”: but (a) pera/sh|s with a simple gen. could not bear this sense: (b) the antithesis pointed by me\n and de\ is thus destroyed.

a)gnw=tos active, as in 681, 1133: but passive, “unknown,” Soph. Phil. 1008, Soph. Ant. 1001. Ellendt is not quite accurate in saying that Soph. was the first who used a)gnw/s in an active sense, for it is clearly active in Pind. P. 9.58 (478 B.C.) ou)/te pagka/rpwn futw=n nh/poinon ou)/t' a)gnw=ta qhrw=n (xqono\s ai)=san), “a portion of land not failing in tribute of plants bearing all manner of fruit, nor a stranger to beasts of chase.” The passive use was, however, probably older than the active: compare Hom. Od. 5.79 a)gnw=tesa)llh/loisi (pass.) with Thuc. 3.53 a)gnw=tes a)llhlwn (act.).

e)n de\ toi=sd' i)/sos: e)n of the tribunal or company by whom one is judged: Soph. Ant. 459 e)n qeoi=si th\n di/khn | dw/sein: Eur. Hipp. 988 oi( ga\r e)n sofoi=s | fau=loi par' o)/xlw| mousikw/teroi le/gein: and so, more boldly, Soph. OC 1213 skaiosu/nan fula/sswn e)n e)moi\ (me iudice) kata/dhlos e)/stai.

i)/sos aequus, just: Plat. Laws 975c to
 me/llonta dikasth
 i)/son e)/sesqai. Dem. 7.35 (by a contemporary of Dem.) i)/sw| kai\ koinw=| dikasthri/w|. So Soph. Phil. 685 i)/sos w)
 i)/sois a)nh/r. The Scholiast explains, para\ de\ tou/tois th=s o(moi/as do/chs h(
 kai\ prw/hn ei)=xon peri\ e)me/, i.e. “of the same repute as before.” To me such a version of i(/sos appears most strange.
Creon leaves the scene. The Chorus wish Iocasta to withdraw Oedipus also, that he may be soothed in the house: but she wishes first to learn how the dispute began.
maqou=sa/ g' sc. komiw=: cp. Soph. Trach. 335 (n.).

do/khsislo/gwn a suspicion resting on mere assertions (those made by Oedipus), and not supported by facts (e)/rga): hence a)gnw\s, unknowing, guided by no real knowledge. Thuc. 1.4 ou) lo/gwnko/mpos ta/de ma=llon h)\ e)/rgwn e)sti\n a)lh/qeia: 3. 43 th=s ou) bebai/ou dokh/sews.
da/ptei de\: Oedipus was incensed against Creon, without proof; on the other hand (de\) Creon also (kai\) was incensed by the unjust accusation.

da/ptei might be historic pres., but need not be so taken: Creon is still pained. Aesch. PB 437 sunnoi/a| de\ da/ptomai ke/ar. The version, “and even injustice wounds,” would make the words a reflection;—“An accusation galls, even when unfounded”: but this is unsuitable.

a)mfoi=n a)p' au)toi=n sc. h)=lqe to\ nei=kos; Thus far, Iocasta only knew that Oedipus charged Creon with treason. The words of the Chorus now hint that Oedipus himself was partly to blame. “So then,” Iocasta asks, “provocation had been given on both sides?”
lo/gos the story (of the alleged treason): for the words of Oed. (642 drw=nta kakw=s, te/xnh kakh/) had been vague.

proponoume/nas “already troubled,” not, “troubled exceedingly.” proponei=n always = to suffer before, or for: Luc. Iupp. Trag. 40 *)aqhna= *)/arhn katagwni/zetai, a)/te kai\ propeponhko/ta oi)=mai e)k tou= trau/matos, already disabled.
The evasive answer of the Chorus has nettled Oedipus by implying that the blame was divided, and that both parties ought to be glad to forget it. He could never forget it (672).

o(ra=|s i(/n' h(/keis conveys indignant reproach: a grave charge has been laid against your king; instead of meeting it with denial, you are led, by your sympathy with Creon, to imply that it cannot be directly met, and must be hushed up. Soph. Ant. 735 o(ra=|s ta/d' w(s ei)/rhkas w(s a)/gan ne/os: Soph. El. 628 o(ra=|s; pro\s o(rgh\n e)kfe/rei.

pariei\s with tou)mo\n ke/ar, seeking to relax, enervate, my resentment: a sense which the close connection with katamblu/nwn interprets, though the more ordinary meaning for pariei\s, had it stood alone here, would be “neglecting,” “slighting” (po/qos parei=, Soph. El. 545): cp. Aristoph. Kn. 436 tou= podo\s pari/ei, slack away (some of) the sheet: Eur. Cycl. 591 u(/pnw| pareime/nos: Eur. Orest. 210 tw=| li/an pareime/nw|, (neut.) by too great languor. Schneidewin understands, “neglecting my interest, and blunting (your) feeling”: but tou)mo\n must surely agree with ke/ar.

cit.quote:
e)pi\ me
 kalo
 h)\ xrhsto
 h)\ th=s po/lews a)/cion pra=gma ou)de
 ou(=to/s e)sti xrh/simos.

div2.p:
pefa/nqai a)
 oblique of pefasme/nos a)
 h)=n: for the tense cp. Isoc. 5.56 loipo
 a)
 h)=nei) mh\ e)pepoi/hto. Whitelaw, taking pefa/nqai m' a)/n as oblique of pefasme/nos a)
 ei)/hn, defends the ei)/ se nosfi/zomai of the MSS. by Plat. Phaedrus 228a ei) e)gw\ *fai=dron a)gnow=, kai\ e)mautou= e)pile/lhsmai, and Plat. Apol. 25b pollh\ a)/n tis eu)daimoni/a ei)/h peri\ tou\s ne/ous, ei) ei(=s me
 mo/nos au)tou\s diafqei/rei, k.t.l. But the playful or ironical tone which ei) with the pres. indic. gives to those passages seems hardly in place here. The change of one letter restores the required e)nosfizo/man.

o(/s te is not for o(/s, though in Soph. El. 151 a(/t = h(/, and Soph. Trach. 824 o(/t = o(/: rather te goes with ou)/risas: cp. Soph. El. 249 e)/rroi t' a)\n ai)dw\s | a(pa/ntwn t' eu)se/beia qnatw=n.
a)lu/ousan of one maddened by suffering, Soph. Phil. 1194 a)lu/onta xeimeri/w| lu/pa|. The conj. saleu/ousan is tame.

a)
 ge/noio The MSS. have ei) du/naio genou=: for du/naio, the 1st hand of L had written du/nai, i.e. du/na|. Now ei) du/na| genou= is satisfactory in itself, since du/na| for du/nasai has good authority in Attic, as Eur. Hec. 253 dra=|s d' ou)de
 h(ma=s eu)=, kakw=s d' o(/son du/na|. But then we must correct the strophe, 667, —as by writing there ta\ pro\s sfw=|n toi=s pa/lai prosa/yeton, which I should prefer to Nauck's ingenious prosa/yei toi=s pa/lai ta\ pro/sfata. Verse 667, however, seems right as it stands: it gives a better rhythm for the closing cadence than we should obtain by adding a syllable. And if so, ei) du/naio (or du/na|) genou= here must be reduced to ˘¯˘. (i) If with Hermann we simply omit genou=, the elliptical ei) du/naio— understanding i)/sqi or genou=— is intolerably harsh; to me it does not seem even Greek. (2) ei) ge/noio, “mayest thou become!” is read by Bergk and Dindorf; cp. 863 ei)/ moi cunei/h. (3) To this I much prefer a)
 ge/noio, which Blaydes adopts; but I do so for a reason which he does not give. I suspect that ei) du/naio was a marginal gloss intended to define the sense of a)
 ge/noio, and that a)
 ge/noio was corrupted to genou= when ei) du/naio had crept into the text. (4) Prof. Kennedy conjectures ei)= to/ g' e)/n soi: “now also | with thy best skill thou ably waftest.” Since the metre of 667 is not certainly sound, no treatment of our verse can be confident.
ka)/m' these men know it: allow me also to know it.
o(/toupra/gmatos causal gen.; Soph. Ant. 1177 patri\ mhni/sas fo/nou.
sth/sas e)/xeis hast set up, i.e. conceived as an abiding sentiment, referring to 672 and 689. Cp. Eur. IA 785 e)lpi\s| oi(/an| sth/sasai ta/d' e)s a)llh/las | muqeu/sousi (Fritzsch).

tw=nd' e)s ple/on = ple/on h)\ tou/sde, not ple/on h)\ oi(/de. The Chorus having hinted that Oedipus was partly to blame, he deigned no reply to their protests of loyalty (689 f.). But he respects Iocasta's judgment more, and will answer her
*kre/ontos, sc. sth/sas e)/xw th\n mh=nin: causal gen. answering to o(/tou pra/gmatos.
bebouleukw\s in this periphrasis, the perf. part. is rarer than the aor. part.: Soph. Phil. 600 n.
le/g' speak. if you can make a clear statement (ei) safw=s e)rei=s) in imputing the blame of the feud: i.e. if you are prepared to explain the vague oi(=a (701) by defining the provocation.
e)gkalei=n nei=ko/s (tini)= to charge one with (beginning) a quarrel: as Soph. Phil. 328 xo/lon (tino\s) kat' au)tw=n e)gkalw=n, charging them with having provoked your anger at a deed.
au)to\s cuneidw/s i.e. does he speak as from his own knowledge (of your guilt)?

me
 ou)=n “nay.” Soph. El. 1503. Aristoph. Kn. 13 *n*i. le/ge su/. *d*h. su\ me
 ou)=n le/ge. Distinguish me
 ou)=n in 483, where each word has a separate force.

to/ g' ei)s e(auto\n in what concerns himself: Eur. IT 691 to\ me\n ga\r ei)s e)/m' ou) kakw=s e)/xei. —pa=n e)leuqeroi=, sets wholly free (from the discredit of having brought such a charge): Soph. Ant. 445 e)/cw barei/as ai)ti/as e)leu/qeron: Plat. Laws 756d e)leu/qeron a)fei=sqai th=s zhmi/as.

a)fei\s seauto/n an appropriate phrase, since a)fie/nai was the regular term when the natural avenger of a slain man voluntarily released the slayer from the penalties: Dem. 38.59 a)
 o( paqw
 au)to\s a)fh=| tou= fo/nou to
 dra/santa: Antiph. 2.2 ou) to
 ai)/tion a)fe/ntes to
 a)nai/tion diw/komen.
ma/q' k.t.l.: learn that thou canst find no mortal creature sharing in the art of divination.

soi ethic dat.: e)sti
 e)/xon = e)/xei (Eur. Supp. 427 ti/ tou/twn e)sti
 ou) kalw=s e)/xon;): te/xnhs. partitive gen. The gods have prescience (498); but they impart it to no man, —not even to such ministers as the Delphian priests. Iocasta reveres the gods (647): it is to them, and first to Apollo, that she turns in trouble (911). But the shock which had befallen her own life, —when at the bidding of Delphi her first-born was sacrificed without saving her husband Laius—has left a deep and bitter conviction that no mortal, be he priest or seer, shares the divine foreknowledge. In the Greek view the ma/ntis might be (1) first, the god himself, speaking through a divinely frenzied being in whom the human reason was temporarily superseded (hence the popular derivation of mantikh/ from mani/a): Plat. Tim. 71e mantikh
 a)frosu/nh| qeo\s a)nqrwpi/nh| de/dwken: ou)dei\s ga e)/nnous e)fa/ptetai mantikh=s e)nqe/ou kai\ a)lhqou=s: this was much the same as the Egyptian belief, Hdt. 2.83 mantikh\ de\ au)toi=si w)=de diake/etai. a)nqrw/pwn me
 ou)deni\ proske/etai h( te/xnh, tw=n de\ qew=n metecete/roisi. (2) Secondly, the ma/ntis might be a man who reads signs from birds, fire, etc., by rule of mystic science: it was against this te/xnh that scepticism most readily turned: Eur. El. 399 *loci/ou ga e)/mpedoi | xrhsmoi/, brotw=n de\ mantikh
 xai/rein le/gw. Iocasta means: “I will not say that the message came through the lips of a truly god-possessed interpreter; but at any rate it came from the priests; it was an effort of human mantikh/.” So in 946, 953 qew=n manteu/mata are oracles which professed to come from the gods. Others render: — “Nothing in mortal affairs is connected with the mantic art”: i.e. is affected by it, comes within its ken. Then e)sti
 e)/xon will not stand for e)/xetai (which it could not do), but for e)/xei, as meaning “is of,” “belongs to.” Hdt. has e)/xein as = ei)=nai with expressions equivalent to an adverb, as Hdt. 2.91 a)gw=na gumniko
 dia\ pa/shs a)gwni/hs e)/xonta, “consisting in every sort of contest,” as he might have said polutro/pws e)/xonta: so Hdt. 3.128 peri\ pollw=n e)/xonta prhgma/twn (= pollaxw=s): Hdt. 6.42 kata\ xw/rhn (= e)mpe/dws) e)/xontes: Hdt. 7.220 e)n e)/pesie(came/troisi e)/xonta. But such instances are wholly different from the supposed use of e)/xein alone as = ei)=nai with a partitive genitive.

ou)k e)rw= k.t.l. The exculpation of Apollo himself here is obviously not inconsistent with 720, which does not ascribe the prediction to him. And in 853 (o(/n ge *loci/as | diei=pe) the name of the god merely stands for that of his Delphian priesthood.

h(/coi is better than the conject. e(/coi ( “constrain”), as expressing the suddenness with which the doom should overtake him. Soph. El. 489 h(/cei*)erinu/s. The simple acc. au)to\n, since h(/coi = katalh/yoito: cp. Hdt. 9.26 fame\n h(me/as i(kne/esqai h(gemoneu/ein, instead of e)s h(me/as (2. 29).
o(/seis ge/noit' is oblique for o(/stis a)\n ge/nhtai (whoever may be born), not for o(/stis e)ge/neto (who has been born): Laius received the oracle before the birth of the child.
ce/noi not Thebans, much less of his own blood.
See on 733.

die/sxon “Three days had not separated the child's birth from us”: three days had not passed since its birth. Plut. Tib. Gracch. 18 keleu/santos e)kei/nou diasxei=n to\ plh=qos, to keep the crowd off.

bla/stas cannot be acc. of respect (“as to the birth”), because die/sxon could not mean “had elapsed”: when die/xein is intrans. it means (a) to be distant, Thuc. 8.79 die/xei de\ o)li/gon tau/th| h( *sa/mos th=s h)pei/rou: or (b) to extend, Hdt. 4.42 diw/ruxadie/xousan e)s to\n *)ara/bion ko/lpon.
kai/ = o(/te (parataxis instead of hypotaxis): Thuc. 1.50 h)/dh de\ h)=n o)ye\kai\ oi( *kori/nqioi e)capi/nhs pru/mnan e)krou/onto.

a)/rqra podoi=n = ta\ sfura/: e)nzeu/cas, fastened together by driving a pin through them, so as to maim the child and thus lessen the chance of its being reared if it survived exposure: Eur. Phoen. 22 (Iocasta speaks) e)/speiren h(mi=n pai=da, kai\ spei/ras bre/fos, | gnou\s ta)mpla/khma tou= qeou= te th\n fa/tin, | leimw=n' e)s *(/hras kai\ *kiqairw=nos le/pas | di/dwsi bouko/loisin e)kqei=nai bre/fos, | sfurw=n sidhra= ke/ntra diapei/ras me/son (better me/swn), | o(/qen nin *(ella\s w)no/mazen *oi)di/poun. Seneca Oed. 812 Forata ferro gesseras vestigia, Tumore nactus nomen ac vitio pedum.

ei)s a)/baton o)/ros the tribrach contained in one word gives a ruggedness which is certainly intentional here, as in 1496 to\n pate/ra path/r, Soph. Aj. 459 pedi/a ta/de. A tribrach in the 5th place, always rare, usually occurs either when the penultimate word of the verse is a paeon primus (¯˘˘˘), as Soph. El. 326 e)nta/fia xeroi=n, or when the last word is a paeon quartus (˘˘˘¯), as Soph. Phil. 1302 a)/ndra pole/mion. Verse 967 below is exceptional.
ka)ntau=q' cp. 582.

It is more likely that, as our MSS. suggest, paqei=n should have been a commentator's conjecture than that qanei=n should have been a copyist's error (from v. 713). No objection can be drawn from the occurrence of pro\s paido\s qanei=n so soon after 713: see on 519.

toiau=tadiw/risan i.e. made predictions at once so definite and so false: fh=mai, a solemn word used scornfully: cp. 86. The sense of diw/risan in 1083 is slightly different: here we might compare Dem. 20.158 o( *dra/kwnkaqaro\n diw/risen ei)=nai, “has laid down that the man is pure.”

w(=n xrei/an e)reuna=|: a bold phrase blended, as it were, from w(=n a)\n xrei/an e)/xh| and a)\ a)\n xrh/sima (o)/nta) e)reuna=|: cp. Soph. Phil. 327 ti/nos| xo/lone)gkalw=n, instead of ti/nos xo/lon e)/xwn or ti/ e)gkalw=n.

The mention of “three roads” (716) has startled Oedipus. He now asks concerning (1) the place, (2) the time, (3) the person. The agreement of (1) with (2) dismays him; that of both with (3) flashes conviction to his mind.
pla/nhma denotes the fearful “wandering” of his thought back to other days and scenes; as e)/doc' (729) is the word of one who has been in a troubled dream.

poi/as mer. u(postr. having turned round on account of (= startled by) what care, —like a man whom a sound at his back causes to turn in alarm: —far more expressive than e)pistrafei/s, which would merely denote attention. For the gen., cp. Soph. Aj. 1116 tou= de\ sou= yo/fou | ou)k a)\n strafei/hn.
lh/cant' the breath of rumour is as a breeze which has not yet fallen: cp. Soph. Aj. 258 no/tos w(s lh/gei, and Soph. OC 517.

sxisth\ d' o(do/s In going from Thebes to Delphi, the traveller passes by these “Branching Roads,” —still known as the tri/odoi, but better as the steno/: from Daulia it is a leisurely ride of about an hour and a half along the side of Parnassus. The following is from my notes taken on the spot: — “A bare isolated hillock of grey stone stands at the point where our path from Daulia meets the road to Delphi, and a third road that stretches to the south. There, in front, we are looking up the road down which Oedipus came [from Delphi]; we are moving in the steps of the man whom he met and slew; the road runs up a wild and frowning pass between Parnassus on the right hand and on the left the spurs of the Helicon range, which here approach it. Away to the south a wild and lonely valley opens, running up among the waste places of Helicon, a vista of naked cliffs or slopes clothed with scanty herbage, a scene of inexpressible grandeur and desolation” (Modern Greece p. 79). At this sxisth\ o(do/s Pausanias saw ta\ tou= *lai/+ou mnh/mata kai\ oi)ke/tou tou= e(pome/nou: the legend was that Damasistratus king of Thebes had found the bodies and buried them (10. 5 sect. 4). The spot has a modern monument which appeals with scarcely less force to the imagination of a visitor, —the tomb of a redoubtable brigand who was killed in the neighbourhood many years ago.
