tau)to\ but in 325 tau)to\n: cp. Soph. Trach. 325 n. a)po\ with both genitives: cp. 761, 1205.

toi=sd' For the dat. cp. Hdt. 2.145 *dionu/sw| me/n nunkata\ e(cako/sia e)/tea kai\ xi/lia ma/lista/ e)sti e)s e)me/: *hrakle/i+ de\kata\ ei)nako/sia e)/tea: *pani\ de\ kata\ ta\ o)ktako/sia ma/lista e)s e)me/. Then from persons the idiom is transferred to things: Thuc. 3.29 h(me/rai ma/lista h)=san th=| *mutilh/na| e(alwkui/a| e(pta/.

sxedo/n ti pro/sqen The interval supposed between the death of Laius and the accession of Oedipus must be long enough to contain the process by which the Sphinx had gradually brought Thebes to despair: but Soph. probably had no very definite conception of it: see on 758.
w)= *zeu= A slow, halting verse, expressing the weight on his soul: the neglect of caesura has this purpose.

cit.quote: h( selh/nh e)klei/peikai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oie)pisxei=n e)ke/leuon tou\s strathgou/s, e)nqu/mion poiou/menoi.

div2.p: I do not believe that Soph., or any Greek, could have written fu/sin | ti/n' ei)=xe, fra/ze, ti/na d' a)kmh\n h(/bhs e)/xwn, which Herm. was inclined to defend as if ti/na fu/sin ei)=xe = ti/s h)=n fu/sin. Now ti/nos would easily pass into ti/na d' with a scribe who did not follow the construction; and to restore ti/nos seems by far the most probable as well as the simplest remedy. No exception can be taken to the phrase ti/nos a)kmh\n h(/bhs as = “the ripeness of what period of vigorous life.”

xnoa/zwn leukanqe\s ka/ra = e)/xwn xnoa/zon leukai=s ka/ra: Aristoph. Cl. 978 xnou=s w(/sper mh/loisin e)ph/nqei (the down on his chin was as the bloom on apples): here the verb marks the light strewing of silver in dark hair. Cp. Soph. El. 43 h)nqisme/non. As Aesch. has melanqe\s ge/nos, “swarthy” (Aesch. Supp. 154), so in Anthol. 12.165 (Jacobs 2.502) leukanqh/s = “of fair complexion” as opp. to meli/xrous.

ta/lās as being for ta/lans: Aristoph. Birds 1494 oi)/moi ta/las, o( *zeu\s o(/pws mh/ m' o)/yetai. In Anthol. 9.378 (Jac. 2.132) kai\ koimw= metaba/s, w)= ta/las, a)llaxo/qi, ta/lan is an easy remedy: but not so in Theocr. 2.4 a)f' w)= ta/las ou)de/poq' h(/kei, where pe/las has been conjectured.
e)/oikaou)k ei)de/nai = e)/oiken o(/ti ou)k h)/|dh: cp. 236 f.
kai\ mh\n “indeed” I fear (as you do): Soph. Ant. 221, Soph. El. 556.

a(
d' is certainly preferable to a(\ d' a)
 in a poet whose versification is not characterised by any love of unnecessary dia/lusis. Even in prose we find o(\s a)
 de/ instead of o(\s de\ a)/n, Hdt. 7.8.

baio/s identifies the chief with his retinue, —the adjective, when so used, suggesting a collective force like that of a stream, full or thin: so polu\s r\ei=, polu\s pnei= of vehement speech, etc.; Eur. Orest. 1200 h)\n polu\s parh=|, if he come in his might: suxno\n poli/xnion, a populous town (Plat. Rep. 370d).
loxi/tas cp. Aesch. Lib. 766 XO. pw=s ou)=n keleu/ei nin molei=n e)stalme/non; |h)\ cu\n loxi/tais ei)/te kai\ monostibh=; TP. a)/gein keleu/ei dorufo/rous o)pa/onas (said of Aegisthus).

kh=ruc as the meet attendant of a king on the peaceful and sacred mission of a qewro/s (114). The herald's presence would add solemnity to the sacrifice and libation at Delphi: Athen. 660 A e)/drwn (= e)/quon) de\ oi( kh/rukes a)/xri pollou=, bouqutou=nteskai\ skeua/zontes kai\ mistu/llontes, e)/ti de\ oi)noxoou=ntes. a)ph/nh h)=ge mi/a = mi/a h)=n a)ph/nh, h)\ h)=ge: Pind. N. 9.41 e)/nq' *)are/as po/ron a)/nqrwpoi kale/oisi = e)/nqa po/ros e)sti\n o)\n *)a. kalou=sin. The a)ph/nh, properly a mule-car (Pind. P. 4.94) but here drawn by colts (802), and in the Odyssey synonymous with a)/maca (Hom. Od. 6.37, 57), was a four-wheeled carriage used for travelling, as dist. from the two-wheeled war-chariot (a)/rma): its Homeric epithet u(yhlh/ indicates that it stood higher on its wheels than the a(/rma: it could be fitted with a frame or basket for luggage (u(perteri/h Hom. Od. 6.70, pei/rins Hom. Il. 24.190).

Cp. 118. oi)keu/s=oi)ke/ths, as in the Odyssey and in a no/mos *so/lwnos in Lys. 10.19, who explains it by qera/pwn. The Iliad has the word only twice, both times in plur., of “inmates” (slave or free: Hom. Il. 5.413: Hom. Il. 6.366).
h)= kai\ marks keen interest: Soph. El. 314 h)= ka)\n e)gw\ qarsou=sa ma=llon e)s lo/gous | tou\s sou\s i(koi/mhn;

The poet has neglected clearness on a minor point. The oi)keu/s— sole survivor of the four attendants—had fled back to Thebes with the news that Laius had been slain by robbers (118-123). This news came before the trouble with the Sphinx began: 126-131. And the play supposes an interval of at least several days between the death of Laius and the election of Oedipus: see on 736. Hence kei=qen h)=lqe kai\ei)=de cannot mean that the oi)keu/s, on reaching Thebes, found Oedipus already reigning. Nor can we suggest that he may have fled from the scene of the slaughter before he was sure that Laius had been killed: that is excluded by 123 and 737. Therefore we must understand:— “when he had come thence, and [afterwards] found that not only was Laius dead, but you were his successor.” (For the parataxis se/ te*la/i+o/n te see on 673.) I incline to suspect, however, that Sophocles was here thinking of the man as coming back to find Oedipus already on the throne, and had overlooked the inconsistency. The conjecture *lai/+ou te dw/mata for *la/i+o/n t' o)lwlo/ta (Wolff) would remove the difficulty, but seems very improbable.
xeiro\s qigw\n marking that the i(ketei/a was formal; as when the suppliant clasped the knees (a(/ptesqai gona/twn). Eur. Hec. 850 tu/xas se/qen, | *(eka/bh, di' oi)/ktou xei=ra/ q' i(kesi/an e)/xw.

a)grou/s might be acc. of motion to (Soph. OC 1769 qh/bas d' h(ma=s |pe/myon); but it is better here governed by e)pi\: for the position of the prep. cp. 734, 1205, Soph. El. 780 ou)/te nukto\s ou)/t' e)c h(me/ras.
noma/s on Cithaeron, or near it, 1127. The man had formerly served as a shepherd (1039), and had then been taken into personal attendance on Laius (oi)keu/s).

tou=d' a)/poptos a)/stews “far from the sight of this town”: that is, far from the power of seeing it: whereas in Soph. El. 1487 ktanw\n pro/qes |a)/popton h(mw=n= “far from our eyes”: the gen. as after words of “distance from.” See Appendix.

oi)=' the o(/ g' of L (clumsily amended to o( de/ g' in other MSS.) prob. came from oi(=', rather than from w(s or w(/s g'. Soph. Phil. 583 oi(=' a)nh\r pe/nhs, “for a poor man”: Eur. Orest. 32 ka)gw\ mete/sxon, oi(=a dh\ gunh/, fo/nou, “so far as a woman might.” w(s, however, is commoner in this limiting sense (1118); oi(=a more often = “like” (751). Here oi(=a qualifies a)/cios, implying that in strictness the faithful service of a slave could not be said to create merit.
fe/rein cp. 590.

pa/restin “it is easily done.” Eur. Ba. 843 *p*e. e)lqw/n g' e)s oi)/kous a)\n dokh=| bouleu/somai. | *d*i. e)/cesti: pa/nth| to/ g' e)mo\n eu)trepe\s pa/ra. Not, “he is here” (nor, “he is as good as here,” as the schol. explains): in 769 i(/cetai = “he will come from the pastures.”

di' a(/ The sense is: “I fear that I have spoken too many words; and on account of those words I wish to see him”: cp. 744, 324. Not: “I fear that my words have given me only too much cause to desire his presence.” A comma after moi is here conducive to clearness.
ka)gw\ and pou express the wife's sense that he should speak to her as to a second self.

e)n soi\ =within thee, in thy mind (not “in thy case”): cp. e)n with the reflexive pronouns, Plat. Theaet. 192d e)n e)mautw=| memnhme/nos: Plat. Crat. 384a prospoiou/meno/s ti au)to\s e)n e(autw=| dianoei=sqai.

e)s tosou=ton e)lpi/dwn Isoc. 8.31 ei)s tou=to ga/r tines a)noi/as e)lhlu/qasin: Aristoph. Cl. 832 su\ d' e)s tosou=ton tw=n maniw=n e)lh/luqas. The plural of e)lpi/s is rare as = anxious forebodings: but cp. 487.

mei/zoni strictly, “more important”: cp. Dem. 19.248 a)nti\th=s p*|olews th\n *fili/ppou ceni/an kai\ fili/an pollw=| mei/zona h(gh/sato au)tw=| kai\ lusiteleste/ran (alluding to Soph. Ant. 182 kai\ mei/zon' o(/stis a)nti\ th=s au(tou= pa/tras | fi/lon nomi/zei): Soph. Ant. 637 ou)dei\sga/mos | mei/zon' o(/stis qai sou= kalw=s h(goume/nou, no marriage can be a greater prize than your good guidance. The kai\ with le/caim' a)\n: — could I speak? Lys. 12.29 para\ tou= pote kai\ lh/yesqe di/khn; from whom will you ever exact satisfaction?
i)w/n present, not future, part.: Soph. Ant. 742 dia\ di/khs i)w\n patri/. Xen. Anab. 3.2.8 dia\ fili/as i)e/nai.

The epithet “Dorian” carries honour: Meropee was of the ancient stock, claiming descent from Dorus son of Hellen, who settled in the region between Oeta and Parnassus. The Scholiast's comment, *peloponnhsiakh/, forgets that the Theban story is laid in times before the Dorian conquest.

pri/n moie)pe/sth (1) pri/n with infin. = our “before,” whether the sentence is affirmative or negative: h)=lqe pri
 klhqh=nai, ou)k h)=lqe pri
 klhqh=nai. (2) pri/n with a finite mood (indic., subj., or opt.) = our “until” in negative sentences. Thus ou)k h)=lqe pri
 e)klh/qh differs from ou)k h)=lqe pri
 klhqh=nai by implying that at last he was called, and then came. Here, the form of the sentence is affirmative (h)go/mhn), and e(/ws would therefore be more strictly correct. But the thought is negative ( “nothing happened to disturb me”); hence pri/n. So Thuc. 3.29 tou\s*)aqhnai/ous lanqa/nousi (= ou)x o(rw=ntai u(po\ tw=n *)a.) pri
 dh\ th=| *dh/lw| e)/sxon. Cp. Whitelaw in Trans. Cam. Phil. Soc. 1886, p. 26.
e)pe/sth a verb often used of enemies suddenly coming upon one: Isoc. 9.58 mikrou= dei=n e)/laqen au)to\n e)pi\ to\ basi/leion e)pista/s: Hdt. 4.203 e)pi\ th=| *kurhnai/wn po/li e)pe/sthsan.

u(perplhsqei\s me/qh|, lit., intoxicated by drinking (caus. dat.): me/qh always = “drinking” (not “strong wine”): cp. Hdt. 5.20 kalw=s e)/xontasme/qhs (“having had enough of drinking”). For the dat. cp. Aesch. Pers. 132 le/ktrapi/mplatai dakru/masin.
par' oi)/nw|: Plut. Mor. 143c tou\s th=| lu/ra| xrwme/nous par' oi)=non. Thuc. 6.28 meta\ paidia=s kai\ oi)/nou.

plasto\s w(s ei)/hn instead of plasto/n, as if preceded by o)neidi/zei moi instead of kalei= me. Somewhat similarly o)noma/zw = le/gw, as Plat. Prot. 311e sofisth\no)noma/zousito\n a)/ndra ei)=nai. plasto\s, “feigned (in speech),” “falsely called a son,” patri/, “for my father,” i.e. to deceive him. Eur. Alc. 639 mastw=| gunaiko\s sh=s u(peblh/qhn la/qra, whence u(pobolimai=os = no/qos.

kate/sxon sc. e)mauto/n. In classical Attic this use occurs only here: in later Greek it recurs, as Plut. Artax. 15 ei)=pen ou)=n mh\ katasxw/n. u(mei=s me/n k.t.l. Cp. e)/xe, sxe/s, e)pi/sxes (“stop”), in Plat., Dem., etc.

tw=| meqe/nti: the reproach was like a random missile: Menander fr. 88 ou)/t' e)k xero\s meqe/nta kartero\n li/qon | r(a=|on katasxei=n, ou)/t' a)po\ glw/sshs lo/gon. The dat., because dusfo/rws tou)/neidos h)=gon = w)rgi/zonto e(/neka tou= o)nei/dous.
o(/mws d' cp. 791, and n. on 29.

u(fei=rpe ga\r polu/ so u(fe/rpein of malicious rumour, Aesch. Ag. 450 fqonero\n d' u(p' a)/lgos e(/rpei | prodi/kois *)atrei/dais. Libanius 784 A (quoted by Musgrave) polu\s toiou=tos u(fei=rpe lo/gos (perhaps suggested by this passage). Pind. I. 3.58 tou=to ga\r a)qa/naton fwna=en e(/rpei, | ei)/ tis eu)= ei)/ph| ti. Cp. Soph. Ant. 700 toia/d' e)remnh\ si=g' e)pe/rxetai fa/tis. For polu/ cp. Soph. OC 517 to\ polu/ toi kai\ mhdama\ lh=gon, that strong rumour which is in no wise failing: Soph. OC 305 polu\to\ so\n o)/noma | dih/kei pa/ntas. This version also agrees best with 775, which implies that the incident had altered his popular repute. We might render: “it was ever recurring to my mind with force”: but this (a) is a repetition: (b) is less suited to polu/, which implies diffusion.

w)=n i(ko/mhn a)/timon = a)/timon tou/twn a(\ i(ko/mhn, not graced in respect of those things (responses) for which I had come: Eur. Andr. 1014 a)/timon o)rga/nan xe/ra tektosu/nas, not rewarded for its skill. For a(\ i(ko/mhn (cogn. accus. denoting the errand, like e)/rxomai a)ggeli/an) cp. 1005 tou=t' a)fiko/mhn: Soph. OC 1291 a(\ d' h)=lqonqe/lw le/cai: Aristoph. Pl. 966 o(/ ti ma/list' e)lh/luqas: Plat. Prot. 310e a)ll' au)ta\ tau=ta kai\ nu=n h(/kw para\ se/ (where the acc. is cogn. to h(/kw, not object to the following dialexqh=|s).

prou)/fhnen suggested by Herm., has been adopted by several recent editors. Cp. Hdt. 1.210 tw=| de\ o( dai/mwn proe/faine, and so Hdt. 3.65, Hdt. 7.37: Plut. Dem. 19 e)n oi(=s h(/ te *puqi/a deina\ prou)/faine manteu/mata kai\ o( xrhsmo\s h)/|deto: Plut. Camill. 4 (a man who pretended to mantikh/) lo/gia prou)/fainen a)po/rrhta: Dem. 21.54 toi=s e)f' e(ka/sths mantei/as profainome/nois qeoi=s, the gods announced (as claiming sacrifice) on each reference to the oracle. Yet the fact that profai/nein was thus a vox sollennis for oracular utterance would not suffice to warrant the adoption of prou)/fhnen, if the prou)fa/nh of the MSS. seemed defensible. prou)fa/nh le/gwn would mean, “came into view, telling”: cp. above, 395, and Soph. El. 1285 nu=n d' e)/xw seprou)fa/nhs de\ | filta/tan e)/xwn pro/soyin. It might apply to the sudden appearance of a beacon (cp. o( frukto\s a)gge/llwn pre/pei, Aesch. Ag. 30): but, in reference to the god speaking through the oracle, it could only mean, by a strained metaphor, “flashed on me with the message,” i.e. announced it with startling suddenness and clearness. The difficulty of conceiving Sophocles to have written thus is to me so great that the special appropriateness of prou)/fhnen turns the scale.
ge/nos d' see on 29.
o(ra=n with a)/tlhton, which, thus defined, is in contrast with dhlw/soim': he was to show men what they could not bear to look upon.
e)pakou/sas (708), “having given ear”—with the attention of silent horror.

th
 Korinqi/an “Henceforth measuring from afar (e)kmetrou/menos)by the stars the region of Corinth, I went my way into exile, to some place where I should not see fulfilled the dishonours of [= foretold by] my evil oracles.” a)/strois e)kmetrou/menos: i.e. visiting it no more, but only thinking of it as a distant land that lies beneath the stars in this or that quarter of the heavens. Schneidewin cp. Aelian Hist. Anim. 7.48 (peri\ zw/|wn i)dio/thtos) h(=ke d' ou)=n (*)androklh=s) e)s th
 *libu/hn kai\ ta\s me
 po/leis a)peli/mpane kai\ tou=to dh\ to\ lego/menon a)/strois au)ta\s e)shmai/neto, proh/|ei de\ e)s th
 e)rh/mhn: “proceeded to leave the cities, and, as the saying is, knew their places only by the stars, and went on into the desert.” Wunder quotes Medea's words in Valer. Flacc. 7.478 quando hic aberis, dic, quaeso, profundi Quod caeli spectabo latus? e)/feugon might share with e)kmetr. the government of th
 *kor. xqo/na, but is best taken absolutely. Sense, not grammar, forbids the version: - “I went into exile from the Corinthian land (th
 *korinqi/an),thenceforth measuring my way on earth (xqo/na) by the stars.” Phrases like u(/pastronmh=xar o(ri/zomai ga/mou du/sfronos | fuga=| (Aesch. Supp. 395), a)/strois tekmai/resqai o(do/n (Luc. Icaromen. 1), are borrowed from voyages in which the sailor has no guides but the stars. Such phrases could be used figuratively only of a journey through deserts: as Hesych. explains the proverb a)/strois shmeiou=sqai: makra
 kai\ e)rh/mhn o(do
 badi/zein: h( de\ metafora\ a)po\ tw=n pleo/ntwn.

e)/nqa = e)kei=se e)/nqa, as in Soph. Phil. 1466. feu/gw e)/nqa mh\ o)/yomai = “I fly to such a place that I shall not see”; the relative clause expresses purpose, and mh/ gives a generic force: cp. 1412: Soph. Aj. 659: Soph. El. 380, 436: Soph. Trach. 800. Here, the secondary tense e)/feugon permits o)yoi/mhn. Remark, however, that in such relative clauses (of purpose or result) the fut. indic. is usually retained, even where the optat. is admissible. A rare exception is Plat. Rep. 416c. fai/h a)/n tisdei=nou)si/an toiau/thn au)toi=s pareskeua/sqai, h(/tis mh/tepau/soi k.t.l.: where pau/soi (if sound) is probably due to fai/h a)/n (see on Soph. OC 778) rather than to dei=n as = o(/ti e)/dei.

kai/ soitriplh=s The hand which added this verse in the margin of L seems to be “as early as the beginning of the fourteenth century” (Mr E. M. Thompson, Introd. to Facsimile of Laur. MS.). The verse is in A (1t(h cent.) and all our other MSS. To eject the verse, as Dindorf and Nauck have done, is utterly unwarrantable. It has a fine dramatic force. Oedipus is now at the critical point: he will hide nothing of the truth from her who is nearest to him. It is part of his character that his earnest desire to know the truth never flinches: cp. 1170.
kh=ruc te not kh=ru/c te: see Chandler, Accentuation sect. 971.
a)ph/nhs see on 753.
oi)=on adverbial neut. = w(s, referring to Iocasta's whole description; not acc. masc., referring to the person of Laius as described by her.

The kh=ruc is, I think, identical with the h(gemw/n, and distinct from the troxhla/ths. I understand the scene thus. Oedipus was coming down the steep narrow road when he met the herald (to be known for such by his stave, khru/keion) walking in front of the carriage (h(gemw/n).The herald rudely bade him stand aside; and Laius, from the carriage, gave a like command. (With the imperfect h)laune/thn, “were for driving,” pro\s bi/an need not mean more than a threat or gesture.) The driver (troxhla/ths),who was walking at his horses “ heads up the hill, then did his lord's bidding by actually jostling the wayfarer (e)ktre/ponta). Oedipus, who had forborne to strike the sacred herald, now struck the driver; in another moment, while passing the carriage, he was himself struck on the head by Laius. He dashed Laius from the carriage; the herald, turning back, came to the rescue; and Oedipus slew Laius, herald, driver, and one of two servants who had been walking by or behind the carriage; the other servant (unperceived by Oedipus) escaped to Thebes with the news.

o)/xou “from the chariot— having watched for the moment when I was passing— he came down on me, full on my head (me/son ka/ra acc. of part affected), with the double goad.” The gen. o)/xou marks the point from which the action sets out, and is essentially like ta=s poluxru/sou | *puqw=nose)/bas v. 151: cp. Hom. Od. 21.142 o)/rnusqe| a)rca/menoi tou= xw/rou o(/qen te/ per oi)noxoeu/ei, from the place. In prose we should have had a)p' o)/xou. As the verb here involves motion, we cannot compare such a gen. as i(=zentoi/xou tou= e(te/rou (Hom. Il. 9.219), where, if any prep. were supplied, it would be pro/s.
thrh/sas Dem. 53.17 (contemporary with Dem.) thrh/sas me a)nio/nta e)k *peiraiw=s o)ye\a(rpa/zei.

kaqi/keto governs mou, which me/son ka/ra defines: Plut. Anton. 12 sku/tesi lasi/oiskaqiknou/menoi tw=n e)ntugxano/ntwn: Lucian Sym. 16 ta/xa d' a)/n tinos kaqi/keto th=| bakthri/a|: Lucian Icaromenippus 24 sfo/dra h(mw=n o( pe/rusi xeimw\n kaqi/keto. This verb takes accus. only as = to reach, lit. or fig. (as Hom. Il. 14.104 ma/la pw/s me kaqi/keo qumo/n).

diploi=s ke/ntroisi a stick armed at the end with two points, used in driving. Cp. Hom. Il. 23.387 (horses) a)/neu ke/ntroio qe/ontes. The troxhla/ths had left it in the carriage when he got out to walk up the hill.
ou) mh\n i)/shn g' not merely an even penalty (cp. th\n o(moi/an a)podido/nai, par pari referre): Thuc. 1.35 ou)x o(moi/a h( a)llotri/wsis, the renunciation of such an alliance is more serious.
e)/teisen tei/sw, e)/teisa, e)tei/sqhn (not ti/sw, etc.) were the Attic spellings of the poet's age: see the epigraphic evidence in Meisterhans, Gramm. p. 88.

sunto/mws in a way which made short work: cp. Thuc. 7.42 h)pei/geto e)piqe/sqai th=| pei/ra| kai/ oi( cuntomwta/thn h(gei=to diapole/mhsin, the quickest way of deciding the war: Hdt. 5.17 e)/sti de\ su/ntomos ka/rta (sc. o(do/s), there is a short cut. The conject. sunto/nws (Soph. Trach. 923 sunto/nw| xeri/) would efface the grim irony.

me/shs implies that a moment before he had seemed firmly seated: “right out of the carriage.” Eur. Cycl. 7 i)te/an me/shn qenw/n, striking full on the shield: Eur. IT 1385 nho\s d' e)k me/shs e)fqe/gcato | boh/ tis, from within the ship itself: Soph. El. 965 a)/rkun ei)s me/shn, right into the net.

ei) suggene/s ti tw=| *lai/+w| if any tie with Laius prosh/kei tou/tw| tw=| ce/nw| belongs to this stranger. suggenh/s can take either dat. (akin to) or gen. (kin of): and here several editors give *lai/+ou. But the dat.*lai/+w|, making it verbally possible to identify the ce/nos with Laius, suits the complex suggestiveness with which the language of this drama is often contrived: cp. tw=n in 1167. Again,tw=| ce/nw| tou/tw| might apply to Oedipus himself (452). Had we ti without suggene/s, *lai/+ou (part. gen.) would then be necessary. The constructions of prosh/kein are (1) prosh/kw tini/, I am related to: (2) prosh/kei moi/ tinos, I have a right in, or tie with: (3) prosh/kei moi/ ti, it belongs to me. Here it is (3).

dntini The MS.w(=|tina must be rendered, with Hermann: “to whom it is not allowed that any one should receive (him)”: but the words would naturally mean: “to whom it is not allowed to receive any one.” In 376, where seg' e)mou= is certain, all our MSS. have mege sou=: much more might the cases have been shifted here.
mhde\tina sc. e)/cesti, absolutely: not is it lawful that anyone should speak to him.
w)qei=n d' the positive dei= must be evolved from the negative ou)k e)/cesti: cp. Soph. El. 71 kai\ mh/ m' a)/timon th=sd' a)postei/lhte gh=s | a)ll' a)rxe/plouton (sc. katasth/sate). See above, 241.

kai\ ta/d' And these things—these curses— none but I laid on myself. And as the thought proceeds, the speaker repeats ta/de in a more precise and emphatic form: cp. Plat. Rep. 606b e)kei=no kerdai/nein h(gei=tai, th\n h(donh/n.
e)n xeroi=n not, “in their embrace,” but, “by their agency”: Hom. Il. 22.426 w(s o)/felen qane/ein e)n xersi\n e)mh=|sin.

a)=r'—a)=r' ou)xi\ Where a)=ra is equivalent in sense to a)=r' ou), this is because it means, “are you satisfied that it is so?” i.e. “is it not abudantly clear?” (Soph. El. 614). Here, the transition from a)=ra to a)=r' ou)xi\ is from bitter irony to despairing earnest.

*po/lubon Wunder and others think this verse spurious. But it is, in fact, of essential moment to the development of the plot. Oedipus fears that he has slain Laius, but does not yet dream that Laius was his father. This verse accentuates the point at which his belief now stands, and so prepares us for the next stage of discovery. A few MSS. give e)ce/qreye ka)ce/fuse: but the Homeric pro/teron u)/steron (Hom. Od. 12.134 qre/yasa tekou=sa/ te) seems out of place here just because it throws a less natural emphasis on e)ce/fuse.

e)p' a)ndri\ tw=|de with o)rqoi/h lo/gon, speak truly in my case. Isaeus 8.1 e)pi\ toi=s toiou/tois, w)= a)/ndres, a)na/gkh e)sti\ xalepw=s fe/rein, in such cases. Hom. Il. 19.181 su\ d' e)/peita dikaio/teros kai\ e)p' a)/llw| | e)/sseai, in another's case.
toia/nde not toia=sde: cp. 533.
khli=da cp. a)/gos 1426: Soph. OC 1133 khli\s kakw=n. For sumfora=s, see on 99.
d' ou)=n So where the desponding fu/lac hopes for the best, Aesch. Ag. 34, ge/noito d' ou)=n k.t.l.
tou= paro/ntos imperf. part., = e)kei/nou o(\s parh=n: Dem. 19.129 oi( sumpresbeu/ontes kai\ paro/ntes katamarturh/sousin, i. e. oi(\ sunepre/sbeuon kai\ parh=san.

th=s e)lpi/dos The art. is due to the mention of e)lpi/da just before, but its force is not precisely, “the hope of which you speak.” Rather e)lpi/da is “some hope,” th=s e)lpi/dos is “hope” in the abstract: cp. Dem. 19.88 h(li/ka pa=sin a)nqrw/pois a)gaqa\ e)k th=s ei)rh/nhs gi/gnetai, i.e. “from peace,” not “the peace.”
pefasme/nou sc. au)tou=: gen. absol. Soph. El. 1344 teloume/nwn ei)/poim' a)/n, when (our plans) are being accomplished.

pa/qos a calamity, —viz. that of being proved blood-guilty. The conjecture a)/gos is specious. But pa/qos shows a finer touch; it is the euphemism of a shrinking mind (like the phrase h)/n ti pa/qw for qa/nw). For perf. with a)/n cp. 693.

perisso/n more than ordinary, worthy of special note: Hdt. 2.32 tou\s a)/lla te mhxana=sqaiperissa/, i.e. among other remarkable enterprises: Eur. Supp. 790 to\ me\n ga\r ou)k h)/lpizon a)\n peponqe/nai | pa/qos perisso/n, ei) ga/mwn a)pezu/ghn, I had not deemed it a more than common woe. Iocasta is unconscious of any point peculiar to her version, on which a hope could depend: she had reported the story of the slaughter in the fewest words, 715 -716.

to
 au)to
 a)riqmo/n i.e. plei/ous and not e(/na: or, in the phrase of grammarians, to
 plhquntiko
 and not to
 e(niko
 a)riqmo/n.
i)/sos “one cannot be made to tally with (cannot be identified with) those many”: toi=s polloi=s, referring to the plur. lh|sta/s (842).

oi)o/zwnon journeying alone. The peculiarity of the idiom is that the second part of the compound is equivalent to a separate epithet for the noun: i. e. oi)o/zwnos, “with solitary girdle,” signifies, “alone, and girt up.” Soph. OC 717 tw=n e(katompo/dwn *nhrh/|dwn, not, “with a hundred feet each,” but, countless, and dancing: Soph. OC 17 pukno/pteroi ah)do/nes, not, thickly-feathered, but, many and winged: Soph. OC 1055 disto/lous a)delfa/s, not, separately-journeying sisters, but, two sisters, journeying: Soph. Aj. 390 dissa/rxas basilh=s, not, diversely-reigning kings, but, two reigning kings: Eur. Alc. 905 ko/ros mono/pais, not, a youth with one child, but, a youth, his only child: Eur. Phoen. 683 diw/numoi qeai/, not, goddesses with contrasted names, but, several goddesses, each of whom is invoked. So I understand Eur. Orest. 1004 mono/pwlon *)aw=, “Eos who drives her steeds alone” (when moon and stars have disappeared from the sky).
ei)s e)me\ r(e/pon as if he were standing beneath the scale in which the evidence against him lies; that scale proves the heavier of the two, and thus descends towards him.

e)pi/staso fane\n tou)/pos w)=de know that the tale was thus set forth: e)pi/staso w(s fane\n tou)/pos w(=de, know that you may take the story to have been thus set forth: where w(s merely points to the mental attitude which the subject of e)pi/staso is to assume. Soph. Phil. 567 w(s tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/men', ou) me/llont' e)/ti, know that you may assume these things to be a-doing, not delayed: and Soph. Phil. 253, Soph. Phil. 415: below 956. So with the gen. abs.: Soph. Aj. 281 w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn tw=nd' e)pi/stasqai/ se xrh/, these things being so, you must view them in that belief.
e)kbalei=n repudiate: Plat. Crito 46b tou\s de\ lo/gous ou(\s e)n tw=| e)/mprosqen e)/legon ou) du/namai nu=n e)kbalei=n.
ei) ka)ktre/poito if he should turn aside: see on 772 kai\le/caim' a)/n.

to/n ge *lai/+ou fo/non Iocasta argues: “Even if he should admit that the deed was done by one man (a circumstance which would confirm our fears that the deed was yours), at any rate the death of Laius cannot be shown to have happened as the oracle foretold; for Laius was to have been killed by my son, who died in infancy. The oracular art having failed in this instance, I refuse to heed Teiresias when he says that you will yet be found guilty of slaying your father Polybus.” Iocasta, bent on cheering Oedipus, merely alludes to the possibility of his being indeed the slayer of Laius (851), and turns to the comforting aspect of the case—viz., the undoubted failure of the oracle, on any supposition. This fine and subtle passage is (to my apprehension) utterly defaced by the conjecture so/n ge *lai/+ou fo/non (Bothe), “it cannot be shown that your slaying of Laius fulfils the oracle.” Herm. reads to/nde, “this slaying” (of which you think yourself guilty): but the ge is needed.
dikai/ws o)rqo/n in a just sense correct, i.e. properly fulfilled: for o)rqo/n see 506.

Loci/as a surname of the oracular Apollo, popularly connected with loco/s, “oblique” (akin to le/x‐rios, obliquus, luxus, ‘sprained ’), as = the giver of indirect, ambiguous responses (loca\ kai\ e)pamfoteri/zonta, Lucian Dial. Deor. 16): Cornutus 32 locw=n de\ kai\ periskelw=n o)/ntwn tw=n xrhsmw=n ou(\s di/dwsi *loci/as w)no/mastai, and so Lycophron 14.1467: to this Pacuvius alludes, Flexa non falsa autumare dictio Delphis solet. The association of Apollo with Helios suggested to the Stoics that the idea connecting loco/s with *loci/as might be that of the ecliptic: to which it might be replied that the name *loci/as was older than the knowledge of the fact. It is not etymologically possible to refer *loci/as to luk, lux. But phonetic correspondence would justify the connection, suggested by Dr Fennell, with a)-lec (Skt. rak-sh). *loci/as and his sister *locw/ (Callim. Del. 292) would then be other forms of Phoebus and Artemis a)lechth/rioi, a)leci/moroi (above, 164), ‘defenders.’ Iocasta's utterance here is not really inconsistent with her reservation in 712: see note there.
diei=pe expressly said: cp. diadei/knumi, to show clearly (Her.), diadhlo/w, diarrh/dhn, “in express terms” : so above, 394 ai)/nigmadieipei=n = ‘to declare’ (solve) a riddle.

ou)/te th=|de—ou)/te th=|de = ou)/t' e)pi\ ta/de ou)/t' e)pi\ qa/tera, neither to this side nor to that: Soph. Phil. 204 h)/ pou th=|d' h)\ th=|de to/pwn: Hom. Il. 12.237 (Hector to Polydamas): tu/nh d' oi)wnoi=si tanupteru/gessi keleu/eis | pei/qesqai: tw=n ou)/ti metatre/pom' ou)/t' a)legi/zw, | ei)/t' e)pi\ deci/' i)/wsi pro\s h)w= t' h)e/lio/n te, | ei)/t' e)p' a)ristera\ toi/ ge poti\ zo/fon h)ero/enta.
mantei/as g'ou(/neka so far as it is concerned: Soph. OC 22 xro/nou me\n ou(/nek', n.
kalw=s nomi/zeis he assents, almost mechanically—but his thoughts are intent on sending for the herdsman.

stelou=nta, “to summon”: ste/llein = “to cause to set out” (by a mandate), hence “to summon”: Soph. OC 297 skopo\s de/ nin | o(\s ka)me\ deu=r' e)/pempen oi)/xetai stelw=n.—mhde\ tou=t' a)fh=|s, “and do not neglect this.” With a point after stelou=nta we could render: “neglect not even this”: but Oed. does not feel, nor feign, indifference.
ga/r since i)/wmen k.t.l. implies consultation. The doubled a)\n gives emphasis: cp. 139.
w(=n ou) soi\ fi/lon = tou/twn a(\ pra=cai ou) soi\ fi/lon e)sti/. Soph. Phil. 1227 e)/pracas e)/rgon poi=on w(=n ou)/ soi pre/pon;

div1.p: Second sta/simon. The second e)peiso/dion (512-862) has been marked by the overbearing harshness of Oedipus towards Creon; by the rise of a dreadful suspicion that Oedipus is a)/nagnos —blood-guilty for Laius; and by the avowed contempt of Iocasta, not, indeed, for Apollo himself, but for the mantikh/ of his ministers. These traits furnish the two interwoven themes of the second stasimon: (1) the prayer for purity in word as in deed: (2) the deprecation of that pride which goes before a fall; —whether it be the insolence of the tu/rannos, or such intellectual arrogance as Iocasta's speech bewrays (lo/gw|, v. 884). The tone of warning reproof towards Oedipus, while only allusive, is yet in contrast with the firm though anxious sympathy of the former ode, and serves to attune the feeling of the spectators for the approach of the catastrophe. 1st strophe (863-872). May I ever be pure in word and deed, loyal to the unwritten and eternal laws. 1st antistrophe (873-882). A tyrant's selfish insolence hurls him to ruin. But may the gods prosper all emulous effort for the good of the State. 2nd strophe (883-896). Irreverence in word or deed shall not escape: the wrath of the gods shall find it out. 2nd antistrophe (897-910). Surely the oracles concerning Laius will yet be justified: O Zeus, suffer not Apollo's worship to fail.

div2.p: ei)/ moi cunei/h moi=ra fe/ronti is equivalent to ei)/qe diateloi=mi fe/rwn, the part. implying that the speaker is already mindful of a(gnei/a, and prays that he may continue to be so: whereas ei)/ moi cunei/h moi=ra fe/rein would have been equivalent to ei)/qe moi ge/noito fe/rein, an aspiration towards a(gnei/a as not yet attained. Though moi=ra is not expressly personified (cp. Pind. P. 3.84 ti\n de\ moi=r' eu)daimoni/as e(/petai), the conception of it is so far personal that cunei/h( “be with”) is tinged with the associations of cuneidei/h ( “be witness to”), and thus softens any boldness in the use of the participle; a use which, in principle, is identical with the use after such verbs as diatelw=, tugxa/nw, lanqa/nw. fe/ronti (= ferome/nw|, see on 590)a(gnei/an, winning purity, regarded as a precious kth=ma (Soph. Ant. 150): cp. 1190 ple/on ta=s eu)daimoni/as fe/rei: Soph. El. 968 eu)se/beianoi)/sei (will win the praise of piety): Eur. Orest. 158 u(/pnouferome/nw| xara/n. —Others take fe/ronti as = “bearing about with me” (or “within me”). Cp. Soph. Ant. 1090 to\n nou=n t' a)mei/nw tw=n frenw=n h)\ nu=n fe/rei (where it = tre/fein in 1089): Soph. Trach. 108 eu)/mnaston dei=ma fe/rousan (where Casaubon tre/fousan, as Blaydes tre/fonti here). This may be right: but the use here, at least, would be bold; and I still incline to the former view.
eu)/septon active, “reverent,” only here: so 890 tw=n a)se/ptwn, also act., “irreverent deeds,” as in Eur. Hel. 542 *prwte/ws a)se/ptou paido/s, impious, unholy: see on 515.

w(=n no/moi pro/keintai u(yi/p. “for which (enjoining which) laws have been set forth, moving on high,” —having their sphere and range in the world of eternal truths: u(yi/podes being equiv. to u(yhloi\ kai\ u(you= patou=ntes: see on oi)o/zwnon 846, and contrast xqonostibh= 301. The metaphor in no/moi was less trite for a Greek of the age of Sophocles than for us: cp. Plat. Laws 793a ta\ kalou/mena u(po\ tw=n pollw=n a)/grafa no/mima—ou)/te no/mous dei= prosagoreu/ein au)ta\ ou)/te a)/rrhta e)a=n.

pro/keintai (Thuc. 3.45 e)n ou)=n tai=s po/lesi pollw=n qana/tou zhmi/a pro/keitai) strengthens the metaphor: Xen. Mem. 4.4.21 di/khn ge/ toi dido/asin oi( parabai/nontes tou\s u(po\ tw=n qew=n keime/nous no/mous, h(
 ou)deni\ tro/pw| dunato
 a)nqrw/pw| diafugei=n, w(/sper tou\s u(p' a)nqrw/pwn keime/nous no/mous e)/nioi diafeu/gousi to\ di/khn dido/nai: where Socrates speaks of the a)/grafoi no/moi which are e)n pa/sh| xw/ra| kata\ tau)ta\ nomizo/menoi, —as to revere the gods and honour parents. Aristot. Rh. 1.13.2: ‘I consider law (no/mon) as particular (i)/dion) or universal (koino/n), the particular law being that which each community defines in respect to itself, —a law partly written, partly unwritten [as consisting in local custom]; the universal law being that of nature (to
 kata\ fu/sin). For there is a certain natural and universal right and wrong which all men divine ((manteu/ontai), even if they have no intercourse or covenant with each other; as the Antigone of Sophocles is found saying that, notwithstanding the interdict, it is right to bury Polyneices’ (Soph. Ant. 454, where she appeals to the a)/grapta ka)sfalh= qew=n no/mima). Cp. Cope's Introd. to Aristot. Rh. p. 239.

ou)rani/an di' ai)qe/ra teknwqe/ntes called into a life that permeates the heavenly ether (the highest heaven): the metaphor of teknwqe/ntes being qualified by its meaning in this particular application to no/moi, viz. that they are revealed as operative; which allows the poet to indicate the sphere throughout which they operate by di' ai)qe/ra, instead of the verbally appropriate e)n ai)qe/ri: much as if he had said di' ai)qe/ra e)nergoi\ a)nafane/ntes. So, again, when he calls Olympus, not Zeus, their path/r, the metaphor is halffused with the direct notion of “source.” Cp. Aristot. Rh. 1.13.2 quoted on 865, which continues (illustrating to\ fu/sei di/kaion): kai\ w(s *)empedoklh=s le/gei peri\ tou= mh\ ktei/nein to\ e)/myuxon: tou=to ga\r ou) tisi\ me\n di/kaion tisi\ d' ou) di/kaion, *)alla\ to\ me\n pa/ntwn no/mimon dia/ t' eu)rume/dontos | ai)qe/ros h)neke/ws te/tatai dia/ t' a)ple/tou au)= gh=s (so Scaliger rightly amended au)gh=s: Emped. 438): where the special reference of Empedocles is to a principle of life common to gods, men, and irrational animals (pneu=ma to\ dia\ panto\s tou= ko/smou dih=kon yuxh=s tro/pon, Sext. Emp. Adv. Math. 9.127: cp. Cope ad loc.).

ai)qe/ra Hom. Il. 16.364 w(s d' o(/t' a)p' *ou)lu/mpou ne/fos e)/rxetai ou)rano\n ei)/sw | ai)qe/ros e)k di/hs: where, Olympus being the mountain, the ou)rano/s is above the ai)qh/r, since e)c ai)qe/ros could not = e)c ai)/qpas, after clear weather: and so Hom. Il. 2.458 di' ai)qe/ros ou)rano\n i(/kei: Hom. Il. 19.351 ou)ranou= e)kkate/palto di' ai)qe/ros: cp. Soph. Ant. 420. Here ou)rani/an ai)qe/ra =the highest heaven.

*)/olumpos not the mountain, as in the Iliad, but, as in the Odyssey (Hom. Od. 6.42), the bright supernal abode of the gods: and so = the sky itself: Soph. OC 1654 gh=n te proskunou=nq' o(mou= | kai\ to\n qew=n *)/olumpon.

e)/tikten “was their parent,” sometimes used instead of e)/teke where the stress is not so much on the fact of the birth as on the parentage, 1099, Soph. OC 982, fr 501: Pind. P. 9.15 o(/n pote = *nai/+se)/tikten. (It would be prosaic to render, “brought forth successively,”—developed.)ou)de\ mh/ pote katakoima/sh|. I formerly gave ou)de\ ma/n pote katakoima/sei, —regarding L's mh/n as more significant than its katakoima/shi. But I now think that the probabilities are stronger for mh/n having come from mh/. In point of fitness, the readings are here equal. ou) mh/ expresses conviction: Plat. Phaedo 105d ou)kou=n h( yuxh\ to\ e)nanti/on w(=| au)th\ e)pife/rei a)ei\ ou) mh/ pote de/chtai, w(s e)k tw=n pro/sqen w(molo/ghtai;

me/gas e)n tou/tois qeo/s the divine virtue inherent in them is strong and unfailing. qeo/s without art., as 880: Soph. OC 1694 to\ fe/ron e)k qeou=. For this use of the word, to express an indwelling power, cp. Eur. fr. inc. 1007 o( nou=s ga\r h(mi=n e)stin e)n e(ka/stw| qeo/s.

u(/bris The tone of Oedipus towards Creon (esp. 618-672) suggests the strain of warning rebuke. Aeschylus, with more elaborate imagery, makes u(/bris the daughter of dussebi/a and the parent of a ne/a u(/bris which in turn begets ko/ros and qra/sos (Aesch. Ag. 764).

tu/rannon here not “a prince,” —nor even, in the normal Greek sense, an unconstitutionally absolute ruler (bad or good), —but, in our sense, “a tyrant”: cp. Plat. Stat. 301c o(/tan mh/te kata\ no/mous mh/te kata\ e)/qh pra/tth| tis ei)=s a)/rxwn, prospoih=tai de\ w(/sper o( e)pisth/mwn w(s a)/ra para\ ta\ gegramme/na to/ ge be/ltiston poihte/on, h)=| de/ tis e)piqumi/a kai\ a)/gnoia tou/tou tou= mimh/matos h(goume/nh, mw=n ou) to/te to\n toiou=ton e(/kaston tu/rannon klhte/on; Plat. Rep. 573b a)=r' ou)=nkai\ to\ pa/lai dia\ to\ toiou=ton tu/rannos o( *)/erws le/getai;

ei)u(perplhsqh=|: Plat. Rep. 573c turanniko\s de\a)nh\r a)kribw=s gi/gnetai, o(/tan h)\ fu/sei h)\ e)pithdeu/masin h)\ a)mfote/rois mequstiko/s te kai\ e)rwtiko\s kai\ melagxoliko\s ge/nhtai. For ei) with subj., see on 198.
a(\ mh/ the generic mh/ (such wealth as is not meet): cp. 397 n.

The reading of all the MSS., a)krota/tan ei)sanaba=s', is accounted for by Wolff's emendation, which I have now received, a)kro/tata gei=s' a)naba=s'. The change of g into n was very easy for cursive minuscule; while on the other hand the presence of a)na/gkan in the next verse is not enough to explain the change of an original a)kro/taton into the unmetrical a)krota/tan.

gei=sa the coping of a wall: cp. Eur. Phoen. 1180 (of Capaneus) h)/dh d' u(perbai/nonta gei=sa teixe/wn | ba/llei keraunw=| *zeu/s nin (as Soph. Ant. 131, of the same, balbi/dwn | e)p' a)/krwn h)/dh | ni/khn o(rmw=nt' a)lala/cai). So here the u(/bris is hurled down, Capaneus-like, at the crowning moment of wicked triumph. In Eur. Supp. 728 there is a similar image of insolent ambition hurled down, as from the topmost round of a scaling-ladder: u(bristh\n lao/n, o(\s pra/sswn kalw=s | ei)s a)/kra bh=nai klima/kwn e)nh/lata | zhtw=n a)pw/les' o)/lbon.

With the MS. a)po/tomon w)/rousen ei)s a)na/gkan, there is a defect of \v\ \v\ or\h\. Reading a)kro/taton in 876, Arndt supplies ai)=pos before a)po/tomon, as I formerly supplied a)/kron in the same place: E. L. Lushington thought of o)/ros to follow a)po/tomon: Campbell reads e)cw/rousen. But none of these remedies, nor any other of a like kind, is satisfactory, or very probable. I now agree with Wecklein in preferring Schnelle's a)potmota/tan for a)po/tomon. This is metrically exact (= 867 di' ai)qe/ra tekn-), and removes the necessity for any conjectural supplement. (The superlative of a)/potmos occurs Hom. Od. 2.219.)
w)/rousen gnomic aor. (cp. Soph. OC 1215 kate/qento).

a)na/gkan a constraining doom from the gods: Eur. Phoen. 1000 ei)s a)na/gkhn daimo/nwn a)figme/noi. Cp. Plat. Laws 716a o( de/ tis e)carqei\s u(po\ megalauxi/as h)\ xrh/masin e)pairo/menos h)\ timai=s h)\ kai\ sw/matos eu)morfi/a|, a(/ma neo/thti kai\ a)noi/a| fle/getai th
 yuxh
 meq' u(/brewsmeta\ de\ xro/non ou) polu
 u(posxw
 timwri/an th=| di/kh| e(auto/n te kai\ oi(=kon kai\ po/lin a)/rdhn a)na/staton e)poi/hse.

xrhsi/mw|xrh=tai: where it does not use the foot to any purpose: i.e. the leap is to headlong destruction; it is not one in which the feet can anywhere find a safe landing-place. For the paronomasia cp. Pind. P. 2.78 kerdoi= de\ ti/ ma/la tou=to kerdale/on tele/qei; “but for the creature named of gain,” (the fox) “what so gainful is there here?”

to\ kalw=s d' e)/xon but I ask that the god never do away with, abolish, that struggle which is advantageous for the city,—i.e. the contest in which citizen vies with citizen who shall most serve the State. The words imply a recognition of the proqumi/a which Oed. had so long shown in the service of Thebes: cp. 48, 93, 247.

pa/laisma cp. Isoc. Letter 7.7 toi=s kalw=s ta\s po/leis ta\s au(tw=n dioikou=sin a(millhte/on kai\ peirate/on dienegkei=n au)tw=n. Plut. Mor. 820c w(/sper ou)k a)rguri/thn ou)de\ dwri/thn a)gw=na politei/as a)gwnizome/nois (the emulous service of the State), a)lla\ i(ero\n w(s a)lhqw=s kai\ stefani/thn (like the contests in the great games).
prosta/tan defender, champion: not in the semi-technical sense of ‘patron,’ as in 411.

u(pe/ropta adverbial neut. of u(pe/roptos [not u(pero/pta, epic nom. for u(pero/pths, like i(ppo/ta]: cp. Soph. OC 1695 ou)/toi kata/mempt' e)/bhton, ye have fared not amiss. Hom. Il. 17.75 a)ki/xhta diw/kwn | i(/ppous: Eur. Supp. 770 a)/krant' o)du/rei: Eur. Phoen. 1739 a)/peimia)parqe/neut' a)lwme/na: Eur. Ion 255 a)nereu/nhta dusqumei= (hast griefs which I may not explore).

xersi\n in contrast with lo/gw|, merely = e)/rgois, not ‘deeds of violence ’: cp. Eur. Phoen. 312 pw=s| kai\ xersi\ kai\ lo/goisi| perixoreu/ousa te/ryinla/bw, find joy in deed and word of circling dance, i.e. in linking of the hands and in song: cp. 864.

*di/kas a)fo/bhtos not fearing Justice: cp. 969 a)/yaustos e)/gxous, not touching a spear. The act. sense is preferable only because class. Greek says fobhqei\s th\n di/khn, not fobhqei\s u(po\ th=s di/khs: the form of the adj. would warrant a pass. sense: cp. Soph. Trach. 685 a)kti=nosa)/qikton. With a)/fobos (Soph. Aj. 366) a)fo/bhtos cp. a)tarbh/s (Soph. Trach. 23) a)ta/rbhtos (Soph. Aj. 197).

e(/dh images of gods, whether sitting or standing; but always with the added notion that they are placed in a temple or holy place as objects of worship. Timaeus p. 93 e(/dos: to\ a)/galma kai\ o( to/pos e)n w(=| i(/drutai: where to/pos prob. denotes the small shrine in which an image might stand. Dion. Hal. 1.47 uses e(/dh to render penates. Liddell and Scott s.v. cite the following as places in which e(/dos ‘may be a temple ’: but in all of them it must mean image. Isoc. 15.2 *feidi/an to\n to\ th=s *)aqhna=s e(/dos e)rgasa/menon, i.e. the chryselephantine Athena Parthenos; cp. Plut. Per. 13 o( de\ *feidi/as ei)rga/zeto me\n th=s qeou=to\ xrusou=n e(/dos: Xen. Hell. 1.4.12 *plunth/ria h)=gen h( po/lis, tou= e(/dous katakekalumme/nou th=s *)aqhna=s: i.e. the a)rxai=on bre/tas of Athena Polias in the Erechtheum was veiled in sign of mourning (the death of Aglauros being commemorated at the festival of the Plunteria). Paus. 8.46.2 fai/netai de\ ou)k a)/rcas o( *au)/goustos a)naqh/mata kai\ e(/dh qew=n a)pa/gesqai para\ tw=n krathqe/ntwn (i.e. carry off to Italy): where a)naqh/mata are dedicated objects generally, e(/dh images worshipped in temples. Is Sophocles glancing here at the mutilators of the Hermae in 415 B.C., and especially at Alcibiades? We can hardly say more than this:—(i) There is no positive probability as to the date of the play which can be set against such a view. (2) The language suits it, -nay, might well suggest it; nor does it matter that the *(ermai=, though a)naqh/mata (Andoc. 1.34), were not properly e(/dh. (3) It cannot be assumed that the dramatic art of Sophocles would exclude such a reference. Direct contemporary allusion is, indeed, uncongenial to it. But a light touch like this—especially in a choral ode—might fitly strike a chord of contemporary feeling in unison with the emotion stirred by the drama itself. I do not see how to affirm or to deny that such a suggestion was meant here. (Cp. Soph. OC 1537 n.)
duspo/tmou miserably perverse: Soph. Ant. 1025 ou)ke/t' e)/st'| a)/boulos ou)/t' a)/nolbos.
tw=n a)se/ptwn see on 864.

e)/rcetai keep himself from: Soph. OC 836 ei)/rgou, “stand back”: Hdt. 7.197 w(s kata\ to\ a)/lsos e)ge/neto, au)to/s te e)/rgeto au)tou= kai\ th=| stratih=| pa/sh| parh/ggeile. Plat. Laws 838a w(s eu)= te kai\ a)kribw=s ei)/rgontai th=s tw=n kalw=n cunousi/as. As to the form, Herodotus has e)/rgw or e)e/rgw: in Attic the MSS. give Aesch. Eum. 566 katergaqou=: Soph. Aj. 593 cune/rcete: Thuc. 5.2 perie/rcantes (so the best MSS., and Classen): Plat. Gorg. 461d kaqe/rch|s (so Stallb. and Herm., with MSS.): Plat. Rep. 461b cune/rcantos: Plat. Stat. 285b e(/rcas. So far as the MSS. warrant a conclusion, Attic seems to have admitted e)r- instead of ei)r- in the forms with c. The smooth breathing is right here, even if we admit a normal distinction between ei)/rgw “to shut out” and ei(/rgw “to shut in.”

qi/cetai This conjecture of Blaydes seems to me certain. The form occurs Eur. Hipp. 1086 klai/wn tis au)tw=n a)=r' e)mou= ge qi/cetai: Eur. Her. 652 ei) de\ tw=nde prosqi/cei xeri/. Hesych. has qi/cesqai. L has e/cetai with no breathing. Soph. could not conceivably have used such a phrase as e)/xesqai tw=n a)qi/ktwn, to cling to things which should not even be touched. He himself shows the proper use of e)/xesqai in fr. 327 tou= ge kerdai/nein o(/mws | a)pri\c e)/xontai, ”still they cling tooth and nail to gain “: fr. 26 ta\ me\n | di/kai' e)pai/nei tou= de\ kerdai/nein e)/xou. Some explain e(/cetai as ”abstain “: Hom. Od. 4.422 sxe/sqai te bi/hs lu=sai/ te ge/ronta: Hdt. 6.85 e)/sxonto th=s a)gwgh=s. To this there are two objections, both insuperable: (1) the disjunctive h)/, —with which the sense ought to be, ”unless he gain etc.or else abstain “: (2) mata/|zwn, which could not be added to e(/cetai as if this were pau/setai.—mata/|zwn, acting with rash folly: Hdt. 2.162 a)pemata/i+se, behaved in an unseemly manner: Aesch. Ag. 995 spla/gxna d' ou)/ti mata/|zei, my heart does not vainly forebode. The reason for writing mata/|zwn, not mata/zwn, is that the form matai/+zw is well attested (Her., Josephus, Hesych., Herodian): while there is no similar evidence for mata/zw, though the latter form might have existed, being related to a stem mata (ma/th) as dikaz-w to dika (di/kh).

ti/s e)/ti pot'a)mu/nein; Amid such things (if such deeds prevail), who shall any longer vaunt that he wards off from his life the shafts of the gods? The pres. a)mu/nein, not fut. a)mu^nei=n, because the shafts are imagined as already assailing him. e)n toi=sd':1319: Soph. Ant. 38 ei) ta/d' e)n tou/tois.

qew=n be/lh The MSS. have qumw=i, qumou= or qumw=: in A over qumw=i be/lh is written th\n qei/an di/khn. This points to the true sense, though it does not necessarily presuppose the true reading. The phrase qumou= be/lh, “arrows of anger,” could mean, ”taunts hurled by an angry man “; but, alone, could not mean, “the arrows of the divine wrath.” The readings of the MSS. might have arisen either through the n of qew=n being written, as it often is, in a form resembling m, and w having then been transposed (so that qumw= would have arisen before qumw=i); or from a gloss qumou= on yuxa=s. For be/lh cp. Plat. Laws 873e plh\n o(/sa kerauno\s h)/ ti para\ qeou= toiou=ton be/los i)o/n.

eu)/cetai This conject. of Musgrave (which Blaydes adopts) involves only the change of one letter from e)/rcetai: and nothing would have been more likely than a change of eu)/cetai into e)/rcetai if the scribe's eye or thought had wandered to e)/rcetai in 890, especially since the latter is not obviously unsuited to the general sense. But e)/rcetai here is impossible. For (1) we cannot render: ”will keep off the shafts from himself, so as to ward them from his life “: this would be intolerable. Nor (2), with Elmsley: ”who will abstain from warding off the shafts of the soul (the stings of conscience, yuxa=s be/lh) from his mind (qumou=)? “ i.e. who will not become reckless? This most assuredly is not Greek. eu)/cetai, on the other hand, gives just the right sense: ”If justice and religion are trampled under foot, can any man dare to boast that he will escape the divine wrath? “

xoreu/ein The words ponei=n h)\ toi=s qeoi=s added in a few MSS. (including L) have plainly arisen from a contracted writing of panhguri/zein toi=s qeoi=s which occurs in a few others. This gloss correctly represents the general notion of xoreu/ein, as referring to the xoroi/ connected with the cult of Dionysus, Apollo and other gods. The xoro/s was an element so essential and characteristic that, in a Greek mouth, the question ti/ dei= me xoreu/ein; would import, “why maintain the solemn rites of public worship?” Cp. Polybius 4. 20 (speaking of the youth of Arcadia) meta\ de\ tau=ta tou\s *filoce/nou kai\ *timoqe/ou no/mous manqa/nontes (learning the music of those masters) pollh=| filotimi/a| xoreu/ousi kat' e)niauto
 toi=s *dionusiakoi=s au)lhtai=s e)n toi=s qea/trois, oi( me
 pai=des tou\s paidikou\s a)gw=nas, oi( de\ neani/skoi tou\s tw=n a)ndrw=n legome/nous. Eur. Ba. 181 dei=*dio/nusono)/son kaq' h(ma=s dunato
 au)/cesqai me/gan: | poi= dei= xoreu/ein, poi= kaqista/nai po/da, | kai\ kra=ta sei=sai polio/n; e)chgou= su/ moi | ge/rwn ge/ronti, *teiresi/a. The Theban elders need not, then, be regarded as momentarily forgetting their dramatic part. Cp. 1095 xoreu/esqai.

a)/qikton cp. the story of the Persian attack on Delphi in 480 B.C. being repulsed by the god, who would not suffer his priests to remove the treasures, fa\s au)to\s i(kano\s ei)=nai tw=n e(wutou= prokath=sqai, Hdt. 8.36.
o)mfalo/n see on 480.

to
 *)abai=si nao/n The site of Abae, not far N. of the modern village of Exarcho, was on a hill in the northwest of Phocis, between Lake Copais and Elateia, and near the frontier of the Opuntian Locrians. Hdt. 8.33 e)/nqa h)=n i(ero
 *)apo/llwnos plou/sion, qhsauroi=si/ te kai\ a)naqh/masi polloi=si kateskeuasme/non: h)=n de\ kai\ to/te kai\ nu=n e)sti\ xrhsth/rion au)to/qi: kai\ tou=to to\ i(ero
 sulh/santes e)ne/prhsan (the Persians in 480 B.C.). Hadrian built a small temple beside the ancient i(ero/n, Paus. 10.35.3.

ta\n *)olumpi/an called by Pindar de/spoin' a)laqei/as (Pind. O. 8.2), because divination by burnt offerings (mantikh\ di' e)mpu/rwn) was there practised on the altar of Zeus by the Iamidae, hereditary ma/nteis (Hdt. 9.33): Pind. O. 6.70 *zhno\s e)p' a)krota/tw| bwmw=|xrhsth/rion qe/sqai ke/leusen (Apollo): | e)c ou(= polu/kleiton kaq' *(/ellanas ge/nos *)iamida=n.

ei) mh\ ta/de a(rmo/sei if these things (the prophecy that Laius should be slain by his son, and its fulfilment) do not come right (fit each other), xeiro/deikta pa=sin brotoi=s, so as to be signal examples for all men. Cp. Soph. Ant. 1318 ta/d' ou)k e)p' a)/llon brotw=n | e)ma=s a(rmo/sei pot' e)c ai)ti/as, can never be adjusted to another, —be rightly charged on him. Prof. Campbell cites Plat. Soph. 262c pri\n a)/n tis toi=s o)no/masi ta\ r(h/mata kera/sh|. to/te d' h(/rmose/ te, k.t.l., where I should suppose h(/rmose to be transitive: h(/rmose/ tis toi=s o)no/masi ta\ r(h/mata: if so, it is not parallel. xeiro/d. only here.

a)kou/eis audis, alluding chiefly to the title *zeu\s basileu/s, Xen. Anab. 3.1.12; under which, after the victory at Leuctra in 371 B.C., he was honoured with a special festival at Lebadeia in Boeotia, Dio. Sic. 15.53.

The subject to la/qoi is not definitely ta/de(902), but rather a motion to be inferred from the whole preceding sentence, — “the vindication of thy word.” Elms. cp. Eur. Med. 332 *zeu=, mh\ la/qoi se tw=nd' o(\s ai)/tios kakw=n.

After fqi/nonta ga\r *lai/+ou we require a metrical equivalent for qew=n be/lh in 893. The palaia/ in the marg. of L and in the text of other MSS. favours palai/fata, proposed by Linwood and Arndt, which suits fqi/nonta: cp. 561. Schneidewin conj. *puqo/xrhsta *lai/+ou. *lai/+ou, object. gen.: cp. Thuc. 1.140 to\ tw=n *megare/wn yh/fisma (about them).

e)cairou=sin are putting out of account. This bold use comes, I think, not from the sense of destroying (Xen. Hell. 2.2.19 mh\ spe/ndesqai *)aqhnai/ois a)ll' e)cairei=n), but from that of setting aside, excluding from consideration: Plat. Soph. 249b tou/tw| tw=| lo/gw| tau)to\n tou=to e)k tw=n o)/ntwn e)cairh/somen, “by this reasoning we shall strike this same thing out of the list of things which exist.” Cp. Plat. Theaet. 162d qeou\sou(\s e)gw\ e)/k te tou= le/gein kai\ tou= gra/fein peri\ au)tw=n, w(s ei)si\n h)\ w(s ou)k ei)si/n, e)cairw=. The absence of a gen. like lo/gou for e)cairousin is softened by fqi/nonta, which suggests ”fading from men's thoughts. “
timai=se)mfanh/s manifest in honours (modal dat.): i.e. his divinity is not asserted by the rendering of such worship as is due to him. Aesch. PB 171 (of Zeus) skh=ptron tima/s t' a)posula=tai.
ta\ qei=a “religion,” both faith and observance: cp. Soph. OC 1537.

div1.p: e)peiso/dion tri/ton. A messenger from Corinth, bringing the news that Polybus is dead, discloses that Oedipus was not that king's son, but a Theban foundling, whom the messenger had received from a servant of Laius. Iocasta, failing to arrest the inquiries of Oedipus, rushes from the scene with a cry.

div2.p: Iocasta comes forth, bearing a branch (i(kethri/a), wreathed with festoons of wool (ste/fh), which, as a suppliant, she is about to lay on the altar of the household god, Apollo *lu/keios, in front of the palace. The state of Oedipus frightens her. His mind has been growing more and more excited. It is not that she herself has much fear for the future. What alarms her is to see “the pilot of the ship” (923) thus unnerved. Though she can believe no longer in human mantikh/, she has never ceased to revere the gods (708); and to them she turns for help in her need.

naou\s daimo/nwn can only mean the public temples of Thebes, as the two temples of Pallas and the *)ismh/nion (20). The thought had come to Iocasta that she should supplicate the gods; and in effect she does so by hastening to the altar which she can most quickly reach (919).
ste/fh see on 3.

e)piqumia/mata offerings of incense: cp. 4. In Soph. El. 634, where Clytaemnestra comes forth to the altar of Apollo prostath/rios, an attendant carries qu/mata pa/gkarpa, offerings of fruits of the earth.—labou/sh|. labou=san would have excluded a possible ambiguity, by showing that the do/ca had come before and not after the wreaths were taken up: and for this reason the accus. often stands in such a sentence: Xen. Anab. 3.2.1 e)/docen au)toi=s profulaka\s katasth/santas sugkalei=n tou\s stratiw/tas.
ta\ kaina\ the prophecies of Teiresias, toi=s pa/lai, by the miscarriage of the oracle from Delphi: 710 f.

tou= le/gontos Plat. Gorg. 508d ei)mi\ de\ e)pi\ tw=| boulome/nw|, w(/sper oi( a)/timoi tou= e)qe/lontos, a)/nte tu/ptein bou/lhtai, k.t.l. —as outlaws are at the mercy of the first comer: Soph. OC 752 tou)pio/ntos a(rpa/sai.h)
 fo/bous le/gh| has better MS. authority than ei) le/goi, and is also simpler: the latter would be an opt. like Soph. Aj. 520 a)ndri/ toi xrew
 (= xrh\) | mnh/mhn prosei=nai, terpno
 ei)/ ti/ pou pa/qoi: cp. Soph. Aj. 1344: Soph. Ant. 666. But the statement of abstract possibility is unsuitable here. ei)le/gh| has still less to commend it.
o(/te seeing that, = e)peidh/: Soph. Ant. 170: Soph. El. 38: Dem. 1.1 o(/te toi/nun ou(/tws e)/xei: so o(po/te Thuc. 2.60.
*lu/kei' *)/apollon see on *lu/keie 203.

kateu/gmasin the prayers symbolised by the i(kethri/a and offerings of incense. The word could not mean “votive offerings.” Wunder's conject. kata/rgmasin, though ingenious, is neither needful nor really apposite. That word is used of (a) offerings of first-fruits, presented along with the ei)resiw/nh or harvestwreath, Plut. Thes. 22: (b) the ou)loxu/tai or barley sprinkled on the altar and victim at the beginning of a sacrifice: Eur. IT 244 xe/rniba/s te kai\ kata/rgmata.

lu/sineu)agh= a solution without defilement: i.e. some end to our anxieties, other than such an end as would be put to them by the fulfilment of the oracles dooming Oedipus to incur a fearful a)/gos. For eu)agh\s lu/sis as = one which will leave us eu)agei=s, cp. Pind. O. 1.26 kaqarou= le/bhtos, the vessel of cleansing.

w(s kubernh/thn new/s not w(s (o)/nta) kubern. n., because he is our pilot, but w(s (o)knoi=men a)\n) ble/pontes kubern. n. e)kpeplhgme/non: Aesch. Seven 2 o(/stis fula/ssei pra=gos e)n pru/mnh| po/lews | oi)/aka nwmw=n, ble/fara mh\ koimw=n u(/pnw|.

When the messenger arrives, Iocasta's prayer seems to have been immediately answered by a lu/sis eu)agh/s (921), as regards part at least of the threatened doom, though at the cost of the oracle's credit.

ma/lista denotes what stands first among one's wishes: cp. 1466: Soph. Trach. 799 ma/lista me/n me qe\s | e)ntau=q' o(/pou me mh/ tis o)/yetai brotw=n: | ei)d' oi)=kton i)/sxeis, k.t.l.: Soph. Phil. 617 oi)/oito me
 ma/lisq' e(kou/sion labw/n, | ei) mh\ qe/loi d', a)/konta: Soph. Ant. 327 a)ll' eu(reqei/h me
 ma/list': e)a
 de/ toi | lhfqh=| te kai\ mh\ k.t.l.
gunh\ de/ Here, and in 930, 950, the language is so chosen as to emphasise the conjugal relation of Iocasta with Oedipus.

pantelh/s because the wife's estate is crowned and perfected by the birth of children (928). The choice of the word has been influenced by the associations of te/los, te/leios with marriage. Aesch. Eum. 835 qu/h pro\ pai/dwn kai\ gamhli/ou te/lous (the marriage rite): Aesch. Eum. 214 *(/hras telei/as kai\ *dio\s pistw/mata: schol. on Aristoph. Thes. 973 e)timw=nto e)n toi=s ga/mois w(s pruta/neis o)/ntes tw=n ga/mwn: te/los de\ o( ga/mos: Pind. N. 10.18 telei/a mh/thr = *(/hra, who (Aristoph. Thes. 976) klh=|das ga/mou fula/ttei. In Aesch. Ag. 972 a)nh te/leios = oi)kodespo/ths: as do/mos h(mitelh\s (Hom. Il. 2.700) refers to a house left without its lord: cp. Luc. Dial. Mort. 19 h(mitelh= me
 to
 do/mon katalipw/n, xh/ran de\ th
 neo/gamon gunai=ka.

au)/tws (Soph. Trach. 1040 w(=d' au)/tws w(/s m' w)/lese) can be nothing but adverb from au)to/s (with Aeolic accent), = ”in that very way “: hence, according to the context, (a) simply “likewise,” or (b) in a depreciatory sense, “only thus,” —i.e. “inefficiently,” “vainly.” The custom of the grammarians, to write au(/tws except when the sense is “vainly,” seems to have come from associating the word with ou(=tos, or possibly even with au(to/s. For Soph., as for Aesch. and Eur., our MSS. on the whole favour au(/tws: but their authority cannot be presumed to represent a tradition older than, or independent of, the grammarians. It is, indeed, possible that au(/tws was an instance of old aspiration on false analogy, —as the Attic h(mei=s (Aeolic a)/mmes for a)sme/s) was wrongly aspirated on the analogy of u(mei=s (see Peile, Greek and Latin Etymology p. 302, who agrees on this with Curtius). In the absence of evidence, however, that au)/tws was a like instance, it appears most reasonable to write au)/tws.

eu)epei/as gracious words, = eu)fhmi/as, in this sense only here: elsewhere = elegance of diction: Isocrates th\n eu)e/peian e)k panto\s diw/kei kai\ tou= glafurw=s le/gein stoxa/zetai ma=llon h)\ tou= a)felw=s (Dion. Hal. Isoc. 538).

para\ ti/nos The change of para/ into pro/s by an early hand in L is remarkable. I formerly received pro/s, supporting the phrase by Hom. Od. 8.28 cei=nos o(/d', ou)k oi)=d' o(/stis, a)lw/menos i(/ket' e)mo\n dw= | h)e\ pro\s h)oi/wn h)\ e)speri/wn a)nqrw/pwn. There, however, pro/s is more natural, as virtually denoting the geographical regions (cp. Hom. Od. 21.347 pro\s *)/hlidos, ”on the side of Elis “). And pro\s qew=n w(rmhme/nos (Soph. El. 70) would be parallel only if here we had e)stalme/nos. Questioning, then, whether a)fiknei=sqai pro/s tinos is defensible, I now read para/, with most edd.
to\ d' e)/pos “at the word,” accus. of the object which the feeling concerns: Eur. El. 831 ti/ xrh=m' a)qumei=s;

a)sxa/llois from root sex, prop. “not to hold oneself,” “to be impatient,” the opposite of the notion expressed by sxo-lh/ (Curt. Etym. 170): the word occurs in Her., Xen., Dem.; and in Hom. Od. 2.193 replaces the epic a)sxala/an. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 1049 pei/qoi' a)/n, ei) pei/qoi', a)peiqoi/hs d' i)/sws.
e)gkrath\s = e)n kra/tei: cp. e)/narxos = e)n a)rxh=|, in office, Appian Civ. War 1.14.

A defective verse, pw=s ei)=pas; h)= te/qnhke Po/lubos; has been patched up in our best MSS. by a clumsy expansion of the next verse (see crit. note). The ge/rwn supplied by Triclinius (whence some late MSS. have ge/ron)was plainly a mere guess. Nauck's conj. h)= te/qnhken *oi)di/pou path/r; is recommended (1) by the high probability of a gloss *po/lubos on those words: (2) by the greater force which this form gives to the repetition of the question asked in 941: (3) by the dramatic effect for the spectators.

w)= qew=n manteu/mata Iocasta's scorn is pointed, not at the gods themselves, but at the ma/nteis who profess to speak in their name. The gods are wise, but they grant no pro/noia to men (978). Cp. 712.
i(/n' e)ste/: i(/na = o(/ti e)ntau=qa, ”to think that ye have come to this! “: cp. 1311.
tou=ton to\n a)/ndratre/mwn e)/feuge he feared and avoided this man, mh\ kta/noi (au)to/n).
pro\s th=s tu/xhs i.e. in the course of nature, and not by the special death which the oracle had foretold. Cp. 977.
e)cepe/myw the midd. as in e)kkalei=sqai (see on 597), metape/mpesqai, etc., the act. being properly used of the summoner or escort: see on stelou=nta (860).
ti/ moi le/gei; ”what does he tell (of interest) for me? “ (not ”what does he say to me? “: nor ”what, pray, does he say? “).
w(s see on 848.

shma/ntwr is, I think, unquestionably right. A is among the MSS. which have it, and in several it is explained by the gloss mhnuth/s. That the word was not unfamiliar to poetical language in the sense (“indicator,” “informant”) which it has here, may be inferred from Anthol. 6.62 (Jacobs 1.205) kukloterh= mo/libon, seli/dwn shma/ntora pleurh=s, the pencil which makes notes in the margin of pages: Nonnus 37.551 shma/ntori fwnh=|. On the other hand, shmh/nas genou= could mean nothing but “place yourself in the position of having told me,” and could only be explained as a way of saying, “tell me at once.” But such a use of gene/sqai with aor. partic. would be unexampled. The only proper use of it is made clear by such passages as these: Soph. Aj. 588 mh\ prodou\s h(ma=s ge/nh|, do not make yourself guilty of having betrayed us: Soph. Phil. 772 mh\ sauto/n q' a(/ma | ka)me\ktei/nas ge/nh|, do not make yourself guilty of having slain both yourself and me.

eu)= i)/sq' Dion. Hal. 1.41 thus quotes a verse from the *promhqeu\s *luo/menos of Aesch. (Nauck fr. 193. 2) e)/nq' ou) ma/xhs eu)= oi)=da kai\ qou=ro/s per w)/n, where Strabo p. 183 gives sa/f' oi)=da: and so Pors. here would write sa/f' i)/sqi. But the immediately preceding safw=s is decisive against this. Soph. had epic precedent, Hom. Il. 1.385 eu)= ei)dw\s a)go/reue, etc. Cp. 1071, i)ou\ i)ou/.
qana/simon bebhko/ta Soph. Aj. 516 moi=ra| kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras: Soph. Phil. 424 qanw\nfrou=dos.
cunallagh=|: see on 34.

smikra\ r(oph/ leve momentum: the life is conceived as resting in one scale of a nicely poised balance: diminish the weight in the other scale ever so little, and the inclination (r(oph/), though due to a slight cause (smikra/), brings the life to the ground (eu)na/zei).Plat. Rep. 556e w(/sper sw=ma nosw=des mikra=s r(oph=s e)/cwqen dei=tai proslabe/sqai pro\s to\ ka/mnein,ou(/tw dh\ kai\ h( kata\ tau)ta\ e)kei/nw| diakeime/nh po/lis a)po\ smikra=s profa/sewsnosei=.

Yes, he died of infirmities (no/sois e)/fqito), and of the long years(tw=| makrw=| xro/nw|, causal dat.), in accordance with their term (summetrou/menos, sc. au)toi=s, lit. ”commensurably with them “): the part. being nearly equiv. to summe/trws, and expressing that, if his years are reckoned, his death cannot appear premature. Cp. 1113, and Soph. Ant. 387 poi/a| cu/mmetros prou)/bhn tu/xh|; “seasonably for what hap?”
skopoi=to midd. as Soph. Trach. 296.

th
 *p. e(sti/an = th
 *puqoi= mantikh
 e(sti/an, as Apollo himself is *puqo/mantis, i.e. o( *puqoi= ma/ntis, Aesch. Lib. 1030: cp. *puqo/krantos, *puqo/xrhstos, *puqo/nikos. e(sti/an, as Soph. OC 413 *delfikh=s a)f' e(sti/as: Eur. Ion 461 *foibh/iosga=s | meso/mfalos e(sti/a.
kla/zontas the word used by Teiresias of the birds when their voice (fqo/ggos) had ceased to be clear to him, Soph. Ant. 1001 kakw=| | kla/zontas oi)/strw| kai\ bebarbarwme/nw|.

w(=n u(fhghtw=n sc. o)/ntwn, quibus indicibus: 1260 w(s u(fhghtou= tinos: Soph. OC 1588 u(fhghth=ros ou)deno\s fi/lwn. In these instances the absence of the part. is softened by the noun which suggests the verb; but not so in Soph. OC 83 w(s e)mou= mo/nhs pe/las.

ktenei=n ktanei=n, which the MSS. give, cannot be pronounced positively wrong; but it can hardly be doubted that Soph. here wrote ktenei=n. If ktanei=n is right, it is the only aor. infin. after me/llw in Soph., who has the fut. infin. 9 times (Soph. El. 359, 379, 538: Soph. Aj. 925, 1027, 1287: Soph. Ant. 458: Soph. Phil. 483, 1084): and the pres. infin. 9 times (Soph. El. 305, 1486: Soph. Aj. 443: Soph. OT 678, 1385: Soph. OC 1773: Soph. Trach. 79, 756: Soph. Phil. 409). Aeschylus certainly has the aor. in Aesch. PB 625 mh/toi me kru/yh|s tou=q' o(/per me/llw paqei=n. Excluding the Laconic i)dh=n in Aristoph. Lys. 117, there are but two instances in Comedy, Aristoph. Birds 366 ti/ me/llet'—a)pole/sai, and Aristoph. Ach. 1159 me/llontos labei=n. Cp. W. G. Rutherford, New Phrynichus pp. 420-425, and Goodwin, Greek Moods and Tenses sect. 23.2. The concurrence of tribrachs in the 4th and 5th places gives a semi-lyric character which suits the speaker's agitation.

keu/qei is hidden. Soph. Aj. 635 *(/aida| keu/qwn. In Soph. Trach. 989 sigh=| keu/qein may be regarded as transitive with a suppressed acc., ”to shroud (thy thought) in silence. “ Elsewhere keu/qw is always trans., and only the perf. ke/keuqa intransitive.
dh\ here nearly = h)/dh: cp. Soph. Ant. 170 o(/t' ou)=n w)/lonto| e)gw\ kra/th dh\e)/xw.

a)/yaustos = ou) yau/sas: cp. a)fo/bhtos 885 (n.): Hdt. 8.124 a)/kritos, without deciding: id. 9. 98 a)/pistos, mistrustful; Soph. OC 1031 pisto/s, trusting (n.): Soph. Phil. 687 a)mfi/plhkta r(o/qia, billows beating around: Soph. Trach. 446 mempto/s, blaming: Eur. Hec. 1117 u(/poptos, suspecting. Cp. note on a)tlhtw=n 515.
ei)/ ti mh\ an abrupt afterthought: -unless perchance: see on 124.—tw)mw=| po/qw|: cp. 797: Hom. Od. 11.202 so\spo/qos, longing for thee.
ei)/h c cp. 1075: Soph. Phil. 467 plei=n mh\ c a)po/ptou. e)c, as dist. from u(po/, is strictly in place here, as denoting the ultimate, not the proximate, agency.

ta\ d' ou)=n paro/nta but the oracles as they stand, at any rate (d' ou)=n,669, 834), Polybus has carried off with him, proving them worthless (a)/ci' ou)deno/s, tertiary predicate), and is hidden with Hades.

ta\ paro/nta with emphasis: even supposing that they have been fulfilled in some indirect and figurative sense, they certainly have not been fulfilled to the letter. The oracle spoke of bloodshed (foneu/s, 794), and is not satisfied by kate/fqito e)c e)mou= in the sense just explained.

sullabw
 is a contemptuous phrase from the language of common life: its use is seen in Aristoph. Pl. 1079 nu=n d' a)/piqi xai/rwn sullabw
 th
 mei/raka, now be off—with our blessing and the girl: Aristoph. Birds 1469 a)pi/wmen h(mei=s sullabo/ntes ta\ ptera/, let us pack up our feathers and be off: Soph. has it twice in utterances of angry scorn, Soph. OC 1383 su\ d' e)/rr' a)po/ptusto/s te ka)pa/twr e)mou= | kakw=n ka/kiste, ta/sde sullabw
 a)ra/s, begoneand take these curses with thee: Soph. Phil. 577 e)/kplei seauto
 sullabw
 e)k th=sde gh=s, ”hence in thy ship—pack from this land! “
hu)/das instead of prou)/leges: see on 54.

nun enforcing the argument introduced by ou)/koun (973), is clearly better than the weak nu=n.—e)s qumo
 ba/lh|s: Hdt. 7.51 e)s qumo
 baleu= kai\ to\ palaio
 e)/pos: Hdt. 8.68 kai\ to/de e)s qumo
 baleu=, w(s k.t.l.: Hdt. 1.84 i)dw
tw=n tina *ludw=n kataba/ntae)fra/sqh kai\ e)s qumo
 e(ba/leto. The active in the *bi/os *(omh/rou sect. 30 e)s qumo
 e)/bale to\ r(hqe/n. In Soph. El. 1347 ou)de/ g' e)s qumo
 fe/rw is not really similar.
w)=|, “for whom,” in relation to whom: not, “in whose opinion.”

ta\ th=s tu/xhs is here somewhat more than a mere periphrasis for h( tu/xh, since the plur. suggests successive incidents. tu/xh does not here involve denial of a divine order in the government of the world, but only of man's power to comprehend or foresee its course. Cp. Thuc. 5.104 pisteu/omen th=| me\n tu/xh| e)k tou= qei/ou mh\ e)lassw/sesqai. Lys. 24.22 ou)= mo/nou metalabei=n h( tu/xh moi e(/dwken e)n th=| patri/di, the only privilege which Fortune (i.e. my destiny) has permitted me to enjoy in my country.

pro/noia Bentley on Phalaris (xvii, Dyce ii. 115) quotes Favorinus in Diog. Laert. Plat. 24 as saying that Plato prw=tos e)n filosofi/a|w)no/maseqeou= pro/noian. Bentley takes this to mean that Plato was the first to use pro/noia of divine providence (not merely of human forethought), and cites it in proof that Phalaris Ep. 3 (= 40 Lennep) e(/ws a)
 h( dioikou=sa pro/noia th
 au)th
 a(rmoni/an tou=-ko/smou fula/tth| is later than Plato. Lennep, in his edition of Phalaris (p. 158), puts the case more exactly. The Stoics, not Plato, first used pro/noia, without further qualification, of a divine providence. When Plato says th
 tou= qeou=pro/noian (Plat. Tim. 30c), pronoi/as qew=n (Plat. Tim. 44c), the phrase is no more than Herodotus had used before him, Hdt. 3.108 tou= qei/ou h( pronoi/h. The meaning of Favorinus was that Plato first established in philosophy the conception of a divine providence, though popular language had known such a phrase before. Note that in Soph. OC 1180 pro/noia tou= qeou= = ”reverence for the god “: in Eur. Phoen. 637 a man acts qei/a| pronoi/a| = ”with inspired foresight “: in Xen. Mem. 1.4.6 pronohtikw=s = not, “providentially,” but simply, ”with forethought. “
ei)kh= cp. Plat. Gorg. 503e ou)k ei)kh= e)rei=, a)ll' a)poble/pwn pro/s ti (with some definite object in view).

kra/tistono(/pws du/naito Cp. Soph. Ant. 666 a)ll' o)
 po/lis sth/seie tou=de xrh\ klu/ein: where xrh\ klu/ein = dikai/ws a)
 klu/oi. So here, though e)sti/ (not h)=n) must be supplied with kra/tiston, the whole phrase = ei)kh= kra/tiston a)/n tis zw/|h. Xen. Cyrop. 1.6.19 tou=au)to
 le/gein a(\ mh\ safw=s ei)dei/h fei/desqai dei= = o)rqw=s a)
 fei/doito.
fobou= fobei=sqai ei)/s ti = to have fears regarding it: Soph. Trach. 1211 ei) fobei= pro\s tou=to: Soph. OC 1119 mh\ qau/maze pro\s to\ lipare/s.

ka)n o)nei/rasin in dreams also (as well as in this oracle); and, as such dreams have proved vain, so may this oracle. Soph. was prob. thinking of the story in Hdt. 6.107 that Hippias had such a dream on the eve of the battle of Marathon, and interpreted it as an omen of his restoration to Athens. Cp. the story of a like dream coming to Julius Caesar on the night before he crossed the Rubicon (Plut. Caes. 32, Suet. 7).

cit.quote: to\ pra=gm' a)/gein | ou)x w(s par' ou)de/n.

div2.p: e)cei/rhto the e)c‐ glances at her blunt expression of disbelief, not her frank reference to a horrible subject.

o)fqalmo\s the idea is that of a bright, sudden comfort: so Soph. Trach. 203 Deianeira calls on her household to rejoice, w(s a)/elpton o)/mm' e)moi\ | fh/mhs a)nasxo\n th=sde nu=n karpou/meqa (the unexpected news that Heracles has returned). More often this image denotes the “darling” of a family (Aesch. Lib. 934 o)fqalmo\s oi)/kwn), or a dynasty that is “the light” of a land (*sikeli/as d' e)/san | o)fqalmo/s, Pind. O. 2.9: o( *ba/ttou palaio\s o)/lbospu/rgos a)/steos, o)/mma te faenno/taton | ce/noisi, Pind. P. 5.51). Not merely (though this notion comes in) “a great help to seeing” that oracles are idle (dh/lwsis w(s ta\ manteu/mata kakw=s e)/xei, schol.). A certain hardness of feeling appears in the phrase: Iocasta was softened by fear for Oedipus and the State: she is now elated.
kai\ with e)kfobei=sqe; 772, 851.
e)kei/nhs what is there belonging to her, in her (attributive gen.): Eur. IA 28 ou)k a)/gamai tau=t' a)ndro\s a)riste/ws. — e)s fo/bon fe/ron, tending to fear: cp. 519.
qeh/laton sent upon us by the gods: cp. 255.

The MSS. having ou) qemito
, the question is between ou)xi\ qemito
 and ou) qemisto
. The former is much more probable, since qemito/s is the usual form, found in Attic prose, in Eur. (as Eur. Orest. 97 soi\ d' ou)xi\ qemito/n), and in Soph. OC 1758 a)ll' ou) qemito
 kei=se molei=n. On the other hand qemisto/s is a rare poet. form, found once in Pindar (who has also qemito/s), and twice in the lyrics of Aesch. Had we a)/llw|, the subject of qemito
 would be ma/nteuma: the accus. a)/llon shows qemito
 to be impersonal, as in Eur. Orest. 97, Pind. P. 9.42 ou) qemito
 yeu/dei qigei=n.

to\ patrw=|on ai(=ma e(lei=n is strictly ”to achieve (the shedding of) my father's blood. “ Classical Greek had no such phrase as ai)=ma xei=n or e)kxei=n in the sense of “to slay.” ai(rei=n is to make a prey of, meaning “to slay,” or “to take,” according to the context (Soph. Trach. 353 *eu)/ruto/n q' e(/loi | th\n q' u(yi/purgon *oi)xali/an). Cp. fr. 726 a)ndro\s ai)=ma suggene\s | ktei/nas, which is even bolder than this, but similar, since here we might have had simply to\n pate/ra e(lei=n, ”to slay my father “: Eur. Orest. 284 ei)/rgastai d' e)moi\ | mhtrw=|on ai)=ma, I have wrought the murder of a mother.

The simplest view ofh( *ko/rinqos e)c e)mou= a)pw|kei=to is, as Whitelaw says, that it means literally, “Corinth was lived-away-from by me,” —being the passive of e)gw\ a)pw/|koun th=s *kori/nqou. It is thus merely one of those instances in which a passive verb takes as subject that which would stand in gen. or dat. as object to the active verb: cp. the passive katagelw=mai, katafronou=mai, katayhfi/zomai, e)pibouleu/omai, etc. [I formerly took it to be passive of e)gw\ a)pw/|koun th\n *ko/rinqon, “I inhabited C. only at a distance,” —a paradoxical phrase like e)n sko/tw| o(ra=n (1273).] a)poikei=n is a comparatively rare word. Eur. has it twice (Eur. Her. 557: Eur. IA 680: in both with gen., ‘to dwell far from ’): Thuc. once with makra\n (Thuc. 3.55) and Xen. once (Xen. Oec. 4.6), —both absol., as = ‘to dwell afar ’: as prob. Theocr. 15.7 (reading w)= me/l' a)poikei=s with Meineke): Plato once thus (Plat. Laws 753a), and twice as = to emigrate (e)k *go/rtunos, Plat. Laws 708a, e)s *qouri/ous, Plat. Euthyd. 271c): in which sense Isocr. also has it twice (Isoc. 4.122, Isoc. 6.84): Pindar once (with accus. of motion to a place), Pind. P. 4.258 *kalli/stan a)pw/|khsan, they went and settled at Callista.
eu)tuxw=s because of his high fortunes at Thebes.
tw=n teko/ntwn = tw=n gone/wn: Eur. Hipp. 1081 tou\s teko/ntas o(/sia dra=n, and oft.: cp. Eur. Her. 975 boa=| de\ mh/thr, w)= tekw/n [= w)= pa/ter], ti/ dra=|s
a)po/ptolis exile, as Soph. OC 208.

patro/s te So the MSS., rightly. It is the fear of Oed. regarding his mother by which the messenger's attention has been fixed. In explaining this, Oed. has indeed mentioned the other fear as to his father; but in v. 1000, h)= ga\r ta/d' o)knw=n, the messenger means: “So this, then, was the fear about her which kept you away? ” —alluding to his own question in 991. As the speaker's tone seems to make light of the cause, Oed. answers, “and that further dread about my father which I mentioned. ” patro/s ge is unsuitable, since it would imply that this was his sole fear.
e)gw\ ou)xi\ synizesis: see on 332 e)gw\ ou)/t'.

e)celusa/mhn the aor. implies, “why have I not done it already?” i.e. “why do I not do it at once?” Aesch. PB 747 ti/ dh=t' e)moi\ zh=n ke/rdos, a)ll' ou)k e)n ta/xei | e)/rriy' e)mauth\n th=sd' a)po\ stu/flou pe/tras;
kai\ mh\n properly “however ”; here, like our “well indeed ” (if you would do so). The echoing kai\ mh\n of 1005 expresses eager assent. Cp. Soph. Ant. 221.
tou=t' a)fiko/mhn see on 788.

kalw=s pulchre, belle, thoroughly, a colloquialism, perh. meant here to be a trait of homely speech: cp. Alciphron Ep. 1.36 peinh/sw to\ kalo/n ( “I shall be fine and hungry ”): Aelian Ep. 2 e)pe/koye to\ ske/los pa/nu xrhstw=s ( “in good style ”).

With Erfurdt I think that tarbw=n is right; not that tarbw= could not stand, but Greek idiom distinctly favours the participle. Soph. Ant. 403 *k*r. h)= kai\ cuni/hs kai\ le/geis o)rqw=s a(\ fh/s; *f*u. tau/thn g' i)dw\n qa/ptousan. Soph. Ant. 517 *a*n.a)delfo\s w)/leto. *k*r. porqw=n ge th/nde gh=n. Plat. Sym. 164e ei)=pon ou)=n o(/tih(/koimi. —kalw=s (v. l. kalw=s g'), e)/fh, poiw=n. Cp. 1130 cunalla/cas. —e)ce/lqh|; cp. 1182 e)ch/koi safh=, come true.
Cp. Soph. Trach. 408 tou=t' au)/t' e)/xrh|zon, tou=to/ sou maqei=n.

pro\s di/khs as justice would prompt, “justly.” pro\s prop. = “from the quarter of,” then “on the side of ”: Thuc. 3.59 ou) pro\s th=s u(mete/ras do/chsta/de, not in the interest of your reputation: Plat. Gorg. 459c e)a/n ti h(mi=n pro\s lo/gou h)=|, “if it is in the interest of our discussion.” Plat. Rep. 470c ou)de\na)po\ tro/pou le/geis: o(/ra dh\ kai\ ei) to/de pro\s tro/pou le/gw, “correctly.” Theophr. Char. 30 (= 26 in my 1st ed. p. 156) pro\s tro/pou pwlei=n, to sell on reasonable terms.
e)n ge/nei Dem. 47.70 ou)k e)/stin e)n ge/nei soi h( a)/nqrwpos, compared with sect. 72 e)moi\ de\ ou)/te ge/nei prosh=ken.
tw=| mhdeni/, dat. of o( mhdei/s, one who is such as to be of account (in respect of consanguinity with me), —the generic use of mh/ (cp. 397, 638).
a)p' a)/llhs xeiro\s sc. labw/n.

e)mpolh/sash)\ tuxw/n i.e. “Did you buy me, or did you light upon me in the neighbourhood of Corinth? ” Oed. is not prepared for the Corinthian's reply that he had found the babe on Cithaeron. e)mpolh/sas: cp. the story of Eumaeus (Hom. Od. 15.403-483) who, when a babe, was carried off by Phoenician merchants from the wealthy house of his father in the isle Syria, and sold to Laertes in Ithaca: the Phoenician nurse says to the merchants, to/n ken a)/goim' e)pi\ nho/s, o( d' u(mi=n muri/on w)=non | a)/lfoi, o(/ph| pera/shte kat' a)lloqro/ous a)nqrw/pous. tuxw/n is answered by eu(rw/n (1026) as in 973 prou)/legon by hu)/das. Cp. 1039. The tekw/n of the MSS. is absurd after vv. 1016-1020. The man has just said, “Polybus was no more your father than I am ”; Oed. is anxiously listening to every word. He could not ask, a moment later, “Had you bought me, or were you my father?”

The fitness of the phrase napai/ais ptuxai=s becomes vivid to anyone who traverses Cithaeron by the road ascending from Eleusis and winding upwards to the pass of Dryoscephalae, whence it descends into the plain of Thebes.

e)pi\ qhtei/a|, like e)pi\ misqw=| Hdt. 5.65 etc. qhtei/a, labour for wages, opp. to doulei/a: Isoc. 14.48 pollou\s me\ndouleu/ontas, a)/llous d' e)pi\ qhtei/an i)o/ntas. pla/nhs, roving in search of any employment that he can find (not merely changing summer for winter pastures, 1137).
