The word falls lightly from him who is so soon to be o( planh/ths *oi)di/pous (Soph. OC 3).

sou= d' With the sou= g' of most MSS.: “Yes, and thy preserver” (the first ge belonging to the sentence, the second to swth/r). Cp. Hdt. 1.187 mh\ me/ntoi ge mh\ spani/sas ge a)/llws a)noi/ch|: where the second ge belongs to spani/sas. There is no certain example of a double ge in Soph. which is really similar. With sou= d': “But thy preserver”: the ge still belonging to swth/r, and de\ opposing this thought to that of v. 1029. For de/ ge cp. Aesch. Ag. 938 *a*g. fh/mh ge me/ntoi dhmo/qrous me/ga sqe/nei. *k*l. o( d' a)fqo/nhto/s g' ou)k e)pi/zhlos pe/lei. “True, but” The gentle reproof conveyed by de/ ge is not unfitting in the old man's mouth: and a double ge, though admissible, is awkward here.

ti/ d' a)/lgos k.t.l. And in what sense wast thou my swth/r? The e)n kakoi=s of the later MSS. is intolerably weak: “what pain was I suffering when you found me in trouble?” The e)n kairoi=s of L (found also, with the addition of me, in one later MS., Pal.) seems most unlikely to have been a corruption of e)n kakoi=s. Among the conjectures, a)gka/lais me (Kock), or, better, a)gka/laisi, is perh. most probable; being slightly nearer the letters than Verrall's ingenious i)/sxon ta)gka/lisma. (For the dat. a)gka/lais without e)n, cp. Eur. IT 289, etc.) Such conjectures as e)n de/onti (Wecklein), e)n kalw=| (Wunder), presuppose that e)n kairoi=s was a gloss: but it is more probable that it was a corruption.
deino/n ge in comment, as Soph. Phil. 1225, Soph. El. 341, Soph. Aj. 1127.

sparga/nwn “from my swaddling clothes ”: i.e. “from the earliest days of infancy ” (cp. Ovid Heroid. 9.22 Et tener in cunis iam Iove dignus eras). The babe was exposed a few days after birth (717). Soph. El. 1139 ou)/tepuro\s | a)neilo/mhna)/qlion ba/ros. Some understand, “I was furnished with cruelly dishonouring tokens of my birth,” deinw=s e)ponei/dista spa/rgana, alluding to a custom of tying round the necks of children, when they were exposed, little tokens or ornaments, which might afterwards serve as means of recognition (crepundia, monumenta): see esp. Plaut. Rud. 4.4.111-126, Plaut. Epidic. 5.1.34: and Rich s. v. Crepundia, where a woodcut shows a statue of a child with a string of crepundia hung over the right shoulder. Plut. Thes. 4 calls such tokens gnwri/smata. In Aristoph. Ach. 431 the spa/rgana of Telephus have been explained as the tokens by which (in the play of Eur.) he was recognised; in his case, these were r(akw/mata (431). But here we must surely take sparga/nwn witha)neilo/mhn.
w(/ste assents and continues: “(yes,) and so”
o(\s ei)= i.e. *oi)di/pous: see on 718.

pro\s mhtro/s, h)\ patro/s; sc. o)/neidos a)neilo/mhn (1035): “was it at the hands of mother or father (rather than at those of strangers) that I received such a brand?” The agitated speaker follows the train of his own thoughts, scarcely heeding the interposed remark. He is not thinking so much of his parents' possible cruelty, as of a fresh clue to their identity. Not: “was I so named by mother or father?” The name —even if it could be conceived as given before the exposure—is not the sting; and on the other hand it would be forced to take “named” as meaning “doomed to bear the name. ”
both/r cp. 837, 761.

ei)dei=t' = ei)dei/hte, only here, it seems: but cp. ei)=te = ei)/hte Hom. Od. 21.195 (doubtful in Soph. Ant. 215). ei)dei=men and ei)=men occur in Plato (Plat. Rep. 581e, Plat. Theaet. 147a) as well as in verse. In Dem. 14.27 kataqei=te is not certain (kata/qoite Baiter and Sauppe): in Dem. 18.324 he has e)nqei/hte. Speaking generally, we may say that the contracted termination -ei=en for -ei/hsan is common to poetry and prose; while the corresponding contractions, -ei=men for -ei/hmen and -ei=te for -ei/hte, are rare except in poetry.
ou)=n with the first ei)/te, as Soph. El. 199, 560: it stands with the second above, 90, 271, Soph. Phil. 345.

e)p' a)grw=n Hom. Od. 22.47 polla\ me\n e)n mega/roisinpolla\ d' e)p' a)grou=: (cp. Soph. OC 184 e)pi\ ce/nhs, Soph. El. 1136 ka)pi\ gh=s a)/llhs:) the usual Attic phrase was e)n a)grw=| or kat' a)grou/s.

o( kairo\s for the art., cp. Plat. Axioch. 364b nu=n o( kairo\s e)ndei/casqai th\n a)ei\ qruloume/nhn pro\s sou= sofi/an. — hu(rh=sqai: Bellermann (objecting to the tense) reads eu(re/sqai, citing Soph. Aj. 1023 (where, as usual, the aor. midd. = “to gain ”): but the perf. is right, and forcible, here; it means, “to be discovered once for all. ” For the form, cp. 546 n. Isoc. 15.295 tw=n duname/nwn le/gein h)\ paideu/ein h( po/lis h(mw=n dokei= gegenh=sqai dida/skalos, to be the established teacher.

Supply e)nne/pein (au)to/n), not e)nne/pei. The form oi)=mai, though often parenthetic (as Soph. Trach. 536), is not less common with infin. (Plat. Gorg. 474a oi)=on e)gw\ oi)=mai dei=n ei)=nai), and Soph. often so has it, as Soph. El. 1446.
a)\na)\n see on 862.

noei=s = “you wot of, ” the man- i.e. you understand to whom I refer. We need not, then, write ei) kei=non for e)kei=non with A. Spengel, or noei=s; e)kei=non with Blaydes, who in 1055, reading to/nd', has a comma at e)fie/mesqa. Cp. 859.

to/nd' is certainly right: to/n q' arose, when the right punctuation had been lost, from a desire to connect le/gei with e)fie/mesqa. Dindorf, however, would keep to/n q': “know ye him whom we summoned and him of whom this man speaks?” i.e. “Can you say whether the persons are identical or distinct?” But the language will not bear this.

cit.quote: qe/orton h)\ bro/teion [ga/mon gamei=]; ei) r(hto/n, fra/son. *p*r. ti/ d' o(/ntin';
su\ d' ei)= ti/s a)ndrw=n; *m. o(/stis ei)/m' e)gw/; *me/twn.
ti/na grafh/n se ge/graptai; *s*w. h(/ntina; ou)k a)gennh=.

div2.p: Since ou)k e)/stin o(/pws, ou)k a)\n ge/noito o(/pws mean “there is, there could be found, no way in which, ” tou=q' is abnormal; yet it is not incorrect: “this thing could not be attained, namely, a mode in which,” etc. Cp. the mixed constr. in Soph. Aj. 378 ou) ga\r ge/noit' a)\n tau=q' o(/pws ou)x w(=d' e)/xein (instead of e(/cei).

Since the answer at 1042, Iocasta has known the worst. But she is still fain to spare Oedipus the misery of that knowledge. Meanwhile he thinks that she is afraid lest he should prove to be too humbly born. The tragic power here is masterly.

a(/lis (ei)mi\) nosou=s' e)gw/ instead of a(/lis e)sti\ to\ nosei=n e)me/: cp. 1368: Soph. Aj. 76 e)/ndon a)rkei/tw me/nwn: Soph. Aj. 635 krei/sswn ga\r *(/aida| keu/qwn: Hdt. 1.37 a)mei/nw e)sti\ tau=ta ou(/tw poieu/mena: Dem. 4.34 oi)/koi me/nwn, belti/wn: Isaeus 2.7 i(kano\s ga\r au)to\s e)/fh a)tuxw=n ei)=nai: Athen. 435d xrh\ pi/nein, *)anti/patros ga\r i(kano/s e)sti nh/fwn.

For the genitive tri/ths mhtro\s without e)k, cp. Soph. El. 341 ou)=san patro/s, 366 kalou= | th=s mhtro/s. tri/ths mhtro\s tri/doulos, thrice a slave, sprung from the third (servile) mother: i.e. from a mother, herself a slave, whose mother and grandmother had also been slaves. No commentator, so far as I know, has quoted the passage which best illustrates this: Theopompus fr. 277 (ed. Muller 1. 325) *puqoni/khnh(\ *bakxi/dos me\n h)=n dou/lh th=s au)lhtri/dos, e)kei/nh de\ *sinw/phs th=s *qra/|tths,w(/ste gi/nesqai mh\ mo/non tri/doulon a)lla\ kai\ tri/pornon au)th/n. Dem. 58.17 ei) ga\r o)fei/lontos au)tw=| tou= pa/ppou pa/laidia\ tou=t' oi)h/setai dei=n a)pofeu/gein o(/ti ponhro\s e)k trigoni/as e)sti/n, “if, his grandfather having formerly been a debtor,he shall fancy himself entitled to acquittal because he is a rascal of the third generation.” Eustathius Hom. Od. 15. 42-50 quotes from Hippônax *)afe/w tou=ton to\n e(pta/doulon (Bergk fr. 75), i.e. “seven times a slave. ” For the force of tri-, cp. also trigi/gas, tri/pratos (thricesold, —of a slave), tripe/dwn (a slave who has been thrice in fetters). Note how the reference to the female line of servile descent is contrived to heighten the contrast with the real situation.
kakh/ = dusgenh/s, like deilo/s, opp. to a)gaqo/s, e)sqlo/s: Hom. Od. 4.63 a)ll' a)ndrw=n ge/nos e)ste\ diotrefe/wn basilh/wn | skhptou/xwn: e)pei\ ou)/ ke kakoi\ toiou/sde te/koien.
ta\ lw=|statau=ta: cp. Soph. Ant. 96 to\ deino\n tou=to (i.e. of which you speak).
o(\s = o(/stis: Soph. OC 1171 e)/coid' a)kou/wn tw=nd' o(/s e)sq' o( prosta/ths (n.).

Iocasta rushes from the scene-to appear no more. Cp. the sudden exit of Haemon (Soph. Ant. 766), of Eurydice (Soph. Ant. 1245), and of Deianeira (Soph. Trach. 813). In each of the two latter cases, the exit silently follows a speech by another person, and the Chorus comments on the departing one's silence. Iocasta, like Haemon, has spoken passionate words immediately before going: and here siwph=s(1075) is more strictly “reticence” than “silence.”

de/doika has here the construction proper to a verb of taking thought (or the like), as promhqou=mai o(/pws mh\ genh/setai, —implying a desire to avert, if possible, the thing feared. Plat. Euthyph. 4e ou) fobei= dikazo/menos tw=| patri/, o(/pws mh\ au)= su\ a)no/sion pra=gma tugxa/nh|s pra/ttwn;

The subject to a)narrh/cei is kaka/, not h( gunh/: for (1) h( gunh\ a)narrh/cei kaka/ would mean, “the woman will burst forth into reproaches, ” cp. Aristoph. Kn. 626 o( d' a)/r' e)/ndon e)lasi/bront' a)narrhgnu\s e)/ph: Pind. fr. 172 mh\ pro\s a(/pantas a)narrh=cai to\n a)xrei=on lo/gon: (2) the image is that of a storm bursting forth from a great stillness, and requires that the mysterious kaka/ should be the subject: cp. Soph. Aj. 775 e)krh/cei ma/xh: Aristot. Meteor. 2.8 e)krh/casa)/nemos.
xrh/|zei scornfully personifies the kaka/.

boulh/somai “I shall wish ”: i.e. my wish will remain unaltered until it has been satisfied. Cp. 1446 prostre/yomai: Soph. Aj. 681 w)felei=n boulh/somai, it shall henceforth be my aim: Eur. Med. 259 tosou=ton ou)=n sou tugxa/nein boulh/somai, I shall wish (shall be content) to receive from you only thus much (cp. Soph. Aj. 825 ai)th/somai de/ s' ou) makro\n ge/ras laxei=n). Soph. OC 1289 kai\ tau=t' a)f' u)mw=nboulh/somai |kurei=n e)moi/: Pind. O. 7.20 e)qelh/swdiorqw=sai lo/gon, I shall have good will to tell the tale aright. That these futures are normal, and do not arise from any confusion of present wish with future act, may be seen clearly from Plat. Phaedo 91a kai\ e)gw moi dokw= e)n tw=| paro/nti tosou=ton mo/non e)kei/nwn dioi/sein: ou) ga\r o(/pws toi=s parou=sin a(\ e)gw\ le/gw do/cei a)lhqh= proqumhqh/somai: and Plat. Phaedo 191c.

w(s gunh\ for a woman: though, as it is, her “proud spirit” only reaches the point of being sensitive as to a lowly origin. She is proud of her lineage; Oedipus, of what he is. Whitelaw well compares Tennyson: “Her pride is yet no mate for mine, Too proud to care from whence I came.” Cp. Eur. Heraclid. 978 pro\s tau=ta th
 qrasei=an o(/stis a)
 qe/lh| | kai\ th
 fronou=san mei=zon h)\ gunai=ka xrh\ | le/cei: Eur. Hipp. 640 mh\ ga e)/n g' e)moi=s do/mois | ei)/h fronou=sa plei=on h)\ gunai=ka xrh/. w(s is restrictive; cp. 1118: Thuc. 4.84 h)=n de\ ou)de\ a)du/natos, w(s *lakedaimo/nios, ei)pei=n (not a bad speaker, for a Lacedaemonian): imitated by Dionys. 10. 31 (of L. Icilius) w(s *(rwmai=os, ei)pei=n ou)k a)du/natos. See on 763.

Whatever may have been his human parentage, Oed. is the “son of Fortune ” (said in a very different tone from “Fortunae filius” in Hor. Sat. 2.6.49): Fortune brings forth the months with their varying events; these months, then, are his brothers, who ere now have known him depressed as well as exalted. He has faith in this Mother, and will not shrink from the path on which she seems to beckon him; he will not be false to his sonship. We might recall Schiller's epigram on the Wolfians; whatever may be the human paternity of the Iliad, “hat es doch Eine Mutter nur, Und die Züge der Mutter, Deine unsterblichen Züge, Natur.”

th=s eu)= didou/shs the beneficent: here absol., usu. with dat., as sfw=|n d' eu)= didoi/h *zeu/s, Soph. OC 1435. Not gen. abs., “while she prospers me, ” since the poet. th=s for au)th=s could stand only at the beginning of a sentence or clause, as 1082.

suggenei=s as being also sons of *tu/xh: the word further expresses that their lapse is the measure of his life: cp. 963: a)lka=| cu/mfutos ai)w/n (Aesch. Ag. 107), years with which bodily strength keeps pace. Pind. N. 5.40 po/tmos suggenh/s, the destiny born with one.

diw/risan not: “have determined that I should be sometimes lowly, sometimes great”; to do this was the part of controlling *tu/xh. Rather: “have distinguished me as lowly or great”: i.e., his life has had chapters of adversity alternating with chapters of prosperity; and the months have marked these off (cp. 723). The metaphor of the months as sympathetic brothers is partly merged in the view of them as divisions of time: see on 866, 1300.

“Having sprung of such parentage (e)kfu\s, whereas fu/s would be merely ”having been born such “) I will never afterwards prove (e)ce/lqoimi, evadam, cp. 1011) another man ” (a)/llos, i.e. false to my own nature). The text is sound. The license of pot' at the beginning of 1085 is to be explained on essentially the same principle as me/las d' |, etc. (29, cp. 785, 791) at the end of a verse; viz. that, where the movement of the thought is rapid, one verse can be treated as virtually continuous with the next: hence, too, Soph. Aj. 986 ou)x o(/son ta/xos | dh=t' au)to\n a)/ceis deu=ro: Soph. Phil. 66 ei) d' e)rga/sei | mh\ tau=ta. So here Soph. has allowed himself to retain e)/ti | pote/ in their natural connexion instead of writing e)/ti | a)/llos pot'. The genuineness of pot' is confirmed by the numerous instances in which Soph. has combined it with e)/ti, as above, 892, below, 1412: Soph. Aj. 98, 687: Soph. Trach. 830, 922.

div1.p: This short ode holds the place of the third sta/simon. But it has the character of a “dance-song ” or u(po/rxhma, a melody of livelier movement, expressing joyous excitement. The process of discovery now approaches its final phase. The substitution of a hyporcheme for a regular stasimon has here a twofold dramatic convenience. It shortens the interval of suspense; and it prepares a more forcible contrast. For the sake of thus heightening the contrast, Soph. has made a slight sacrifice of probability. The sudden exit of Iocasta has just affected the Chorus with a dark presentiment of evil (1075). We are now required to suppose that the spirited words of Oedipus (1076-1085) have completely effaced this impression, leaving only delight in the prospect that he will prove to be a native of the land. A hyporcheme is substituted for a stasimon with precisely similar effect in the Ajax, where the short and joyous invocation of Pan immediately precedes the catastrophe (693-717). The stasimon in Soph. Trach. 633-662 may also be compared, in so far as its glad anticipations usher in the beginning of the end. Strophe (1086-1097). Our joyous songs will soon be celebrating Cithaeron as native to Oedipus. Antistrophe (1098-1109). Is he a son of some god, —of Pan or Apollo, of Hermes or Dionysus?

div2.p: ma/ntis as Soph. El. 472 ei) mh\ gw\ para/frwn ma/ntis e)/fun kai\ gnw/mas | leipome/na sofa=s: cp. Soph. OC 1080, Soph. Ant. 1160, Soph. Aj. 1419: and manteu/omai = “to presage. ”

kata\ with an accus. of respect is somewhat rare (Soph. Trach. 102 kratisteu/wn kat' o)/mma: Soph. Trach. 379 h)= ka/rta lampra\ kai\ kat' o)/mma kai\ fu/sin), except in such phrases as kata\ pa/nta, kat' ou)de/n, kata\ tou=to. Cp. Metrical Analysis.
ou) = ou) ma\: see on 660.

a)pei/rwn = a)/peiros: Hesych. 1.433 a)pei/ronas: a)peira/tous. *sofoklh=s *que/sth|. Ellendt thinks that a)peira/tous here meant a)pera/ntous ( “limitless ”): but elsewhere a)pei/ratos always = “untried” or “inexperienced.” Conversely Soph. used a)/peiros in the commoner sense of a)pei/rwn, “vast, ” fr. 481 xitw\n a)/peiros e)nduth/rios kakw=n. pera/-w, to go through, pei=ra (peri/a), a going-through (peritus, periculum), are closely akin to pe/ra, beyond, pe/ras, pei=rar a limit (Curt. Etym. 356-357): in poetical usage, then, their derivatives might easily pass into each other's meanings.

ta
 au)/rion panse/lhnon “the full-moon of to-morrow, ” acc. of h( au)/rion panse/lhnos (there is no adj. au)/rios), as Eur. Alc. 784 th
 au)/rion me/llousan, acc. of h( au)/rion me/llousa, Eur. Hipp. 1117 to
 au)/rion xro/non. At Athens the great Dionysia were immediately followed by the *pa/ndi_a, a festival held at full-moon in the middle of the month Elaphebolion (at the beginning of April): cp. A. Mommsen Heortol. p. 389, and C. F. Hermann Ant. 2.59. Wolff remarks that, if this play was produced on the last day of the Dionysia, the poet would have known that arrangement long beforehand, and may have intended an allusion to the *pa/ndia which his Athenian hearers would quickly seize. This would explain why precisely “to-morrow's fullmoon ” is named. —Nauck reads au)=ri(as = taxe/ws, “the coming ” full-moon): Wecklein, h)=ri(dat. of h)=r), “the vernal full-moon ” —that, namely, in Elaphebolion.

panse/lhnon (sc. w(/ran): Hdt. 2.47 e)n th=| au)th=| panselh/nw|. For the accus., cp. on 1138 xeimw=na. The meaning is: “At the next full-moon we will hold a joyous pannuxi/s, visiting the temples with xoroi/ (Soph. Ant. 153), in honour of the discovery that Oedipus is of Theban birth; and thou, Cithaeron, shalt be a theme of our song. ” Cp. Eur. Ion 1078, where, in sympathy with the nocturnal worship of the gods, a)sterwpo\s | a)nexo/reusen ai)qh/r, | xoreu/ei de\ *sela/na. The rites of the Theban Dionysus were nu/ktwr ta\ polla/ (Eur. Ba. 486).

patriw/tan since Cithaeron partly belongs to Boeotia; so Plutarch of Chaeroneia calls the Theban Dionysus his patriw/thn qeo/n, Plut. Mor. 671c. —I read *oi)di/poun instead of *oi)di/pou. With the genitive, the subject to au)/cein must be either (1) h(ma=s understood, which is impossibly harsh; or (2) ta
panse/lhnon. Such a phrase as h( panse/lhnos au)/cei se, i.e., “sees thee honoured,” is possible; cp. 438 h(/d' h(me/ra fu/sei se kai\ diafqerei=: but it is somewhat forced; and the order of the words is against it. The addition of one letter, giving *oi)di/poun, at once yields a clear construction and a pointed sense. “Thou shalt not fail to know that Oedipus honours thee both as native to him, and as his nurse and mother (i.e., not merely as belonging to his Theban fatherland, but as the very spot which sheltered his infancy); and that thou art celebrated in choral song by us (pro\s h(mw=n), seeing that thou art well-pleasing to him.” mh\ ou) with au)/cein, because ou)k a)pei/rwn e)/sei = a verb of hindrance or denial with a negative. au)/cein, not merely by praises, but by the fact of his birth in the neighbourhood: as Pindar says of a victor in the games, Pind. O. 5.4 ta
 sa
 po/lin au)/cwn, Pind. P. 8.38 au)/cwn pa/tran. The acc. fe/ronta, instead of fe/rwn, may be explained by supposing that se/ ge is carried on as subject to xoreu/esqai: cp. Soph. Trach. 706 n. Another defence of the acc. would be to take kai\ xor. pro\s h(mw=n as a parenthesis (cp. Soph. Ant. 1279 n.): so Tyrrell in Class. Rev. 2.141.
trofo\n as having sheltered him when exposed: ti/ m' e)de/xou; 1391. mate/r', as the place from which his life rose anew, though it had been destined to be his ta/fos, 1452.
xoreu/esqai to be celebrated with choral song: Soph. Ant. 1153 pa/nnuxoi | xoreu/ousi to\n tami/an *)/iakxon. (Not “danced over, ” like a)ei/deto te/menos, Pind. O. 11.76.)

e)pi\ h)=ra fe/ronta see Merry's note on Hom. Od. 3.164 au)=tis e)p' *)atrei/dh| *)agame/mnoni h)=ra fe/rontes. h)=ra was probably acc. sing. from a nom. h)=r, from root a)r (to fit), as = “pleasant service. ” After the phrase h)=ra fe/rein had arisen, e)pi\ was joined adverbially with fe/rein, e)pi\ h)=ra fe/rein being equivalent to h)=ra e)pife/rein. Aristarchus, who according to Herodian first wrote e)pi/hra, must have supposed an impossible tmesis of a compound adj. in the passage of the Od. just quoted, also in Hom. Od. 16.375, Hom. Od. 18.56.
toi=s e)moi=s tur. i.e. to Oedipus: for the plur., see on qana/twn, 497.
i)h/i+e esp. as the Healer: see on 154.
a)re/st' i.e. consistent with those oracles which still await a lu/sis eu)agh/s (921).
e)/tikte see on 870.

ta=n makraiw/nwn here not goddesses (Aesch. Seven 524 darobi/oisi qeoi=sin), but the Nymphs, who, though not immortal, live beyond the human span; HH 4.260 ai(/ r(' ou)/te qnhtoi=s ou)/t' a)qana/toisin e(/pontai: | dhro\n me\n zw/ousi kai\ a)/mbroton ei)=dar e)/dousin. They consort with Pan, o(/s t' a)na\ pi/sh | dendrh/ent' a)/mudis foita=| xoroh/qesi *nu/mfais, HH 19.2.

In *pano\s o)ressiba/ta prospelasqei=s', the reading of the MSS., we note (1) the loss after o)ressiba/ta of one syllable, answering to the last of a)pei/rwn in 1087: (2) the somewhat weak compound prospelasqei=s': (3) the gen., where, for this sense, the dat. is more usual, as Aesch. PB 896 mhde\ plaqei/hn gameth=|. L has koi/th| written over o)ressiba/ta. I had thought of le/ktrois pelasqei=s'. But the gen. is quite admissible: and on other grounds Lachmann's patro\s pelasqei=s' is far better, since patro\s, written pros (with line superscribed), would explain the whole corruption.

If in 1090 we keep ou)k e)/sei ta\n au)/rion, it is best to read here with Arndt. h)\ se/ g' eu)na/teira/ tis. On the view that in 1090 ta\n e)piou=san e)/sei was a probable emendation (see Appendix on that verse), I proposed to read here, h)\ se/ g' e)/fuse path\r | *loci/as; If the se of e)/fuse had once been lost (through a confusion with the preceding se/), *g*e*f*u*p*a*t*h*r might easily have become *g*e*q*u*g*a*t*h*r: the tis (which is not in L) would have been inserted for metre's sake, and the change of *loci/as to *loci/ou would have followed. (It cannot be objected that a mention of the mother is required here, since, as the context shows, the foremost thought is, “what god was thy sire? ”) It would be a very forced way of taking h)\ se/ ge/ tis quga/thr to make quga/thr depend on makraiw/nwn, and *loci/ou on pelasqei=s' (i.e., “some daughter of the Nymphs wedded to Pan, or haply to Loxias ”). Nor does it seem easy to take quga/thr with ta=n makraiw/nwn in both clauses ( “some daughter of the Nymphs, wedded to Pan, or perhaps to Loxias ”). On the whole, I now prefer Arndt's correction. -For se/ ge in the second alternative, cp. Soph. Phil. 1116 po/tmos se daimo/nwn ta/d', | ou)de\ se/ ge do/los e)/sxen. Hdt. 7.10 (ad fin.) diaforeu/menon h)/ kou e)n gh=| th=| *)aqhnai/wn h)\ se/ ge e)n th=| *lakedaimoni/wn.

pla/kes a)gro/nomoi = pl. a)grou= nemome/nou, highlands affording open pasturage: so a)gron. au)lai=s, Soph. Ant. 785. Apollo as a pastoral god had the title of *no/mios (Theocr. 25. 21), which was esp. connected with the legend of his serving as shephered to Laomedon on Ida (Hom. Il. 21.448) and to Admetus in Thessaly (Hom. Il. 2.766: Eur. Alc. 572 mhlono/mas). Macrobius 1.17.43 (Apollinis) aedes ut ovium pastoris sunt apud Camirenses [in Rhodes] e)pimhli/ou, apud Naxios poimni/ou, itemque deus a)rnoko/mhs colitur, et apud Lesbios napai=os [cp. above, 1026], et multa sunt cognomina per diversas civitates ad dei pastoris officium tendentia. Callim. Apoll. 47 ou)de/ ken ai)=ges | deu/ointo brefe/wn e)pimhli/des, h(=|sin *)apo/llwn | boskome/nh|s o)fqalmo\n e)ph/gagen.

o( *kulla/nas a)na/sswn Hermes: HH 3.1 *(ermh=n u(/mnei, *mou=sa, *dio\s kai\ *maia/dos ui(o/n, | *kullh/nhs mede/onta kai\ *)arkadi/hs polumh/lou: Verg. Aen. 8.138 quem candida Maia | Cyllenes gelido conceptum vertice fudit. The peak of Cyllene (now Ziria), about 7300 ft. high, in N. E. Arcadia, is visible from the Boeotian plain near Leuctra, where Cithaeron is on the south and Helicon to the west, with a glimpse of Parnassus behind it: see my Modern Greece, p. 77.

o( *bakxei=os qeo\s not “the god *ba/kxos” (though in Soph. OC 1494 the MSS. give *poseidawni/w| qew=| = *poseidw=ni), but “the god of the *ba/kxoi, ” the god of Bacchic frenzy; HH 19.46 o( *ba/kxeios *dio/nusos: Soph. OC 678 o( *bakxiw/tas*dio/nusos. Some would always write *ba/kxeios (like *(omh/reios, *ai)a/nteios, etc.): on the other hand, *bakxei=os is said to have been Attic (cp. *kadmei=os): see Chandler, Greek Accentuation, §381, 2nd ed.

eu(/rhma expresses the sudden delight of the god when he receives the babe from the mother, —as Hermes receives his new-born son Pan from the *nu/mfh e)u+plo/kamos, HH 19.40 to\n d' ai)=y' *(ermei/hs e)riou/nios e)s xe/ra qh=ken | deca/menos: xai=ren de\ no/w| periw/sia dai/mwn. The word commonly = a lucky “find, ” like e(/rmaion, or a happy thought. In Eur. Ion 1349 it is not “a foundling, ” but the box containing spa/rgana found by Ion.

sumpai/zei Anacreon fr. 2 (Bergk p. 775) to Dionysus: w)=nac, w(=| dama/lhs (subduing) *)/erws | kai\ *nu/mfai kuanw/pides | porfure/h t' *)afrodi/th | sumpai/zousin: e)pistre/feai d' | u(yhlw=n korufa\s o)re/wn. *(elikwni/dwn is Porson's correction of *(elikwnia/dwn (MSS.), ad Eur. Orest. 614. Since ai)=s answers to de/ in 1097, Nauck conjectured *(elikw=nos ai)=si. But this is unnecessary, as the metrical place allows this syllable to be either short or long: so in Soph. El. 486 ai)sxi/stais answers to 502 nukto\s eu)=.

div1.p: e)peiso/dion te/tarton. The herdsman of Laius is confronted with the messenger from Corinth. It is discovered that Oedipus is the son of Laius.

div2.p: The oi)keu/s, who alone escaped from the slaughter of Laius and his following, had at his own request been sent away from Thebes to do the work of a herdsman (761). Oedipus had summoned him in order to see whether he would speak of lh|stai/, or of one lh|sth/s (842). But meanwhile a further question has arisen. Is he identical with that herdsman of Laius (1040) who had given up the infant Oedipus to the Corinthian shepherd? He is now seen approaching. With his coming, the two threads of discovery are brought together.
ka)me\ as well as you, who perhaps know better (1115).
mh\ sunalla/canta/ pw though I have never come into intercourse with him, have never met him: see on 34, and cp. 1130.
e)ngh/ra|: e)n describes the condition in which he is, as Soph. Phil. 185 e)/n t' o)du/nais o(mou= | limw=| t' oi)ktro/s: Soph. Aj. 1017 e)n gh/ra| baru/s.
cuna/|dei withtw=|de ta)ndri\: su/mmetros merely strengthens and defines it: he agrees with this man in the tale of his years.

a)/llws te and moreover: cp. Hdt. 8.142 a)/llws te tou/twn a(pa/ntwn ai)ti/ous gene/sqai doulosu/nhs toi=si *(/ellhsi *)aqhnai/ous ou)damw=s a)nasxeto/n ( “and besides,” introducing an additional argument). Soph. has a)/llws te kai/ = “especially,” Soph. El. 1324. “I know them as servants” would be e)/gnwka o)/ntas oi)ke/tas. The w(/sper can be explained only by an ellipse: w(/sper a)\n gnoi/hn oi)ke/tas e)mautou= (cp. 923). Here it merely serves to mark his first impression as they come in sight: “I know those who bring him as (methinks) servants of mine own. ”

ga/r in assent ( “you are right, for,” etc.), 731: Soph. Phil. 756: Soph. Ant. 639, etc. —*lai/+ou ga\r h)=nnomeu\s: a comma at h)=n is admissible (cp. 1122), but would not strictly represent the construction here, in which the idea —*lai/+ou h)=n pisto\s nomeu/s, ei)/per tis a)/llos —has been modified by the restrictive w(s before nomeu/s.
w(s only means that the sense in which a nomeu/s can show pi/stis is narrowly limited by the sphere of his work. See on 763: cp. 1078.

to
 *kori/nq. ce/non with se\, instead of a vocative, gives a peremptory tone: Soph. Ant. 441 se\ dh/, se\ th
 neu/ousan ei)s pe/don ka/ra, | fh\s h)\ katarnei= k.t.l., where the equivalent of e)rwtw= here is understood. Cp. Soph. Aj. 71 ou(=tos, se\ to
 ta\s k.t.l. So in the nomin. Xen. Cyrop. 4.5.22 su\ d', e)/fh, o( tw=n *(urkani/wn a)/rxwn, u(po/meinon. Blaydes thinks that tw=| *korinqi/w| ce/nw| in Aristoph. Thes. 404 comes hence. Surely rather from the Sthenoboea of Eur. ap. Athen. 427e peso
 de\ nin le/lhqen ou)de
 e)k xero/s, | a)ll' eu)qu\s au)da=|, tw=| *korinqi/w| ce/nw|.
Cp. Soph. Trach. 402 ou(=tos, ble/f' w)=de.

h)= the old Attic form of the 1st pers., from e)/a (Hom. Il. 4.321, Hdt. 2.19): so the best MSS. in Plat. Phaedo 61b, etc. That Soph. used h)= here and in the Niobe (fr. 409) h)= ga fi/lh gw\ tw=nde tou= proferte/rou, is stated by the schol. on Hom. Il. 5.533 and on Hom. Od. 8.186. L has h)=n here and always, except in Soph. OC 973, 1366, where it gives h)=. In Eur. Tro. 474 h)= me
 tu/rannos kei)s tu/rann' e)ghma/mhn is Elmsley's corr. of h)=men tu/rannoi k.t.l. On the other hand Eur., at least, has h)=n in several places where h)= is impossible: Eur. Hipp. 1012 ma/taios a)=r' h)=n, ou)damou= me
 ou)=n frenw=n: Eur. Her. 1416 w(s e)s to\ lh=ma panto\s h)=n h(/sswn a)nh/r: Eur. Alc. 655 pai=s d' h)=n e)gw/ soi tw=nde dia/doxos do/mwn: Eur. Ion 280 bre/fos neogno
 mhtro\s h)=n e)n a)gka/lais. — oi)/koi trafei/s, and so more in the confidence of the master: cp. schol. Aristoph. Kn. 2 (on *pafla/gona to
 new/nhton), pefu/kamen ga kai\ tw=n oi)ketw=n ma=llon pisteu/ein toi=s oi)/koi gennhqei=si kai\ trafei=sin h)\ ois a(
 kthsw/meqa pria/menoi. Such vernae were called oi)kogenei=s (Plat. Meno 82b: Dio Chrys. 15.25 tou\s para\ sfi/si gennhqe/ntas ou(\s oi)kogenei=s kalou=si), oi)kotrafei=s (Pollux 3.78), e)ndogenei=s (oft. in inscriptions, as C. I. G. 1.828), or oi)ko/tribes Dem. 13.24, Hesych. 2.766.

merimnw=n In classical Greek merimna=n is usu. “to give one's thought to a question ” (as of philosophy, Xen. Mem. 4.7.6 to\n tau=ta merimnw=nta); here merely = “to be occupied with ”: cp. Xen. Cyrop. 8.7.12 to\ polla\ merimna=n: and so in the 1 Cor. 7.33 merimna=| ta\ tou= ko/smou.

cu/naulos prop. “dwelling with ” (mani/a| cu/naulos Soph. Aj. 611): here, after pro\s, merely: “having thy haunts ”: an instance of that redundant government which Soph. often admits: below 1205 e)n po/nois | cu/noikos: Soph. Aj. 464 gumno\ntw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter: Soph. Phil. 31 kenh\n oi)/khsin a)nqrw/pwn di/xa: Soph. Ant. 919 e)/rhmos pro\s fi/lwn: 445 e)/cw barei/as ai)ti/as e)leu/qeron.
h)=n me\n as if replying to xw=roi ti/nes h)=san pro\s oi(=s cun. h)=sqa;

oi)=sqa with maqw/n, are you aware of having observed this man here? Cp. 1142 oi)=sqadou/s; We could not render, “do you know this man, through having observed him?” ei)de/nai, implying intuitive apprehension, is said of knowing facts and propositions: in regard to persons, it is not used in the mere sense of “being acquainted with one” (gnwri/zw), but only in that of “knowing one's character, ” as Eur. Med. 39 e)gw)=|da th/nde. So scire, wissen, savoir, Ital. sapere. On the other hand, gignw/skw, implying a process of examination, applies to all mediate knowledge, through the senses, of external objects: so noscere, kennen, connaître, Ital. conoscere. Cp. Cope in Fourn. of Philology 1.79.
kai\ le/geis see on 772.

The constr. is oi)=sqa maqw/nh)\ cunalla/cas; Oed. takes no more notice of the herdsman's nervous interruption than is necessary for the purpose of sternly keeping him to the point. h)= sunh/llacas; “have you ever met him? ” mars the force of the passage. The testimony of L to sunalla/cas has the more weight since this is the less obvious reading. Cp. verse 1037, which continues after an interruption the construction of verse 1035.
ou)x w(/ste g' ei)pei=n cp. 361.

mnh/mhs u(/po, at the prompting of memory, —u(po/ having a like force as in compound verbs meaning to “suggest, ” etc.: Plut. Mor. 813e logismou\s ou(\s o( *periklh=s au(to\n u(pemi/mnhsken, recalled to his mind: so u(poboleu/s (ib.), “a prompter. ” The phrase is more poetical and elegant than mnh/mhs a)/po, the conjecture of Reiske. Blaydes, reading a)/po, compares a)po\ th=s glw/sshs (Soph. OC 936).
kou)de/n ge cp. Soph. Phil. 38 n. a)gnw=t' = ou) gignw/skonta, not recognising me: 677 n.

Soph. has the epic h)=mos in two other places of dialogue, Soph. Trach. 531 (answered by th=mos) and 155; also once in lyrics Soph. Aj. 935; Eur. once in lyrics (Eur. Hec. 915); Aesch. and Comedy, never.

to
 *kiqairw=nos to/pon The sentence begins as if it were meant to proceed thus: to
 *k. to/pon o( me
 diploi=s poimni/ois e)/nemen, e)gw\ d' e(ni\ (e)/nemon), plhsia/zwn au)tw=|: but, the verb e)/neme having been postponed, the participle plhsia/zwn is irregularly combined with the notion of e)/nemon and turned into a finite verb, e)plhsi/azon: thus leaving to
 *k. to/pon without any proper government. (In the above explanation, the act. voice of ne/mw has been used, since this was specially said of shepherds: cp. Xen. Cyrop. 3.2.20 e)pei\ o)/rh a)gaqa\ e)/xete, e)qe/loit' a)
 e)a=n ne/mein tau=ta tou\s *)armeni/ous; The midd. would also be correct, as = “to range over. ”) For the irregular but very common change of participle into finite verb cp. Soph. El. 190 oi)konomw=w(=de me
 a)eikei= su
 stola=| | kenai=s d' a)mfi/stamai trape/zais (instead of a)mfistame/nh): so Soph. Ant. 810 (u)/mnos u)/mnhsen instead of u(/mnw| u(mnhqei=san): Soph. Trach. 676 h)fa/nistai, dia/boron pro\s ou)deno\s | tw=n e)/ndon, a)ll' e)desto
 e)c au(tou= fqi/nei. Thuc. 4.100 prose/balon tw=| teixi/smati, a)/llw| te tro/pw| peira/santes kai\ mhxanh
 prosh/gagon. Though we can have dw=ma pela/zei (Eur. Andr. 1167), “is carried towards the house,” the dat.tw=|de ta)ndri\ after e)plhsi/azon here is proof in itself that the verb does not govern to/pon: further the sense required is not “approached,” but “occupied.” Brunck, taking tw=|de ta)ndri\ as = e)moi/, was for changing e)plhsi/azon to e(plhsi/aze: which only adds the new complication of an irregular me/n and de/. The text is probably sound. Heimsoeth's conjecture, ne/mwn for o( me/n, with e)plhsi/aze, is attractive, but the parenthetic e)gw\ d' e(ni/ is then very awkward. Nauck proposes e)n *kiqairw=nos na/pais | (this with Blaydes) nomeu\s diploi=si poimni/ois e)pistatw=n | e)plhsi/aze: but this is to re-write, not to correct.

e)c h)=ros ei)s a)rktou=ron from March to September. In March the herd of Polybus drove his flock up to Cithaeron from Corinth, and met the herd of Laius, who had brought up his flock from the plain of Thebes. For six months they used to consort in the upland glens of Cithaeron; then, in September, when Arcturus began to be visible a little before dawn, they parted, taking their flocks for the winter into homesteads near Corinth and Thebes.

a)rktou=ron (the star a of the constellation Bootes,) first so called in Hes. WD 566 where (610) his appearance as a morning star is the signal for the vintage. Hippoc. Epidem. 1.2.4, has peri\ a)rktou=ron as = “a little before the autumnal equinox ”: and Thuc. 2.78 uses peri\ a)rktou/rou e)pitola/s to denote the same season. See Appendix. e(kmh/nous. Plato (Plat. Laws 916b) e)nto\s e(kmh/nou, sc. xro/nou: the statement in Lidd. and Scott's Lexicon (t\h ed.) that it is feminine was due to a misunderstanding of the words plh
 th=s i(era=s (sc. no/sou) just afterwards. Aristotle also has this form. Cp. e(/kpleqros (Eur.), e(/kpous, e(/kpleuros. The form e(cme/dimnon in Aristoph. Peace 631 is an Atticism: cp. e(/cpoun Plat. Comicus fr. 36, where Meineke quotes Philemon (a grammarian who wrote on the Attic dialect): *)attikw=s me
 e(/cpoun kai\ e(/cklinon le/getai, w(/sper kai\ para\ *sofoklei= e(cphxusti/: adding Steph. Byz. 345 *(/ecguios, po/lis *sikeli/as, grafh
 *)attikh
 e)/xousa. Besides e)/kmhnos, Aristotle uses the form e(ca/mhnos (which occurs in a perhaps interpolated place of Xen. Hell. 2.3.9); as he has also e(ca/pous. The Attic dialect similarly preferred pente/pous to penta/pous, o)ktw/pous to o)kta/pous, but always said pentaplou=s, e(caplou=s, o)ktaplou=s.

The fact that L has xeimw=na without notice of a variant, while some other MSS. notice it as a variant on their xeimw=ni, is in favour of the accus., the harder reading. It may be rendered “for the winter,” since it involves the notion of the time during which the flock was to remain in the e)/paula. It is, however, one of those temporal accusatives which are almost adverbial, the idea of duration being merged in that of season, so that they can even be used concurrently with a temporal genitive: Hdt. 3.117 to
 me
 ga xeimw=na u(/ei sfi o( qeo/stou= de\ qe/reos spei/rontesxrhi/+skonto tw=| u(/dati. 2.95 th=s me
 h(me/rhs i)xqu=s a)greu/ei, th
 de\ nu/kta ta/de au)tw=| xra=tai. 2.2 th
 w(/rhn e)pagine/ein sfi ai)=gas, “at the due season.” 7.151 to
 au)to
 tou=ton xro/non pe/myantasa)gge/lous. Cp. above, 1090 ta
 au)/rion panse/lhnon. The tendency to such a use of the accus. may have been an old trait of the popular language (cp. a)wri/an h(/kontes Aristoph. Ach. 23, kairo
 e)fh/keis Soph. Aj. 34). Modern Greek regularly uses the accus. for the old temporal dat.: e. g. th
 tri/thn h(me/ran for th=| tri/th| h(me/ra|. Classical prose would here use the genit.: Thuc. 1.30 xeimw=nos h)/dh a)nexw/rhsan. The division of the year implied is into e)/ar, qe/ros (including o)pw/ra), and xeimw/n (including fqino/pwron).
pepragme/non predicate: = re/rpaktai/ ti tou/twn a(\ le/gw;
e)k properly “at the interval of ”; cp. Xen. Anab. 1.10.11 e)k ple/onos h)\ to\ pro/sqen e)/feugon, at a greater distance: so e)k to/cou r(u/matos, at the interval of a bowshot, Xen. Anab. 3.3.15.
ti/ d' e)/sti; = “what is the matter?” “what do you mean?” Cp. 319 (n.).

pro\s ti/ cannot be connected as a relative clause with ti/ d' e)/sti, since ti/s in classical Greek can replace o(/stis only where there is an indirect question; e.g. ei)pe\ ti/ soi fi/lon. Cp. Soph. El. 316: Soph. Trach. 339. Hellenistic Greek did not always observe this rule: Mark xiv. 36 ou) ti/ e)gw\ qe/lw, a)lla\ ti/ su/.

w)= ta=n triumphantly, “my good friend. ” It is not meant to be a trait of rustic speech: in Soph. Phil. 1387 Neoptolemus uses it to Philoctetes; in Eur. Her. 321 Iolaus to Demophon, and Eur. Her. 688 the qera/pwn to Iolaus; in Eur. Ba. 802 Dionysus to Pentheus.
ou)k ei)s o)/leqron; see on 430.

ou) siwph/sas e)/sei; = a fut. perfect,—at once, or once for all; Dem. 4.50 ta\ de/onta e)so/meqa e)gnwko/tes kai\ lo/gwn matai/wn a)phllagme/noi. So Soph. Ant. 1067 a)ntidou\s e)/sei, Soph. OC 816 luphqei\s e)/sei. The situation shows that this is not an “aside. ” The qera/pwn, while really terrified, could affect to resent the assertion that his master had been a foundling.
ko/laze of words, Soph. Aj. 1107 ta\ se/mn' e)/ph | ko/laz' e)kei/nous. On the Harvard stage, the Theban at 1146 was about to strike the Corinthian (see sect. 9 of the first note in the Appendix).
w)= fe/riste in tragedy only here and Aesch. Seven 39 (*)eteo/klees, fe/riste *kadmei/wn a)/nac); ironical in Plat. Phaedrus 238d.
pro\s xa/rin so as to oblige: Dem. 8.1 mh/te pro\s e)/xqran poiei=sqai lo/gon mhde/na mh/te pro\s xa/rin: Soph. Phil. 594 pro\s i)sxu/os kra/tos, by main force.
klai/wn see on 401.

Cp. Soph. Aj. 72 to
 ta\s ai)xmalwti/das xe/ras | desmoi=s a)peuqu/nonta (preparatory to flogging): Hom. Od. 22.189 su
 de\ po/das xei=ra/s te de/on qumalge/i+ desmw=| | eu)= ma/l' a)postre/yante (of Melanthius the goat-herd); then ki/on a)n' u(yhlh
 e)/rusan pe/lasa/n te dokoi=sin: and so left him hanging.
du/sthnos sc. e)gw/. This agrees best with Soph.'s usage: see Soph. Trach. 377 w)= du/sthnas (n.): though the adj. could also refer to Oed. (cp. 1071).
ei)s to/d' = ei)s to\ o)le/sqai: Soph. Aj. 1365 au)to\s e)nqa/d' i)/comai, i.e. ei)s to\ qa/ptesqai.

e)s triba\s e)la=|, will push (the matter) to delays (Soph. Ant. 577 mh\ triba\s e)/ti), —is bent on protracting his delay: e)lau/nein as in Hdt. 2.124 e)s pa=san kako/thta e)la/sai, they said that he went all lengths in wickedness: Tyrt. 11.10 a)mfote/rwn d' ei)s ko/ron h)la/sate, ye had taken your fill of both. For the fut., expressing resolve, cp. Aristoph. Birds 759 ai)=re plh=ktron, ei) maxei=.
ou) dh=t' e)/gwge as Soph. Phil. 735, 1157: so dudum can refer to a recent moment.

The words could mean either: (1) “he was one of the children of Laius ”; or (2) “he was one of the children of the household of Laius, ” tw=n *lai/+ou being gen. of oi( *lai/+ou. The ambiguity is brought out by 1168. See on 814.
kei/nou tis e)ggenh\s gegw/s some one belonging by birth to his race, the genit. depending on the notion of ge/nos in the adj., like dwma/twn u(po/stegoi, Soph. El. 1386.

I am close on the horror, —close on uttering it: (w(/ste) le/gein being added to explain the particular sense in which he ispro\s tw=| deinw=|, as a)kou/ein defines that in which Oedipus is so. Cp. Soph. El. 542 tw=n e)mw=ni(/meron te/knwne)/sxe dai/sasqai: Plat. Crito 52b ou)d' e)piqumi/a se a)/llhs po/lews ou)d' a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai.
While ge/ toi, ge me/ntoi, ge me\n dh/ are comparatively frequent, ge/ toi dh/ is rarer: we find it in Aristoph. Cl. 372, Plat. Phaedrus 264a, Plat. Rep. 476e, Plat. Rep. 504a, Plat. Crito 44c.

w(s = “in her intention ”: see on 848. —pro\s ti/ xrei/as nearly = pro\s poi/an xrei/an, with a view to what kind of need or desire, i.e. with what aim: cp. 1443: Soph. Phil. 174 e)pi\ panti/ tw| xrei/as i(stame/nw|: Soph. Ant. 1229 e)n tw=| ( = ti/ni) cumfora=s, in what manner of plight.
tou\s teko/ntas not, as usually, “his parents ” (999), but “his father ”: the plur. as tura/nnois, 1095.

“I gave up the child through pity,” w(sdokw=n, “as thinking” etc.: i.e., as one might fitly give it up, who so thought. This virtually elliptic use of w(s is distinct from that at 848, which would here be represented by w(s a)poi/sonti.
a)/llhn xqo/na a)poi/sein (au)to/n): cp. Soph. OC 1769 qh/bas d' h(ma=s | ta\s w)gugi/ous pe/myon.

ka/k' a disyllabic subst. or adj. with short penult. is rarely elided unless, as here, it is (a) first in the verse, and also (b) emphatic: so Soph. OC 48, 796: see A. W. Verrall in Fourn. Phil. xii. 140.

a)
 e)ch/koi must have come true (cp. 1011), the opt. as Plat. Gorg. 502d ou)kou=n h( r(htorikh\ dhmhgori/a a)
 ei)/h: Hdt. 1.2 ei)/hsan d' a)
 ou(=toi *krh=tes: Hdt. 8.136 ta/xa d' a)
 kai\ ta\ xrhsth/ria tau=ta/ oi( prole/goi.
a)f' w(=n ou) xrh=n (fu=nai), since he was foredoomed to the acts which the two following clauses express.

div1.p: sta/simon te/tarton. See sect. 10 of the first note in the Appendix. 1st strophe (1186-1195). How vain is mortal life! 'Tis well seen in Oedipus: 1st antistrophe (1196-1203): who saved Thebes, and became its king: 2nd strophe (1204-1212): but now what misery is like to his? 2nd antistrophe (1213-1222). Time hath found thee out and hath judged. Would that I had never known thee! Thou wast our deliverer once; and now by thy ruin we are undone.

div2.p:
w(s with e)nariqmw=: to\ mhde
 adverbially with zw/sas: i.e. how absolutely do I count you as living a life which is no life. zw/sas should not be taken as = “while you live,” or “though you live.” We find ou)de/n ei)mi, “I am no more,” and also, with the art., to\ mhde/n ei)mi, “I am as if I were not”: Soph. Trach. 1107 ka)
 to\ mhde
 w)=: Soph. Aj. 1275 to\ mhde
 o)/ntas. Here zw/sas is a more forcible substitute for ou)/sas, bringing out the contrast between the semblance of vigour and the real feebleness.

i)/sa kai\ = i)/sa (or i)/son) w(/sper, a phrase used by Thuc. 3.14 (i)/sa kai\ i(ke/tai e)sme/n), and Eur. El. 994 (sebi/zw s' i)/sa kai\ ma/karas), which reappears in late Greek, as Aristid. 1. 269 (Dind.).
e)nariqmw= only here, and (midd.) in Eur. Orest. 623 ei) tou)mo\n e)/xqos e)nariqmei= kh=do/s t' e)mo/n = e)n a)riqmw=| poiei=, if you make of account.
fe/rei = fe/retai, cp. 590.

dokei=n “to seem,” sc. eu)daimonei=n: not absol., “to have reputation,” a sense which oi( dokou=ntes, ta\ dokou=nta can sometimes bear in direct antithesis to oi( a)docou=ntes or the like (Eur. Hec. 291 etc.) Cp. Eur. Her. 865 to
 eu)tuxei=n dokou=nta mh\ zhlou=n pri
 a)
 | qano/nt' i)/dh| tis: Soph. Aj. 125 o(rw= ga h(ma=s ou)de
 o)/ntas a(/llo plh
 | ei)/dwl' o(/soiper zw=men h)\ kou/fhn skia/n.

a)pokli=nai a metaphor from the heavenly bodies; cp. a)poklinome/nhs th=s h(me/rhs (Hdt. 3.104): and so kli/nei h( h(me/ra, o( h(/lios in later Greek: Dem. 1.13 ou)k e)pi\ to\ r(a|qumei=n a)pe/klinen. Xen. Mem. 3.5.13 h( po/lise)pi\ to\ xei=ron e)/klinen.

to
 so/n ton k.t.l. The apparently long syllable to
 (= e)c in 1202) is “irrational, ” having the time-value only of ˘: see Metrical Analysis. The to\ so/n toi of the MSS. involves a most awkward construction:— “having thy example,—having thy fate, I say, (as an example) ”; for we could not well render “having thy case (to\ so/n) as an example. ” Against to
 so/n, which is decidedly more forcible, nothing can be objected except the threefold repetition; but this is certainly no reason for rejecting it in a lyric utterance of passionate feeling.

ou)de
 brotw=n nothing (i.e. no being) among men, a stronger phrase than ou)de/na: Nauck compares fr. 652 oi( de\ th=| glw/ssh| qrasei=s | feu/gontes a)/tas e)kto/s ei)si tw=n kakw=n: | *)/arhs ga ou)de
 tw=n kakw=n lwti/zetai, “no dastard life ”: HH Herm. 34 ou)/per ti pefugme/non e)/st' *)afrodi/thn | ou)/te qew=n maka/rwn ou)/te qnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn. Add Soph. Phil. 446 (with reference to Thersites being still alive) e)/mell': e)pei\ ou)de/n pw kako/n g' a)pw/leto, | a)ll' eu)= periste/llousin au)ta\ dai/mones: | kai/ pws ta\ me
 panou=rga kai\ palintribh= | xai/rous' a)nastre/fontes e)c *(/aidou, ta\ de\ | di/kaia kai\ ta\ xrh/st' a)poste/llous' a)ei/. The ou)de/na of the MSS. involves the resolution of a long syllable (the second of ou)de
)which has an ictus; this is inadmissible, as the ear will show any one who considers the antistrophic verse, 1203, *qh/baisin a)na/sswn.
kaq' u(perbola\n toceu/sas having hit the answer to the riddle of the Sphinx, when Teiresias and all others had failed: cp. 398: Aesch. Ag. 628 e)/kursas w(/ste toco/ths a)/kros skopou=.

e)kra/thse At 1193 the Chorus addressed Oedipus: at 1197 (o(/stis k.t.l.) they turn to invoke Zeus as the witness of his achievements; and so in 1200 L, which here has the corrupt e)kra/thsas, rightly gives a)ne/sta. Then at 1201 (e)c ou(= k.t.l.) they resume the direct address to Oedipus, which is thenceforth maintained to the end of the ode. To read e)kra/thsas and a)ne/stas would be to efface a fine trait, marking the passion of grief which turns from earth to heaven, and then again to earth.
tou= pa/nt' eu)dai/monos for the adverbial pa/nta see on 475; also 823, 1425.
fqi/sas because the Sphinx, when her riddle was solved, threw herself from a rock (Apollod. 3.5): cp. 397 e)/pausa/ nin.

ta
 gamyw/nuxa k.t.l. The place of the second adj. may be explained by viewingparqe/non-xrhsmw|do/n as a composite idea: cp. Soph. Phil. 393 to
 me/gan *pa/ktwlon-eu)/xruson: Soph. OC 1234 to/ te kata/mempton| gh=ras-a)/filon: Soph. El. 133 to
 e)mo
pate/r' a)/qlion. So Pind. P. 1.95, 5. 99 etc. This is not like to\ so
 sto/mae)leino/n in 672 (n.). - parqe/non: see on ko/ra, 508.
qana/twn pu/rgos see on 218.

a)kou/ein to hear of, defining a)qliw/teros:Eur. Hipp. 1202 frikw/dh klu/ein. Whose woes are more impressive to others, or more cruel for himself? Cp. Soph. OC 306 polu\to\ so\n | o)/noma dih/kei pa/ntas. The constr. is ti/s a)qliw/teros a)kou/ein, ti/s (a)qliw/teros) cu/noikos e)n a)/tais k.t.l., who is more wretched to hear of (whose story is more tragic), who is more wretched as dwelling amid woes (whose present miseries are sharper)? It is not possible to supply ma=llon with cu/noikos froma)qliw/teros.

In 1214 the dika/zei to\n of the MSS. should be kept (see Metrical Analysis): here the simple transposition of ti/s e)n po/nois is far the most probable cure for the metre. e)n with a)/tais as well as po/nois: see on 734: for the redundant e)ncu/n-,1126.
The dat.a)llaga=| might be instrumental, but is rather circumstantial, = tou= bi/ou h)llagme/nou.
limh\n schol. o(/ti mh/thr h)=n kai\ gunh\ h( *)ioka/sth, h(\n le/gei lime/na. Cp. 420 ff.

pesei=n here = e)mpesei=n (which Hartung would read, but unnecessarily). Aristoph. Thes. 1122 pesei=n e)s eu)na\s kai\ gamh/lion le/xos. The bold use is assisted byqalamhpo/lw| (bridegroom) which goes closely with pesei=n.
a)/lokes cp. 1256, Soph. Ant. 569, Aesch. Seven 753.
si=g' cp. Aesch. Ag. 37 oi)=kos d' au)to/s, ei) fqoggh\n la/boi, | safe/stat' a)\n le/ceien.

a)/konq' not as if he had been a criminal who sought to hide conscious guilt; but because he had not foreseen the disclosure which was to result from his inquiry into the murder of Laius. —xro/nos, which fu/ei a)/dhla (Soph. Aj. 647): fr. 280 pro\s tau=ta kru/pte mhde/n, w(s o( pa/nq' o(rw=n | kai\ pa/nt' a)kou/wn (cp. note on 660) pa/nt' a)naptu/ssei xro/nos: see on 614. Time is here invested with the attributes of the divine omniscience and justice.

dika/zei (see on 1205), prop. “tries, ” as a judge tries a cause (di/khn dika/zei): here, “brings to justice,” punishes: a perhaps unique poetical use, for in Pind. O. 2.59, which Mitchell quotes, a)litra\dika/zei tis = simply “tries.” Aesch. has another poet. use, Aesch. Ag. 1412 dikaa/zeisfugh\n e)moi/ = katadika/zeis fugh\n e)mou=.

ga/mon pa/lai teknou=nta kai\ teknou=menon one in which o( teknou/menos has long been identified with o( teknw=n: i.e. in which the son has become the husband. The expression is of the same order as ta/ g' e)/rga mou | peponqo/t' e)sti\ ma=llon h)\ dedrako/ta, Soph. OC 266.

i)w\ *lai/+eion w(= te/knon Erfurdt's w)= is the most probable way of supplying the required syllable, and Reisig's objection to its place is answered by Soph. Aj. 395 e)/rebos w)= faenno/taton. Hermann, however, preferred w)/, as a separate exclamation: “Alas, of Laius (oh horror!) the son. ” Bothe's *lai+h/ion could be supported by Eur. IA 757 *foibh/ion da/pedon: Eur. fr. 775. 64 o(si/an basilh/ion: but seems less likely here.

The MSS. give du/romai ga\r w(s peri/alla[sic; in one MS. w(s peri/ala] | i)axe/wn e)k stoma/twn. I conjecture du/romai ga\r w(/sper i)a/lemon xe/wn | e)k stoma/twn: “I lament as one who pours from his lips a dirge ”: i.e., Oedipus is to me as one who is dead. Cp. Pind. I. 7.58 e)pi\ qrh=nonpolu/famon e)/xean, “over the tomb they poured forth a resounding dirge. ” My emendation has been adopted by Prof. Kennedy (ed. 1885). Every attempt to explain the vulgate is unavailing. (1) w(s peri/all' is supposed to be like w(s e)thtu/mws, w(s ma/lista, “in measure most abundant. ” Now peri/alla could mean only “preeminently,” “more than others”: Soph. fr. 225 no/mwn | ou(\s *qamu/ras peri/alla mousopoiei=, “strains which Thamyras weaves with art preeminent”: Aristoph. Thes. 1070 ti/ pot' *)androme/da | peri/alla kakw=n me/ros e)ce/laxon; “why have I, Andromeda, been dowered with sorrows above all women?” Pind. P. 11.5 qhsauro\n o)\n peri/all' e)ti/mase *loci/as, honoured preeminently. Here, peri/alla is utterly unsuitable; and the added w(s makes the phrase stranger still. (2) The MSS. have i)axe/wn. Both i)a^xei=n and i)a_xei=n occur: but the latter should, with Dindorf, be written i)akxe/w. Eur. Her. 752 i)akxh/sate: 783 o)lolu/gmatai)akxei=: Eur. Orest. 826 *tundari\s i)a/kxhse ta/laina: 965 i)akxei/tw de\ ga= *kuklwpi/a. The participle, however, is unendurably weak after du/romai, and leaves e)k stoma/twn weaker still. (3) e)k stoma/twn can mean only “from my lips” (the plur. as Soph. Trach. 938 a)mfipi/ptwn sto/masin, kissing her lips: Eur. Alc. 404 poti\ soi=si pi/tnwn sto/masin): it could not mean “loudly. ” (4) Elmsley, doubtless feeling this, took i)axe/wn as gen. of a supposed, but most questionable, i)axe/os, “loud,” formed from i)axh/. Erfurdt conjectured i)akxi/wn, “from lips wild as a bacchant's.” But a Greek poet would not have brought Iacchos and Thanatos so close together; xwri\s h( timh\ qew=n. (5) i)a/lemon gives exactly the right force; for them, Oed. is as the dead. i)a/lemos is a wail for the dead in the four places of Eur. where it occurs (Eur. Orest. 1391, Eur. Phoen. 1033, Eur. Tro. 600, Eur. Tro. 1304), in Eur. Rh. 895, and in the one place of Aesch. Supp. 115, which is just to our point: the Chorus of Danaides say, pa/qeaqreome/na| i)hle/moisin e)mpreph= zw=sa go/ois me timw=, “lamenting sorrows meet for funeral wails (i.e. the sorrows of those who are as dead), while yet living, I chant mine own dirge.” e)k stoma/twn fits xe/wn, since xei=n was not commonly used absolutely for “to utter” (as by Pindar, l. c. above). (6) The corruption may have thus arisen in a cursive MS.: i)a/lemon being written i)alemo\, the last five letters of w(sperialemox*\ewn would first generate axewn (as in one MS.), or, with the second stroke of the m, iaxewn: the attempt to find an intelligible word in the immediately preceding group of letters would then quickly produce the familiar peri/alla (in one MS. peri/ala). The nonelision of the final a in the MSS. favours this view. As to metre, with patri\ in 1209, a tribrach (-tri\ qalam) answers to a dactyl (w(s peri-, my w(/sper i)-), whether we keep the traditional text, or adopt my conjecture, or that of Wecklein or of Burges; though Wecklein, by a strange oversight, has noticed this objection as if it were peculiar to my conjecture. Wunder's po/sei for patri\ in 1209 would restore exact correspondence, and may be right; but I rather prefer, with Heinrich Schmidt (Compositionslehre 64), to regard the w(s as an “irrational syllable ”: see Metrical Analysis.

to\ d' o)rqo\n ei)pei=n like w(s ei)pei=n e)/pos, prefaces the bold figure of speech: I might truly say that by thy means (e)k se/qen)I received a new life (when the Sphinx had brought us to the brink of ruin); and now have again closed my eyes in a sleep as of death, —since all our weal perishes with thine. The Thebans might now be indeed described as sta/ntes t' e)s o)rqo\n kai\ peso/ntes u)/steron (50).
a)ne/pneusa “revived, ” i.e. was delivered from anguish; cp. Hom. Il. 11.382 a)ne/pneusan kako/thtos, had a respite from distress: Soph. Aj. 274 e)/lhce ka)ne/pneuse th=s no/sou.
katekoi/mhsa cp. Aesch. Ag. 1293 w(s a)sfa/dastoso)/mma sumba/lw to/de: Soph. Aj. 831 kalw= q' a(/ma | pompai=on *(ermh=n xqo/nion eu)= me koimi/sai.

div1.p: e)/codos. It is told how Iocasta has taken her own life. The selfblinded Oedipus comes forth. Creon brings to him the children his daughters, but will not consent to send him away from Thebes until Apollo shall have spoken.

div2.p: A messenger comes forth from the house. An e)ca/ggelos is one who announces ta\ e)/sw gegono/ta toi=s e)/cw (Hesych.), while the a)/ggelos (924) brings news from a distance: in Thuc. 8.51 (tw=| strateu/mati e)ca/ggelos gi/gnetai w(s, k.t.l.), one who betrays secrets.
o(/son d' see on 29.

a)rei=sqe take upon you, i.e. have laid upon you: like ai)/resqai a)/xqos (so Soph. Ant. 907 po/non, Soph. Trach. 491 no/son): while in Hom. Il. 14.130 mh/ pou/ tis e)f' e(/lkei+ e(/lkos a)/rhtai is more like Hom. Il. 12.435 misqo\n a)/rhtai, “win. ”
e)ggenw=s = w(s e)ggenei=s o)/ntes, like true men of the Cadmean stock to which the house of Labdacus belonged (261, 273).

*)/istron the Thracian name for the lower course of the river which the Kelts called Danuvius (for this rather than Danubius is the correct form, Kiepert Anc. Geo. §196 n., Byzantine and modern *dou/nabis).

*fa=sin (Rion), dividing Colchis from Asia Minor and flowing into the Euxine. ( “Phasis ” in Xen. Anab. 4.6.4 must mean the Araxes, which flows into the Caspian.) Soph. names these simply as great rivers, not with conscious choice as representatives of Europe and Asia. Ovid Met. 2.248 arsit Orontes | Thermodonque citus Gangesque et Phasis et Ister. Commentators compare Seneca Hipp. 715 Quis eluet me Tanais? aut quae barbaris Maeotis undis Pontico incumbens mari? Non ipse toto magnus Oceano pater Tantum piarit sceleris, and Shaksp. Macbeth 2.2.60 “Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand?”: where, however, the agony of personal remorse renders the hyperbole somewhat more natural than it is here in the mouth of a messenger.
kaqarmw=|, modal dat., “by way of purification, ” so as to purify.

ni/yai Eur. IT 1191 a(gnoi=s kaqarmoi=s prw=ta/ nin ni/yai qe/lw. The idea of washing off a defilement belongs to ni/zein (as to its cognates in Sanskrit and Old Irish, Curt. Etym. 439), cp. Hom. Il. 11.830 etc.

o(/sa causal, = o(/ti tosau=ta: Hdt. 1.31 e)maka/rizon th\n mhte/ra oi(/wn (= o(/ti toiou/twn) te/knwn e)ku/rhse: Aesch. PB 908 e(/stai tapeino/s, oi)=on e)cartu/etai | ga/mon gamei=n: Hom. Il. 5.757 ou) nemesi/zh| *)/arei| o(ssa/tio/n te kai\ oi(=on a)pw/lese lao\n *)axaiw=n: Hom. Il. 18.262 oi(=os (= e)pei\ toi=os) e)kei/nou qumo\s u(pe/rbios, ou)k e)qelh/sei | mi/mnein e)n pedi/w|. Cp. Soph. OC 263 n.

The construction is o(/sa kaka\ (ta\ me\n) keu/qei, ta\ de\ au)ti/ka e)s to\ fw=s fanei=: cp. Soph. El. 1290 patrw/|an kth=sin| a)ntlei=, ta\ d' e)kxei= k.t.l. The house conceals (keu/qei)the corpse of Iocasta; it will presently disclose (fanei=)the selfblinded Oedipus: both these horrors were due to conscious acts (e(ko/nta),as distinguished from those acts in which Oed. and Iocasta had become involved without their knowledge (a)/konta). e(ko/ntaa)/konta for e(kou/siaa)kou/sia, the epithet of the agent being transferred to the act: see on 1215.

ma/lista because there is not the consolation of recognising an inevitable destiny: cp. Soph. Aj. 260 to\ ga\r e)sleu/ssein oi)kei=a pa/qh | mhdeno\s a)/llou parapra/cantos | mega/las o)du/nas u(potei/nei: but here lupou=si refers rather to the spectators than to the sufferers.
ai(\ for ai(\ a)/n, as oft. in poetry (Soph. OC 395 etc.), rarely in prose, Thuc. 4.17 ou(= me\n braxei=s a)rkw=si, 18 oi(/tinesnomi/swsi.

lei/pei fail: Polyb. 2. 14 h( tw=n *)/alpewn parw/reiaprokatalh/gousa lei/pei tou= mh\ suna/ptein au)tw=|, the chain of the Alps, stopping short, fails of touching (the inmost recess of the Adriatic).

mh\ ou) because of ou)de\ with lei/pei: the added to\ makes the idea of the infin. stand out more independently of lei/pei: cp. 283.-h)/|deimen, which the MSS. give, should be kept. It was altered to h)/|demen by Elms. on Eur. Ba. 1345 o)/y' e)ma/qeq' h(ma=s, o(/te d' e)xrh=n, ou)k h)/|dete: where the ei)/dete of the MSS. is possible, but less probable. Aeschin. 3.82 has h)/|deimen: Dem. 55.9 h)/|deite. See Curtius Verb 11.239, Eng. tr. 432, who points out that the case of the third pers. plur. is different: for this, the forms in esan (as h)/|desan) alone have good authority.

qei=on epic epithet of kings and chiefs, as in Il. of Achilles, Odysseus, Oileus, Thoas, etc., also of heralds, and in Od. of minstrels, as di=os Hom. Od. 16.1 of Eumaeus: Plat. Phaedrus 234d suneba/kxeusa meta\ sou= th=s qei/as kefalh=s ( “your worship ”).
For pro\s here see note on 493 ad fin.
ou) pa/ra = ou) pa/restin u(mi=n: ye have not been eye-witnesses, as I have been.

ka)n e)moi\ “e'en in me, ” —though your own memory, had you been present, would have preserved a more vivid impression than I can give: cp. Plat. Alc. 1 127e a)\n qeo\s e)qe/lh| ei)/ ti dei= kai\ th=| e)mh=| mantei/a| pisteu/ein, su/ te ka)gw\ be/ltion sxh/somen. e)n—e)/ni (= e)/nesti), as e)nei=nai e)n Aristoph. Kn. 1132 etc.

We are to suppose that, when she rushed from the scene in her passionate despair (1072), Iocasta passed through the central door of the palace (basi/leios qu/ra) into the qurw/n, a short passage or hall, opening on the court (au)lh/) surrounded by a colonnade (peri/stulon). Across this court she hurried to the qa/lamos or bedroom of the master and mistress of the house, and shut herself into it. Presently Oedipus burst into the court with that cry of which we heard the first accents (1182) as he fled from the scene (bown ei)se/paisen,1252). The messenger and others who were in the court watch him in terror as he raves for a sword and asks for Iocasta. Then the thought strikes him that she is in the qa/lamos. He bursts into it (e)nh/lato1261). They follow. There they find Iocasta dead, and see Oedipus blind himself.

eu)qu\ “straight,” is obviously more forcible here than eu)qu/s, “without delay”; a distinction to which Eur. Hipp. 1197 th\n eu)qu\s *)/argous ka)pidauri/as o(do/n is an exception rare in classical Attic. Nauck, with tasteless caprice, writes eu)qu\s e)s.

a)mfideci/ois here = not simply “both,” but “belonging to both hands” (for a)kmai=s alone would scarcely have been used for “hands ”): so in Soph. OC 1112 e)rei/sate pleuro\n a)mfide/cion can mean, “press your sides to mine on either hand.” a)mfide/cios usu. means “equally deft with either hand ” (ambidexter), opp. to a)mfari/steros, “utterly gauche ” (Ar. fr. 432): hence “ambiguous ” (of an oracle, Hdt. 5.92). The Sophoclean use has at least so much warrant from etymology that decia/, from dek with added s, prop. meant merely “the catcher” or “receiver”: see Curt. Etym. 11.266.

e)pirra/cas' from e)pirra/ssw, Plut. Mor. 356c tou\s de\ suno/ntas e)pidramo/ntas e)pirra/cai to\ pw=ma, hastily put the lid on the chest. Hom. Il. 24.452 qu/rhn d' e)/xe mou=nos e)pi/blhs | ei)la/tinos, to
 trei=s me
 e)pirrh/sseskon *)axaioi/, | trei=s d' a)naoi/geskon k.t.l. (from e)pirrh/ssw). Hesych. e)pirrh/ssei. e)piklei/ei. Plat. Prot. 314c a)mfoi=n toi=n xeroi=n th
 qu/rane)ph/race (from e)para/ssw). In Soph. OC 1503 (xa/laz') e)pirra/casa is intrans.

to
 h)/dh *l. pa/lai nekro/n for the order cp. Soph. OC 1514 ai( polla\ brontai\ diatelei=s: Soph. Phil. 1316: Soph. El. 183: Thuc. 7.23 ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai: Isoc. 4.179 th/n te peri\ h(ma=s a)timi/an gegenhme/nhn: Dem. 18.271 th
 a(pa/ntwna)nqrw/pwn tu/xhn koinh/n: esp. with proper names, as Pind. O. 13.53 ta
 patro\s a)nti/a *mh/deian qeme/nan ga/mon: Soph. El. 283.

paidourgi/an for paidourgo/n, i.e. gunai=ka teknopoio/n (Hdt. 1.59), abstract for concrete: see on 1 (trofh/): cp. Hom. Od. 3.49 new/tero/s e)stin, o(mhliki/h de/ moi au)tw=| (= o(mh=lic). Not acc. in appos. with sentence, “an evil way of begetting children, ” because li/poi | toi=s oi(=sin au)tou=, “left to (or for) his own, ” would then be very weak.

goa=to Cp. Curt. Verb 1.138, Eng. tr. 92: “It seems to me best on all grounds to suppose that shortly before the rise of the Greek Epic the [syllabic] augment became occasionally exposed to the same tendency towards wearing away (Verwitterung) which the a) of a)/ra and the e) of e)/nerqe could not always withstand; that there were, in short, pairs of forms then in use, one with the augment and one withoutThe omission of the syllabic augment in Homer was purely a matter of choicePost-Homeric poetry adopts the power of dispensing with the syllabic augment as an inheritance from its predecessor, and makes the greater use of it in proportion as it is removed from the language of ordinary life. Hence it is that, as is shown by the careful investigations made by Renner (Stud. 1.2.18 ff.), the omission of the syllabic augment is extremely rare in iambic, and far more common in elegiac and lyric verse. Hence, as is shown (Stud. 1.2.259) by Gerth, in the dialogue of tragedy the range of this license is very limited indeed, while the majority of instances of it occur in the slightly Epic style of the messengers” speeches, or still more commonly in lyric passages. “ The tragic r(h/seis here borrow from a practice more marked in epic narrative than in epic speeches. In Homer, where augmented and unaugmented forms are on the whole about equally numerous, the proportion of augmented to unaugmented is in the speeches about 10 to 3, in the narrative about 5 to 7: see Monro, Hom. Grammar sect. 69.

diplou=s acc. plur., a twofold progeny, viz. (1) Oedipus by Laius (e)c a)ndro\s a)/ndra), and (2) her four children by Oedipus (te/kna e)k te/knwn, where the poetical plur. te/knwn is for symmetry with te/kna, as 1176 tou\s teko/ntas = to\n pate/ra).

The order (instead of a)po/llutai, ou)ke/t' oi)=da)is a bold ”hyperbaton “: cp. Soph. OC 1427 ti/s de\ tolmh/sei klu/wn | te\ tou=d' e(/pesqai ta)ndro/s; and Soph. OC 135 ff. Blaydes cp. Eur. Her. 205 soi\ d' w(s a)na/gkh tou/sde bou/lomai fra/sai | sw/|zein, where sw/|zein ought to come before bou/lomai.

foita=|, moves wildly about. Cp. Hom. Il. 15.685 w(\s *ai)/as e)pi\ polla\ qoa/wn i)/kria nhw=n | foi/ta makra\ biba/s— where he has just been likened to a man jumping from one horse to another, qrw/skwn a)/llot' e)p' a)/llon. So of the sharp, sudden visits of the no/sos, Soph. Phil. 808 o)cei=a foita=| kai\ taxei=' a)pe/rxetai. Soph. Aj. 59 foitw=nt' a)/ndra mania/sin no/sois, “raving.” Curtius (Curt. Etym. 417) would refer the word to fu, foita/w coming from fov-i-ta-w, “to be often” (in a place).

porei=n is epexegetic of e)caitw=n, which governs a double accusative. —(e)caitw=n) te o(/pou ki/xoi, optative, and not subj., because the pres.foita=| is historic, representing a deliberative subjunctive, pou= ki/xw; Cp. n. on 72 r(usai/mhn. Xen. Hell. 7.4.39 h)po/rei te o(/ ti xrh/saito tw=| pra/gmati: i.e. his thought was, ti/ xrh/swmai;
a)/rouran see on 1211.
ou)dei\s ga\r a)ndrw=n cp. Aesch. Ag. 662 h)/toi tis e)ce/kleyen h)\ c*)h|th/sato | qeo/s tis, ou)k a)/nqrwpos: Soph. Aj. 243.
w(s u(fhg see on 966.
pu/lais diplai=s the folding doors of the qa/lamos. Hom. Od. 2.344 (the qa/lamos of Odysseus) klhistai\ d' e)/pesan sani/des pukinw=s a)rarui=ai | dikli/des.

puqme/nwn prop. “bases”: Aesch. PB 1046 xqo/na d' e)k puqme/nwn | au)tai=s r(i/zais pneu=ma kradai/noi. Here the “bases” of the klh=|qra (bolts) are the staples or sockets which held them. They were on the inner side of the doors, which Iocasta had closed behind her (1244). The pressure of Oedipus on the outer side forces the bolts, causing them to bend inwards (koi=la).So Oedipus, within the house, gives the order dioi/gein klh=|qra, 1287. Others understand: ”forced the doors from their hinges or posts “: but this gives an unnatural sense to klh=|qra. puqme/nes would then mean the stro/figges (Theophr. Hist. Pl. 5.5.4) or pivots (working in sockets called strofei=s) which served as hinges.

ai)w/raisin expresses that the suspended body was still oscillating, and is thus more than a)rta/nais. ai)w/ra (akin to a)ei/rw, a)/or, a)orth/r, a)/wros “uplifted,” Hom. Od. 12.89, Curt. Etym. 518) meant a swing (as in Modern Greek), or swinging movement: Plat. Phaedo 111e tau=ta de\ pa/nta kinei=n a)/nw te kai\ ka/tw w(/sper ai)w/ran tina\ e)nou=san e)n th=| gh=|, there is a sort of swinging in the earth which moves all these things up and down; ai)wrei=tai dh\ kai\ kumai/nei a)/nw kai\ ka/tw, so they swing and surge: Plat. Laws 789d o(/sa te u(po\ e(autw=n (kinei=tai) h)\ kai\ e)n ai)w/rais (in swings) h)\ kai\ kata\ qa/lattan h)\ kai\ e)f' i(/ppwn o)xoume/nwn. Cp. Athen. 618e h)=n de\ kai\ e)pi\ tai=s e)w/rais tis, e)p' *)hrigo/nh|, h)
 kai\ a)lh=tin kalou=sin w)|dh/n, “at the Feast of Swings there was also a song in memory of Erigone, otherwise called the Song of the Wanderer.” The festival was named e)w=rai (small images, like the oscilla offered to Bacchus, Verg. Georg. 2.389, being hung from trees) because Erigone had hanged herself on the tree under which she had found the corpse of her father Icarius; the name a)lh=tis alluding to her wanderings in search of him. Hesych. s. v. a)lh=tis has e)w/ra: the gloss of Suidas (e)w/ra: u(/ywsis h)\ me/tarsis) is from the schol. here. e)w/rhma for ai)w/rhma (the stage mhxanh/) occurs in schol. Aristoph. Peace 77. ai)wra, however, is the only form for which there is good authority of the classical age. [Eustathius on Hom. Il. 3.108 says: h)ere/qesqai de\ kuri/ws me
 to\ e)n a)e/ri kre/masqai, e)c ou(= kai\ h( ai)w/ra. o(/ti de\ h( r(hqei=sa ai)w/ra kai\ dia\ tou= e yilou= e)/xei th
 a)/rxousan, w(s dhloi= ou) mo/non to\ plektai=s e)w/rais e)mpeplegme/nhn, a)lla\ kai\ to\ mete/wros, e(/teroi e)pagwnize/sqwsan. Prof. Kennedy quotes this to prove ”the classical use of e)w/ra. “ But it rather indicates that this verse furnished the only classical example of e)w/ra known to Eustathius; and there is no proof that here he was following an older or better MS. than L.]

e)mpeplhgme/nen (see crit. n.) would mean ”having dashed herself into“: but this can hardly be justified by the intrans. use of the active, Hom. Od. 22.468 ff. o(/tanpe/leiai | e(/rkei e)niplh/cwsi: nor is it appropriate here in reference to the hanging corpse.
gh=|, locative dat.: see on 20: cp. 1451 nai/ein o)/resin.

deina\ d' For de/ introducing the apodosis after a temporal protasis (even when it is a short one), cp. Hom. Od. 7.46 a)ll' o(/te dh\ basilh=os a)gakluta\ dw/maq' i(/konto, | toi=si de\ mu/qwn h)=rxe qea\ glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh: and Hom. Od. 7.184 e)pei\ spei=sa/n t' e)/pio/n q' o(/son h)/qele qumo/s, | toi=sin d' *)alki/noos a)gorh/sato.

pero/nas (called po/rpai by Eur. Phoen. 62), brooches with long pins which could serve as small daggers: one fastened Iocasta's i(ma/tion on her left shoulder, and another her Doric xitw/n on the right shoulder, which the i(ma/tion did not cover. The Doric xitw/n was sleeveless, and usually made with a slit at each shoulder, requiring the use of brooches. (Cp. Guhl and Koner, Life of the Greeks and Romans, p. 162 Eng. tr.) In “The Harvard Greek Play” (1882), plate 11. p. 26 represents Iocasta with the i(ma/tion thus worn. Cp. Hdt. 5.87, where the Athenian women surround the sole survivor of the expedition to Aegina, kenteu/sas th=|si pero/nh|si tw=n i(mati/wn, and so slay him. Thus too in Eur. Hec. 1170 the women blind Polymestor; po/rpas labou=sai ta\s talaipw/rous ko/ras | kentou=sin, ai(ma/ssousin.

a)/rqra can only mean the sockets of the eye-balls (ku/klwn). “He struck his eye-balls in their sockets,” is a way of saying that he struck them full. a)/rqra could not mean ko/ras (pupils), as the schol. explains it. Eur. has another bold use of the word, Eur. Cycl. 624 siga=te pro\s qew=n, qh=res, h(suxa/zete, | sunqe/ntes a)/rqra sto/matos, i.e. shut your lips and be still.

ou)k o)/yointo k.t.l. His words were: —ou)k o)/yesqe/ me ou)/q' o(poi=' e)/pasxon ou)/q' o(poi=' e)/drwn kaka/, a)ll' e)n sko/tw| to\ loipo
 ou(\s me
 ou)k e)/dei o)/yesqe, ou(\s d' e)/xrh|zon ou) gnw/sesqe: Ye shall not see the evils which I was (unconsciously) suffering and doing [as defiled and defiling], but in darkness henceforth ye shall see those whom ye ought never to have seen [Iocasta and his children], and fail to know those whom I longed to know [his parents, Laius and Iocasta]. -e)/pasxene)/drae)/deie)/xrh|zen can represent nothing but imperfects of the direct discourse: had they represented presents, they must have been pa/sxei, etc., or else pa/sxoi, etc. e)/pasxene)/dra mean “was suffering,” “was doing” all this time, while ye failed to warn me; and express the reciprocal, though involuntary, wrong of the incestuous relation, with its consequences to the offspring. (Cp. Soph. Ant. 171 pai/sante/s te kai\ | plhge/ntes au)to/xeiri su
 mia/smati.)

e)n sko/tw|o)yoi/aq', i.e. ou)k o)/yontai: see on 997. The other verbs being plural (with ku/kloi for subject), the subject toe)/xrh|zen cannot be a)/rqra ku/klwn, but only Oed. He had craved to learn his true parentage (782 ff.). o)yoi/ato, gnwsoi/ato, Ionic, as Soph. OC 44 decai/ato, 921 puqoi/ato, 945 decoi/ato: Soph. El. 211 a)ponai/ato: Aesch. Pers. 369 feucoi/ato, 451 e)kswzoi/ato: Eur. Her. 547 e)ktisai/ato: Eur. Hel. 159 a)ntidwrhsai/ato. So Thuc. 3.13 can say e)fqa/ratai *)aqhnai=oiai( d' e)f' h(mi=n teta/xatai (and 4. 31, 5. 6, 7. 4).

e)fumnw=n of imprecation, as Soph. Ant. 1305 kaka\s | pra/ceis e)fumnh/sasa tw=| paidokto/nw|: here the idea of repetition is also suggested: cp. Soph. Aj. 292 bai/' a)ei\ d' u(mnou/mena: so Lat. canere, decantare.

Cp. Soph. Ant. 52 o)/yeis a)ra/cas au)to\s au)tourgw=| xeri/. o(mou= = at each blow (hence imperf. e)/teggon):but in 1278 o(mou= = all at once, not drop by drop (a)stakti/, and not sta/gdhn). See on 517 (fe/ron).

The best choice lies between Heath's o)/mbros xala/zhs ai(matou=s and Porson's o)/mbros xa/laza/ q' ai(matou=ss'. The fact that all the MSS. have xala/zhs and that most (including L, A) have ai(/matos favours Heath's reading, which is also the stronger. Dindorf prefers Porson's on the ground that such forms as ai)matou=s, ai(matou=n are rarer than the feminine forms; but this seems an inadequate reason. Seneca's free paraphrase (Oed. 978 rigat ora foedus imber, et lacerum caput Largum revulsis sanguinem venis vomit) affords no clue as to his text of Sophocles. me/las o)/mbros ai(matou=s xala/zhs = a shower of dark blood-drops rushing down as fiercely as hail: cp. Soph. OC 1502 o)mbri/a | xa/laz' e)pirra/casa. Pindar has e)n polufqo/rw|*dio\s o)/mbrw| | a)nari/qmwn a)ndrw=n xalaza/enti fo/nw| (Pind. I. 4.49) of a slaughter in which deathblows are rained thick as hail; and so xa/lazan ai(/matos (Pind. I. 6.27): so that the resemblance is only verbal.

Soph. cannot have written these two verses as they stand; and the fault is doubtless in 1280. Porson's ou)x e(no\s mo/nou. though plausible, is in sense somewhat weak, and does not serve to connect 1280 with 1281. In the conjecture, ou) mo/nou ka/ta, the force of the prep. is suitable to the image of a descending torrent which overwhelms: and for its place cp. Soph. Aj. 969 ti/ dh=ta tou=d' e)peggelw=|en a)\n ka/ta; Soph. Aj. 302 lo/goustou\s me\n *)atreidw=n ka/ta.
o( pri\n = which they had till lately: palaio\s, because the house of the Labdacidae was a)rxaio/ploutos; tracing its line to Cadmus and Agenor, 268.
dikai/ws in a true sense: cp. 853.

Instead of kaka\ pa/nta, o(/sa o)noma/zetai, pa/restin, we have o(/s' e)sti\ pa/ntwn o)no/mata, (tou/twn) ou)de/n e)st' a)po/n: o)/noma kakou= standing for kako\n o)nomazo/menon. So Aesch. PB 210 *gai=a, pollw=n o)nma/twn morfh\ mi/a = morfh\ mi/a qea=s pollaxw=s o)nomazome/nhs.

e)/n tini is right. Even if ti/s sxolh\ kakou= could mean “what form of respite from misery?” ti/ni would be less suitable. The Chorus mean: “and is he now calmer?” —to which the answer is that he is still vehemently excited.
mhte/r' (Schneidewin), suggested by Aristoph. Wasps 1178, would debase this passage.

do/mois a)rai=os fraught with a curse for the house, making it accursed, w(s h)ra/sato, in terms of his own curse (238 mh/t' ei)sde/xesqai mh/te prosfwnei=n, k.t.l.), according to which anyone who was knowingly cune/stios with the criminal incurred the like curse as he (270). Cp. Eur. Med. 608 kai\ soi=s a)rai/a g' ou)=sa tugxa/nw do/mois, i.e. bring a curse on it. Eur. IT 778 (ko/misai/ me)h)\ soi=s a)rai/a dw/masin genh/somai. Aesch. Ag. 236 fqo/ggon a)rai=on oi)/kois. Not menw=n do/mois, as though the dat. were locative, like gh=|, 1266.
h)\ fe/rein Eur. Hec. 1107 krei/sson' h)\ fe/rein kaka/: the fuller constr., Hdt. 3.14 me/zw kaka\ h)\ w(/ste a)naklai/ein.

The subject to dei/cei is Oedipus. Cp. Soph. Aj. 813 xwrei=n e(/toimos, kou) lo/gw| dei/cw mo/non. Soph. OC 146 dhlw= d': “and I prove it” (viz. that I am wretched), like tekmh/rion de/. In Aristoph. Eccl. 933 dei/cei ge kai\ soi/: ta/xa ga\r ei)=sin w(s e)me/, a person just mentioned is the subject of both verbs, as just afterwards we have, Aristoph. Eccl. 936, dei/cei ta/x' au)to/s. On the other hand the verb seems really impersonal in Aristoph. Frogs 1261 pa/nu ge me/lh qaumasta/: dei/cei dh\ ta/xa (for the subject cannot well be either me/lh or Aeschylus): and so in Hdt. 2.134 die/dece, it was made clear: as Hdt. 2.117 dhloi=, it is manifest. In Hdt. 3.82, however, the subject to die/dece may be mounarxi/h. Cp. Plat. Hipp. Maj. 288b ei) d' e)pixeirh/sas e)/stai katage/lastos, au)to\ dei/cei (the event will show): cp. Plat. Theaet. 200e, and see on 341. The central door of the palace is now opened. Oedipus comes forth, leaning on attendants; the bloody stains are still upon his face.

oi(=on e)poikti/sai proper for one to pity, kai\ stugou=nta, even though he abhors it. The infin. with oi(=os, as with other adjectives of ability or fitness (i(kano/s, e)pith/deios, etc.): so, too, with o(/sos as = sufficient ”: Xen. Anab. 4.1.5 e)lei/peto th=s nukto\s o(/son skotai/ous dielqei=n to\ pedi/on. Cp. Soph. Trach. 672: fr. 598. 8 feu=: ka)\n a)noikti/rmwn tis oi)kti/reie/ nin.

A kommo/s (see p. 9). The Chorus begin with anapaests (1297 -1306). The first words uttered by Oedipus are in the same measure (1307 -1311). Then, after a single iambic trimeter spoken by the Chorus (1312), (1) 1st strophe 1313-1320 = (2) 1st antistrophe 1321-1328; (3) 2nd strophe 1329 -1348 = (4) 2nd antistrophe 1349-1368. Oedipus here speaks in dochmiac measures blended with iambic; the Chorus, in iambic trimeters or dimeters only. The effect of his passionate despair is thus heightened by metrical contrast with a more level and subdued strain of sorrow. Compare Soph. Aj. 348-429, where the kommo/s has in this sense a like character. Some regard the kommo/s as beginning only at 1313; less correctly, I think. Its essence is the antiphonal lament rather than the antistrophic framework.

o(/saprose/kursa I know no other example of an accus. after proskurei=n, which usu. takes the dat.: but the compound can at least claim the privilege of the simple kurei=n. The neut. plur. accus. of pronouns and adjectives can stand after tugxa/nein and kurei=n, not as an accus. directly governed by the verb, but rather as a species of cognate or adverbial accus.: Soph. Phil. 509 a)=ql' oi(=a mhdei\s tw=n e)mw=n tu/xoi fi/lwn: Soph. OC 1106 ai)tei=s a(\ teu/cei (which need not be explained by attraction): Aesch. Lib. 711 tugxa/nein ta\ pro/sfora, Aesch. Lib. 714 kurou/ntwnta\ pro/sfora: Eur. Phoen. 1666 ou) ga\r a)\n tu/xois ta/de: cp. Munro on Aesch. Ag. 1228 ff. oi)=ateu/cetai in Journ. Phil. 11.134. In Eur. Hipp. 746 te/rmona ku/rwn is not similar, since ku/rwn = “reaching, ” and the accus. is like that after a)fiknei=sqai.

o( phdh/sasmoi/ra|; “who is the deity that hath sprung upon thy hapless life with a leap greater than the longest leap?” i.e. “has given thee sorrow which almost exceeds the imaginable limit of human suffering? ” For mei/zona tw=n maki/stwn see on 465 a)/rrht' a)rrh/twn. The idea of a malignant god leaping from above on his victim is frequent in Greek tragedy: see on 263. But here maki/stwn, as in 311 i(/na, combines the notion of swooping from above with that of leaping to a far point, — as with Pindar makra\a(/lmata (Pind. N. 5.19) denote surpassing poetical efforts. We should then conceive the dusdai/mwn moi=ra, the ill-fated life, as an attacked region, far into which the malign god springs. Here we see a tendency which may sometimes be observed in the imagery (lyric especially) of Sophocles: the image is slightly crossed and blurred by the interposing notion of the thing: as here he was thinking, “what suffering could have gone further?” See on di' ai)qe/ra teknwqe/ntes, 866. With Aeschylus, on the other hand, the obscurity of imagery seldom or never arises from indistinctness of outline, but more often from an opposite cause, —the vividly objective conception of abstract notions.

pro\s with dat., after a verb of throwing or falling, is warranted by epic usage: Hom. Od. 5.415 mh/pws m' e)kbai/nonta ba/lh| li/qaki poti\ pe/trh| | ku=ma me/g' a(/rpacan: Hom. Il. 20.420 liazo/menon proti\ gai/h|, sinking to earth. Soph. Aj. 95 pro\sstratw=|, 97 pro\s *)atrei/daisin are different, since no motion is strictly implied. Here the conjecture e)pi\ is metrically admissible (Aesch. Ag. 66 ka/makos qh/swn *danaoi=si, Aesch. Pers. 48 fobera\n o)/yin proside/sqai), but needless.

The Attic du/sthn' harmonises with sh=| (1302) and fri/khn (1306), while du/stan' would hardly be confirmed by maki/stwn, since Tragedy used the latter form, and not mh/kistos, in dialogue also (Aesch. fr. 275: cp. Aesch. Ag. 289: so Aesch. Pers. 698 makisth=ra). The use of Attic forms by the Chorus helps to bring out the more passionate lyric tone which Doricisms lend to the words of Oedipus (1307 f.). Cp. n. on Soph. Ant. 804 ff.
