The fate of Oedipus is a dark and dreadful mystery into which they are fain to peer (a)nere/sqai, puqe/sqai: cp. the questions at 1299 ff., 1327): in its visible presentment it has a fascination (a)qrh=sai)even for those whom it fills with horror.

diape/tatai (MSS.) is unquestionably corrupt. The view that these are anapaests of the “freer kind ” ( “ex liberioribus, ” Herm.) does not explain a verse which is not anapaestic at all. diapwta=tai is far the most probable remedy. The epic pwta=sqai, which Pind. uses, is admissible in lyrics. When there is no caesura after the 2nd foot, there is usually one in the 3rd: cp. however Aesch. PB 172 kai/ m' ou)/ ti meliglw/ssois peiqous: and Aristoph. Birds 536, Aristoph. Peace 1002. Cp. Soph. OC 1771 diakwlu/sw | men i)o/nta fo/non. The wilder and more rugged effect of such a rhythm makes it preferable here to fqogga\ fora/dhn diapwta=tai, though the hiatus before i)w\ (in 1311) would be justified by the pause. To the conjecture pe/tetai(or pe/tatai)it may be objected that the notion of dispersed sounds supports the compound with dia/. Hermann simply omitted diape/tatai, dividing thus: ai)ai=—| du/stanos—| tla/mwn; pa= moi fqogga\ fopa/dhn; Bergk, pa= moi | fqogga/; dia/ moi pe/tatai fora/dhn. Schneidewin (ed. Nauck) pa= moi fqogga/; | fora/dhn, w)= dai=mon, e)nh/lw.

fora/dhn = “in the manner of that which is carried ”; here correlative to fe/resqai as said of things which are swept onward by a tide or current: thus, of persons deficient in self-restraint, Plat. Theaet. 144b a)/|ttontes fe/rontai w(/sper ta\ a)nerma/tista ploi=a, they are hurried away on currents like boats without ballast: Plat. Crat. 411c r(ei=n kai\ fe/resqai: Plat. Rep. 496d pneu=ma fero/menon. He has newly lost the power of seeing those to whom he speaks. He feels as if his voice was borne from him on the air in a direction over which he has no control. With the use of the adverb here, cp. ba/dhn, droma/dhn, su/dhn. Elsewhere fora/dhn is parallel with fe/resqai as = to be carried, instead of walking: Eur. Andr. 1166 fora/dhndw=ma pela/zei, i.e. borne in a litter: Dem. 54.20 u(gih\s e)celqw\n fora/dhn h)=lqon oi)/kade. Such adverbs in -dhn, which were probably accusatives cognate to the notion of the verb, are always formed from the verbal stem, (a) directly, like ba/-dhn, or (b) with modified vowel and inserted a, like fora/dhn instead of * ferdhn, spora/dhn instead of * sperdhn.

e)ch/lou In a paroemiac, the foot before the catalectic syllable is usually an anapaest, seldom, as here (e)ch/l—), a spondee: but cp. Aesch. Pers. 33 i(/ppwn t' e)lath\r *swsqanhs: Aesch. Supp. 7 yh/fw| po/lews gnwsqei=sai: Aesch. Supp. 976 ba/cei law=n e)n xw/rw|: Aesch. Ag. 366 be/los h)li/qion skh/yeien. L and A are of the MSS. which give e)ch/lou: and good MS. authority supports e)nh/lou in Aesch. Pers. 516, ei)saloi/mhn in Soph. fr. 685, h(/lonto in Xen. Hell. 4.4.11. The evidence, so far as it goes, seems to indicate that, while h(la/mhn (itself rare in prose) was preferred in the indicative, a form h(lo/mhn was also admitted: see Veitch, Irreg. Verbs, ed. of 1879. Blaydes gives e)ch/lw: Elms. gave e)ca/lw, “inaudite dwri/zwn, ” in Ellendt's opinion: but Veitch quotes Theocr. 17.100 e)ca/lato. The imperf. e)ch/llou, which Dindorf, Campbell and others read, was explained by Hermann as = tendebas, i.e. “whither wast thou purposing to leap? ” To this I feel two objections: (1) the unfitness of thus representing a swift act: (2) the use of i(/na, which means where. This could not be used with the imperfect of a verb of motion (as i(/na e)/baine, instead of oi(=), but only with the perfect, as i(/na be/bhke (i.e. where is he now) or the aorist when equivalent to the perfect: as Soph. OC 273 i(ko/mhn (I have come) i(/n' i(ko/mhn. So, here, the aor. alone seems admissible: i(/n' e)ch/lou, where hast thou leaped to, i.e. where art thou? cp. 1515 i(/n' e)ch/keis, and see on 947.

a)po/tropon = o(/ tis a)
 a)potre/poito (Hesych.): and so Soph. Aj. 608 to
 a)po/tropon a)i/+dhlon *(/aidan, such as all would turn away from, abhorred. Not, “turning away from others,” “solitary,” as Bion Idyll. 2.2 to
 a)po/tropon*)/erwta.
e)piplo/menon = e)pipelo/menon, pres. part., as Hom. Od. 7.261 e)piplo/menon e)/tos h)=lqe.

dusou/riston is defective by one syllable as compared with 1323 tuflo\n khdeu/wn. Now the second syllable of khdeu/wn is “irrational, ” i.e. it is a long syllable doing metrical duty for a short one (the third of an antibacchius, \h\\h\\v\). Hence in this verse also the penultimate syllable can be either long or short. Hermann's dusou/riston o)/n is therefore metrically admissible. It is, however, somewhat weak, and the sound is most unpleasing. I should rather propose dusou/rist' i)o/n: for the adverbial neut. plur., cp. u(pe/roptaporeu/etai (883, where see note); for the part., Plat. Laws 873e para\ qeou=be/los i)o/n. Nauck conjectured dusoiw/niston. Blaydes gives dusecou/riston(not found), in the dubious sense of “hard to escape from. ”

ke/ntrwn not literally the pins of the brooches, (which we can scarcely suppose that he still carried in his hands,) but the stabs which they had dealt: as piercing pangs are ke/ntra, Soph. Trach. 840.
e)n tosoi=sde ph/masin when thy woes are so many: cp. 893 e)n toi=sd'.

penqei=nkai\ fe/rein The form of the sentence, in dependence on qau=ma ou)de/n, seems to exclude the version: “It is not strange that, as you bear, so you should mourn, a double pain ” (parataxis for hypotaxis). Rather the sense is: “that you should mourn (aloud) and (inwardly) suffer a double pain ” — i.e., the physical pain of the wounds, and the mental pain of retrospect. I do not agree with Schneidewin in referring dipla= penqei=n to the double oi)/moi (1316 f.) as = “make a twofold lament.” The fe/rein of A must be right. forei=n can stand for fe/rein “to carry” when habitual carrying is implied (Hdt. 3.34, and of bearers in Soph. Trach. 965): or fig., of mental habit (h)=qos forei=n Soph. Ant. 705): but forei=n kaka/ could only mean “to carry ills about with thee ”; which is not appropriate here.

mo/nimos steadfast: Xen. Cyrop. 8.5.11 oi( monimw/tatoi pro/sqen o)/ntes (said of hoplites). Cp. Soph. Aj. 348 ff. where Ajax addresses the Chorus as mo/noi e)mw=n fi/lwn, | mo/noi e)mme/nontes e)/t' o)rqw=| no/mw|.

A distinct echo of Hom. Il. 24.563 kai\ de\ se\ gignw/skw, *pri/ame, fresi/n, ou)de/ me lh/qeis. Besides lh/qw, lh/sw, le/lhqa, Soph. has e)/lhqon (Soph. El. 1359). Cp. Soph. OC 891, where Oed. recognises the voice of Theseus.
skoteino/s cp. Soph. Aj. 85 e)gw\ skotw/sw ble/fara kai\ dedorko/ta.

*)apo/llwn The memory of Oedipus (cp. 1318) is connecting the oracle given to him at Delphi (789) with the mandate which afterwards came thence (106). Apollo was the author of the doom (telw=n),but the instrument of execution (e)/paise)was the hand of Oedipus.

o( kaka\ kaka\ k.t.l. The dochmiac metre is sound (see Metrical Analysis): it is noma/dos in the antistrophe (1350) which is corrupt. Prof. Campbell, however, retaining the latter, here changes the second kaka\ to kakw=s, and the first e)ma\ to e)moi/. The iteration of ta/de, kaka\, e)ma\ is in a style which the lyrics of tragedy admitted where vehement agitation was expressed. Euripides carried it to excess. But here, at least, it is in place.

nin ta\s o)/yeis (1328). —ou)/tis (a)/llos), a)ll': cp. Hom. Od. 8.311 a)ta\r ou(/ ti/ moi ai)/tios a)/llos | a)lla\ tokh=e du/w. Schneid. cp. Hom. Il. 21.275 a)/llos d' ou)/tis moi to/son ai)/tios ou)raniw/nwn | a)lla\ [instead of o(/son] fi/lh mh/thr.

The simple mode of expression would have been: ti/ e)moi\ h(de/ws blepto/n, h)\ sterkto/n, h)\ a)kousto\n e)/t' e)sti/n; what henceforth can be pleasurably seen, or loved, or heard by me? But instead of the third clause, we haveh)\ prosh/goron | e)/t' e)/st' a)kou/ein h(dona=|, “or what greeting is it longer possible for me to hear with pleasure? ” prosh/goron, passive in Soph. Phil. 1353, is here active, as in Soph. Ant. 1185 *palla/dos qea=s | o(/pws i(koi/mhn eu)gma/twn prosh/goros. h(dona=|, modal dat. adverbially, as o)rgh=| 405. The form h(dona/n, intermediate between Attic h(donh/n and Doric a(dona/n, is given by L in Soph. El. 1277, where Herm. keeps it, but most edd. give a(dona/n. If right, it was a compromise peculiar to tragedy. The Doricism of scenic lyrics was not thoroughgoing: here, for instance, we have tla/mwn (1333) yet prosh/goron (1338).
e)kto/pion cp. 1411 qala/ssion, and see Appendix on v. 478.

to\n me/g' o)le/qrion is a certain correction of the MS. to\n o)le/qrion me/gan (or me/ga), a corruption due to the omission and subsequent marginal insertion of me/ga. Cp. Hom. Il. 1.158 w)= me/g' a)naide/s: 16. 46 me/ga nh/pios: Soph. Phil. 419 me/ga | qa/llontes. The antistrophic words are au)to\s e)/fun ta/las (1363). o)le/qrion, pass., “lost, ” as Soph. Trach. 878 ta/lain' o)leqri/a. ti/ni tro/pw| qanei=n sfe fh/s; The objections to the conject. o)/leqron me/gan(metrically admissible as a dochmiac, if the second of o)/leqron is made short) are: (1) the awkward necessity of supplying o)/nta in order to defend the position of me/gan: (2) the phrase o)/leqron, which belongs to the colloquial vocabulary of abuse; Dem. 18.127 peri/trimma a)gora=s, o)/leqros grammateu/s.
He is to be pitied alike for the intrinsic misery of his fate, and for his full apprehension (sune/sews, schol.) of it. A clouded mind would suffer less.

a)
 with h)qe/lhsa: ge emphasises mhde/. Oedipus had been the all-admired (8), the “saviour of the land ” (48). But now the Theban elders wish that they had never so much as heard his name or looked upon his face. That bitter cry is drawn from them by the very strength of their sympathy: for his ruin was the result of his coming to Thebes. The objections to the reading of the MSS., w(/s s' h)qe/lhsa mhd' a)nagnw=nai/ pote, are these: (1) Eur. Hel. 290 has the 1st aor. pass., a)negnw/sqhmen a)/n, “we should have been recognised ”: but a)nagignw/skein occurs nowhere else in tragedy; and in Attic its regular sense was “to read,” or in the 1st aor. act., “to persuade.” I have not found a single example of a)nagignw/skw as = a)nagnwri/zw ( “to recognise ”) in Thuc., Plato, Xen., or the Orators. (2) But the 2nd aor. has that sense in Homer, in Pind. I. 2.23 and in Hdt. 2.91: may not an Attic poet have followed them? Granted. The sense required here, however, after mhde/, is to know, not to recognise: the latter would be pointless. (3) The ellipse of a)/n with the aor. h)qe/lhsa would be strangely harsh. Such an ellipse with the imperf. sometimes occurs: as Antiph. 5.1 e)boulo/mhn (and so Aristoph. Frogs 866), Antiph. 5.86 h)ci/oun. But if, as seems clear, a)/n is required here, then the probability is strengthened that a)nagnw=nai arose from a)
 gnw=nai. Between Dindorf's w(s h)qe/lhsa mhde/ s' a)
 gnw=nai and Hermann's w(/s s' h)qe/lhsa mhde/ g' a)
 gnw=nai the question is: Which is more likely to have passed into the reading of the MSS.? Now they have w(/s s', and the loss of g' through a confusion with the same letter in gnw=nai is slightly more probable than the double error of omitting s' before a)
 and inserting it afterw(s.

The noma/dos of the MSS. is corrupt. It would require an improbable alteration in the strophe (see on 1330); and it yields no good sense. The Scholiasts hesitated between rendering it (1) “feeding on my flesh ”! or (2) “in the pastures.” Reading noma/d', we have a dochmiac dimeter, agreeing with 1330: see Metrical Analysis. But the use of the word is extraordinary. It must mean e)n nomai=s, “in the pastures”—said of the babe whom the shepherd had been ordered to expose on Cithaeron. Now elsewhere noma/s always means “roaming,” said (e.g.) of pastoral tribes, or of animals: Soph. Trach. 271 i(/ppous noma/das e)cixnoskopw=n, tracking horse that had strayed: fr. 87 noma\s de/ tis kerou=ss' a)p' o)rqi/wn pa/gwn | kaqei=rpen e)/lafos: of waters wandering over the land which they irrigate, Soph. OC 686 krh=nai| *khfisou= noma/des r(ee/qrwn. The idea of wandering movement is inseparable from the word. To apply it to a babe whose feet were pinned together would have been indeed a bold use. Prof. Campbell, retaining noma/dos, takes pe/das as acc. plur.: “that loosed the cruel clog upon my feet, when I was sent astray.” But could noma/s, ‘roaming, ’ be said of the maimed child merely in the sense of ‘turned adrift’ by its parents? The nomin. noma\s, referring to the roving shepherd (pla/nhs 1029) would be intelligible; but the quadruple -as is against it. Now cp. Aesch. Pers. 734 mona/da de\ *ce/rchn e)/rhmon, “Xerxes alone and forlorn. ” Simply transposing n and m I conjecture mona/d', a word appropriate to the complaint that the babe, sent to the lonely mountain, had not been left to perish in its solitude. The fact that the Corinthian shepherd received the child from the Theban is no objection: the child was fi/lwn memonwme/nos, desolate and forlorn. e)/lus', which suits the dochmiac as well as e)/labe/ m', is more forcible here. There is a further argument for it. The MSS. give a)p' a)gri/as in 1349, but the strophe (1329) shows that a)p' must be omitted, since *)apo/llwn, fi/loi = o(\s a)gri/as pe/das, the first syllable of a)gri/as being short, as in 1205, Soph. Ant. 344, 1124. Now pe/das (i.e. pe/dhs) e)/labe, took from the fetter, would be too harsh: we could only do as Schneidewin did, and refer a)po/ back to pe/das: but though *delfw=n ka)po\ *dauli/as (734) admits of such treatment, the case is dissimilar here. On the other hand pe/das e)/lus', loosed from the fetter, is correct. Thus the metrical impossibility of a)p' confirms e)/lus'. The epithet a)gri/a, “cruel, ” is applied to pe/dh as it is to o)du/nh in Soph. Trach. 975.

e)/rruto a strong aorist of r(u/w, formed as if there were a present r(u/mi: in Hom. Il. 18.515 r(u/ato for r(u/nto is its 3rd plur. Cp. Hom. Il. 5.23 e)/ruto sa/wse de/, where the aor. has a like relation to e)ru/w (the temporal augment being absent).
ei)s xa/rin see on 1152.
qe/lonti Soph. OC 1505 poqou=nti prou)fa/nhs: Soph. Trach. 18: Thuc. 2.3 tw=| ga\r plh/qeiou) boulome/nw| h)=na)fi/stasqai: Tac. Agric. 18 quibus bellum volentibus erat.

foneu\s h)=lqon have come to be the slayer, a compressed phrase for e)s tosou=ton h)=lqon w(/ste foneu\s ei)=nai: cp. 1519 and Soph. Ant. 752 h)= ka)papeilw=n w)=d' e)pece/rxei qrasu/s; Soph. Trach. 1157 e)ch/keis d' i(/na | fanei=. Hom. Il. 18.180 ei)/ ke/n ti ne/kus h)|sxumme/nos e)/lqh|, come to be dishonoured (where some explain, “reach thee dishonoured ”): in Xen. Anab. 3.2.3 o(/mws de\ dei= e)k tw=n paro/ntwn a)/ndras a)gaqou\s e)lqei=n (so the MSS.: tele/qein G. Sauppe) kai\ mh\ u(fi/esqai, the clause e)k tw=n paro/ntwn helps e)lqei=n as = evadere. In 1433 e)lqw/n is not similar. No classical use of venire seems really parallel: thus in Iuv. 7.29 ut dignus venias hederis, venias = “may come forward ” (Mayor ad loc.).
(tou/twn) a)f' w(=n, i.e. tau/ths a)f' h(=s: plur., as 1095, 1176, 1250.

a)/qeos is a necessary correction of the MS. a)/qlios, the verse being a dochmiac dimeter, = 1340 a)pa/get' e)kto/pion o(/ti ta/xista/ me. nu=n answers to the short first syllable of a)pa/get', since the anacrusis can be either long or short: cp. Aesch. Seven 181, where ai)qeri/a ko/nis is metrically parallel to nu=n d' a)/qeos me/n ei)m' here. He is a)nosi/wn (i.e. a)nosi/as) pai=s since through him Iocasta became such.

o(mogenh\s d' a)f' w(=n e)/fun = koino
 ge/nos e)/xwn (tou/tois) a)f' w)=n au)to\s e)/fun: i.e. having a common brood (one born of the same wife) with those (Laius) from whom he sprang. For the plur., cp. 366: for (tou/tois) w(=n, Soph. Phil. 957 pare/cw dai=q' u(f' w)=n e)ferbo/mhn. o(mogenh\s is usu. taken as = o(mou= gennw=n, i.e. “engendering ” o(mou= th=| tekou/sh|. But o(mogenh/s is a compound from o(mo- and the stem of ge/nos, and could no more mean gennw=n o(mou= than suggenh/s could mean gennw=n su
, or e)ggenh/s, gennw=n e)n. In 460 patro\s o(mo/sporos as = spei/rwn th
 au)th
 h(
 o( path/r is different, since the second part of the compound adj. represents a transitive verb. Meineke's o(molexh\s would be better than Musgrave's o(mo/gamos: but neither is needed.

presbu/teron “older,” then, “ranking before”; here, “more serious ”: Hdt. 5.63 ta\ ga\r tou= qeou= presbu/tera e)poieu=nto h)\ ta\ tw=n a)ndrw=n: Thuc. 4.61 tou=topresbu/tatonkri/nas, to\ koinw=s fobero\n a(/pantas ei)= qe/sqai.

krei/sswnh)=sqa mhke/t' w)/n = krei=sson h)=n se mhke/t' ei)=nai: see on 1061. a)/n is omitted, as after e)/dei, ei)ko\s h(=n, etc., krei/sswn h)=sqa mh\ w)/n implying the thought, ou)k a)\n h)=sqa, ei) ta\ be/ltista e)/pasxes: see on 256.
a)/rist' is adverbial, the construction being ou)x w)=de (ei)rgasme/na) e)sti\n a)/rista ei)rgasme/na: that, thus done, they are not done best. So a)/rista is adverb 407, 1046, Soph. Aj. 160.

ble/pwn = ei) e)/blepon, which is more forcible than to take it with poi/ois o)/mmasin. Cp. Soph. Phil. 110 pw=s ou)=n ble/pwn tis tau=ta tolmh/sei lalei=n; Hdt. 1.37 nu=n te te/oisi/ me xrh\ o)/mmasi e)/s te a)gorh\n kai\ e)c a)gorh=s foite/onta fai/nesqai; Dem. 25.98 (the work of a later rhetorician) poi/ois prosw/pois h)\ ti/sin o)fqalmoi=s pro\s e(/kaston tou/twn a)ntible/yete; Cp. Soph. Aj. 462 kai\ poi=on o)/mma patri\ dhlw/sw fanei\s | *telamw=ni;

ei)s *(/aidou Blind on earth, Oed. will be blind in the nether world. Cp. Hom. Od. 12.266 kai/ moi e)/pos e)/mpese qumw=| | ma/nthos a)laou= *qhbai/ou *teiresi/ao, where Odysseus is thinking of the blind Teiresias as he had found him in Hades. Cp. Hom. Od. 11.91, where e)/gnw need not imply that the poet of the ne/kuia conceived Teiresias as having sight. So Achilles in Hades is still swift-footed (Hom. Od. 11.546).

oi)=nduoi=n a dative of the persons affected, as, instead of the usual poiw= tau=ta/ se, we sometimes find poiw= tau=ta/ soi: cp. Soph. Trach. 808 (drw=s'): Hom. Od. 14.289 trw/kths, o(\s dh\ polla\ ka/k' a)nqrw/poisin e)w/rgei. Plat. Apol. 30a tau=ta kai\ newte/rw| kai\ preseute/rw|poih/sw, kai\ ce/nw| kai\ a)stw=|, ma=llon de\ toi=s a)stoi=s. Plat. Charm. 157c ou)k a)
 e)/xoimen o(/ ti poioi=me/n soi. Xen. Hiero 7.2 toiau=ta ga dh\ poiou=si toi=s tura/nnois oi( a)rxo/menoi kai\ a)/llon o(/ntin' a(
 a)ei\ timw=ntes tugxa/nwsi. Aristoph. Wasps 1350 polloi=s ga h)/dh xa(te/rois au)/t' ei)rga/sw. In Xen. Anab. 5.8.24 tou/tw| ta/nanti/a poih/sete h)\ tou\s ku/nas poiou=si, there is warrant for tou=ton: and in Isoc. 16.49 mhde
 a)gaqo
 poih/sas th=| po/lei, for th
 po/lin.

krei/sson' a)gxo/nhs not “worse than hanging ” (such that, rather than do them, he would have hanged himself): but “too bad for hanging ” (such that suicide by hanging would not adequately punish their author). Eur. Hipp. 1217 ei)sorw=si de\ | qe/ama krei=sson dergma/twn e)fai/neto, too dreadful to be looked on: Aesch. Ag. 1376 u)/yos krei=sson e)kphdh/matos, too high to be leaped over. a)gxo/nhs: cp. Eur. Alc. 229: Aristoph. Ach. 125 tau=ta dh=t' ou)k a)gxo/nh; “is not this enough to make one hang oneself? ”

a)ll' introduces (or answers) a supposed objection (the u(pofora/ of technical Rhetoric): Andoc. 1.148 ti/na ga\r kai\ a)nabiba/somai dehso/menon u(pe\r e)mautou=; to\n pate/ra; a)lla\ te/qnhken. a)lla\ tou\s a)delfou/s; a)ll' ou)k ei)si/n. a)lla\ tou\s pai=das; a)ll' ou)/pw gege/nhntai.
te/knwn o)/yisblastou=sa = o(rw/mena te/kna blasto/nta: cp. Eur. Alc. 967 *qrh/|ssais e)n sani/sin ta\s | *)orfei/a kate/grayen gh=rus, which the melodious Orpheus wrote down.

pu/rgos the city-wall with its towers and its seven gates (already famous in the Hom. Od. 11.263 *qh/bhs e(/dos e(ptapu/loio). Cp. Eur. Ba. 170 *ka/dmono(\s po/lin *sidwni/an | lipw\n e)pu/rgws' a)/stu *qhbai=on to/de. Eur. Hec. 1209 pe/ric de\ pu/rgos ei)=x' e)/ti pto/lin.
a)ga/lmaq' i(era/ the images of the gods in their temples: cp. 20.
tw=n = w(=n, as Soph. Ant. 1086: cp. 1427. Soph. has this use in many other places of dialogue: see Soph. OC 747 n.

ka/llist' a)nh\r ei(=strafei/s. ei(=s in connection with a superlative, is strictly correct only where one is compared with several: as Thuc. 8.40 oi( ga\r oi)ke/tai toi=s *xi/ois polloi\ o)/ntes kai\ mia=| ge po/lei plh\n *lakedaimoni/wn plei=stoi geno/menoi: Eur. Heraclid. 8 plei/stwn mete/sxon ei)=s a)nh\r *(hrakle/ei. So Soph. Trach. 460 plei/stas a)nh\r ei(=se)/ghme. But here, where the question is of degree in nobility, it merely strengthens ka/llist': cp. Thuc. 8.68 plei=sta ei)=s a)nh/r, o(/stis cumbouleu/saito/ ti, duna/menos w)felei=n: which, notwithstanding plei=sta, is really like our passage, since we cannot suppose a contrast with the collective wisdom of several advisers.

e)/n ge tai=s Qh/bais the ge, by adding a second limitation, helps, like ei)=s a)nh/r, to emphasise the superlative. If the glories of Thebes can rejoice the sight, no Theban at least had a better right to that joy: (and who could have a better right than Thebans?)

a)peste/rhs' e)mauto/n a regular phrase in reference to separation from civic life: Antiph. 5.78 ei) d' e)n *ai)/nw| xwrofilei=, tou=to ou)k a)posterw=n ge tw=n ei)s th\n po/lin e(auto\n ou)deno\s (not forfeiting any of his relations with Athens) ou)d' e(te/ras po/lews poli/ths gegenhme/nos: Dem. 13.22 ou)deno\s e)/rgwn tw=n to/te a)peste/rhsan e(autou/s, the Athenians of those days did not renounce their share in any of the great deeds of the Persian Wars.

to
 a)sebh= naturally depends on w)qei=n. But, if so, it would be very awkward to take to
fane/nta k.t.l. with a)peste/rhs' e)mauto/n. Rather to
 fane/nta k.t.l. also depends on w)qei=n. “Bidding all to expel the impious one, —that man who has [since] been shown by the gods to be unholy—and of the race of Laius. ” His thought passes from the unknown person of the edict to himself, precisely as in 1440 f. The words kai\ ge/nous tou= *lai/+ou are a climax, since the guilt of bloodshed, which the oracle had first denounced, was thus aggravated by a double horror.
khli=da see on 833: mhnu/sas e)mh/n, sc. ou)=san.
o)rqoi=s see on 528.

th=s a)kouou/shsphgh=s the source (viz. the orifice of the ear) from which sounds flow in upon the sense: cp. Plat. Phaedrus 245c yuxh/phgh\ kai\ a)rxh\ kinh/sews. (Not the stream of sound itself.) di' w)/twn supplements th=s a)kouou/shs phgh=s by suggesting the channel through which the sounds pass from the fount. Cp. fr. 773 bradei=a me\n ga\r e)n lo/goisi prosbolh\ | mo/lis di' w)to\s e)/rxetai trupwme/nou. h( a)kou/ousa phgh/, instead of h( phgh\ th=s a)kou/sews, is said with a consciousness that phgh/ means the organ of hearing, just as we might have ta\ a)kou/onta w)=ta. Seneca paraphrases: utinam quidem rescindere has quirem vias, Manibusque adactis omne qua voces meant Aditusque verbis tramite angusto patet, Eruere possem, gnata:aures ingerunt, quicquid mihi Donastis, oculi (Sen. Oed. 226 ff.).
e)sxo/mhn usu. in this sense with gen., as Hom. Od. 4.422 sxe/sqaibi/hs.
to\ mh/ cp. 1232. The simple mh/, where (as here) mh\ ou) is admissible, occurs also in prose, as Antiph. 4.2.4 ou)dei\s h(mi=n lo/gos u(pelei/peto mh\ foneu=sin ei)=nai.

i(/n h)= For h)= (as 1393) see on 1123. The negative mhde/n here shows how in this construction i(/na is essentially final, “so that I might have been ”; not = “in which case I should have been ”—for which the negative must have been ou)de/n. So w(s e)/deica mh/pote (1392), that I might never have shown. Eur. fr. 442 feu= feu= to\ mh\ ta\ pra/gmat' a)nqrw/pois e)/xein | fwnh/n, i(/n' h)=san mhde\n oi( deinoi\ lo/goi.
e)/cw tw=n kakw=n i.e. undisturbed by those sights and sounds from the outer world which serve to recall past miseries.
The imperf. e)de/xou helps the personification: “wast ready to shelter me. ”
w(s e)/deica see on 1389, and cp. Aesch. PB 776 ti/ou)k e)n ta/xei | e)/rriy' e)mauth/no(/pws pe/dw| skh/yasa tw=n pa/ntwn po/nwn | a)phlla/ghn;

ta\ pa/tria lo/gw| = ta\ lo/gw| pa/tria, an order the less harsh since pa/tria (= of my fathers, not patrw=|a, of my father) is supplemented by palaia/. Cp. Soph. Aj. 635 o( nosw=n ma/tan: Soph. El. 792 tou= qano/ntos a)rti/ws: Aesch. PB 1013 tw=| fronou=nti mh\ kalw=s: Eur. Med. 874 toi=si bouleu/ousin eu)=.

ka/llos kakw=n u(/poulon a fair surface, with secret ills festering beneath it (gen. kakw=n as after words of fulness, = kruptw=n kakw=n ge/mon): because he had seemed most prosperous (775), while the doom decreed from his birth was secretly maturing itself with his growth.
ka/llos concrete, a fair object, Xen. Cyrop. 5.2.7 th\n qugate/ra, deino/n ti kallos kai\ me/geqos, penqikw=s d' e)/xousan.

u(/poulon of a sore festering beneath an ou)lh/ or scar which looks as if the wound had healed: Plat. Gorg. 480b o(/pws mh\ e)gxronisqe
 to\ no/shma th=s a)diki/as u(/poulon th
 yuxh
 poih/sei kai\ a)ni/aton, “lest the disease of injustice become chronic, and render his soul gangrenous and past cure ” (Thompson). Thuc. 8.64 u(/poulon au)tonomi/an, unsound independence opp. to th
 a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/an. Dem. 18.307 h(suxi/an a)/gein a)/dikon kai\ u(/poulon, unjust and insecure peace. Eustath. Od. 1496.35 *sofoklh=sle/getaiu(/poulon ei)pei=n to
 dou/reion i(/ppon, the wooden horse at Troy, as concealing foes.
ka)k kakw=n like a)nosi/wn pai=s (1360), with reference to the stain incurred by Iocasta.

His memory recalls the scene as if he were again approaching it on his way from Delphi. First, he descries three roads converging in a deep glen or ravine (trei=s ke/leuqoi—kekrumme/nh na/ph):then, descending, he comes to a coppice (drumo/s)at a point where his own road narrows (stenwpo/s)just before its junction with the two others (e)n triplai=s o(doi=s).See on 733. The genuineness of v. 1399 has been groundlessly questioned, on the score of supposed tautology. The language may be compared with that of the verses from the Oedipus of Aeschylus (fr. 167), quoted in the Introduction.
tou)mo\n ai(=ma thus divided from patro/s, is more than ai(=ma tou)mou= patro/s: “the same blood which flows in my own veins—the blood of my father. ”

For ti, which has a tone of bitterness here, see on 124, 969. The o(/ti of the MSS. must be explained in one of two ways: —(1) as if the construction was irregularly changed by oi)=a, o(poi=a: but the immediate succession of oi)=a to o(/ti makes this intolerably harsh: or (2) as if oi)=a, o(poi=a were exclamatory substitutes for deina/ or the like: which seems inadmissible.

a)nei=te tau)tou= spe/rma By the change of one letter, we restore sense to the passage. The tau)to\n of the MSS. is unintelligible. Oedipus was the spe/rma of Laius and Iocasta. When Iocasta weds Oedipus, the marriage cannot be said a)nie/nai tau)to\n spe/rma: for it is absurd to suppose that the seed sown by Oedipus could be identified with Oedipus himself. But the marriage can be rightly said a)nie/nai tau)tou= spe/rma, to yield seed from the same man (Oedipus) whom that womb had borne.

The marriage of Iocasta with Oedipus constituted (a)pedei/cate)Oedipus at once father and brother (of his children), while he was also son (of his wife),the closest relation in blood (ai)=m' e)mfu/lion)becoming also the husband. The marriage made Iocasta the bride (nu/mfas)aye, and the child-bearing wife (gunai=kas),—of him to whom she was also mother (mhte/ras).Thus, through the birth of children from such a marriage, complex horrors of relationship arose (o(po/sa ai)/sxista e)/rga gi/gnetai). ai)=m' e)mfu/lion is in apposition with pate/ras a)delfou\s pai=das,— “a blood-kinship” standing for “a blood-kinsman.” It expresses that the monstrous union confounded the closest tie of consanguinity with the closest tie of affinity. The phrase e)mfu/lion ai(=ma, like suggene\s ai)=ma, would in Tragedy more often mean “murder of a kinsman.” But it can, of course, mean also “kindred blood” in another sense; and here the context leaves no ambiguity. Cp. Soph. OC 1671 (n.) e)/mfuton ai(=ma, Eur. Phoen. 246 koino\n ai(=ma, koina\ te/kea | th=s kerasfo/rou pe/fuken *)iou=s.

e)/cw me/ pou | kalu/yat' the blind man asks that they will lead him away from Thebes, and hide him from the sight of men in some lonely spot—as amid the wilds of Cithaeron (1451). We must not transpose kalu/yat' and e)kri/yat', as is done in Schneidewin's ed. (as revised by Nauck), after Burges.
qala/ssion cp. Appendix, note on v. 478. Cp. Soph. OC 119 n. - e)/nqa mh/ with fut. indic., as Soph. Aj. 659, Soph. El. 380, Soph. Trach. 800.

No one can share the burden of his ills. Other men need not fear to be polluted by contact with him, as with one guilty of blood. His unwitting crimes and his awful sufferings—alike the work of Apollo—place him apart. In illustration of the fear which he seeks to allay, compare the plea of Orestes that, since he has been duly purified from bloodshed, contact with him has ceased to be dangerous (Aesch. Eum. 285 o(/sois prosh=lqon a)blabei= cunousi/a|). —Contrast Soph. OC 1132 ff., where Oed. will not allow his benefactor Theseus to touch him. There, he feels that he is still formally a)/nagnos, and that gratitude forbids him to impart a possible taint. Here, he thinks only of his unique doom and his incommunicable anguish.

w(=n e)paitei=s e)s de/on = seasonably in respect of those things which (w(=n = tou/twn a(/) you ask. For the gen. of relation cp. Xen. Hell. 6.2.9 kei=sqai th
 *ke/rkuran e)n kalw=| me
 tou= *korinqiakou= ko/lpou kai\ tw=n po/lewn ai(\ e)pi\ tou=ton kaqh/kousin ( “conveniently in respect to ”), e)n kalw=| de\ tou= th
 *lakwnikh
 xw/ran bla/ptein.

to\ pra/ssein kai\ to\ bouleu/ein are strictly accusatives of respect, “as to the doing and the planning, ” i.e. with a view to doing and planning. So Soph. Ant. 79, Soph. El. 1030, Soph. OC 442, Soph. Phil. 1253, etc.

mou=nos see on 304. Kuhlstadt (De Dial. Trag. 104) thinks that Soph. never uses mou=nos for mo/nos unless with some special emphasis: but, as Ellendt remarks, such instances as Soph. OC 875, 991, Soph. Ant. 705, fr. 434 refute that view. Rather it was a simple question of metrical convenience. The same is true of cei=nos and ce/nos, with this exception, that, even where metre admitted ce/n', cei=n' occurs as the first word of an address: Eur. IT 798 cei=n', ou) dikai/ws. In Soph. OC 928 also, L and A give cei=non par' a)stoi=s.

ti/s moi fanei=tai pi/stis e)/ndikos; “what reasonable claim to confidence can be produced on my part?” Oedipus had brought a charge against Creon which was false, and had repudiated a charge against himself which was true. He means: — “How can I expect Creon to believe me now, when I represent myself as the blind victim of fate, —when I crave his sympathy and pity? ” pi/stis has two main senses, each of which has several shades, —(1) faith, and (2) a warrant for faith. Here it is (2) essentially as in Soph. OC 1632 do/s moi xero\s sh=s pi/stin. Not “a persuasive argument” in the technical sense of Rhetoric, for which pi/steis were “instruments of persuasion,” whether e)/ntexnoi, provided by the Art itself (logikh/, paqhtikh/, h)qikh/), or a)/texnoi, external to the art, as depositions, documents, etc.
pa/nt' see on 475.
Cp. the words of Tennyson's Arthur to Guinevere: “Yet think not that I come to urge thy crimes. ”

Nauck gives these verses to Oedipus, making them follow 1415. He regards toio/nd' a)/gos k.t.l. as inconsistent with the profession which Creon has just made. Rather may we consider them as showing a kinsman's anxious and delicate concern for the honour of Oedipus and of the house (1430). Creon, deeply moved, deprecates the prolonged indulgence of a painful curiosity (cp. 1304). It is again Creon who says i)/qi ste/ghs e)/sw (1515) when Oedipus would fain linger. Clearly, then, these verses are rightly placed in the MSS.
bo/skousan boldly for tre/fousan: cp. Aesch. Ag. 633, where the sun is tou= tre/fontosxqono\s fu/sin.

deiknu/nai depends on ai)dei=sqe, for the constr. of which with (1) acc. of persons revered, and (2) infin. of act which such reverence forbids, cp. Xen. Anab. 2.3.22 h)|sxu/nqhmen kai\ qeou\s kai\ a)nqrw/pous prodou=nai au)to/n, “respect for gods and for men forbade us to betray him. ”

to\ (= o(/, see on 1379) mh/te, not ou)/te, since toio/nd' a)/gos indicates a class of a)/gh: not merely “which, ” but “such as, ” “earth will not welcome ” (quod Terra non admissura sit): cp. 817, Soph. El. 654 o(/swn e)moi\ | du/snoia mh\ pro/sestin. gh=—o)/mbros—fw=s. The pollution (a)/gos) of Oedipus is such that the pure elemental powers—represented by earth, the rain from heaven, the light— cannot suffer it to remain in their presence (prosde/cetai):it must be hidden from them. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 904 ff., where the Erinyes, as Chthonian powers, invoke blessings on Attica, gh=qen—e)/k te ponti/as dro/sou—e)c ou)ranou= te. o)/mbros here is not a synonym but a symbol of water generally, as with Empedocles 282 w(\s to/t' e)/peit' e)di/hne *ku/pris xqo/na dhro\n e)n o)/mbrw| | ei)/dea kai\ poiou=sa qow=| puri\ dw=ke kratu=nai: cp. Lucr. 1.714 f. quattuor ex rebus posse omnia rentur Ex igni terra atque anima procrescere et imbri. In Soph. Ant. 1073 the exposure of the unburied corpse is spoken of as a violence to oi( a)/nw qeoi/ (bia/zontai). It was a common form of oath to pray that, if a man swore falsely, neither earth, nor sea, nor air, might tolerate the presence of his corpse (Eur. Orest. 1085, Eur. Hipp. 1030).

The original sense of i(ero/s, “strong ” (Curt. Etym. 614), suits a few phrases, such as i(ero\s i)xqu/s (Hom. Il. 16.407). But in such as i(ero\n h)=mar, kne/fas, o)/mbros, potamoi/ etc. it is more likely that the poet had no consciousness of any other sense than “sacred. ”

The objection to taking ma/lista with toi=s e)n ge/nei is not that it follows these words (see on 1394), but that ta)ggenh= intervenes. Rather join it with eu)sebw=s e)/xei. o(ra=n mo/nois t' a)kou/ein = mo/nois o(ra=n a)kou/ein te.

e)lpi/dos m' a)pe/spasas suddenly plucked me away from (made me to abandon) my uneasy foreboding: cp. Lat. revellere (falsorum persuasionem, Sen. Letter 95), and our phrase, “a revulsion of feeling ”: Soph. Aj. 1382 w(/s m' e)/yeusas e)lpi/dos polu/. Conversely (Soph. El. 809) a)pospa/sasfreno\s | ai(/ moi mo/nai parh=san e)lpi/dwn.
a)/ristos e)lqw\n pro\se)me/ having come to me in so noble a spirit; cp. 1422 e)lh/luqa. This is more natural than to render, “having proved thyself most noble towards me ” (see on 1357).
pro\s sou= in thy interest: Eur. Alc. 58 pro\s tw=n e)xo/ntwn, *foi=be, to\n no/mon ti/qhs: Soph. Trach. 479 dei= ga\r kai\ to\ pro\s kei/nou le/gein, the argument on his side.
xrei/as request: Soph. OC 1754 prospi/tnome/n soi. *q*h. ti/nos, w)= pai=des, xrei/as a)nu/sai;

mhdeno\s prosh/goros accosted by no one: for the gen., cp. Soph. El. 1214 ou(/tws a)/timo/s ei)mi tou= teqnhko/tos; Soph. El. 344 kei/nhs didakta/. With dat. Soph. Phil. 1353 tw=| prosh/goros; see on 1337: for o(/pou mh/ with fut. indic., on 1412.
For the double a)/n, cp. 139. tou=t' depends on i)/sqi, not e)/drasa.

fa/tis (151), the message brought by Creon from Delphi (86); pa=s', “in full, ” explicitly: Soph. Aj. 275 kei=noslu/ph| pa=s e)lh/latai. The indefinite person of the fa/tis is identified with Oedipus just as in 1382 f.
a)pollu/nai could refer either to misery in exile (1436), or to death: cp. 100. Soph. Phil. 252 diwllu/mhn.
i(/naxrei/as see 367.
ou(/tws with a)qli/ou: Soph. Phil. 104 ou(/tws e)/xei ti deino\n i)sxu/os qra/sos;

The kai\ belongs to su/: “even thou ” who didst not believe Teiresias. This is not spoken in mockery, but with grave sorrow. The phrase pi/stin fe/rois as = pisteu/ois (Soph. El. 735 tw=| te/lei pi/stin fe/rwn) prob. = “render belief” (as a tribute due), cp. fo/ron, dasmo/n, xrh/mata fe/rein, and the like figure in Pind. O. 11.17 nikw=n | *)/ila| fere/tw xa/rin.

kai\ soi/ g' yes [I am prepared to abide by Apollo's word], and on thee too I lay an injunction, and I will now make a prayer to thee; i.e. as I turn to the god for what he alone can give (cp. 1519 tou= qeou= m' ai)tei=s do/sin), so I turn to thee for that which lies in thine own power. The midd. prostre/yomai as in fr. 759 *)erga/nhn (Athene) prostre/pesqe: the active has the same sense in Soph. Aj. 831, Soph. OC 50. On the future, see 1077. There is no cause to desire e)piskh/yw: each tense has its due force: I now enjoin, and am going on to ask. Just so in Thuc. 2.44 ou)k o)lofu/romai ma=llon h)\ paramuqh/somai, where the conjecture o)lofurou=mai is needless: “I do not bewail them, but rather intend to comfort them. ” The reading protre/yomai must be judged by the context. With it, the sense is: —yes [I am sensible of my duty to Apollo], and I enjoin on thee, and will exhort thee, to do thine. (Cp. 358 prou)tre/yw; Plat. Laws 711b pro\s a)reth=s e)pithdeu/mata protre/pesqai tou\s poli/tas.) But this strain of lofty admonition seems little in accord with the tone of the broken man who has just acknowledged Creon's unexpected goodness (1432), and is now a suppliant (cp. 1468). In Soph. Aj. 831 and Soph. OC 50, where prostre/pw is undoubtedly right, protre/pw occurs as a variant.
th=skat' oi)/kous the name of Iocasta has not been uttered since 1235. Contrast 950.
telei=s absol., like e)/rdein, perform rites, i.e. the e)nta/fia (Isaeus 8.38). The special term for offerings to the dead was e)nagi/zein (Isaeus 3.46).
a)ciwqh/tw be condemned: Hdt. 3.145 e)me\ me/n, w)= ka/kiste a)ndrw=n,a)dikh/santa ou)de\n a)/cion desmou= gorgu/rhs h)ci/wsas, doomed me to a dungeon though I had done no wrong worthy of bonds.
e)/a a monosyllable by synizesis, and in Soph. Ant. 95 a)ll' e)/a me. Cp. Hom. Od. 9.283 ne/a me/n moi kate/ace *poseida/wn e)nosi/xqwn.

o)/resin locative dative, cp. gh=|, 1266.—e)/nqa klh/|zetai k.t.l., lit., “where my Cithaeron yonder is famed,” = “where yonder is Cithaeron, famed as mine,” —i.e. made famous by the recent discovery that it is *oi)di/pou trofo\s kai\ mh/thr (1092). There is an intense bitterness in the words; the name of Cithaeron is for ever to be linked with his dark story. Statius (quoted by Schneidewin) was doubtless thinking of this place: habeant te lustra tuusque Cithaeron (Stat. Theb. 11.752). klh/|zetai is stronger than kalei=tai, as in Soph. Trach. 659 e)/nqa klh/|zetai quth/r means, “where fame (that brought the tidings of his great victory) tells of him as sacrificing. ” For the idiom cp. Hom. Il. 11.757 *)aleisi/ou e)/nqa kolw/nh | ke/klhtai.

The words e)c e)kei/nwn form the decisive argument for the zw=nte of the MSS. against Toup's specious emendation, zw=nti. His parents in their life-time appointed Cithaeron to be his grave. Now they are dead; but, though he can no longer die by their agency, he wishes to die e)c e)kei/nwn, by their doom; i.e. by selfexposure in the same wilds to which they had consigned him (cp. 719 e)/rriyen a)/llwn xersi\n ei)s a)/baton o)/ros). The thought of the dead bringing death upon the living is one which Sophocles has also in Soph. Aj. 1026 ei)=des w(s xro/nw| | e)/melle/ s' *(/ektwr kai\ qanw\n a)pofqiei=n; Soph. Trach. 1163 (Heracles speaking of Nessus) zw=nta/ m' e)/kteinen qanw/n: Soph. Ant. 871. The reading zw=nti, on the other hand, yields nothing but a weak verbal antithesis with ta/fon. Had his parents meant him to live in lonely misery on Cithaeron, there would be some point in calling it his “living grave. ” But they meant him to die there forthwith (cp. 1174); zw=nti, then, would mean nothing more than that the grave was chosen before the babe was dead.
ku/rion appointed by their authoritative decision: cp. Aesch. Eum. 541 poina\ ga\r e)pe/stai: | ku/rion me/nei te/los.
a)pwllu/thn for the imperf. of intention, cp. Andoc. 1.41 to\n pate/ra mou a)pw/llue ( “sought to ruin ”), suneido/ta a)pofai/nwn.

oi)=da mh\ a)
 pe/rsai = “I am confident that nothing can destroy me ” mh/ is admissible since oi)=da here = pe/poiqa, and mh\ a)
 pe/rsai represents a negative conception of the mind. So with partic. Soph. OC 656 oi)=d' e)gw/ se mh/ tina | e)nqe/nd' a)pa/cont'. oi)=da ou)k a)
 pe/rsai would be more usual; the difference being that this would be the oblique form of oi)=da o(/ti ou)k a)
 pe/rseie. The ordinary usage is (1) ou) with infin. (= o(/ti with indic.) after verbs of saying or thinking, le/gw, fhmi/, oi)/omai, etc; (2) mh/ with infin. after verbs of feeling confident, promising, etc., as pisteu/w, pe/poiqa, u(pisxnou=mai, o)/mnumi. But a few exceptions occur both ways, when a verb of either class is virtually equivalent to a verb of the other: e.g. (1) Dem. 29.48 oi)/esqe ou)k a)
 au)th
 labei=n (= o(/ti ou)k a)
 e)/laben au)th/n), but Xen. Mem. 1.2.41 oi)=mai mh\ a)
 dikai/ws tuxei=n tou/tou tou= e)pai/nou to
 mh\ ei)do/ta: (2) Plat. Prot. 336b o(mologei= mh\ metei=nai/ oi( makrologi/as, but Plat. Apol. 17a o(mologoi/hn a)
 e)/gwge ou) kata\ tou/tous ei)=nai r(h/twr. Cp. Whitelaw in Trans. Cam. Phil. Soc. (1886) p. 34, and Gildersleeve in Amer. Fourn. Philol. 1.49. —Whitelaw here takes pe/rsai a)/n as = e)/persen a)/n, and reads tw=| (not tw|) deinw=| kakw=|: “my parents wished to kill me; but nothing could have killed me; I was reserved for this dread evil. ” Surely, however, it is better to connect the verses with the wish for death which he has just uttered. The poet of Colonus gives Oedipus a presentiment that his end is not to be as that of other men.
with mh/ understand swqei/s, = ei) mh\ e)sw/qhn e)pi\ kakw=| tw|: cp. Soph. Aj. 950 ou)k a)\n ta/d' e)/sth th=|de mh\ qew=n me/ta, sc. sta/nta = ei) mh\ e)/sth.

prosqh=| me/rimnan, take care upon thee: so often of assuming a needless burden: Thuc. 1.78 mh\oi)kei=on po/non prosqh=sqe: Thuc. 1.144 kindu/nous au)qaire/tous mh\ prosti/qesqai: Plat. Prot. 346d e)/xqras e(kousi/asprosti/qesqai. Elmsley's plausibleproqh=| (Soph. El. 1334 eu)la/beian prou)qe/mhn) would be weaker.
a)/ndres, males (though not e)chndrwme/noi); cp. Soph. Trach. 1062 qh=lus ou(=sa kou)k a)ndro\s fu/sin.

toi=n d' a)qli/ain Instead of supplying pro/sqou me/rimnan, it is better to regard oi(=n in 1466 as an anacolouthon for tou/toin, arising from the length of the preceding clause. Cp. Antiph. 5.11-12 de/on se diomo/sasqaia(\ su\ parelqw/n, where, after a long parenthetic clause, a(/ has been irregularly substituted for tau=ta.

oi(=n for whom h( e)mh\ bora=s tra/peza the table at which I ate ou)/pote xwri\s e)sta/qh was never placed apart, a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s(so that they should be) without me. Instead of a)/neu au)tai=n, we have a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s, because (oi)=n being dat. of persons affected) oi)=n ou)/pote h( e)mh\ tra/peza xwri\s e)sta/qh a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s is equivalent to w(\ ou)/pote th\n e)mh\n tra/pezan xwri\s staqei=san ei)de/thn, (w(/ste ei)=nai) a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s. This is simpler than to construe: “for whom the dinner-table, which was (always) mine, was never placed apart, or without me ”: when h(mh/ would be a compressed substitute for h( e)mh\ a)ei\ ou)=sa in the sense of a)lla\ h( e)mh\ a)ei\ h)=n. We cannot take h(mh\ bora=s tra/peza as merely = “the table which I provided”: the emphasis on h(mh/ would alone exclude this. Prof. Kennedy understands: “apart from whom (oi(=n xwri/s) my dinner-table ne'er was set without my bidding,” i.e. never except on special occasions, when I had so directed. a)/neu could certainly mean this (Soph. OC 926 etc.). But can we understand Oedipus as saying, in effect, — “who always dined with me—except, indeed, when I had directed that they should not”? —I am much inclined to receive Arndt's a)/llh for h(mh/ (*l*l for M), as Wecklein has done. —The attributive gen. bora=s is equivalent to an adj. of quality like tro/fimos, as Eur. Phoen. 1491 stoli\s trufa=s = stoli\s trufera/: not like a(/macai si/tou (Xen. Cyrop. 2.4.18) “waggon-loads of grain. ”
e)sta/qh because a light table is brought in for the meal, and removed after it (cp. Hom. Il. 24.476, Hom. Od. 10.354 etc).

a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s explaining xwri/s, as in Soph. Phil. 31 kenh\n oi)/khsin is explained by a)nqrw/pwn di/xa, Soph. Aj. 464 gumno\n fane/nta by tw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter. a)/neu as in Soph. Trach. 336 ma/qh|s a)/neu tw=nd', hear apart from these.
me/lesqai infin. for imper.: cp. 462. ma/lista me/n: see on 926.

i)/q' w)=nac A moment of agitated suspense is marked by the bacchius interrupting the trimeters, as Soph. Phil. 749 ff. (in an anxious entreaty, as here) i)/q', w)= pai=. So Soph. OC 1271 ti/ siga=|s; 318 ta/laina. The speech of the agonised Heracles is similarly broken by short dactylic or choriambic phrases, Soph. Trach. 1081, ai)=, ai)=, w)= ta/las: 1085 w)=nac *)ai/+dh de/cai m', | w)= *dio\s a)kti/s, pai=son. But Soph. has used the license most sparingly, and always, it may be said, with fine effect.

gonh=| gennai=e, noble in the grain, —one whose gennaio/ths is gnhsi/a, inbred, true, —referring to the a)reth/ just shown by Creon (1433).gonh=| here is not merely intensive of gennai=e, making it = gennaio/tate, (as the sarcastic ge/nei seems to be in Plat. Soph. 231b h( ge/nei gennai/a sofistikh/, “the most noble. ”) Cp. Soph. Aj. 1094 mhde\n w)\n gonai=sin.

dokoi=m' for this form, cp. Soph. Phil. 895 drw=|m' (n.). e)/xein sfas. sfe/as has the accent in Homer when it is emphatic, as when joined with au)tou/s, being then a disyllable: Hom. Il. 12.43 sfe/as au)tou/s. When non-emphatic and enclitic, it is a monosyllable: Hom. Od. 4.77 kai/ sfeas fwnh/sas. The perispomenon sfa=s corresponds to sfe/as, as in sfa=s au)tou/s: the enclitic sfas to sfeas. Thus in Soph. OC 486 we must write w(/s sfas kalou=men with Herm.; where Elmsley gave w(s sfa=s, holding (against the grammarians) that this form was never enclitic. Here, as in 1508, the pronoun is non-emphatic. According to the rule now generally received, a monosyllabic enclitic stands unaccented after a paroxytone word, the latter remaining unaffected: we therefore write e)/xein sfas. But, according to Arcadius and Herodian, a paroxytone word followed by an enclitic beginning with s f took the acute on its last syllable, as e)/xei/n sfas: see Chandler, §§965, 966, 2nd ed.
ti/ fhmi/; the cry of one startled by a sound or sight, as Soph. Trach. 865: Soph. OC 315 ti/ fw=; Aesch. PB 561 ti/s gh=; ti/ ge/nos; ti/na fw= leu/ssein;

toi=nfi/loin | dakrurroou/ntoin Cp. Soph. Ant. 381 ou) dh/ pou ..; In participles belonging to the 3rd declens. the masc. form of the dual is often used as fem.; indeed the specially fem. forms, such as e)xou/sa, are very rare. See Soph. OC append. on 1676, p. 293. Similarly tw/, toi=n, tou/toin, oi)=n were the usual fem. forms: cp. 1462 f., 1504, and Soph. Ant. 769 n. Thus Xen. Cyrop. 1.2.11 mi/an a)/mfw tou/tw tw\ h(me/ra logi/zontai. Plat. Phaedrus 237d h(mw=n e)n e)ka/stw| du/o tine/ e)ston i)de/a a)/rxonte kai\ a)/gonte, oi)=n e(po/meqa. So tw\ qew/, toi=n qeoi=n (Demeter and Persephone).
ta\ fi/ltat' e)kg. e)moi=n my chief treasure, (consisting in) my two daughters: cp. on 261 koinw=n pai/dwn koina/: Soph. El. 682 pro/sxhm' a)gw=nos, a glory (consisting in) a contest.

le/gw ti; see Plat. Crat. 404a kinduneu/eis ti le/gein, compared with Plat. Sym. 205d kinduneu/eis a)lhqh= le/gein. Aristoph. Kn. 333 nu=n dei=con w(s ou)de\n le/gei to\ swfro/nws trafh=nai, “what nonsense it is. ”
gnou\spa/lai aware of the delight which you now feel, —as you ever felt it: i.e. taught by the past to foresee that you would thus rejoice.

Soph. may have been thinking of Aesch. Lib. 1063 a)ll' eu)tuxoi/hs, kai/ s' e)popteu/wn pro/frwn | qeo\s fula/ttoi kairi/osi sumforai=s. th=sde th=s o(dou=, causal gen.: Soph. El. 626 qra/sous | tou=d' ou)k a)lu/ceis: Eur. Orest. 1407 e)/rroi ta=s a(su/xou pronoi/as.

h)\ me\ is required here, since with h)/ me the stress would fall wholly on frourh/sas. On the other hand in 1478 kai/ se is right, because, after eu)tuxoi/hs, the person does not need to be at once emphasised again. This is not, however, like Hom. Il. 23.724 h)/ m' a)na/eir' h)\ e)gw\ se/, where me suffices because the sense is, “slay or be slain.” In Soph. El. 383, Soph. El. 1213 me and soi are justified by the stress on u(/steron and prosh/kei respectively.

w(s ta\sxe/ras As the sense is so plainly equivalent to w(s e)me/, we are scarcely justified in changing w(s to ei)s(with Elmsley), or e)s(with Blaydes). Soph. Trach. 366 do/mous | w(s tou/sde is a slightly stronger case for such a change, yet not a conclusive one. e)s is now read for w(s in Aristoph. Ach. 242 (w(s to\ pro/sqen) and in Thuc. 8.36 (w(s th\n *mi/lhton), 103 (w(s th\n *)/abudon). Soph. has w(s u(ma=s Soph. Trach. 366.

Construe: ai(\ prou)ce/nhsan u(mi
 who have effected for you ta\ pro/sqe lampra\ tou= fut. patro\s o)/mmata w(=de o(ra=n that the once bright eyes of your sire should see thus, i.e. should be sightless: cp. his own phrase quoted in 1273 e)n sko/tw| to\ loipo
o)yoi/ato. Soph. Phil. 862 w(s *)ai/+da| parakei/menos o(ra=|, he sees as the dead, i.e. not at all. Cp. Xen. Apol. 7 o( qeo\s di' eu)me/neian procenei= moi ou) mo/non to\ e)n kairw=| th=s h(liki/as katalu=sai to
 bi/on, a)lla\ kai\ to\ h(=| r(a=|sta, the god's kindly offices grant to me that I should close my life etc. procenei=n = (1) to be a pro/cenos: then (2) fig., to lend one's good offices: either (a) absol., as Soph. OC 465 proce/nei, stand my friend: or (b) with dat. and acc., or acc. and infin., to effect a thing, or result, for one: Xen. Anab. 6.5.14 i)/stemeou)de/na pw ki/ndunon procenh/santa u(mi=n: Plut. Alex. 22 au)tw=|toiau=ta o)nei/dh procenw=n (said of one who panders to vices): Soph. Trach. 726 e)lpi\s h(/tis kai\ qra/sos ti procenei=. In particular, procenei=n tina/ tini = sunista/nai, to introduce one person to another. So Prof. Kennedy understands here: “which introduced to you your father's once brilliant eyes, that you should thus behold them ” —i.e. presented them to you in this state. But w)=d' o(ra=n seems thus to lose its force: and the ordinary usage of procenei=n confirms the version given above. The conjecture prouse/lhsan( “maltreated ”) has found some unmerited favour. Besides prouselou/menon in Aesch. PB 438, we find only prouselou=men in Aristoph. Frogs 730.

ou)/q' o(rw=n ou)/q' i(storw=n i.e. neither recognising his mother when he saw her, nor possessing any information which could lead him to suspect that she was such. i(storei=n is (1) to be, or (2) to become, i(/stwr, a knower: i.e. (1) to have information, or (2) to seek it. Sense (2) is more frequent: but Aesch. has (1) in Aesch. Eum. 455 and Aesch. Pers. 454. [In Soph. Trach. 382 ou)de
 i(storw=n prob. = o(/ti ou)de
 i(sto/rei (imperf.), “did not ask. ”] Here (1) is best, because it would be almost absurd to say that he had wedded Iocasta “without asking any questions ”—as if he could have been expected to do so. Cp. Soph. OC 273 nu=n d' ou)de
 ei)dw\s i(ko/mhn i(/n' i(ko/mhn.

o(mili/ase(orta/s The poet is thinking of his own Athens, though the language is general. o(mili/as comprises all occasions on which Attic women could appear in public, —as at the delivery of e)pita/fioi (Thuc. 2.45): e(orta/s suggests such festivals as the Thesmophoria, the Panathenaea, or the Dionysia (when women were present in the theatre, at least at tragedy). To feel the force of this passage, we must remember how closely the Greek festivals were bound up with the life of the family. Kinsfolk took part in them together: and at such moments a domestic disgrace, such as that which the sisters inherited, would be most keenly felt. In Athenian law-courts the fact of association at festivals could be cited in evidence of family intimacy: Isoc. 19.10 e(/ws me
 ga pai=des h)=men, peri\ ple/onos h(ma=s au)tou\s h(gou/meqa h)\ tou\s a)delfou/s, kai\ ou)/te qusi/an ou)/te qewri/an (public spectacle) ou)/t' a)/llhn e(orth
 ou)demi/an xwri\s a)llh/lwn h)/gomen. Isaeus 8.15 kai\ ei)s *dionu/sia ei)s a)gro
 h)=gen a)ei\ h(ma=s, kai\ met' e)kei/nou te e)qewrou=men (in the theatre) kaqh/menoi par' au)to/n, kai\ ta\s e(orta\s h)/gomen par' e)kei=non pa/sas. It was the Attic custom for a bridegroom *qesmofo/ria e(stia=n ta\s gunai=kas, to provide a banquet at the next Thesmophoria for the women of his deme (Isaeus 3.80), and also fra/torsi gamhli/an ei)sfe/rein, to provide a banquet for his clansmen when his bride was introduced into his fratri/a (Isaeus 8.18).

keklaume/nai only poet.: later poets and Plut. have ke/klausmai: the poet. dedakrume/nos also occurs in later prose, Plut., Lucian, etc. The festivals were religious celebrations, which would be polluted by the presence of persons resting under an inherited a)/gos (cp. note on 240). Some word or act reminds the daughters of Oedipus that they are thus regarded, and they go home in tears. Greek sensitiveness to public notice on such occasions might be illustrated by the story in Herodotus of the affront offered to the deposed king Demaratus by his successor Leotychides at the Spartan festival of the gumnopaidi/ai (Hdt. 6.67). Demaratus drew his robe over his head, and left the theatre: katakaluya/menos h)/i+e e)k tou= qeh/trou e)s ta\ e(wutou= oi)ki/a. Contrast the effusive public greeting which Electra imagines herself and Chrysothemis as receiving e)/n q' e(ortai=s e)/n te pandh/mw| po/lei (Soph. El. 982).

a)nti\ th=s qewri/as in place of the sight-seeing (for which they had looked). qewri/a is (1) subjectively, a sight-seeing: (2) objectively, a spectacle. In sense (1) the article is added here because a definite occasion is meant; usually, the art. is absent: Thuc. 6.24 po/qw| o)/yews kai\ qewri/as: Plat. Rep. 556c h)\ kata\ qewri/as h)\ kata\ stratei/as (on travels or campaigns): Isoc. 17.4 a(/ma kat' e)mpori/an kai\ kata\ qewri/an. In Hdt. 1.30 th=s qewri/hs e)kdhmh/sasei(/neken, the art. is added as in h( ei)rh/nh ( “peace ”) etc., because “seeing the world ” is spoken of generically.

ti/s ou(=tos e)/stai, ti/s k.t.l., is more animated for ti/s ou)=tos e)/stai, o(/stis. Theocr. 16.13 ti/s tw=n nu=n toio/sde; ti/s eu)= ei)po/nta filasei=; is compared by Jacobs there, and by Schneidewin here, but is not really similar, since toio/sde there refers back to v. 5 f., ti/s ga/ru(pode/cetai (k.t.l.);
lamba/nwn instead of the infin. with pararri/yei, as Plat. Laws 699a ou)dei\s to/te e)boh/qhsen ou)d' e)kindu/neuse cummaxo/menos.

gonai=sin The disgraces of the polluted house will be ruinous not only to the children of Oedipus, but to his children's children (sfw=|n, genit., sc. gonai=s). I formerly read go/noisin: but Kennedy justly objects that the plur. of go/nos is not used; and his conjecture, tai=s e)mai=s gonai=sin, gives more point here. For gonai/, “offspring, ” cp. Soph. OC 1192, Soph. Ant. 641. The goneu=sin of the MSS. yields no tolerable sense, whether it is referred to Laius and Iocasta or to Iocasta alone. —dh/lhma is a hurt, bane, mischief, in a physical or material sense: Hom. Od. 12.286 a)/nemoi xalepoi/, dhlh/mata nhw=n: HH Apoll. 364 (of the dead monster) ou)de\ su/ ge zw/ousa kako\n dh/lhma brotoi=sin: Aesch. fr. 119 o(doipo/rwn dh/lhma xwri/ths dra/kwn (the serpent in the fields, a bane of wayfarers). The disgraces are dhlh/mata to the sons and daughters as involving their ruin in life: but could not be called dhlh/mata to the dead in the remote figurative sense of disgracing their memories. Nor would there be any fitness in the conjuction of harm of another kind to the living. Oedipus here thinks of the living, and of the future, alone. The conject. gambroi=sin, besides being far from the MSS., presumes the event which he regards as impossible.
pate/ra for the tribrach see on 719.

tw=n i)/swn is poetically equivalent to tw=n au)tw=n, i.e. th=s au)th=s: it is like saying, “from a source which was even as that whence he sprang,” instead of, “from the same source whence he sprang.” Cp. 845 ou) ga\r ge/noit' a)\n ei)=s ge toi=s polloi=s i)/sos, and note.
o)neidiei=sqe see on 672.
dhladh/ prosaic, but also in Eur. Orest. 789, Eur. IA 1366.
a)ll' after the vocative, like su\ de/, but stronger, as introducing an appeal: as Soph. OC 1405 w)= tou=d' o(/maimoi pai=des, a)ll' u(mei=smh/ m' a)tima/shte/ ge: and Soph. OC 237.
du/' o)/nte both of us: cp. Soph. Trach. 539 du/' ou)=sai mi/mnomen: Eur. Ion 518 su\ d' eu)= fro/nei ge kai\ du/' o)/nt' eu)= pra/comen. —perii/dh|s: on Porson's objection, see Appendix.

e)ggenei=s your kinswomen as they are (where in prose we should have ou)/sas added). The word was full of meaning for an Attic audience, who would think of Creon as placed by Oedipus in the position of e)pi/tropos (guardian) and ku/rios (representative before the law) of the unmarried girls who are here viewed as orphans (1505); their brothers not being of age. Cp. Isaeus 5.10; Dem. 46.18.
e)cisw/sh|s ta/sde, do not put them on the level of my miseries: cp. 425: for ta/sde instead of ta\ tw=nde kaka/, cp. note on 467.
thlika/sd' at their age, i.e. so young: Soph. Ant. 726 oi( thlikoi/de (so old) kai\ didaco/mesqa dh\ | fronei=n pro\s a)ndro\s thlikou=de (so young) th\n fu/sin;
plh\n o(/son to\ so\n me/ros except in so far as, on thy part, ou)k e)/rhmoi ei)si/.

ei)xe/thn 2nd pers. dual, with the form proper to the 3rd (meteixe/thn, 1465). Before the Attic period, the Greek language had attained to this regular distinction of active dual forms: —(1) primary tenses, 2nd pers. -ton, 3rd pers. -ton; (2) secondary tenses, 2nd pers. -ton, answering to Skt. tam: 3rd pers. -thn, Skt. tām. As regards (2), two classes of exceptions occur: (a) Homeric 3rd pers. in -ton instead of -thn; three instances, diw/keton (Hom. Il. 10.364), e)teu/xeton (Hom. Il. 13.346), lafu/sseton (Hom. Il. 18.583). These Curtius refers to “the want of proper linguistic instinct on the part of some late rhapsodist. ” (b) Attic 2nd pers. in -thn instead of -ton. Our ei)xe/thn here is the only instance proved by metre: but 8 others are established. Against these fall to be set at least 13 Attic instances of the normal -ton. Curtius regards the 2nd pers. in -thn as due to a false analogy. In the third person dual -thn was distinctive of the secondary tenses. Attic speech sometimes extended this distinction to the second person also. (Curt. Verb 1.80, Eng. tr. 53.) Cp n. on Soph. OC 1378 ff.

Oedipus now turns from Creon to the children. The few words which he addresses to them are spoken rather to the older hearers and to himself. tou=t' eu)/xesqe/ moi, “make this prayer, as I bid you ” (not, “pray on my account, ” in which sense Wunder reads e)moi/): the ethic dat. moi in request, as Soph. OC 1475. In these words Oedipus is thinking solely of his children: he has now passed away from the thought of self (1458). u(ma=s in 1514 is no argument for understanding me as subject to zhn: rather it is added to mark the contrast withpatro/s.

I preferou(= kairo\s e)a=| zh=n, tou= bi/ou k.t.l. to ou(= kairo\s a)ei\ zh=n, bi/ou k.t.l. on these grounds. 1. tou= before bi/ou, though not required, is commended, by Greek idiom; it also gives a decidedly better rhythm; and it is not likely to have crept into the text, since the occurrence of a)ei/ with the a long was not so uncommon that it should have suggested the need of supplementing the metre by tou=: but, apart from metrical motive, there was no other for intruding the article. 2. ou(= kairo/s, without any verb, though a possible phrase, is a harsh one. 3. From eai to aei would be an easy transition. Andkairo\s e)a=| is quite a natural expression: cp. Eur. IA 858 dou=los: ou)x a(bru/nomai tw=|d': h( tu/xh ga\r ou)k e)a=|. The foreboding of Oedipus is that his daughters must become homeless exiles (1506) unless Creon shelters them at Thebes. “To live where occasion allows” means in his inner thought, “to live at Thebes, if that may be—if not, in the least unhappy exile that the gods may grant you. ” The monosyllabic e)/a (1451, Soph. Ant. 95) and e)a=| (Hom. Il. 5.256 trei=n m' ou)k e)a=| *palla\s *)aqh/nh) go far to remove the metrical objection. Meineke's conjecture, h)=|, gives a more prosaic phrase, and is too far from the a)ei/ of the MSS.
e)ch/keis see on 1357.

kairw=| = e)n kairw=|. In Thuc. 4.59 most MSS. give ei) mh\ kairw=| tu/xoien e(ka/teroi pra/ssontes: Classen reads e)n kairw=| on the ground that Thuc. so has it in Thuc. 1.121, Thuc. 5.61, Thuc. 6.9.

The words oi)=sq' e)f' oi)=s ou)=n ei)=mi; were said with some return of his former agitation: le/ceis k.t.l. is said by Creon with calm, grave courtesy; they have nothing in them of such irony as, “I shall know when you are pleased to tell me.” So Aesch. Seven 260 ET. ai)toume/nw| moi kou=fon ei) doi/hs te/los: “would that thou couldst grant me a light boon.” XO. le/gois a)\n w(s ta/xista, kai\ ta/x' ei)/somai (i.e. and then I shall know if I can serve thee).
o(/pws pe/myeis sc. o(/ra: Xen. Anab. 1.7.3 o(/pws ou)=n e)/sesqe a)/ndres, “see that ye be”: Plat. Rep. 337a o(/pws moi, w)= a)/nqrwpe, mh\ e)rei=s. Not (ei)=mi e)pi\ tou/tois), o(/pws k.t.l.
a)lla\ qeoi=s g' i.e. “Nay, the gods, who hate me, will not be displeased that I should be thrust forth.” For the synizesis in qeoi=s cp. 215.

h)/kw cp. 1357, Soph. OC 1177 e)/xqiston h(/kei, has come to be most hateful. Creon's reply, toigarou=n teu/cei ta/xa, means: “if the gods do desire thy banishment, thou wilt soon have thy wish”—when the oracle at Delphi is consulted (1443). According to the story which Soph. follows, Oedipus was at first detained at Thebes against his own wish. But when some time had elapsed, and that wish had given place to a calmer mood, the Thebans, in their turn, demanded his expulsion; and Creon then yielded (Soph. OC 433 ff.).

a(\ mh\ fronw= In Soph. OC 765 ff.) Creon is represented as opposing a distinct refusal to this prayer of Oedipus. His words here could mean: “No, I do not promise, for I am not wont to speak vain words when I lack knowledge” (fronw= as in 569): i.e., “I cannot tell how Apollo may decide.” But I now think that, on the whole, it suits the context better to take them as expressing consent (a(\ mh\ fronw= = what I do not mean to do). As this consent can be only provisional—depending on the approval of Apollo—it is not necessarily inconsistent with Soph. OC 765 ff.
e(/lh| mou: cp. 1022 xeirw=n labw/n.

See critical note. These verses are spoken by the Chorus, as Creon turns with Oedipus to enter the house. The calm close which the tragedy requires would be wanting if they were spoken by the chief sufferer himself. Of extant Greek tragedies, the Prometheus and the Agamemnon are the only ones which end with words spoken by one of the actors; and in each case this is justified by the scheme of the trilogy to which the play belonged.

Here, as elsewhere, the MSS. fluctuate betweenh)/|dei andh)/|dh. The Attich)/|dh, as first pers. sing., is contracted from h)/|dea: in the third, the classical form was not h)/|dh but h)/|dei, or, before a vowel, h)/|dein (as it must be in Eur. Ion 1187, Aristoph. Peace 1182 etc.). No 3rd sing. in ea, from which h could come, is said, or can be supposed, to have existed. Aristarchus, indeed, is quoted by the schol. on Hom. Il. 5.64 in favour of the h. But the Doric 3rd sing. a)polw/lh in Tab. Heracl. 1.39 is the only such form which is beyond question. Curtius (Curt. Verb 11.237, Eng. tr. 431 ff.) therefore agrees with those textual critics who, like La Roche, Cobet, and Kontos (*lo/gios *(ermh=s p. 61) would always write the 3rd sing. h)/|dei (or h)/|dein). h)/|dei ai)ni/gmata (plur. with reference to the hexameter e)/ph in which it was chanted) = knew instinctively, by the intuition of genius: in Eur. Phoen. 1759 the adapter of this verse has altered h)/|dei (perhaps by a slip of memory) to the more natural but less forcible e)/gnw, “read aright,” solved.

ou)= ti/s ou) zh/lw|tai=s tu/xais e)pe/bl., “on whose fortunes what citizen did not look with emulous admiration?” (Cp. Xen. Hiero 1.10 pw=s de\ pa/ntes e)zh/loun a)\n tou\s tura/nnous;) To me it appears certain that we should here read the interrogative ti/s, with e)pe/blepen instead of e)pible/pwn. Cp. Soph. OC 1133 w)=| ti/s ou)k e)/ni | khli\s kakw=n cu/noikos; 871 o(/pou ti/s o)/rnis ou)xi\ klagga/nei; Soph. El. 169 ff. ti/ou)k|a)ggeli/as: Eur. Phoen. 878 a(gw\ ti/ drkwn ou), poi=a d' ou) le/gwn e)/ph, | ei)s e)/xqos h)=lqon. Dem. 18.48 e)launome/nwn kai\ u(brizome/nwn kai\ ti/ kako\n ou)xi\ pasxo/ntwn pa=sa h( oi)koume/nh mesth\ ge/gonen. Then the kai/ of the MSS. should probably be tai=s: though it is possible (as Whitelaw proposes) to take zh/lw| kai\ tu/xais as “his glory and his fortunes”: cp. Soph. Aj. 503 oi(/as latrei/as a)nq' o(/sou zh/lou tre/fei. I doubt, however, whether e)pe/blepen, without zh/lw|, could mean “admired.” On the usage of the verb e)pible/pw, see Appendix.

The use of e)piskopou=nta is peculiar. I take the exact sense to be: —“fixing one's eye on the final day (as on a point towards which one is moving), that one should see it,” i.e. “until one shall have had experience of it.” Thus e)piskopei=n is used in a sense closely akin to its common sense of “attentively considering” a thing: and the whole phrase is virtually equivalent to, “waiting meditatively to see the final day.” For the added infin., cp. Thuc. 3.2 new=n poi/hsin e)pe/menon telesqh=nai, kai\ o(/sa e)k tou= *po/ntou e)/dei a)fike/sqai. Cp. Plin. NH 7.132 alius de alio iudicat dies, et tamen supremus de omnibus, ideoque nullis credendum est. Hartung proposed to replace i)dei=n by ge dei= (where ge would be intolerable); Stanley by e)/dei, Seyffert by de/on, and Nauck by xrew/n. Kennedy, keeping i)dei=n, changes e)kei/nhn into a)/meinon. But the infin. o)lbi/zein as a “sententious” imperative (see on 462) is appropriate in this gnw/mh. The accus. (qnhto
 o)/nt', e)piskopou=nta) stands with the infin. when, as here, the infin. represents an imperat. of the third person; cp. Hom. Il. 3.284 ei) de/ k' *)ale/candron ktei/nh| canqo\s *mene/laos, | *trw=as e)/peiq' *(ele/nhn kai\ kth/mata pa/nt' a)podou=nai, with Leaf's note: and Madvig Gr. sect. 546. When the infin. = an imperat. of the second pers., the case is regularly the nom. (Hom. Od. 11.441), rarely the acc. (Hes. WD 389). The view that o)lbi/zein depends on w(/ste requires a shorter pause at e)lh/luqen, and thus weakens the effect of v. 1527. mhde/n' o)lbi/zein. Eur. Andr. 100 ff. partly reproduces the language of this passage: xrh\ d' ou)/pot' ei)pei=n ou)de/n' o)/lbion brotw=n, | pri
 a)
 qano/ntos th
 teleutai/an i)/dh|s | o(/pws pera/sas h(me/ran h(/cei ka/tw. He has the thought also in Eur. Tro. 510, Eur. Her. 866, Eur. IA 161, as Soph. in Soph. Tr. 1 and fr. 588. The maxim, “Call no man happy before death,” first appears in Greek literature as a set gnw/mh in Aesch. Ag. 928 o)lbi/sai de\ xrh\ | bi/on teleuth/sant' e)n eu)estoi= fi/lh|: but Aristotle recognises the popular tradition which ascribed it to Solon. In Hdt. 1.32 Solon says that a man may be called eu)tuxh/s in life, but o)/lbios only after a life exempt from reverse. Cp. Iuv. 10.274 ff. Et Croesum, quem vox iusti facunda Solonis Respicere ad longae iussit spatia ultima vitae, where Mayor refers to the proverbs *ludo\s (Croesus) a)poqnh/skei sofo\s a)nh/r, and te/los o(/ra bi/ou (Parmoemiogr. 11. 187, I. 315 n.), and to notices of the saying in Cic. (De Fin. 2.87, 3.76), Diog. Laert. (Diog. Laert. 1.50 ta/ qrulou/mena), Ovid (Ovid Met. 3.135), Seneca (De Tranq. An. 11.12), Josephus (Bell. Iud. 1.5.11=29.3), Arrian (7 sect. 16.7), Lucian (Charon 10): cp. Ecclus. 11. 28. Does Solon mean, Aristotle asks, (1) that a man is happy when he is dead? Or (2) that, after death, he may be said to have been happy? If (1), Arist. declines to allow that the dead are positively happy; and popular opinion, he says, denies that they are always negatively so, i.e. free from unhapppiness. If (2), then is it not absurd that at the time when he ishappy we are not to call him so? The fallacy, he concludes, consists in treating “happiness” as dependant on bright fortunes: ou) ga/r e)n tau/tais to\ eu)= h)\ kakw=s a)lla\ prosdei=tai tou/twn o( a)nqrwpos bi/os, kaqa/per ei)/pamen, ku/riai d' ei)si
 ai( kat' a)reth
 e)ne/rgeiai th=s eu)daimonias, ai( d' e)nanti/ai tou= e)nanti/ou. (Aristot. Nic. Eth. 1.11)
